HEADLINE: Cuomo Asks Panel to Consider Privatizing Horse Racing in State

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo plans to instruct his study group on horse racing to focus on whether the New York State Racing Association and Offtrack Betting Corporations throughout the state could be transferred to private ownership, state officials said yesterday.
Mr. Cuomo created the panel, the Commission on Racing in the 21st Century, in an attempt to recast the structure of racing in the state. He has made a target of the nonprofit racing association, saying among other things that its management is overpaid. The $261,000-a-year salary of its top official is twice the Governor's. 
 Mr. Cuomo said yesterday that the commission, which has held hearings in recent months in Albany and New York City, would "take a look at selling all of N.Y.R.A. and OTB to private groups, with the state to get a lump sum and then a stream of profits."
Mr. Cuomo said he would send the commission chairman, Vincent Tese, a letter this week describing what he wanted the commission to do about privatization, but Mr. Tese said that he and the Governor had already briefly discussed the idea of exploring the state's options.
"The Governor would like us to take a long, hard look at privatization, with the hope that we possibly could recommend it," Mr. Tese said yesterday. "There is a general feeling that the private sector could do better than the current configuration, but as to what should be privatized and what should not be privatized, that is still being explored."
Mr. Tese said that some members of the commission "have a bias toward exploring and privatizing the whole thing, and some members probably would like to see just the OTB's privatized."
The commission's recent hearings focused on how to stem the slide in racing's popularity. Racing association officials, who testified last month, proposed letting the race tracks take over off-track betting, as well as reducing the state tax on bets and trimming the winter racing season by six weeks.
Horse breeders, who had their turn before the commission on Dec. 3, assailed the racing association as an autocratic anachronism. They said it should be replaced by a state-supervised profit-seeking enterprise.
The Governor's fight with the racing association began when racing association officials balked at his plan to sell 23 acres of land at Aqueduct to the Port Authority for $40 million. Association officials changed their minds in July after Mr. Cuomo threatened to pack the association's board with his appointees.
Mr. Cuomo has long wanted to sell all or part of the 203-acre Aqueduct property, but it took this year's budget deficit and some cajoling on Mr. Cuomo's part to persuade the state Legislature and the racing association to go along with the deal.
The money came out of a $200 million Port Authority fund earmarked for economic development projects. Port Authority officials described the land purchase as a form of economic development because the land could be sold or leased to airport-related industries.
Even after the racing association agreed to the sale, Mr. Cuomo attacked executives of the association, saying the association's salaries and bonuses were excessive.

HEADLINE: Integrating Hartford;
State and Accusers Agree on the Goal For Schools, but Not on How to Get It

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 18

 BODY:
The first witnesses in a lawsuit seeking to integrate Hartford's public schools with those of its suburban neighbors began painting a grim picture of conditions in the schools of Connecticut's capital this week.
But what also began to emerge were the contradictions involved in a trial in which the defendant, the State of Connecticut, supports its accusers' goals on integration and improving education and is fighting only to avoid having a judge order what the state believes it should do itself. 
 While Connecticut's education officials are working on strategies to persuade towns to adopt voluntary integration plans that would cross municipal lines, lawyers for the state have little choice but to question the efficacy of higher spending and mandatory integration plans on overcoming the problems of inner-city schools.
The problems in the state's largest and most segregated school system, Hartford principals and administrators testified in Superior Court this week, are immense at every level. Many of the children are so poor -- nearly half are from families on welfare -- that they come to school hungry and ill-clothed.
 
Concentrated Poverty
 Many suffer from depression or other emotional problems or from the effects of premature birth or their mothers' drug addiction. Eighteen percent need special-education programs, and 20 percent need bilingual instruction, far higher percentages than in neighboring towns.
The children's need for special instructors, social workers and psychologists takes money from instruction, library books and supplies, principals testified. So many students are poor and either black or Hispanic -- minorities make up 92 percent of the enrollment -- that they have little sense of the open-ended world a few miles away that children in West Hartford or Farmington take for granted.
"Youngsters learn from one another, and I don't think they can aspire to something they don't have around them," said Donald Carso, the principal of McDonough School, which has 846 pupils in a 94-year-old main building, 14 portable classrooms and an antiquated annex four blocks away.
The testimony offers a comprehensive explanation for Hartford's shortcomings in academic achievement, programs, supplies and buildings, despite the city's spending more per-pupil than all but two of its suburbs: the burden of concentrated poverty.
 
Concern As Conditions Worsen
 And conditions are worsening for the city's 25,700 schoolchildren. In the last two years the schools have eliminated 40 teacher positions, all of their reading consultants, and dozens of other jobs. Scores on Connecticut's statewide mastery tests are declining. Some 3,000 children attend school in portable classrooms.
For the civil-rights lawyers presenting the case, called Sheff v. O'Neill, this gloomy portrait is proof that the racial and economic segregation in Hartford's schools deny children the equal educational opportunity guaranteed by the state's constitution.
It also leads toward an important conclusion for them: that these children cannot be offered an equal opportunity simply by spending even more money on them. What is left to be done? Integrate Hartford's children with their suburban neighbors, they say.
"The physical plant can be worked around," Mr. Carso said, when Judge Harry Hammer asked how important his school's physical shortcomings were. "The problem with our school is who's in it."
 
State Aid Stressed
 But for the lawyers defending the state, the picture is evidence of the web of social and economic factors, rather than intentional discrimination, that have divided metropolitan areas into largely white suburbs and mainly minority cities, into bands of wealth ringing the poor.
"There is no state in the country that does not have the kinds of problems that will be discussed in this case, but there is no state in the country that has pursued the objective of quality and integrated education as firmly," Assistant Attorney General John R. Whelan said in his opening statement on Wednesday.
As the portrait given by witnesses for the plaintiffs forms, detail by detail, nearly every stroke drawn by Mr. Whelan's questions seems to point far ahead, not to the issue of whether the despairing conditions in Hartford's schools are a great injustice or merely tragic, but to what more can possibly be done about them.
In cross-examining witnesses, he and a second assistant attorney general, Martha M. Watts, carefully draw out how much the state is already doing for Hartford.
The state provides 57 percent of the city's school budget, compared with 20 percent or less of many of its suburbs' budgets. This year, when financial pressures forced the state to cut school aid to most suburbs, and Hartford to cut its own spending, state aid to Hartford schools rose $4.4 million.
As Hartford educators describe special school programs that address the problems of poverty, from providing breakfast for every elementary pupil to getting more parents involved, the lawyers make sure the state gets credit for financially supporting them.
Betances School, for example, has a family resource center that offers all-day day care and adult education for its children's families. Ms. Watts asked the principal, Edna Negron, to read from the school's brochure describing the center.
"The state-funded center," she read, "proves once again that Connecticut is a leader in providing services to families."
The questions also suggest that the Hartford board of education, ultimately, has responsibility for how it spends its money.
This year, for example, the school board met a budget cut by eliminating reading consultants. But, Mr. Whelan asked the deputy superintendent, Charles Senteio, did not the board also continue a program for gifted and talented students, so that it chose that program, for a small number of children, over reading help for everyone?
 
Double-Edged State Strategy
 "Yes," Mr. Senteio said. "If you are now running 92-percent minority, what are the kinds of things you must provide to keep the people who could move out of the city?"
In bringing out these facts, and in later presenting testimony that court-ordered integration plans elsewhere have produced little improvement for minority students, the state's goal is to persuade the court that no judge, through an order addressing only schools, can correct enormous social problems and that the task is better left to the Legislature, local authorities and parents.
But in underlining how little effect the state's aid has had, Mr. Whelan also strengthens the case of the civil-rights lawyers that something more must be done.
At the same time, he is helping to complete a portrait of despair so deep that it could pose a daunting obstacle to the state's efforts to persuade towns to adopt integration plans voluntarily. Those efforts are based on the argument that integration will improve the education of suburban children as well as Hartford's.

Iris Torres, a second grader, had breakfast at the Betances School, which provides students with milk and cereal. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Municipal Bond Issuers Are Learning to 'Detach'

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Peter Coffin, the municipal-bond portfolio manager at Massachusetts Financial Services in Boston, has the "detachable calls" from millions of dollars of bonds in his portfolios. And he would like to have millions more.
But the immediate future of this new financial product -- it is not a mobile phone -- seems to depend less on demand from him and other portfolio managers and more on the state, city and local government issuers of tax-exempt municipal bonds nationwide. 
 If these borrowers are willing to give up the call -- the protection against getting stuck with high-interest-rate bonds after interest rates fall -- then the brisk business that the State of New Jersey did in these detachable calls last week ought to become a regular part of the bond business.
"The big question is how receptive issuers will be to this," Mr. Coffin said.
 
Parts Exceed the Whole
 What is a call? It is an option to buy a bond in the future at a set price, such as in 10 years at a price of $102, $2 over the bond's face value. Issuers generally put such an option, or call, in their bonds so they can cut their borrowing costs if interest rates decline.
Much of the invention in financial markets involves taking a piece of a security and figuring how the security can be bought or sold if the piece is stripped off. Inherent in this is the sense that the sum of the parts is greater than the whole.
In the case of the detachable call, which has been around for only nine months, the innovation is just selling the option to someone else, leaving the issuer with a bond without a call.
Based on the results of the sale last week of the detachable calls on $86 million of New Jersey bonds due in 2013, the two parts -- the bond and the detachable call -- got a better price than just a bond without any call in it originally.
As part of the $1.8 billion bond sale, New Jersey also sold bonds due in 2011 that did not have a call. They were priced to yield 6.07 percent. The bond due in 2013 with the detachable call was priced to yield 6.15. Then the detachable calls were sold for 11 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. So the net cost to the state was 6.04 percent, 3 basis points less than the bond that was sold originally without any call.
But the inventor of the detachable call, Jeff Holt, first vice president and head of new products for the municipal department at Paine Webber, warned that this advantage in selling a detachable call versus a bond without a call was likely to disappear as investors learned more.
"It might work for the next year or six months, but that yield will have to go away," he said.
 
Advance Refunding
 He said he did not initially intend that the detachable call be sold at the time of issue of the bonds, leaving the issuers with a noncallable bond. The idea, he said, was to give the issuer long-term flexibility and allow it, when interest rates declined, to be able to gain the same savings using the detachable call that an issuer can now get with what is called an advance refunding.
In an advance refunding, an issuer borrows money at lower interest rates to pay off existing higher-interest-rate bonds. The existing bonds are paid off by setting up an escrow account and buying Treasury securities that are used to redeem the old bonds at the date they are callable.
Mr. Holt argues that selling the detachable calls in the future will achieve the same kind of savings for issuers, without going through the process or costs of an advance refunding. In addition, he said, issuers, like airports and ports, which are now prohibited from doing advance refundings, would be able to sell the detachable calls and achieve similar savings.
A lot of what actually will happen is still unclear, however. It is Mr. Holt's computer models that show the savings from selling the detachable calls. Only one other sale of detachable calls besides New Jersey's has been held; that was by the Municipal Electric Authority of Georgia last month. And both of these sales have been at the time of issue.
None of the more than $3 billion of bonds that Paine Webber and other firms have underwritten with the language needed for the issuer to sell the calls has been around long enough for an issuer to be in a position to decide if it is worth trying to sell them. The first detachable call was appended by Paine Webber to a $67.3 million Las Vegas, Nev., bond issue in April.
In addition, many legal issues are still unclear. In some states, including Nevada, legislation must be approved to allow the sale of detachable calls. More important, the Treasury is still pondering how it wants to approach this new financial product. The Treasury could open the door or it could limit it, depending on how it decides to treat the sale of a detachable call.
One main issue is the impact on the tax-exempt municipal bond market, where the Treasury has sought for years to limit issuance because of the revenue the Government loses.
Still, Mr. Coffin of Massachusetts Financial Services loves detachable calls. He bought close to half the detachable calls on the $70 million of bonds issued by the Georgia utility and about a third of the calls on the $86 million in bonds sold by New Jersey on Thursday.
The detachable calls help him even out the volatility in his portfolio, which comes from the fact that so many of the municipal bonds he owns give the issuer the option to redeem them, generally after 10 years.
What the presence of the detachable calls do for his portfolio is this: The movement in the prices of his bonds is varied because some include traditional calls held by the issuer and a few do not. Because of the risk of the call, when interest rates decline, the price of a bond without a call will rise, for example, 10 percent, while the price of a bond with a call will rise 7 percent. But if interest rates rise -- which means a bond is less likely to be called -- the price of both callable and noncallable bonds drops about 10 percent.
The addition of the detachable calls, which have their own value that moves with interest rates, help him gain back the three percentage points he loses on callable bonds when interest rates rise.

HEADLINE: Report Sees Sewer-Plant Threat to L.I. Sound

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 19

 BODY:
Long Island Sound is a vital but ecologically troubled estuary, threatened by pollution that pours into it every day from sewage-treatment plants, according to a preliminary report issued this week on a seven-year study of the Sound.
The report recommends limiting the amount of nitrogen that flows from sewage plants into the Sound, a proposal that some say would stifle development in surrounding communities. Up to $8.1 billion may have to be spent to limit the nitrogen releases, the report says. 
 Describing the Sound as "perhaps the most important estuary in the nation," the study warns that because of intensive use, "the water quality of the Sound and its suitability for human enjoyment, commercial use and as a habitat for fish and wildlife is threatened."
The report, titled "The Long Island Sound Study Comprehensive Conservation and Management Plan," is the culmination of a seven-year study initiated by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. A series of public hearings will be held before a final report is issued.
 
Business Groups Concerned
 The report's proposal to limit sewage-treatment plant discharges is troubling to many municipalities and businesses, which fear those limits would unfairly curb development and lead to a virtual halt on construction as communities seek to discourage new sewage hook-ups.
The proposed limits on sewage discharges drew fire on Thursday at a public meeting in Stamford on the plan, reviving a debate over whether environmental concerns are incompatible with economic priorities.
"We are not so desperate as to stifle the one stimulant to this economy that will not only get us out of this recession, but is vital to human needs," said Gerald D. Lloyd, representing the Westchester County Chamber of Commerce and a builders' group. The limits proposed in the report, he said, "will result in a de facto moratorium on construction."
But members of a panel leading the discussion said there would be no moratorium.
Other environmental experts said the release of nitrogen, a byproduct of sewage treatment, could be controlled in several ways, either through costly technology or simply through increasing public awareness of the problem. Too much nitrogen in the water deprives it of oxygen, creating a condition called hypoxia that can kill fish and other marine life.
 
Call for Conservation
 "There are nutrient-removal technologies that can remove nitrogen from waste water prior to discharging it into the Sound," said Sarah Clark, a staff scientist with the Environmental Defense Fund in Manhattan. "Water conservation is another very cost-effective way of not only reducing nitrogen, but also bringing down the burden on sewage treatment plants."
The management plan also discusses land-use issues, although the study only recently began to consider that aspect and will issue another report on the topic next year.
"This is a new way of doing business -- managing Long Island Sound as an ecosystem," said Mark Tedesco, who heads the Long Island Sound Office of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency in Stamford, one of several set up to coordinate the $15 million study.
The study called hypoxia "the most serious unaddressed problem impacting Long Island Sound." It recommends first limiting any increases in the amount of nitrogen released, and then actually reducing it.
 
Seeking Federal Aid
 Other recommendations include controlling toxics and disease-causing organisms that are frequently released into the Sound, through industrial sewers or mishaps in municipal sewage systems.
Grants available through the Federal Clean Water Act and state revolving funds could help pay for major programs like upgrading sewage-treatment plants, panel members said. "The cost will be an obstacle only if the Federal Government and the states don't step up to their responsibility to pitch in," said Donald S. Strait, executive director of the Connecticut Fund for the Environment. "If the burden is shared, then I think we can have a clean Sound without putting a terrific burden on any municipality."

HEADLINE: GLOOMY PROSPECTS SEEN FOR GROWTH WORLDWIDE IN '93

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
The world economy will grow far more sluggishly next year than was predicted just a few months ago, economists say, because of a surprisingly deep slump in Europe and Japan.
The economists say the situation will not only hurt American exports and make it harder for the American economy to pick up speed, but could also force President-elect Bill Clinton to concentrate more on short-term measures to stimulate the economy rather than on the long-term efforts he says are needed to put it back on track. The sluggish growth, they add, may also compel him to push Japan and Germany to do more to promote growth. 
 The overseas slump, they say, could mean the difference between respectable growth in the United States next year, with unemployment falling substantially, and another lackluster year with the jobless rate hovering above 7 percent.
 
German Recession Gets Blame
 In a forecast to be released Tuesday, the International Monetary Fund says growth in the industrial world will be 2 percent next year, considerably below the respectable 3 percent it predicted just three months ago. The report says that largely because of a recession in Germany, growth in Western Europe will be a feeble 1 percent, with the jobless rate climbing to almost 11 percent.
The Washington-based Institute for International Economics says the global slump may reduce American exports by $20 billion next year and cause employment to grow by 400,000 fewer jobs than previously predicted. When growth falters abroad, foreign businesses buy fewer American-made goods.
"A lot of people are predicting that the United States will have 3 percent growth next year, but I don't believe that, because most people haven't factored in a further deterioration in our trade balance caused by the weakness overseas," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the institute.
Because Europe's and Japan's economies have run out of steam, many experts say, it is now up to the United States to power the world economy. "The world needs a strong and sustainable U.S. recovery," Michel Camdessus, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said in a speech on Thursday.
Although the American economy remains in ragged shape after three years of anemic growth, the outlook for it appears more robust than that for other large industrial nations. The I.M.F. predicts that the American economy will grow by about 3 percent next year, compared with 1 percent for Germany. In September, 2.6 percent growth was estimated for Germany. The growth forecast for Japan next year has been cut to 2.5 percent from the 3.8 percent predicted in September.
 
Higher Taxes and Less Spending
 In blunt advice to Mr. Clinton, Mr. Camdessus said that for the United States to have a strong, sustained economic expansion, it should cut the Federal budget deficit soon through tax increases and spending cuts. He acknowledged that cutting the deficit could be painful, but he said it would increase business confidence and reduce long-term interest rates.
"Past experience shows that the costs of such action are small and temporary, while the benefits are considerable and long lasting," Mr. Camdessus said.
The President-elect has said he plans to focus on the domestic economy, but foreign economic problems could force him and Lloyd M. Bentsen, his nominee for Treasury Secretary, to focus on the international economic scene.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Bentsen could soon find themselves in the same frustrating position as President Bush and his Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady: imploring Germany's fiercely independent central bank to lower its interest rates, only to have their entreaties ignored.
 
Short-Term Rate Increased
 Eager to lower Germany's 4 percent inflation rate to less than 2 percent, the Bundesbank has increased its key short-term interest rate to 9.5 percent. This has plunged Germany into recession and is strangling growth throughout Western Europe. It is also casting a shadow on countries of the former Soviet bloc, hurting their efforts to increase exports.
Mr. Bentsen has talked vaguely about the need for increased international cooperation, and many economists say that will probably mean renewed pressures on Germany and the Bundesbank.
Mr. Bush's international economic team "made a career running into that brick wall," said Rudiger Dornbusch, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "It would be a mistake for the new Administration to break its teeth on the Bundesbank."
He predicted that the overseas slump would cause American growth to be five-tenths of a percentage point lower next year than it would have been without such a slump.
 
Pressure on Kohl
 Many economists suggest that Mr. Clinton will press Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany to reduce Bonn's bloated budget deficit, a move that would give the Bundesbank more leeway to cut rates. Mr. Clinton's doing this might prove more compelling -- and less hypocritical -- if he first puts his own economic house in order by cutting the Federal deficit.
"There's a significant chance that the Bundesbank is looking for an excuse to reduce rates, and if there was some external coordination, some movement abroad, that just might do it," said Mr. Bergsten, the Washington-based international economist.
Mr. Clinton's economic team is also expected to nudge Japan to speed up its growth, which is snail like by that nation's postwar standards. Japan's central bank has cut its rates, and the Government has promised a huge public works program to create jobs.
 
Japan 'Dead in the Water'
 "Japan remains dead in the water," Mr. Bergsten said. "I think it will be easy to pressure them to do more than that."
He sees a possible rebirth for international economic cooperation in which the American Government approves an important deficit reduction plan, Bonn does likewise and Germany's and Japan's central banks agree to cut interest rates.
One wild card for the United States is the dollar. Some economists fear it could soar if the Federal Reserve raises rates in response to faster American growth and if Germany's central bank reduces rates to lift Germany out of recession. Higher American rates would attract more money from foreign investors, helping push up the dollar.
A far stronger dollar could hurt American exports, as it did in the early Reagan years. Economists say cutting the Federal budget deficit might help keep the dollar from soaring because it should in theory lead to lower interest rates.

HEADLINE: The Art of Black Printmakers: Making Life Real

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
In the 1940's, a young artist, Samella Sanders Lewis, traveled to the Bayou Teche region of Louisiana to document the life of black sugar workers. "These were people trapped in a system that wasn't even a sharecropper system: it was beneath that," said Ms. Lewis, now 68 years old and living in Los Angeles.
"I needed a voice and they needed a voice," she continued. "I had things I needed to say about the social situation at that time. There was a hurt inside of me that I could not get rid of unless I understood it a little better." 
 The lithographs Ms. Lewis produced are included in a joint exhibition, "Alone in a Crowd: Prints of the 1930's and 1940's by African-American Artists From the Collection of Reba and Dave Williams," which opened on Dec. 11 in Manhattan at the Equitable Gallery at the Equitable Center, 787 Seventh Avenue, at 52d Street, and in New Jersey at the Newark Museum.
The exhibition, which continues through Feb. 27, comprises 150 prints by 41 artists from the Williamses' collection of more than 3,500 American prints, most of which are works made between the world wars. Mr. Williams is the chairman of Alliance Capital Management, an investment-management concern.
 
'We Were a New People'
 Like Ms. Lewis, many artists in the exhibition concentrated on creating realistic images of black people and their social condition. The documentary impulse ran strong at the time, long before the first stirrings of the civil rights movement, when black Americans felt ignored and abandoned, and when their visual representation lay in the hands of Madison Avenue and Hollywood.
"We were a new people, a new race, in a hostile country, and as a new people, identityless, we had to first define what we looked like," said Leslie King-Hammond, the dean of graduate studies at the Maryland Institute College of Art, who wrote the main catalogue essay for the exhibition.
"If we had not discovered that," she said, "we could not have given rise to the Jacob Lawrences and Romare Beardens and Adrian Pipers."
For many black artists, opportunity came either through employment by the Works Progress Administration or through courses at community art centers, like the Harlem Recreation Art Center, established by the program, and the W.P.A.'s graphics workshop in Philadelphia, where the printmaker Dox Thrash created a new etching technique. Using Carborundum, a grinding and polishing agent, he modified lithograph stones to create rich, velvety forms.
 
Cataloguing Black Artwork
 "For black communities, this was one of the most vital periods, because the Government had set up institutions where students could come to study and work," said Ms. Hammond-King, who has for several years been cataloguing artwork done by blacks under the W.P.A., much of it still languishing in cardboard boxes at the National Archives and at local libraries and government buildings across the country.
Given access to teachers and materials, young black printmakers set about describing rural life in the South, the great migration northward to the factories, the black experience in the military during World War II and the harsh living conditions of most black Americans.
Some printmakers celebrated the achievements of black Americans, depicting inspirational figures from black history or describing black contributions to music and dance, but most of the prints in the exhibition reflect a particularly bleak period for blacks.
"Remember, we did not have our Little Rock, and there was no Jackie Robinson in baseball," said Robert Blackburn, 72, who became a printmaker at the Harlem Recreation Art Center and for the last 30 years has served as director of the Printmaking Workshop in Manhattan. "It was really a cry into the night that we were expressing."
 
Isolation and Employment
 In his lithograph "Streetcar Scene" (1945), John Woodrow Wilson depicted a black worker, lunch box on his lap and a Boston Navy Yard badge on his overalls, riding the streetcar surrounded by white women. The print reflects a giant step forward for blacks in America.
"After the soldiers went off to war, women were recruited to work in factories, and eventually, the defense industries began recruiting black people, who were unemployable before," said Mr. Wilson, now 70 and still working as an artist in his native Boston. "On my street, everybody was on welfare in the 30's. Suddenly, blacks became welders."
 
'I Had to Invent It'
 The print also expresses a mood of isolation that Mr. Wilson says he felt acutely as a black artist. "There was nothing in my formal education that introduced me to a black artist doing art, or examples of art by black people with black images that was important," he said. "There was no precedent for using images of black people, so I had to invent it for myself."
Elizabeth Catlett, 73, is represented by a print series on the plight of black women, who, she said, "had been very neglected in art outside of nudes."
Like several other black artists, Ms. Catlett was deeply influenced by the work of the Mexican muralists Diego Rivera and David Siqueiros. In 1946, she applied for a grant to study at the Taller de Grafica Popular, a cooperative printmaking studio in Cuernavaca, Mexico, where she has lived ever since.
"Black artists heard a parallel voice in the Mexican muralists," Ms. King-Hammond said. "Those who won travel grants often elected to go to Mexico instead of Europe. Besieged by similar problems, they used the Mexican experience to see how they might seek resolutions in their own work."
 
Looking to Africa
 Other artists looked to Africa for a visual language. William McBride, who discovered African art when looking at textile designs in a British magazine, incorporated African design elements and African masks into his silk-screen prints. Such artists as Hughie Lee-Smith and William H. Johnson used the visual language of European modernism to interpret black experience. "We were trying to find a voice and find a place," Mr. Blackburn said.
"When I look back on it," Mr. Wilson said, "I guess what I was trying to do was make the invisible man visible, to build into these images such power and impact that you couldn't ignore them. I guess that's what I've been doing all my life."

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Woodrow Wilson by his lithograph "Streetcar Scene" at the Equitable Center. The exhibition "Alone in a Crowd: Prints of the 1930's and 1940's by African-American Artists From the Collection of Reba and Dave Williams" is at the Equitable and the Newark Museum. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: No Magic in Bank Deregulation

 BODY:
Apply for a loan now, and you'll automatically be entered in our FREE LOAN GIVEAWAY. You could win a FREE LOAN -- borrow up to $15,000 and NEVER pay it back!
Dear Mr. Clinton:  
 Think about this ad placed by a large Wichita, Kan., bank in local newspapers. The bank put up a pot of gold worth $15,000 to lure would-be borrowers. Apparently this bank was perfectly willing to lend more money, but couldn't find many takers during these recessionary times.
The bank's discovery doesn't square with some of the statements made at last week's Little Rock economic conference. Bankers promised to pump billions of dollars of new loans into the economy if only you would ease the amount of reserves banks are required to hold and waive other costly regulations. The new loans, they argued, would jump-start the sluggish economy -- and not cost Congress a dime.
The proposition sounded wondrous -- and it certainly grabbed your imagination. But, as the ad suggests, bank deregulation is no magic elixir.
To see why, recall the elegant testimony provided by Robert Solow and James Tobin. These economists showed that the current high unemployment rate is caused by too little spending. The answer is to stimulate the economy with temporary -- so as not to drive up the long-term deficit -- spending hikes and tax cuts.
As long as consumers aren't buying very much, they won't want to borrow very much. Neither will businesses who aren't selling very much. So giving banks more incentive to lend won't accomplish very much.
That said, there is reason for your administration to review bank regulations passed by Congress last year. Some are wasteful, some even absurd. For example, it took more than 250 pages pages to translate Congress's will into regulations governing how banks would be allowed to advertise interest rates on deposits. And there wasn't much of a problem to begin with.
There is also reason, as Federal Reserve Board Vice Chairman David Mullins pointed out last week, to believe that regulations are unnecessarily steering banks away from small-business loans.
Carefully pruning regulations to make financial markets work better makes a lot of sense. But hasty deregulation for the purpose of manipulating the unemployment rate is foolhardy. If your administration tries, it will risk replaying the savings and loan debacle.

HEADLINE: The Case for the Colorado Boycott

 BODY:
Deciding where to go for a skiing vacation ordinarily poses no moral dilemma. But this winter it surely does. Colorado, site of some of the finest ski areas in the nation, adopted a bigoted anti-gay initiative last month, shattering the state's reputation for tolerance. Gay groups and others are urging a boycott; their call deserves to be heeded.
Admittedly, an economic boycott is not a precision weapon. Targeting Colorado's $5 billion tourist industry stands to hurt not just the unenlightened, but also the progressive towns of Denver, Aspen, and Boulder, where most voters opposed the anti-gay amendment. 
 But that is no reason to let Colorado off the hook. A successful boycott can help energize the most progressive Coloradans to overturn their new law. And it would send a potent warning to other states that may soon consider similar measures.
When it takes effect next month, Colorado's Amendment 2 will void existing civil rights protections in jobs and housing for gay men and lesbians in Denver, Aspen and Boulder and will bar other localities from passing such ordinances. That puts Colorado a big step behind even states like New York, which has no statewide gay rights law but allows cities and towns to enact their own protective ordinances. The Colorado law amounts to an aggressive statewide policy to allow discrimination and block attempts to mitigate it.
Legal challenges to Amendment 2 are under way. Meanwhile, homosexual Coloradans live in fear, with gay-bashing incidents rising steeply. And forces of intolerance aligned with Pat Robertson's Christian Coalition are already working to put Colorado-style initiatives on the ballot by 1994 in at least eight other states: California, Idaho, Maine, Minnesota, Missouri, Ohio, Oregon and Washington.
The boycott's prospects are uncertain. Barbra Streisand's vocal support has ignited a civil war in the Hollywood film community -- leaving the impression that some top entertainers care a lot about civil rights, except when it interferes with their Aspen vacation plans.
But momentum appears to be building. Several big-city mayors, including those of New York City, Los Angeles, Chicago, Philadelphia and Atlanta, have now endorsed the boycott, and the U.S. Conference of Mayors has just pulled its annual meeting from Colorado Springs next June.
Mayor Wellington Webb of Denver, a longtime supporter of gay rights who opposes the boycott, pleads that Colorado is merely the first "casualty" of a broader assault by the Christian right. He warns that the clever stealth strategy used in Colorado -- depicting basic anti-discrimination protections for homosexuals in housing and employment as unjustified "special rights" -- is likely to have even greater appeal in other states with less tolerant traditions.
It's easy to sympathize with Mr. Webb's plight. But a successful boycott could help reverse the tide. The boycott is a legitimate weapon in a democratic society and, historically, one of the most effective.

HEADLINE: Essay;
How Clinton Is Doing 

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
When Ed Koch was Mayor of New York, he would plunge into the subways to ask riders "How'm I doin'?" (His Beijing look-alike, Zhu Rongji, is doin' fine.)
How does Bill Clinton after two-thirds of the interregnum? My criteria are his Cabinet choices, his economic outreach and last week's news conference. 
 1. Thirteen Yes-Persons and a Multiculturalist. Eisenhower's Cabinet was called "Eight Millionaires and a Plumber"; Lord Grenville's star-studded Government, after the death in 1806 of William Pitt, was dubbed "the Ministry of All the Talents" (changed within a year to "all the hacks"). What conclusions can we draw about the coming Clinton administration from the Cabinet choices so far?
"I didn't want a Cabinet of strangers," he says. In a sense, that's a pity; the stranger in the Nixon Cabinet was George Shultz at Labor, who turned out to be the best of the bunch. Clinton's Labor choice, Robert Reich, abandoned his intrusive idea of mandatory job-training spending by business within a week of his nomination, a sensible if gutless retreat; we can hope he is more stalwart about espousing free trade. (Organized labor got its feeble payoff with a protectionist Council of Economic Advisers.)
The Bentsen-Altman team at Treasury along with the Panetta-Rivlin duo at Budget and Ron Brown at Commerce offer a clear indication that Ross Perot's message got through: working with Congress to reduce the deficit is the top priority, which is a good thing. To appear to offer economic stimulus, Clinton will spread about some roads-and-bridges pork under the name of "infrastructure investment," but that is only to get credit for the recovery that is taking place on its own; it will hardly offset the $15 billion in tax refunds that George Bush handed out a year early.
Democratic lefties will get their share of rhetoric and symbolism, more important to them than real money. The sop to the liberal Cerberus is Donna Shalala, reputed high priestess of political correctness, whose multicultural passion will be harmless enough if accompanied by the promised health and welfare reforms.
The leaked intention of nominating a woman (preferably with a law degree) to be Attorney General is blatantly sexist; I hope it is offset by nominating a man to be Treasurer of the U.S., which would be a modern first. (Hang the cost of putting in a men's room at the Mint.) The only group not given its quota so far is Republicans; I'd like to see Carla Hills at the State Department, but that, along with the N.S.C., is supposedly set for Carter II.
Will the Senate's prim Tower Rule be applied to the Clinton choices? The first Republican to drag sex practice or preference into the confirmation hearings will get a zap from us partisans of privacy, but at least a couple of the newcomers can expect to be roughed up; Clinton properly warned of going "beyond the Pale."
2. The Little Rock Economic Seminar. The object was to show "the Presidency is in the details," like God and the Devil; the televised wonkmanship was an exercise in public involvement, and the President-elect succeeded in showing the world he can stay awake through a morning meeting.
3. News Conference Preparation. In last week's introduction of Henry Cisneros, Clinton quietly launched his '96 campaign against Jack Kemp, describing HUD as "an agency that badly needs reform and revitalization."
Asked about the murder of Israeli soldiers followed by the two-year expulsion of members of the Hamas terrorist group, Clinton avoided the standard State Department Arabism. He said: "I share the anger and the frustration and the outrage of the Israeli people . . . on the other hand, I am concerned that this deportation may go too far . . ." We'll see if his choice for Secretary of State veers back to knee-jerk condemnation of Israel.
To an astute question about the wisdom of appointing a veterans' advocate to head Veterans Affairs, Clinton argued that with a couple of veterans lobbyists in charge, he will be better able to get "a serious attempt at eligibility reform." That means he expects the former lobbyists to sell out their constituency by denying expected health benefits. Either Clinton is kidding himself or us.
How's he doing? Our next President is practicing safe politics. He runs the risk of running no risk.

HEADLINE: Patents;
Preserving Tissue in Deep Freeze

BYLINE: By Edmund L. Andrews

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE science of preserving human body parts in deep freeze took a modest step forward last week, when a small Georgia company patented a method for preparing tissue so that it has a better chance of surviving after being thawed.
The method of storing body parts for later use at about 200 degrees below zero Centigrade already constitutes a small business. The technology is nowhere near advanced enough to preserve entire organs, much less to bring about the more lurid science-fiction schemes of storing terminally ill people until cures for their diseases are developed. 
But the method is already being used to preserve and recycle human heart valves and veins used in heart surgery, and it forms the basis for a small service business for Cryolife Inc. of Marietta, Ga. The company stores about 200 heart valves every month, as well as a smaller number of veins that can be used in heart bypass operations. These are removed from people who have just died and are typically thawed for a new recipient within a few weeks.
"The problem is that cells become metabolically depleted, because they are coming from a person who has died," explained Kelvin G. M. Brockbank, head of research at Cryolife. That depletion reduces the chances that a heart valve can be used after it is thawed. "What we do," Dr. Brockbank said, "is give them an opportunity to correct that problem before they are frozen."
He and another researcher, John F. Carpenter, patented what amounts to a special feeding program. Technicians place the heart valve or vein in a dish containing a rich mixture of nutrients and keep it at normal body temperature for at least six hours before freezing it.
He and Mr. Carpenter received patent 5,171,660.
 
Possible Application For 'Buckyballs'
 Researchers at Bell Laboratories have patented one of the first potential applications for "buckyballs," the unusual carbon molecules that are shaped like soccer balls and have fascinated scientists around the world since they were discovered a few years ago.
"Buckyball" is the nickname for a molecule consisting of 60 carbon atoms that are connected in a perfectly symmetrical globe made of hexagons and pentagons. Because the structure closely resembles the geodesic dome developed by R. Buckminster Fuller, scientists formally named the newly discovered molecules "buckminsterfullerenes" and almost universally refer to them in casual parlance as buckyballs.
What fascinates scientists is that buckyballs look exactly the same from all sides, and many believe this symmetry makes them useful for creating a host of innovative compounds. Buckyballs can also be used to make superconductors -- capable of transmitting electricity with virtually no resistance -- though thus far only at colder temperatures than the ceramic materials discovered around 1987.
Last week, three researchers at Bell Labs patented what could be the first practical application. Led by Arthur Heber, a specialist in superconductors, the group discovered that buckyballs convert light into electricity, making them potentially useful for opto-electronic switches used in fiber-optic communications and ultrafast light-based computers.
In one example, Dr. Heber said, he and his colleagues made a thin-film sandwich of buckyballs between two layers of metal. Shining a low-power laser on one side induced a thousandfold increase in electrical current on the other. The scientists also put buckyballs in a water solution, and upon exposing it to light, produced a big jump in electrical voltage.
The inventors believe this may open the door to a wide range of high-speed switches that convert light to electricity -- and vice versa -- more easily than is now possible.
"The challenge is to make it economic and competitive," Dr. Heber said . "It's still very much in the research stage." He and two other researchers, Barry Miller and William L. Wilson, received patent 5,171,373.
 
A New Container For Chilling Liquids
 By reducing air pressure to lower the boiling point of water, Israel Siegel of North Miami, Fla., has invented a self-cooling container that uses no electricity or Freon.
The invention is based on the fact that the boiling temperature of water drops sharply if the air pressure around it is lowered as well. In a vacuum, water will boil -- and thus give off its heat -- even if it is below room temperature.
The container features two chambers, one that holds the liquid to be cooled and a second that features a desiccant, a compound that absorbs vapor. Air is pumped out of the entire container, but vapor created by the liquid initially keeps pressure and boiling temperature at normal levels in the first chamber.
To cool the liquid, a person presses a button that opens up a pipe connecting the two chambers. The desiccant, which can be calcium sulfate, essentially sucks vapor out of the first chamber and almost instantly lowers the pressure of the second chamber. The liquid boils, the heat is sucked with the new vapor into the second chamber and, the inventor said, the liquid chills to refrigerator temperature in about 30 seconds.
Dr. Siegel received patent 5,168,708.
 Patents are available by number for $3 from the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 23, 1992, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
The Patents column in Business Day on Monday missidentified an inventor at Bell Laboratories who patented a new application for carbon molecules known as Buckminsterfullerenes. He is Arthur Hebard. The article also omitted the name of one inventor; he is Joseph M. Rosamilia.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
CLINTON CHOOSES 2 AND DEPLORES IDEA OF CABINET QUOTAS

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 21

 BODY:
At a news conference where he named two more members of his Cabinet, President-elect Bill Clinton lashed out at women's groups who had been complaining about the pace of appointing women, calling them "bean counters" who were more interested in quotas than competence.
His comments came as he announced the appointment of Hazel R. O'Leary, a 55-year-old power company executive from Minnesota, to be Energy Secretary, and former Gov. Richard W. Riley of South Carolina, 59, as Education Secretary. 
 In Mrs. O'Leary, Mr. Clinton turned to a former regulator in the Ford and Carter Administrations who is familiar with Washington's power brokers but whose own views are not widely known. And in Mr. Riley, he chose a champion of education reform with a knack for getting the changes he wants. [Profiles, page B9.]
 
Defending Appointments
 Responding to questions at today's news conference about the complaints from the women's groups, Mr. Clinton voiced sharp displeasure with those who have criticized his Cabinet selection process.
At the same time, he defended his decision to pass over a white man who had been the leading candidate for the energy post, Senator Tim Wirth of Colorado, as part of his effort to assemble a more diverse Cabinet.
Friends of Mr. Wirth said he had been promised the job several weeks ago and had accepted. But the pressure for sexual and racial balance apparently slowed the process of choosing a Cabinet, and gave Mr. Wirth's enemies an opening.
In a candid discussion today, Mr. Clinton said he was particularly unhappy that two of his appointees -- Laura D'Andrea Tyson as chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers and Carol M. Browner as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency -- were being treated by some women's advocates as less important than other appointees because their jobs were not in the Cabinet.
"I believe that if I had appointed white men to those jobs, those people, those same people would have been counting those jobs in a very negative way," he said. "They would have been counting those positions against our Administration, those bean counters who are doing that, if I had appointed white men to those positions."
As recently as this month Mr. Clinton said he intended to raise the head of the E.P.A. to Cabinet level. He has not said whether the administrator would actually become a Cabinet member or simple attend Cabinet meetings.
 
Third Black Nominee
 Gesturing toward Mrs. O'Leary, who is black, he said that no women's group or black group had included her name as a recommended Cabinet choice. Mrs. O'Leary is the third black Mr. Clinton has chosen for a senior position.
Aides said Mr. Clinton was close to selecting a black Agriculture Secretary as well. Representative Mike Espy of Mississippi, a leading candidate, met with Mr. Clinton on Sunday.
The President-elect must also choose an Interior Secretary and Attorney General before turning to national security appointments. Former Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona is the leading choice for Interior.
Mr. Clinton is considering several women to be Attorney General and transition aides said he asked the person at the top of his list, Judge Patricia M. Wald of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, to reconsider her decision to remove herself from consideration.
As for national security positions, Representative Les Aspin is expected to be named Defense Secretary and Warren M. Christopher, the transition director, is expected to become Secretary of State.
Transition officials said Former Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin of Vermont had emerged as a candidate for ambassador to the United Nations, another position that aides have said could be elevated to Cabinet level..
Mr. Clinton has been under pressure in recent days to increase the number of women he appoints. In a letter to Mr. Clinton, Eleanor Smeal, President of the Fund for a Feminist Majority, called on the President-elect to "shatter the glass ceiling" and surpass President Bush's record of appointing three women to Cabinet positions.
Mr. Clinton said today he expected to name more than three women to his Cabinet and added that he felt his critics should consider the influence of his appointees as well as their number.
"I have sought to give the American people a Cabinet that would be both more diverse in terms of numbers, but far more powerful in terms of substantive impact than ever before," he said. "And I may be wrong about this, but I think, unlike some people who are apparently commenting on this in public, that both issues are important."
To tamp down the growing displeasure of some women's groups, Vernon E. Jordan, the transition chairman, met with several of their representatives in Washington today. Some have complained that Donna E. Shalala, Mr. Clinton's choice to head the Health and Human Services Department, was the only woman he had chosen to run a Cabinet-level department.
As for naming more minority members to top posts, Mr. Clinton said today that a "distinct possibility" existed that there would be Hispanic nominees in addition to former Mayor Henry G. Cisneros of San Antonio, whom he has chosen to head the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
In naming Mrs. O'Leary to run the Energy Department, Mr. Clinton turned aside Mr. Wirth, who had all but been offered the job.
But, Mr. Clinton contended, "It is absolutely untrue that his appointment was nixed, if you will, by any interest group contacting me or by anybody within my transition operation."
Some Senate Republicans, including John McCain of Arizona and Phil Gramm of Texas, indicated in recent days that they would oppose Mr. Wirth's appointment and try to tie him to irregularities in the savings and loan industry.
Mr. Clinton said he expected to offer Mr. Wirth another post. But in a statement from Mr. Wirth's office that was phrased in the congratulatory tone of the gracious loser, he indicated that he would pass on this offer.
"For several months, my name has been mentioned as a possible Cabinet nominee," he said. "I would have been pleased to serve, but am equally pleased to be returning to private life." He offered his congratulation to Mrs. O'Leary, whom he called a "wise and prudent choice."

HEADLINE: New Energy Chief Has Seen 2 Sides of Regulatory Fence

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton's choice of Hazel R. O'Leary, a little-known executive with a Minnesota utility, to lead the Department of Energy was bound to please groups that had been looking for more women and blacks in his Cabinet. But it may take longer for energy producers, marketers, environmental groups and the Energy Department's biggest constituency -- the military and the nuclear weapons industry -- to see how they feel.
Mrs. O'Leary, a 55-year-old former regulator in the Ford and Carter Administrations who later worked in an energy-consulting firm, fits the developing mold of the Clinton Administration: she is familiar with Washington's power brokers in her field. Still, her own views are not widely known. 
 She has been executive vice president for corporate affairs at the Northern States Power Company for the last three and a half years, overseeing the company's legal and personnel departments, environmental affairs, public relations and lobbying.
 
Weeks of Intense Lobbying
 Mrs. O'Leary became Mr. Clinton's choice only after several weeks of intense lobbying that dimmed and then sank the prospects of several more prominent candidates, including Senator Tim Wirth, Democrat of Colorado, who decided not to run for a second term this year and had been regarded as the early front-runner for the energy post.
Many of the commentators and Washington power brokers who had been handicapping the selection process had expected Mr. Wirth or some other widely known figure to be tapped because transition officials had been suggesting that Mr. Clinton was planning to give the Energy Department a more prominent role.
Mrs. O'Leary's sudden emergence apparently surprised her employers as much as Washington insiders. Just last week Northern Power announced several executive changes, including her appointment as president in charge of its natural gas operations. That assignment was to begin on Jan. 1.
A company spokeswoman said last night that it was unclear whether Mrs. O'Leary would start the new company assignment pending confirmation of her appointment by Congress.
The Energy Department, a bureaucracy with almost 18,000 employees, had been relegated to the background in the Reagan and Bush Administrations after initial proposals to eliminate it entirely. Mr. Clinton is said to want the department to spearhead efforts to make industry more efficient and cleaner, to create jobs in environmental businesses and to reduce the nation's dependence on coal and oil.
 
Billions in Cleanup Costs
 But the biggest part of the department's budget goes to supervise the nation's nuclear bomb complex, a web of reactors, factories and laboratories that has experienced safety problems and pollution cleanup costs estimated at billions of dollars a year.
Mrs. O'Leary's comments yesterday suggested that her management experience at Northern Power, one of the largest gas and electric utilities in the Midwest, had tempered her views about the wisdom of using Government regulation to meet those or any other goals.
"In the public sector I've regulated industry broadly," she said at a news conference in Little Rock, Ark., where Mr. Clinton announced her appointment. "In the private sector, I've been forced to live with those regulations and, perhaps more importantly, I've seen how those regulations if not carefully crafted and balanced can impact jobs and lives and economies of people who expected and hoped for better from their Government."
Some environmental groups spoke warily of the appointment, noting that Northern States has been involved in several projects that they oppose. The most hotly contested project recently has been a proposal by a consortium of companies to build a nuclear reprocessing plant in an impoverished section of Louisiana.
 
Alternative Energy Projects
 But Northern States in general -- and Mrs. O'Leary in particular -- has also been associated in recent years with several conservation and alternative energy projects similar to those praised by Mr. Clinton and Vice President-elect Al Gore. She noted yesterday, for instance, that she drives a demonstration vehicle that runs on compressed natural gas.
One Minnesota environmentalist who has frequently clashed with the company said Mrs. O'Leary might prove to be surprisingly sympathetic.
"She's not an ideologue," said George Crocker, head of the North American Water Office in Lake Elmo, Minn. He said that Mrs. O'Leary had repeatedly opened doors for him to advocate the utility's move toward a pricing structure that rewarded the company for investments in conservation and tailored its rate of return to progress in meeting conservation goals.
"I talked with her yesterday and she told me that conservation programs are closest to her heart," he added.
There was little talk yesterday of the Energy Department's biggest budget commitment through the years, financing nuclear weapons research and cleanup. The Clinton transition team has said that transferring technologies developed for the military cleanup to the private sector should be a major priority for the Government.
Born and reared in Newport News, Va., Mrs. O'Leary graduated from Fisk University in Nashville in 1959 and earned a law degree at Rutgers University in 1966. She was an assistant New Jersey Attorney General, a prosecutor in Essex County, N.J., and a partner in the Washington office of the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand before working at the Federal Energy Administration under President Gerald R. Ford and in the Energy Department under President Jimmy Carter.
She joined O'Leary Associates, a Washington-based energy consulting firm, in 1981 as vice president and general counsel. In 1980 she married John F. O'Leary, the firm's founder.
Mr. O'Leary, who served as Deputy Energy Secretary in the Carter Administration, died in 1987. Mrs. O'Leary has a son, Carl G. Rollins, a lawyer in Washington.

With Mr. Riley and Mr. Clinton were Vice President-elect Al Gore and Hazel R. O'Leary, who was chosen to lead the Energy Department. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Barricades and Passes for Drug Neighborhood

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LAWRENCE, Mass., Dec. 21

 BODY:
Residents of a neighborhood frequented by drug dealers were required to travel through a police checkpoint starting today just to get home, resulting in protests from civil liberties groups.
Police officials in this city of 70,000, which is about 40 miles north of Boston, said the unusual tactic was an effort to stem drug dealing, often to buyers from suburban communities. 
 "This is not an occupation army coming in and setting up a police state; this is part of community policing," said Police Chief Allen W. Cole.
But John Roberts, director of the Civil Liberties Union in Massachusetts, called the measure "martial law without the Federal troops." Mr. Roberts said his group would probably challenge the measure in court on civil rights grounds.
 
District Attorney Opposes Plan
 The Essex County District Attorney, Kevin Burke, said he had advised Chief Cole not to put up barricades.
"I told him it was not legal, and I didn't see how he could enforce it without running the risk of violations," he said.
The police issued passes to residents of the four-square-block area to come and go. Those without passes could enter the neighborhood but only after having their vehicle identified at a roadblock of squad cars and yellow barrels.
Officers recorded the license plate numbers and planned to send a letter to the owners saying their cars had been seen in that area.
"If you were coming in here to buy drugs, would you drive past a police car, knowing that a letter will be sent to your house?" Chief Cole asked.
 
Police Claim Blocks' Support
 The chief said his department had been trying to drive drug dealers out for months. But when one officer was fired at and another had a gun drawn on him within the past 10 days, he had the police canvass residents, who said they would support barricades.
The police say the barricades will be in place 18 hours a day indefinitely.
Some residents of the barricaded area say they are fed up with the unemployment and crime that have haunted the city for several years.
One, Lisette Ortiz, 24, said her racially mixed neighborhood was pleasant in daylight but became a haven for drug dealers and prostitutes at night.
"Twice they've tried kicking in my door at night, asking if I sold drugs," Ms. Ortiz said. "I don't go out at night. I'm scared."

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS;
Serbia's Enigma: An Aloof Leader Who Stoked Fires of Nationalist Passion

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 21

 BODY:
On the ruined walls of towns and villages across Bosnia and Herzegovina that have been devastated by "ethnic cleansing," one word, "Slobo," appears again and again, scrawled in spray paint by the Serbian fighters who have swept through, terrorizing inhabitants and razing homes.
For those who have made his name a totem of their cause, it seems no matter that "Slobo" -- Slobodan Milosevic, the President of Serbia -- has never visited the battle zone, nor even their wounded fighters. As the political patron of Serbian nationalism, and as the head of the Serbian Government that has given the arms and money Bosnia's Serbs have needed to carry out their killings, Mr. Milosevic is a hero above all others among the forces who have seized two-thirds of Bosnia as an exclusive Serbian domain. 
 Today, those fighters and their supporters in Serbia were celebrating what seemed likely to be a victory for Mr. Milosevic in Sunday's presidential election. If the trend in early returns is sustained, Mr. Milosevic will have defeated Milan Panic, the Serbian-American millionaire who was his principal rival, on a platform that has prompted many in Serbia to fear that Mr. Milosevic may yet widen the war.
Mr. Panic's associates were issuing statements today alleging that the election was rigged, but Mr. Milosevic's associates said that the returns would strengthen the Serbian President and stiffen his resolve in meeting increased Western pressures for an abandonment of the militarist policies he has pursued since the break-up of Yugoslavia began last year.
During the election campaign, which was conducted as the United States and other Western nations reviewed a range of military options intended to restrain Serbian offensives in Bosnia, Mr. Milosevic vowed never to turn away from a policy of "great solidarity with the Serbian people outside Serbia." This is a term he has used in the past to describe the use of military force in support of "ethnic cleansing" and other practices that have been condemned by the Western powers as atrocities.
 
Despite Carnage, Little Remorse
 Already, these policies have caused the deaths of at least 150,000 people in Bosnia and Croatia, and have driven at least 1.6 million people from their communities as refugees. But while Mr. Panic described the conflict as "an intolerable tragedy" and vowed to end it, Mr. Milosevic, who is 51 years old, appears to have been unmoved by the consequences of his actions.
In part, this has been a matter of personality, since even his close associates describe the former Serbian Communist leader as dispassionate, cool and unrattled even amid the growing international condemnation of Serbia and its leaders.
On Wednesday, Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger named Mr. Milosevic among possible war criminals whom Mr. Eagleburger said should face trial on charges relating to atrocities committed in the Balkan fighting.
Mr. Milosevic answered in less than a day. Traveling first to Kosovo, the region of southern Serbia where a million ethnic Albanians are agitating for independence, then to Nis, a Serbian industrial city nearby, Mr. Milosevic offered what appeared to be an oblique justification for "ethnic cleansing" when he said that the Albanian majority in Kosovo had been its first practitioners, by encouraging an exodus of Serbs over the past decade.
He went on to declare that despite all threats Serbia would not abandon what he called "our great solidarity with Serbian people outside Serbia."
"This country has many times in its history endured the challenge of foreign threats," he said. "Now, we are called upon once again to decide whether we will stand up, or go down on our knees and become a new Balkan colony. So I tell you: We will never surrender Serbia."
He attended his closing election meetings to the accompaniment of rhythmic chants of "Slobo! Serbia!" and sat through lengthy speeches that ascribed to him almost mythic qualities. For Mr. Milosevic, this was not new. In Belgrade, portraits have appeared depicting the stocky, almost cherubic-looking Serbian leader as a medieval knight like those who fought, and lost, Serbia's watershed battle against the invading Turks in Kosovo in 1389.
 
Leader Who Plays On Ancient Fears
 The invaders went on to make Serbia and Bosnia an outpost of the Ottoman Empire for nearly 500 years, fostering the embattled political psychology among Serbs, and in particular the fear of Muslims that Mr. Milosevic has exploited in building his political career.
According to former associates, this represents a sharp break with his attitude during the years when he was working his way up through the Communist Party apparatus. Then he aligned himself with Titoist orthodoxy, which outlawed nationalism.
Until three years ago, Mr. Milosevic, as Serbia's Communist Party chief, had little popular following. But after he traveled to Kosovo in 1989 and made a fiery speech about the rights of Serbs, he unleashed a wave of nationalist feeling. Fear of this resurgent nationalism fueled independence movements in four of the other five Yugoslav republics, which had no desire to trade a Communist yoke for a Serbian one.
In 1990, with Yugoslavia beginning to break up, Mr. Milosevic rode the nationalist wave to victory in Serbia's first post-Communist election. From there, it was a short step to the policies that led to war in Croatia and Bosnia.
By conventional standards, the two years since the last election have been a disaster for Serbia. The collapse of the Yugoslav economy, coupled with the stringent economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations, have idled more than 60 percent of the Serbian work force and fostered an annual inflation rate of about 10,000 percent.
But Mr. Milosevic, who rarely appears in public except at election time, seems not to have shared the pain felt by many Serbs. During the election, he addressed crowds of unemployed workers in industrial cities devastated by the economic collapse and congratulated them on increasing production, puzzling some local officials.
At rallies where thousands had been bused in by his Serbian Socialist Party, a new version of the old Communist Party, he stared stony-faced as cheers washed over him, and looked uncomfortable when he was asked to take tea and make small talk with voters. But perhaps the strongest signal to his character has been his attitude toward the war in Bosnia.
Contemptuously rejecting the American war-crimes charges, Mr. Milosevic held to a posture he has adopted from the start of the Bosnian conflict, denying any responsibility for the Bosnian war despite the release of transcripts of telephone conversations between Mr. Milosevic and Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader, that implicate Mr. Milosevic. Western diplomats say their intelligence reports show similar involvement.
 
Is It Dishonesty, Or Self-Delusion?
 Mr. Milosevic's denials of what those around him know as fact is one facet of a complex personality. Warren Zimmermann, the former American Ambassador to Yugoslavia, who was withdrawn in May as a gesture of protest against the Serbian offensives in Bosnia, told associates after a series of bitter encounters with the Serbian leader that his most prominent character trait was dishonesty.
"Warren used to say that he was astonished by the man's ability to lie with a look of total sincerity on his face," a Western European diplomat said.
Others describe this differently. "Many people who have dealt with him recently speak of him as disconnected from reality," said Ivan Jankovic, a Belgrade patent lawyer who followed Mr. Milosevic through law school at the University of Belgrade in the 1960's.
A man who worked with Mr. Milosevic for years, and agreed to discuss the Serbian leader on condition that he not be named, said, "He decides first what is expedient for him to believe, then he believes it."
Those who look for explanations for Mr. Milosevic's behavior beyond the tangled world of Balkan politics often cite his childhood. He was the son of a Serbian Orthodox priest from Montenegro, a region known for engendering fierce nationalism among its Serbian inhabitants. Both his parents committed suicide while he was still in his teens, as did an uncle.
Growing up in Pozarevac, about 50 miles south of Belgrade, he was known as a disciplined, humorless loner. He married his childhood sweetheart, Mirjana Markovic, now a professor of Marxist-Leninist theory in Belgrade, who shared his Communist orthodoxy.
"He was incredibly disciplined, and took Communism with deadly earnestness, even when everybody else thought it was a terrible bore," one former law classmate said.
Another man who helped Mr. Milosevic as he ascended the Communist hierarchy in Belgrade said that he had never met a man who was more assiduous in developing contacts to promote his own career, and less loyal to those who helped him.
"He's a man who makes no friends," this former associate said. "There is only one thing that matters to Slobo Milosevic, and that is Slobo Milosevic."
 
Visitors Are Few At Walled Mansion
 The sense that the Serbian leader is walled off from those around him is strong. Neighbors in Dedinje, the affluent Belgrade suburb where Mr. Milosevic lives in a mansion that was confiscated by Communist authorities from a prominent Jewish family that died in the Holocaust, say that few visitors ever pass through the wall of bomb-proof steel that surrounds the house. Associates say that Mr. Milosevic has few pastimes, preferring to spend nights and weekends working on Government papers than socializing.
Vreme, the weekly news magazine that has been one of Mr. Milosevic's strongest critics, has noted that he has done few of the things that are routine among wartime leaders elsewhere, such as visiting the wounded.
"He's responsible for the war, and he's shown almost no interest in its victims," one Western diplomat said. "It's one thing for him to show no compassion for Muslim victims of the war, but he doesn't even show any feeling for the Serbs who have been killed or wounded."
But even Mr. Milosevic's harshest critics concede that he has been extraordinarily shrewd in building up his domestic political base. For most of the time since the Kosovo speech in 1989 he has outmaneuvered his political opponents and the diplomats who have attempted to constrain the Serbs.
For months, envoys have elicited what they believed were undertakings from Mr. Milosevic to halt "ethnic cleansing," to stop Serbian forces from seizing more territory in Bosnia, and to place Serbian heavy weapons under United Nations supervision. None of these things has happened, and so far, at least, Serbia has escaped direct Western military intervention.
Although the United States and other Western nations have hinted recently that they may meet any new Serbian aggression with direct military action, some opponents see signs that Mr. Milosevic has concluded that the United States and its allies have no willingness for a military confrontation. Mr. Milosevic is said to have concluded that despite its condemnation of Serbian aggression, Russia will block any United Nations approval of military involvement by outside powers.
 
Will Russia Resume An Old Alliance?
 Associates of Mr. Milosevic say he believes that the conservative challenge to Boris N. Yeltsin, the Russian leader, will lead to the emergence of a nationalist government in Russia that will revive Moscow's 19th-century alliance with Serbia, to the point of aiding Serbia militarily if a wider Balkan conflict erupts.
Diplomats say the Serbian leader may be caught in his own strategy, with the nationalist feelings he has stoked driving Serbia into war, and the war heightening nationalist passions, to the point that he cannot turn back.
"It's become a vicious circle," said Mr. Cerovic, the columnist for Vreme. "I just can't imagine that a man who could start all this will suddenly resign and go to live on the money he and his associates are supposed to have put into banks in Cyprus, or that he will somehow begin to act more reasonably. The world should realize that when dealing with Slobodan Milosevic, there is no reasoning. He understands only violence and force."
