HEADLINE: With Casino, the Poor See a Change in Luck

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TUNICA, Miss.

 BODY:
In years past, politicians trooped to this Mississippi Delta town whenever they wanted a backdrop that showed the worst of rural poverty, especially the tumbledown shacks, outhouses and open sewers of the Sugar Ditch section.
But since it opened two months ago, a riverboat casino has begun to transform this town and surrounding county into a gambling and tourist destination, drawing people from Memphis, northern Mississippi, Arkansas and even Kentucky and Missouri. 
 To say that the Splash Casino -- the state's fifth casino over all and the first in the Delta -- has also transformed life for many in Tunica is no exaggeration. That is especially true of the 1,023 casino employees, half of whom live in Tunica County, where the jobless rate has been cut in half.
 
Doubts Behind the Glitter
 The mood is not all upbeat, of course. It will be a while before it becomes clear whether the casino, and its employees, will prosper once the novelty wears off. Others have noted an increase in the cost of living because property values have been pushed up. And some people think that gambling is wrong, no matter what the benefits, and that poor people will be tempted to gamble away their meager savings.
More fundamental is this question: Can riverboat gambling really bring permanent change to a county where, until just a few years ago, a few black people still lived in shacks and emptied their bodily waste into a ditch?
After the plight of the shack dwellers became nationally known in the mid-1980's, when it was revealed that more than $1 million in Federal money had been spent on sewer improvements for white subdivisions rather than the black Sugar Ditch community, the shack dwellers were moved to federally subsidized housing. But Tunica remained mired in poverty: the county was the poorest in the nation, according to the 1980 census, and the fourth-poorest in the 1990 census.
 
Sounds of Optimism
 For now, though, the noise of slot machines, dice tables and roulette wheels are sounds of optimism. Cocktail waitresses like 26-year-old Demetrease Hurt of Memphis and others say they like their new jobs. Some workers say they make more in a day than they used to make in two weeks of stuffing pillows or filleting catfish, to name two jobs typically held by young unskilled workers in these parts.
"Sometimes I can get as much as a $25 chip as a tip from a bettor who's winning," said Ms. Hurt as she took orders for drinks. "I have kids at home, and I can make more in one day here than I made all week at my last job in an auto parts store."
Nearby, a former welfare recipient and part-time school bus driver, Angela Hargrow, made change for slot machine players. "I didn't see much of a future when I was driving the school bus," said Ms. Hargrow, 26. "It was a dead end. But here it's possible for me to get a promotion." She hopes to work in one of the cages where money is counted and the chips are dispensed.
 
Spirits Are Lifted
 This element of optimism is perhaps the most obvious and immediate effect of the casino, said Clayton Henderson, a State Representative and the owner of a local funeral home. He said the casino had lifted the spirits of the county's 8,200 people, 72 percent of whom are black and most of whom are poor.
"The casino has given hope to an area that has been deprived and depressed for years," Mr. Henderson said. "If there is a bad side to any of this, it's either too early to see it or we just haven't seen it."
Those sentiments are being echoed farther south in Biloxi and Bay St. Louis, where four 24-hour riverboat casinos have been moored in the Gulf of Mexico for the last four months. The coast's sagging, tourist-oriented economy has shown signs of improving with 3,000 new jobs. Most of those are attributable to the casinos, whose visitors have accounted for gambling revenues of $46 million.
"People can't believe it, and every call has been positive," said the Bay St. Louis Mayor, Edward A. Favre, whose administration was able to send out property-tax bills this month that reduced most residents' bills by 85 percent because of the revenues anticipated from gambling.
Mississippi estimates that there will be gross revenues of $260 million annually from the casinos already approved for the state, said Lorenzo Creighton, director of the Mississippi Gaming Commission. And while the operations are limited to 14 counties, the state's 8 percent share of the revenue will benefit everyone in Mississippi.
The euphoria and hope may give way to colder assessments, in Mississippi and elsewhere, as gambling outlets become as ubiquitous as sandbars along the Mississippi River's 955 miles from Cairo, Ill., to Venice, La., where it splays into the gulf. Iowa and Illinois now allow riverboat gambling, and Missouri moved in November to do so. Louisiana recently passed a law authorizing a land-based casino in New Orleans and up to 15 riverboat casinos.
What happens in other states could be important to Mississippi because experts on casino gambling have long noted that the gambling market is not limitless. While early entrants prosper quickly, shakeouts from competition are inevitable.
But in the meantime pioneers like the Splash Casino are making big money. Rick Schilling is the managing partner of the group that operates the $22 million casino in a structure that was once a nightclub moored in Cincinnati and later St. Louis.
 
A New 'Boom Town'
 Tunica gets a $1-per-person boarding fee as well as eight-tenths of 1 percent of the gross casino revenues. In the first 11 days of the Splash Casino's operation, the county netted $40,000 from the boarding fees alone; it projects a total annual contribution of $2 million, about equal to the county's current total budget.
All of this has made Tunica a bit of a "boom town," said Paul Battle, the chairman of the county Board of Supervisors and owner of a local catfish-processing plant. The county plans on using $750,000 to build a new access road to the casino, and investors are planning restaurants, hotels, golf courses and apartments.
Mr. Battle said that dozens of workers have left his plant for the $5- to $8-an-hour jobs at the casino. But he added that he had had little trouble finding others to take their place. "Anybody who can't get a job around here now just doesn't want to work," he said, noting that unemployment in the county was about 7 percent, half of what it was before the casino.
 
Eyes on Bigger Things
 Ms. Hargrow, the mother of one child, said that before getting the job making change at the casino she worked part time driving a school bus, and that with that job and her welfare allotment she got about $152 every two weeks, plus food stamps. She lives in Cottonland Apartments, the subsidized housing complex built in 1986 after the Rev. Jesse Jackson highlighted poor living conditions in the county. She pays $68 a month in rent, based on a formula requiring her to pay 25 percent of her income for it.
Ms. Hargrow now makes about $350 every two weeks in salary alone and has her eyes on a promotion that could nearly double her salary. So far, the only downside of the new developments is the notice she got that, because her income is up, her rent would increase to nearly $200 a month in January.
"It's brought some good and some bad," she said of the casino. "I really need to get that promotion for things to really improve for me."
Michael Brown, 25, drove a fork lift for a chemical company until recently. Now he works the floor of the casino, overseeing maintenance crews and attending to the needs of some of the change persons. A native of Tunica, he said he had experienced a tremendous change in attitude with the new job and had noted the same thing in others.
"Usually, we have to scrape so hard for a living and people here are usually always so tired after working on jobs that they don't like," said Mr. Brown. "I was the same way, and every day I got up I hated to go to work. But now I look forward to it."
In her black tights, starched collar and cutaway, it is not likely that a 23-year-old cocktail waitress, Marketta Alexander, would be recognized by anyone she knows from her day job. By day, she is an eighth-grade math teacher in nearby Byhalia. The University of Southern Mississippi graduate said that she was working at the casino to earn extra money to study pharmacy.
 
Rejection Elsewhere Helps
 Tunica's apparent good fortune is largely due to the fact that gambling fever failed to catch on in DeSoto County to the north, when a coalition of churches and others defeated a riverboat-gambling proposal in a November referendum. DeSoto County, considered more a suburb of Memphis than part of the rural Delta and its persistent poverty, had a 3 percent unemployment rate and little economic incentive to approve the gambling proposal. When it was defeated, a lot of people in Tunica breathed more easily.
One reason for their relief is that plans for new housing, restaurants and hotels in Tunica had been frozen as investors awaited the outcome of the DeSoto vote. They reasoned that Tennessee and Arkansas gamblers would not drive the extra 25 miles south to Tunica if there were casinos closer by in DeSoto.
"At first people thought I was an idiot to come here," said Mr. Schilling, the managing partner of the Splash Casino. "But now I'm a genius because its working. And when the competition eventually does come, I suspect they will take some of the cream, but there will still be plenty of milk."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
U.S. Sues 8 Airlines Over Fares

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
The Justice Department filed an antitrust suit today that accused the eight largest American airlines of using a computerized reservation system to fix air fares.
Without admitting or denying the accusation, two airlines, United and USAir, agreed to end the practice of communicating proposed future fare increases to each other through the computerized system. 
 But other airlines insisted that they had done no wrong and said that it was wrong for the Government to be adding to the troubles of an industry that has lost $7 billion in the last two years. The other airlines named in the suit were American, Delta, Northwest, Continental, T.W.A. and Alaska Airlines.
 
Accused of Passing Signals
 The airlines are accused of using the computerized system, maintained by the Airline Tariff Publishing Company, to communicate to one another about changes in fares. The company, which provides airline fare information that is used by travel agents, is owned by a group of airlines, including the eight carriers named in the suit. The publishing company was also named in the antitrust suit, which was filed in United States District Court in Washington.
"We believe that the consumer impact was significant," said J. Mark Gidley, Acting Assistant Attorney General in charge of antitrust. But he said the Justice Department could not provide even a rough estimate of the cost to consumers.
The complaint said the listing of future fares on the computerized system was a source of abuse. An airline could signal that starting on Jan. 1, for example, it would increase by $50 its unrestricted economy fare between New York and Chicago. Competing airlines would see the fare increase in the computer system and act accordingly, the lawsuit contended.
In some cases, the suit stated, an airline would signal its intention to reduce a fare on a route that was lucrative for its competitor, which would then retaliate by signaling its intention to reduce a fare on a route that was lucrative for the first airline. In some cases, both fare reductions were then abandoned, or an accommodation was reached, according to the Justice Department.
 
A Matter of Timing
 Some fare increases are placed in the computerized system two months in advance, but most take effect within a week or two.
"Using A.T.P., the airlines were able to engage in an elaborate dialogue with one another about future fares," Mr. Gidley said. "The airlines engaged in a process that involved repeated exchanges through A.T.P. of price-increase proposals and counterproposals, with the effect of raising fares to consumers.
"By using A.T.P., airlines communicated the details of proposed fare increases to competitors and obtained their reactions. These discussions often continued until there was an agreement on a higher fare."
The system enabled the airlines not only to set future fare increases, but also to settle on expiration dates for discount fares, Mr. Gidley said.
Alfred E. Kahn, who championed airline deregulation when he was chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board during the Carter Administration, said in an interview today: "I think it is certainly the case that they used this method of signaling to one another. It isn't much different from meeting in a hotel room, but the fact is that if they are trying to be conspirators they are like the Three Stooges in their success. Their industry is losing money hand over fist."
The airlines say they announce future fares to inform consumers, not their competitors. "Airline customers want to know in advance when prices will rise so they can plan their travel, and buy tickets before the increase," said Anne H. McNamara, a senior vice president and general counsel of American Airlines.
Noting the industry's big losses, Ms. McNamara said, "Surely our Government has better uses for the taxpayer's hard-earned dollar than to attack an industry which has given new meaning to price competition, one in which about 20 percent of capacity is currently in bankruptcy."
"If we are monopolistic price fixers," she said, "then we are laughably inept."
Continental Airlines issued a statement that "categorically" denied the antitrust charges.
The suit involves the same computer system that was the subject of a class-action lawsuit tentatively settled earlier this year by six major airlines. The carriers agreed to distribute $458 million worth of discount coupons to passengers who contended that they had been affected.
The Justice Department is not suing for monetary damages, but rather to eliminate some practices. The agency wants the airlines to put fare changes into effect immediately, rather than at a future date. The department also wants the airlines to stop indicating the date on which discounts will end.
The airline industry has suffered extraordinary financial distress during the period cited in the price-fixing complaint, as airlines have struggled with erratic fuel prices, terrorist incidents that deterred tourism, and excessive debt piled on during the deal-making days of the 1980's.
At least half a dozen airlines have collapsed into bankruptcy in the last four years, including Pan Am, Braniff and Eastern. Among the defendants named in the complaint, Trans World Airlines and Continental Airlines are operating under bankruptcy court protection. Both are nearing agreements that will permit them to emerge from bankruptcy next year.
Even the strongest carriers have problems. Delta recently instituted widespread pay cuts, sharply reduced its stock dividend payments and curbed its expansion plans. American Airlines has announced severe measures to cut costs.
"Judged in the aggregate, the industry is bankrupt," said Julius Maldutis, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, in a recent report. "If the industry were a savings and loan association, the Government would have seized it and liquidated it."

HEADLINE: Western Experts Feel Russia's Move to Free Market Will Continue

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Despite a series of recent setbacks for President Boris N. Yeltsin's drive to establish a market economy in Russia, many Western economists and experts say that the transition is likely to continue, at a slower pace, and that the process may be too far along to be reversed.
In a dozen interviews, experts on Russia as well as officials who deal with Russia in the United States Government, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank said they were disappointed that Mr. Yeltsin had been thwarted in his efforts. But they said they no longer feared that the Yeltsin reforms were in danger of being undone. 
 The interviews were conducted after the biggest blow to Mr. Yeltsin's program last week, the ouster of Yegor T. Gaidar as Acting Prime Minister. Mr. Gaidar had been the driving force behind the move to capitalism and free enterprise under Mr. Yeltsin.
Another sign that Mr. Yeltsin's program might be in danger was his abrupt decision to fly home from China on Friday. He declared over the weekend that new efforts were under way to undermine his program, and there is talk in Moscow of the Government's flooding the economy with new credits that could drive up inflation.
 
Process 'Irreversible'
 "We would have been better off if Mr. Gaidar had continued in his job for a while longer," said a senior Bush Administration official who asked not to be identified. "But while his agenda was incomplete, he may have already done enough to make the process irreversible."
With Mr. Gaidar out, one major issue among Western experts is whether his successor as Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, will replace the young, market-oriented economists who had worked with Mr. Gaidar.
Mr. Chernomyrdin had said last week that he would keep the group that had worked with Mr. Gaidar. But some Western economists say their main concern is not personnel changes but the fact that Mr. Chernomyrdin's main constituents are the managers of giant, inefficient state-owned manufacturing companies who oppose a market economy in which their companies might shrink or go bankrupt.
"A very bad man became Prime Minister of Russia," said Andre Shleifer, a Harvard University economist who has worked with the Yeltsin Government as an adviser. "Mr. Chernomyrdin's fundamental view is that the revival of the economy will take place through the revival of major state companies. But the country does not need more steel or more weapons or more airplanes that sit at airports because they cannot fly."
A major issue among Western experts appears to be the level of Western financial aid needed to keep Russia moving toward a market economy. Last spring, the West offered $24 billion in loans to help stabilize the Russian currency and ease its transition.
There is a dispute among Western economists and officials of the International Monetary Fund over how to count the amounts actually disbursed, with the I.M.F. reporting that nearly $18 billion in promised loans has been granted, while others assert that the actual amount is much lower.
The optimism that Russia will continue to move toward a market economy seemed to be a change in tone from comments last spring and summer, when many experts said Mr. Yeltsin had little time in which to enact his changes. They argued then that the $24 billion should be disbursed immediately to promote radical "shock therapy" and thus rescue Russia from reverting to Communism or a planned economy.
A few economists continue to argue for shock therapy, whose main features include large-scale sale or transfer of government enterprises to private hands, and a cutback of government credits and subsidies that keep inefficient state enterprises alive.
Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard economist and prominent advocate of shock therapy who served as an adviser to Mr. Gaidar, deplored his ouster and angrily blamed what he sees as the failure of Western nations to support Mr. Gaidar.
"They have no guts, no concept of strategy, and they act, quite frankly, as if they can't tell the difference between a reformer and a Communist," Mr. Sachs said in an interview, referring to officials in the Bush Administration and the governments of the other major industrial nations, as well as the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
But this harsh judgment is challenged by officials in the Bush Administration, who say Mr. Chernomyrdin may continue the economic changes, although perhaps at a slower pace.
"We know that as Oil and Gas Minister for the past six months, Mr. Chernomyrdin worked closely with Mr. Gaidar," an Administration official said. "On energy, there was not a big difference in their views."
President-elect Bill Clinton's aides declined to discuss their opinions about the latest changes in Russia.
 
Influence Termed Limited
 In the interviews, the Russian experts said Western influence in Russia, whatever the spending, is now very limited.
"At this point, the enormous forces of Russian internal politics have overwhelmed events, putting them beyond any Westerner's control," said Robert Hormats, a vice president at Goldman Sachs & Company, which was hired last year by the Yeltsin Government to solicit Western corporate investment.
Given the limited influence, most experts said Western loans should be used to finance specific projects rather than to put pressure on the Yeltsin Government to bring about a rapid and large-scale reorganization of the economy, as Mr. Sachs has advocated.
Under the original shock-therapy approach, the West had offered the $24 billion in loans, but only if the Russians agreed to various steps to force a market system on the country. The I.M.F. was to negotiate this agreement, but those negotiations have been suspended for weeks.
One step in these talks would have required the Yeltsin Government to remove price ceilings, which Mr. Gaidar has done for most products. A second called for rapid privatization of state companies, large and small, and considerable progress has been made on this score, too.
The main stumbling block was a third condition, which required the Yeltsin Government to reduce inflation, mostly by no longer printing rubles to pay out huge subsidies to inefficient state-owned industries, running up the budget deficit in the process. Parliament's resistance to ending the subsidies played a big role in unseating Mr. Gaidar and also in suspending the I.M.F. negotiations.
Nevertheless, Bush Administration and I.M.F. officials say $18 billion in new loans flowed to Russia this year from the West. The biggest part, they say, was $13.9 billion in bilateral aid from various governments, mostly short-term credits to finance Russian imports from the West.
The remaining amounts in the $18 billion were listed as a $1 billion I.M.F. loan, $670 million in World Bank loans, and an agreement to postpone $2.4 billion that Russia owed the West in interest -- in effect, forgiving the money to the Russians until they pay it later.
 
Figures Are Disputed
 But Mr. Sachs disputed these figures, and I.M.F. officials acknowledged that the calculations were subject to different interpretations. Mr. Sachs said that the $13.9 billion from various governments was not part of the $24 billion promised last spring and summer and that the money carried no requirement that the Russians make economic reforms.
Mr. Sachs added that the $18 billion total included $3 billion to $4 billion in German loans to build housing in Russia for Russian soldiers now stationed in eastern Germany, a sum that was never expected to be included in the $24 billion package.
Whatever the amounts, many Russia experts, including one or two who have submitted position papers to the office of President-elect Clinton, argue that the transition should proceed more slowly.
"The real objective is to slowly shrink state industries," said Mr. Shleifer of Harvard. "Even for Mr. Gaidar, the transition has been slower than shock therapy envisioned."

HEADLINE: CANADA TIGHTENS IMMIGRATION LAW

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Long considered a model of generosity in granting asylum to the world's persecuted, Canada is making its immigration procedures more restrictive in the biggest change in Canadian immigration law in 16 years.
After a long period of economic hard times, and with unemployment well over 10 percent, the new law responds to a decline in Canadian tolerance toward immigrants, among other reasons, because they are seen as competitors in the labor force. 
 The law, which received final approval on Thursday, has drawn criticism from refugee and civil liberties groups. Asylum approvals have been on the decline, from 76 percent of the applicants in 1989 to 57 percent this year, and the law is expected to lower the rate further.
 
Still a Refuge
 But Canada's policies will still be more liberal than those of the United States. For instance, Canada has no country quotas; instead, Canada assesses applicants on the basis of professional, educational and financial backgrounds, a process that is further developed in the new law.
Howard Greenberg, chairman of the national immigration section of the Canadian Bar Association, said that under the new law, "applying to Canada will be like applying to law school: The Government will collect applications worldwide and assess them as against one another, and select the cream of the crop for processing."
The main restrictions relate to refugees. "We're concerned that this new legislation will restrict the number of people who get to Canada to make a refugee claim," said Fay Sims, refugee coordinator for Amnesty International's Canadian Section.
 
Spread of Xenophobia
 A recent survey by the Immigration Department demonstrated that Canada is not isolated from the wave of xenophobia rolling over Europe. More than 40 percent of Canadians, according to the poll, say their country admits too many immigrants. One-third say they want to "keep out people who are different from most Canadians."
But Greg James, president of the Refugee Lawyers Assocation, challenge the general perception that Canada receives more than its fair share of refugees. Thirty thousand people sought asylum in Canada last year, he said, compared with 256,000 in Germany, 46,000 in France, 45,000 in Britain, 41,000 in Switzerland, 27,000 in Austria, 27,000 in Sweden and 26,000 in Italy. According to data from the Immigration and Naturalization Service, the United States accepted nearly 500,000 refugee applications last year.
Some critics argue that the law is part of the positioning of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Progressive Conservative Government for elections next year. The measure is seen as stealing thunder from the Reform Party, which has been taking votes from Tories in western Canada and which has long called for immigration curbs.
To Employment and Immigration Minister Bernard Valcourt, the measure meets the "new realities" of the 1990's: according to his figures, 80 million people are on the move worldwide in search of a new homeland. He feels that many would circumvent Canada's immigration laws, if given the chance.
 
Possible Abuse of Power
 Refugee advocates have serious reservations about a provision that gives border guards the right to determine who is entitled to make a refugee claim, without any recourse for appeal.
"We're concerned about that," said Mr. James, the lawyer, "because it will be done in the context of a simple interview in which the claimant may not have counsel or a qualified person to assist him."
Since most refugees come from the United States, a high rejection rate would put a bigger burden on such centers as Vive Inc., in Buffalo, a church-funded way station for refugees from New York City. Of 234 refugees that it bedded and fed last month on their way north, nearly half were from Somalia. The Rev. John Long, Vive's director, worries that his facilities, in an old Roman Catholic school in Buffalo, will be swamped.
 
A 'Militarized Border'?
 Nancy Worsfold, executive director of the Canadian Council for Refugees, which represents about 130 church, community and organizations, said the measure could have a major impact on the border region.
It "creates the incentive to make an illegal border crossing," she said, and Canada could well respond by creating a "militarized border."
Under current law, a refugee who makes it to a border point is automatically given the right to a hearing before the Government and independent adjudicators.
According to immigration records, more than 90 percent of the refugees are initially able to show a credible basis for staying and thus qualify for a second hearing. The Government wants to change the procedure, it says, to cut costs and promote efficiency.
Powers to deport have been broadened, and deportation will be possible not only of a person engaged in illegal activities, but also of a member of any organization linked with illegal activities.

HEADLINE: As Americans Stay Home, Japanese Discover Jamaica

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica

 BODY:
After decades of heavy reliance on the winter cravings of Americans for sun and sand, Jamaica, pushed by the persistently weak American economy, has begun a major restructuring of its travel business that is drawing thousands of tourists from new markets.
Frequently scheduled flights now link the island to South America via Colombia, and there are jam-packed charters from Italy, Germany and even Scandinavia. But nowhere have the efforts to diversify the country's pool of foreign guests paid off so well as with Japan. Despite having to travel two days to cover 8,020 miles from Tokyo to Kingston, Japanese visitors are now flocking to many of this country's finest hotels. 
 While much of Caribbean remains in the doldrums because of the slow growth of the American market, vacancies are rare here at the Half Moon Hotel, an elegantly understated luxury resort here that caters to these new guests. Two Japanese travel agencies have desks beside the finely manicured English-style garden adjacent to the lobby, busily booking free-spending guests for golf, horseback riding and guided shopping jaunts.
 
Dinner by Candlelight

At night, the dinner scene is so busy that reservations often must be made two days in advance for a restaurant where Japanese patrons now make up as much as half of the clientele, read their specially printed menus by twinkling candlelight.
At the turn of the decade, indeed for many years, Americans accounted for 85 percent or more of Jamaica's visitors. But as Japanese, European and South American travelers have poured into the country and the American market has stagnated, visitors from the United States have come to account for only about 60 percent of Jamaica's tourist volume.
While visits from North America are now growing again at an annual rate of about 2 percent, Jamaica's new markets taken together are growing at a clip of 60 percent a year. Arrivals from Japan have risen more steeply than any other tourist market.
In 1988, only about 1,800 Japanese visited Jamaica, while more than 25,000 are expected this year, according to Raphael Barrett, chairman of the Jamaica Tourist Board. Last year, Jamaica received a total of about 800,000 overnight visits, plus about 500,000 cruise ship passengers, earning the country $764 million. For the coming tourism year, officials say they expect 1.5 million visitors to the island.
"We have just finished our best year ever, and there is no doubt but that reaching out to new markets has played a big part in that," said Butch Stewart, chairman of Sandals, one of Jamaica's leading resort chains, which has spent heavily to tap the emerging Latin American market.
In addition to increasing overall volume, Jamaican officials say, the diversification of the tourist trade has smoothed out the traditionally steep seasonal peaks and valleys in arrivals, giving the country a true year-round travel business for the first time.
Although there are traditionally popular warm weather vacation spots in Asia that are much more accessible for the Japanese, many visitors from that country explained the attraction by saying that Jamaica still incarnates a prized quality of alien novelty that many Asian destinations have lost.

HEADLINE: Donors to Neediest Cases Wish They Could Do More

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
"Wish I could do more."
The note scribbled by Therese W. Trachtman of Manhattan was brief, but it gave voice to a sentiment expressed by many donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. More and more people seem frustrated by a recession that refuses to release its grip on the New York region. 
 In letters to the fund, the donors say they feel overwhelmed by the seemingly endless number of stories of homelessness, unemployment, hunger and despair. But they add that they know they must contribute something, even if they face shrinking incomes and savings. Mrs. Trachtman, for example, gave $15.
M. Michael Griggs of Pemaquid Harbor, Me., wrote: "How I wish this gift could be 100 times this donation to your magnificent endeavor. I'm 400 miles away, but I think of you and your wonderful work every day." He wrote a similar message on his check for $11.
Another donor who lives far away, Margaret D. McIntire of Mackinac Island, Mich., said she regretted that she could give only $100 to the fund. "Because I love New York," she wrote. "Wish I could do more."
 
Frustration and Compassion
 Stephen Solender, executive vice president of the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, said many donors have conflicting emotions about the poverty around them. U.J.A.-Federation is one of seven charities assisted by the Neediest Cases fund.
"On the one hand, there is enormous frustration that year after year these terrible problems exist," Mr. Solender said. "At the same time, there is real compassion. People would like to have a society where we don't have an army of folks on the streets."
Thomas DeStefano, executive director of Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens, another Neediest Charity, said he sensed that the donors themselves were feeling vulnerable in the face of the recession.
"People are not as secure in their jobs as they used to be," he said. "That's part of the burnout. But the reality is that they should recognize that even though they are doing just one thing, they are the hope for someone."
 
'The Best I Can'
 For eight decades, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has rescued tens of thousands of New Yorkers with nowhere to turn. The New York Times pays for the fund's overhead, so all contributions are given directly to the charities. This year's appeal ends on Feb. 28.
Like Mr. Griggs, Isabel Andrews, 80, a retired investment consultant, wrote to the fund that she wished her donation could be "100 times larger." She gave $50.
"Every time I pick up The New York Times and read of Somalia or Red Hook or Bosnia, it seems to me that the world is crying for help," Miss Andrews said yesterday from her home in Massapequa, L.I. "How are we going to answer all those appeals? You try to meet some of the needs through your local church and charities, but the flood waters seem to increase rather than go down.
"I think it's a universal feeling, from what I hear my friends say," she added. "I'll just keep on doing the best I can. I think that's all anyone can ask of any of us."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Slightly Higher In Quiet Day and Gold Falls

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar finished modestly higher against most other major currencies yesterday in very quiet trading.
Gold prices fell sharply on primarily technical selling on the Commodity Exchange, where bullion for current delivery settled at $334 an ounce, down $2.90 from Friday. A late quote from the Republic National Bank said spot gold fell $3 to close at $334.05. 
 Despite France's relative economic stability, many speculators and other market players were selling the franc, betting on a devaluation. The lira, meanwhile, was under pressure from political uncertainties in Italy and mounting expectations of a rate cut.
The Canadian dollar sold off overseas and then was bid back up when a large order kicked in.
But dealers said most big market players were staying on the sidelines, having already squared their positions ahead of the end of the year to lock in profits.
"Everyone is flat as a board," said Ken Nixon, a customer dealer at Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank in New York.
Few banks want to jeopardize hefty revenues garnered during the European currency turmoil in September and October, a bank dealer in the United States said.
Traders were also cautious ahead of today's release of the final third-quarter gross domestic product figure, since currencies could be whipsawed if the new number is sharply above or below the Government's latest 3.9 percent growth figure.
"It's absolutely quiet," said Steven Jury, chief dealer at Chemical Bank.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed in thin trading at 123.15 yen, barely above Friday's 123.05. Later in London, it finished barely changed at 123.03 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 123 yen.
In London, the British pound was at $1.5645 in late trading and drifted down to $1.5585 at the close of New York trading. On Friday, sterling ended in the United States at $1.5660.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday quotes, included: 1.4135 Swiss francs, up from 1.4085; 5.3610 French francs, up from 5.3420; 1,408 lira, unchanged from Friday, and $1.2676 Canadian, down from $1.2753.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Medical Costs: The Beat Goes On

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
MEDICAL price inflation seems to be easing a bit, stirring hopes that the health-care monster may yet be tamed. But the price numbers can be misleading and even irrelevant, economists say, because the amount spent on health care is still rising by 10 percent a year, swallowing more of the economy.
The Labor Department says that after climbing steadily since 1987, medical price inflation slid to a 6.7 percent annual rate for the first 11 months of 1992, down from 7.9 percent in 1991 and 9.6 percent in 1990. But the slide probably will not be much help to President-elect Bill Clinton as he seeks a formula for affordable health care. 
 "Health spending is still escalating at the same rate as over the past couple of years," said Walt Bottiny, a health economist in Washington with DRI/McGraw Hill, a consulting firm that forecasts trends for the Federal Medicare program. "Medical inflation is moderating, but not any more than overall inflation is."
Sylvester Schieber, benefits research director at the Wyatt Company consulting firm, said medical price rises caused only about a third of the increase in health spending in the 1980's. He said 42 percent was general inflation and 22 percent was from increased volume of services.
And economists caution that the medical component of the Consumer Price Index no longer reflects actual spending patterns for some major items like hospital charges. The index is still based on list prices for hospital rooms, for example, although most large insurers get discounts, notes Joseph P. Newhouse, a professor of health policy and management at Harvard University.
Henry J. Aaron, economic studies director of the Brookings Institution, the Washington research center, said that even as hospital rates rose, patients spent fewer days there, on average, and the quality of service was up. He added: "We can't measure the restoration of health. We don't know if it lines up with the number of hospital days."
Mr. Newhouse laments that "we don't have a measure of medical care price increases." He adds: "We badly need one. The public believes much of the problem is in prices."
On the positive side, most experts agree that the quality of health care has been rising markedly, at least for those who can afford the expensive new tests and surgical procedures that spur much of the growth. Another plus factor: The expansion has generated jobs. Even while the economy hemorrhaged 1.9 million jobs over the last two years, 320,000 were added in health care, which currently employs 8.4 million Americans, 9.6 percent of all private, nonfarm workers.
The mushrooming costs are a major factor in the Federal deficit, the Congressional Budget Office reported recently, and they are increasingly onerous for private employers. The report noted that employers had squeezed much of the increase in medical costs from payrolls by withholding wage increases, which have not kept pace with general inflation.
Employer costs are rising even faster than the rise in medical spending over all. Jon Gable, benefits research director at KPMG Peat Marwick, the benefits and accounting firm, said employer health premiums would increase by about 12 percent in 1993 and jump even higher in 1994, when he expects hospitals and doctors to pass along several years worth of increases in staffing and overhead expenses.
Efforts to slow growth through managed care like discounts on fees and monitoring patients' care have not been effective, Mr. Bottiny of DRI/ McGraw-Hill said. Mr. Schieber of Wyatt added, "If there is any slowdown in the price pressure, most major purchasers have not noticed it."
The long-running growth in spending on hospitals, doctors and expensive new drugs has also drained billions of dollars from Federal, state and local resources. "There is a real crunch coming in government budgets," said Uwe E. Reinhardt, a Princeton University health economist. "There will be less to put into education and the infrastructure."
The Congressional Budget Office said, "The projected rise in Federal health costs is a major reason for pessimism regarding the long-term outlook for the Federal budget deficit." It said the deficit would "balloon to more than $500 billion," or 5.1 percent of potential G.D.P., by the year 2002. Even if the current double-digit trend in medical spending growth slips a bit, the budget office said, the nation's health spending will still double by 2000, to $1.68 trillion -- a staggering 18 percent of the projected gross domestic product -- from $808 billion, or 13.6, in 1992.
But if Federal spending for health could be held to the 1991 share of G.D.P., the budget office said, the deficit could be pushed back to about 1 percent of potential G.D.P. in 2002, about where it was in the 1960's and 1970's, before soaring above 3 percent of G.D.P. in the 1980's.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "A Growing Share" tracks health-care spending as a percentage of the gross domestic product during 1965, 1980, 1985 and 1990. Projections are supplied for 1992, 1995 and 2000. (Source: Congressional Budget Office)

HEADLINE: BUSH AIDE ACCUSED OF LYING IN INQUIRY ON CLINTON SEARCH

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
The Justice Department says that the White House political director, Janet G. Mullins, "may have made false statements" to Federal investigators and may have helped direct the search of Bill Clinton's passport files during the Presidential election campaign.
The accusations against Ms. Mullins, who is among the inner circle of aides to James A. Baker 3d, mark the first time Federal officials have suggested that the White House may have helped orchestrate the effort to find damaging information about the Democratic candidate at the height of the campaign. 
 An aide to Ms. Mullins said today that she was unavailable for comment.
Ms. Mullins worked for Mr. Baker when he was chairman of George Bush's Presidential campaign in 1988 and when he was Secretary of State, from 1989 to August of this year. She went with Mr. Baker when he was named chief of staff at the White House, where they have been working together since Aug. 23.
 
Responding to Petition
 The accusations were made in the Justice Department's request for appointment of an independent prosecutor to investigate possible crimes. The text of the request was disclosed today by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, in response to a petition by CBS, The New York Times and The Washington Post.
The court appointed Joseph E. diGenova, a former United States Attorney in the District of Columbia, who is a Republican, as independent prosecutor on Dec. 14, a day before the law authorizing such appointments expired.
Attorney General William P. Barr summarized the evidence against Ms. Mullins in his application to the court.
"Mullins was interviewed twice by agents" of the State Department inspector general, Mr. Barr said. "During those interviews, she made statements denying her knowledge of, or participation in, the search of Clinton's files. Other evidence directly contradicts Mullins's statements."
 
Two Findings May Differ
 Moreover, the Attorney General said, "There is also evidence that Mullins was aware of the interest in Clinton's files before the search occurred, and that Mullins helped encourage and direct the search."
This finding appears to differ from the conclusion of the inspector general, Sherman M. Funk. In his report, issued Nov. 18, Mr. Funk wrote, "We found no evidence that the White House -- or any other external source -- orchestrated an 'attack' on the Clinton files."
In the request for an independent prosecutor, Mr. Barr did not name Mr. Baker or Margaret D. Tutwiler, the White House director of communications, as targets of the investigation. The inspector general concluded that both of them were apparently aware of the search at about the time it occurred, on Sept. 30 and Oct. 1, at the height of the campaign.
 
Liaison to Campaign
 But the court's charter authorizes the independent prosecutor to investigate and prosecute "all matters and individuals whose acts may be related" to the search of Mr. Clinton's passport files.
While at the White House, Ms. Mullins was political director and liaison to the Bush campaign. At the State Department under Mr. Baker, she was Assistant Secretary for Legislative Affairs. In Mr. Bush's 1988 campaign, which Mr. Baker ran, she was in charge of advertising.
Ms. Mullins, 43, is also experienced on Capitol Hill, having served as an aide to Senators Mitch McConnell of Kentucky and Bob Packwood of Oregon, both Republicans. A Kentucky native, she majored in political science at the University of Louisville and studied international economics at American University in Washington.
 
What the Court Ordered
 A special three-judge panel of the appeals court ordered Mr. diGenova to investigate whether Ms. Mullins committed a crime by making false statements, by obstructing the inspector general's investigation, by conspiring to violate Federal law, by stealing confidential information from Mr. Clinton's file for the benefit of the Bush campaign or by using her official authority to interfere with the 1992 election.
The independent prosecutor may also turn up evidence that shows whether Mr. Baker or President Bush authorized or approved the search of Mr. Clinton's files. The inspector general's report quotes Mr. Baker as saying that he learned of the search from Ms. Mullins on Sept. 30 or Oct. 1.
Mr. Baker insisted that no one at the State Department was "feeding a 'blow by blow' account of the progress of the file search to the White House," Mr. Funk reported.
 
'From Credible Sources'
 Attorney General Barr said on Nov. 16 the Justice Department became aware of suspicions that Ms. Mullins had been involved in the search of Mr. Clinton's passport files.
"Information was also received suggesting that Mullins may have made false statements to agents of the State Department Office of the Inspector General who were investigating the circumstances surrounding the search," Mr. Barr said. He concluded that "the allegations against Mullins were specific and from credible sources." The sources, he said, included Elizabeth M. Tamposi, an Assistant Secretary of State who was dismissed from her job on Nov. 10.
In the campaign, President Bush raised many questions about Mr. Clinton's character. He suggested that Mr. Clinton had been unpatriotic in demonstrating against the Vietnam War when Mr. Clinton was a student in Britain in 1969 and 1970. The Bush campaign also raised questions about Mr. Clinton's travel to Moscow in 1969.
 
Citizenship Issue Raised
 Republicans encouraged journalists to file requests under the Freedom of Information Act, to see if Mr. Clinton had ever tried to renounce his United States citizenship to avoid military service in Vietnam.
In his report, Mr. Funk said, "Ms. Mullins related that she had no idea how the rumors concerning Governor Clinton's citizenship and foreign travel got started, and all she knew about the department's handling of the Clinton F.O.I.A. requests was what she had read in the newspaper."
Mr. Funk said Ms. Mullins was in Ms. Tutwiler's office on the night of Sept. 30 when Ms. Tamposi tried to call Ms. Tutwiler to discuss the search.
Ms. Tutwiler "raised her eyebrows," refused to take the call and "told Ms. Mullins that she did not think it would be appropriate for her to become involved in the Clinton files matter," the inspector general said in his report.
This account suggests that Ms. Tutwiler knew enough about the search to avoid Ms. Tamposi's phone call. But Mr. Funk never explained how Ms. Tutwiler might have gained such knowledge, and Ms. Tutwiler has refused to discuss it.
The independent prosecutor was appointed under a section of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978. The special panel of three Federal judges exists exclusively for the purpose of appointing such prosecutors. The judges who named Mr. diGenova are David B. Sentelle, John D. Butzner and Joseph T. Sneed. Judge Sentelle was appointed to the Federal bench by President Ronald Reagan, Judge Butzner by President John F. Kennedy and Judge Sneed by President Richard M. Nixon.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
The Saga of the Lonetree Landfill

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EDGEMONT, S.D.

 BODY:
Had everything gone according to the plans of a Colorado entrepreneur named Hunter Swanson, the Burlington Northern Railroad the and waste-disposal giant Browning-Ferris Industries, a visitor heading south of town would see a stream of rail cars hauling bales of trash from around the nation to a modern, federally approved landfill.
Instead, where the arid rolling prairie drops away toward the rails and an abandoned Army munitions depot in the distance, one sees only subtle remnants of those plans. There's some graded land where preparation of Lonetree, as the stalled disposal site here is known, had begun, a low berm intended to direct rainfall away from the fill and three mounds built four years ago to test water flow through the soil and hundreds of feet of dense shale below it. A thin blanket of snow immobilizing the patches of sagebrush and native grass adds to the stillness. 
 The Nimby, or not-in-my-backyard, syndrome may still be the most frequent killer of plans put forward by business groups trying to profit from waste disposal. But the fate of Lonetree shows that overcoming even that barrier is no longer a guarantee of success. Indeed, most of the residents of this impoverished community have repeatedly voted for the landfill project.
Opposition, though, is no longer a local issue. The waste-disposal industry must now contend with environmental groups that oppose interstate transportation of wastes even when the goal is to get them to better disposal sites.
"Zero landfills may never be a reality but it's a good goal," said Kim Marie Kiepke, an environmental activist who lives in Rapid City and organized a statewide campaign that overturned the State Legislature's endorsement of the Lonetree project. She argues that building remote landfills like Lonetree undercuts pressure on people in populated areas to work harder on recycling and reducing the amount of waste they generate.
Moreover, landfill management is no longer the soaring profit generator it was only recently. Landfill operators have not been able to raise prices in many regions as rapidly as they had projected.
Average disposal costs to customers rose rapidly during the late 1980's, as much as 30 percent annually in some areas. But the annual rate of increase through October this year slowed to slightly more than 4 percent, according to an index published by Solid Waste Digest, a trade journal. In some areas, the costs have actually fallen. The City of Philadelphia's new disposal contract with Browning-Ferris is about 20 percent less than its recently expired contract with Waste Management Inc.
There are several reasons for the slowdown in price increases, including the nation's economic slump and the growth of recycling. The most important cause is the bidding war for waste in some regions among new incinerators, mega-fills and hundreds of older landfills scheduled for closing next fall when new Federal environmental regulations take effect. Prices should increase when the obsolete landfills are finally forced to close but no one is sure how quickly.
"Lonetree is wonderful from a geological point of view -- you couldn't get much better -- but even if all the cards fell right, it's no longer economical," said Philip Angell, administrative assistant to William D. Ruckelshaus, the chief executive of Browning-Ferris. The Houston-based disposal company, which is the nation's second largest after Waste Management, had signed preliminary agreements to be a major supplier of waste to Lonetree and invested nearly $2 million in the campaign to get the site up and running.
 
Lonetree's Roots
 Mr. Swanson, a former oil executive and teacher at the Colorado School of Mines, settled on the waste industry after a small oil-exploration company he headed was sold. South Dakota Disposal Systems, the venture that owns Lonetree, was formed after Mr. Swanson stumbled onto the site while scouting for sites along the Burlington Northern rail line suited for a new landfill.
The geology of the region had already attracted other disposal ventures, including a proposal by Chem Nuclear Systems Inc., a subsidiary of Chemical Waste Management Inc., to bury radioactive waste and a project to process and then bury sewage ash.
Edgemont, which has been fighting for survival since the decline of the local uranium mining and processing in the 1970's and reductions in local employment at the Burlington Northern railyard, welcomed all of the proposals. The sewage ash project received state approvals and began operations but soon went bankrupt, leaving the state to clean up.
Lonetree looked like more of a winner and, in 1989, earned a one-year operating permit from the South Dakota Bureau of Mining and Environment. A five-year extension was granted the following year, but the project had already been stopped by environmental groups.
In addition to litigation challenging both permits, Lonetree's opponents introduced an initiative requiring the State Legislature to vote on any landfill of more than 200,000 cubic yards -- a measure designed to focus on sites big enough to rely on out-of-state garbage. The initiative passed despite opposition from 90 percent of Edgemont's voters, 70 percent of the county's and the majority of voters in the western part of the state.
 
Approval Withdrawn
 Lonetree subsequently won a narrow approval in the Legislature and a an endorsement from Gov. George Mickelson, who said he opposed relying on out-of-state garbage for South Dakota's economic development but that the site was well designed.
Ms. Kiepke of the Rapid City-based Action for the Environment group quickly organized a referendum that in November overturned the Legislature's vote in a landslide.
Ms. Kiepke said that in retrospect it would have been "nice" to link the statewide votes to a proposal to provide some other form of economic development to the Edgemont area. She said the state had raised taxes to support an economic fund available to the town.
The suggestion draws a scornful reaction from Keith Andersen, an engineer here who had been hired as the site manager and hoped to be overseeing a staff of 50 local employees.
"They are going to create jobs where the votes are," Mr. Andersen said of the development fund. "That's political reality."
The Lonetree saga is far from over. There are several lawsuits pending, including a challenge in Federal court by South Dakota Disposal Systems to the constitutionality of the entire process by which South Dakota voters blocked the development and a claim in state court by Mr. Swanson and fellow investors for $100 million in damages from the state government. And Mr. Swanson has been talking to several Indian tribes about selling the site to them for $1. He hopes that Lonetree might be out of the reach of its opponents if it can be incorporated into tribal lands.
 
Doubts about Restarting Project
 Mr. Andersen said that he doubts that any developer would try to pick up where Mr. Swanson has left off, regardless of the environmental benefits of burying waste in sites like Edgemont rather than areas with much higher rainfall and water supplies that are more easily polluted by leakage. Others associated with the project are equally pessimistic.
Marvin Truhe, a Rapid City lawyer who has represented Lonetree in several suits, said that he had been shocked by the passions aroused by the proposal. "I've been representing mining companies seeking to expand in the Black Hills for 20 years and I thought that was a red-hot issue," he said. "But it's about a tenth of what you get when you start talking about importing garbage."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Keith Andersen, an engineer hired to manage the Lonetree landfill outside of Edgemont, S.D., expected to be overseeing a staff of 50 local employees until environmentalists organized statewide opposition to the project. (Barnaby J. Feder/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
2 Retired Officers to Return to I.B.M.

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
I.B.M. said yesterday that it had recalled two senior executives from retirement to help run the giant computer maker less than a week after it announced a huge charge against earnings and another big round of job cutbacks.
The fact that one of the returning executives was once the chief rival of John F. Akers, the chairman, for the company's top job is a sign that the move is intended to give the board an independent "second opinion" on management issues, according to industry analysts and former executives of the International Business Machines Corporation. 
 The two executives, Paul Rizzo and Kaspar Cassani, who will begin their new assignments in January, are being called back in the wake of the company's announcement last week that it would take a $6 billion charge in the 1992 fourth quarter and shed another 25,000 workers next year.
 
Areas of Expertise
 Mr. Rizzo, 64, who was passed over when Mr. Akers was selected to become chief executive in 1985, is known as a finance and planning expert. The Swiss-born Mr. Cassani, also 64, rose within the company's international ranks to become the head of the I.B.M. World Trade division before his retirement.
"These two are being called back to help out in a crisis," said John B. Jones Jr., an analyst for Salomon Brothers in San Francisco. "The board is clearly involved in this move."
Word of the return of Mr. Rizzo and Mr. Cassani circulated within the company Friday after Mr. Akers sent a brief memo to 100 executives. Their return was first reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal.
In his memo, Mr. Akers said he had asked the two men to come back to serve as "counselors and advisers."
"Our work will benefit from their insight and seasoned judgment," he added.
A company spokesman, Rob Wilson, said yesterday that the two men would work "essentially as advisers to John Akers," adding that they would focus on increasing the independence of the I.B.M. business units.
A year ago, I.B.M. announced a sweeping reorganization to split itself into smaller entities, intended to give businesses like mainframes, work stations, personal computers, software and services more freedom to respond quickly to changes in the marketplace.
Yet the hoped-for transformation has gone more slowly than anticipated at a time when the pace of change in the computer industry has accelerated, especially the shift from I.B.M.'s traditional strength, mainframe computers, to small but increasingly powerful personal computers and work stations.
"Rizzo and Cassani are not being brought in to change the strategy but to help speed up the execution of the strategy," said Sam Albert, a former I.B.M. executive who is a consultant in Scarsdale, N.Y.
Mr. Akers will not be formally sharing duties or responsibilities with the other two men in an "office of the chief executive," a mechanism some other companies have used to force chief executives to share power. And the company insists that the decision to invite Mr. Rizzo and Mr. Cassani back was made by Mr. Akers.
 
Speculations on Motives
 Still, the move is unusual, and such actions are rarely taken single-handedly by chief executives who decide they want more help. Besides, analysts note, I.B.M.'s share price has plunged from $100 in the summer to $48.875 yesterday, down $2.50 for the day. Bringing back the two executives does show a sense of urgency on the part of the board and management, seeking to ease the concerns of the company's many disgruntled investors.
Whether the return of Mr. Rizzo and Mr. Cassani will help I.B.M. is uncertain, analysts say. Though respected as seasoned managers, they come from the same mainframe-dominated era as Mr. Akers.
"They may be independent from Akers, but Rizzo and Cassani are I.B.M. hard-liners, reared in the I.B.M. way," said Bob Djurdjevic, president of Annex Research in Phoenix. "It's sort of like bringing back Brezhnev's cronies to reform the Russian economy."
Mr. Cassani, a director of the Institute for International Management Development in Lausanne, Switzerland, could not be reached for comment yesterday. Mr. Rizzo, who recently stepped down as dean of the business school at the University of North Carolina, did not return a call yesterday to his home.

HEADLINE: Tax Politics Last of four articles.

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
When Margaret Thatcher became Prime Minister in 1979, the top personal income tax rate was 83 percent, a level that she said sapped incentives to work harder and create more wealth. In a policy shift foreshadowing similar though less drastic moves across the Atlantic, Britain drove down the top rate over several years to 40 percent, where it remains today.
But reductions for people in the middle-income brackets were considerably less, and for all taxpayers, loopholes were tightened or eliminated. And as income tax rates fell, the Government was raising other taxes, most notably the value-added tax, a form of sales tax on goods at the retail, wholesale and producer levels. That levy, which stood at 8 percent in 1979, is now 17.5 percent. 
 The result: a continued increase in overall taxation even during the heyday of a tax-cutter as fervent as Mrs. Thatcher.
 
Upward Pattern Holds True
 As the world's other major industrial democracies have struggled to find tax policies that balance deficit reduction, economic stimulus, pork-barrel politics and social welfare concerns, much the same pattern has held true.
"The public image of what's happened in many countries is that there have been reasonably significant and in some cases dramatic reductions in tax rates," said Jonathan I. Leape, a lecturer in economics at the London School of Economics. But, Mr. Leape said, the amount of taxes people pay has not changed much. In some cases, it has actually increased.
In most countries, public resistance to higher or new taxes has been relatively muted, particularly in comparison with the United States, where the political sensitivity to raising taxes in any form has remained extremely high.
Taxpayers in the United States continue to pay less on a relative basis than their counterparts in almost any other industrialized country. And while nations from Spain to Japan have significantly expanded their use of consumption taxes such as a value-added tax or levies on specific products like gasoline, the United States has remained largely dependent on levies on income and profits.
Economists say it is difficult to isolate the effect of tax-policy changes on economic growth and a nation's fiscal condition, since other factors, including reductions in government spending, play key roles as well. But they said the rising tax burdens in many nations had helped bring deficits down over the last decade.
 
A Choice for Clinton
 In the United States, by contrast, the Federal budget deficit has continued rising over the last decade. And although consumption taxes such as a value-added tax have problems -- they risk putting a higher proportional burden on less affluent taxpayers -- economists said the incoming Clinton Administration might have no choice but to consider them if it was serious about eventually reducing the deficit.
"It would seem that in the U.S. there is not really a lot of room to increase personal or corporate taxes," said Gary Hufbauer, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "There is hardly any way Clinton can achieve his targets for deficit reduction unless he goes with a V.A.T. or a broad-based energy tax."
Among the 24 industrialized nations that are members of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, an international research center based in Paris, total tax revenue as a percentage of gross domestic product increased from an average of 35.2 percent in 1980 to 38.8 percent in 1990, despite widespread cuts in top personal income tax rates and some reductions in corporate rates.
Even excluding social security taxes, which are rising rapidly in many nations to finance retirement and unemployment programs, tax revenues as a percentage of gross domestic product increased from 26.9 percent in 1980 to 29.5 percent a decade later, the O.E.C.D. said.
In the United States, tax revenues as a percentage of gross domestic product increased only to 29.9 percent in 1990 from 29.5 percent in 1980. Excluding social security, the figure actually fell to 21.1 percent from 21.8 percent over that period.
 
True Picture Masked
 But the general trends mask to some degree the widely varying policies enacted in individual nations, each coping with its own political and economic circumstances. And the gross figures mask essential differences between the United States and most other industrialized countries, where, for instance, national health programs are paid for with tax money and gasoline taxes help pay for mass transit. Gas taxes in the United States as high as those in Europe -- which can be as high as 200 percent -- would be impracticable and even unwise, economists argue, because of the vast distances that must be traveled in areas with sparse populations.
Germany had been cutting rates over the last decade, dropping the maximum rate on personal income to 50 percent from 53 percent in 1990. But the staggering costs of reunification with East Germany forced an increase last year in taxes on cigarettes and gasoline, among other goods and services, and a one-year "solidarity" tax -- a 7.5 percent surcharge on gross personal income -- that expired in July.
In Spain, taxes have been rising as the Government scrambles under a tax-and-spend policy to modernize the country and bring its economy into line with the richer European Community nations.
Still, most nations have been generally guided by the notion that rates should be reduced, but that taxes should be levied more broadly and more fairly.
"The predominant trend has been to cut the tax rate and to make up the revenue by widening the tax base," said Jeffrey Owens, the head of the fiscal affairs department at the O.E.C.D. in Paris.
 
France's About-Face
 In France, the Socialist Party Government of President Francois Mitterrand has since 1983 pursued policies designed to favor investment, capital accumulation and personal income -- counterbalanced by high taxes on consumption. The approach was a radical about-face for a Government that had nationalized state industries.
"The French looked at what Reaganism was supposed to do, and really did it," said Jack Anderson, a tax specialist and partner at HSD-Ernst & Young in Paris. "Mitterrand looked to traditional market-oriented ideas to get him out of a recession that his socialist ideas had gotten him into."
Since 1983, France has reduced top corporate income tax rates to 34 percent from 52 percent. Capital gains taxes are low by the standards of the United States. Personal income taxes are progressive, with about half the population paying none at all, and the other half paying a marginal rate that rises to 57 percent for a single person with earnings of more than $75,000.
The Socialist Government has also imposed a special tax surcharge on the assets of wealthy individuals. A tax of five-tenths of a percent is applied to houses, boats, savings and other assets valued above about $828,000, with the rate increasing to 1.5 percent on assets exceeding $8 million. The proceeds of the tax are earmarked for redistribution as a "minimum revenue" of about $400 a month for individuals without other means of support.
Social security taxes remain high in France. And as in many nations, value-added taxes have been rising and remain high.
Value-added taxes are levied every time goods change hands, through the entire production and distribution chain. But the full levy is only borne by the ultimate consumer, because buyers at each stage of the chain can deduct the tax on all but the value they add to the product. (Food and other essentials are often exempt.)
But consumption taxes are by no means without their problems. Japan, like the United States, has traditionally relied primarily on personal income and corporate profit taxes. When Japan introduced a 3 percent value-added tax in 1989, it was accompanied by a reduction in the top personal income tax rate from 60 percent to 50 percent, and by a reduction in the number of tax brackets from 12 to 5.
But the net effect has been an increased burden on most taxpayers.
With Japan's economy slumping, the ensuing reduction in consumer spending has dampened hopes of a consumer-led recovery. And it has led to complaints that the value-added tax has made the Japanese system more regressive -- that is, more of the tax burden is falling on the less affluent.


GRAPHIC: Taxpayers everywhere complain thay they pay too much. Especially in the United states, public debate on economic and fiscal matters has come to be colored by a pervasive assumption that taxes take too much of the national income, sapping growth and putting the country at a competitive disadvantage.
Graphs: "America the Tax Haven"
 Comparative statistics tell a different story.
 By the measure of total tax receipts as a percentage of gross domestic product, the United States now taxes its economy much less than most other developed nations. One reason why: Many developed nations pay for universal health care with tax money.
 In the chart, figures for the United States are superimposed on those of other countries for comparision.
