HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
Clinton's New Foreign-Policy Thinkers: Like-Minded Ex-Carter Teammates

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton said today that the times demanded "bold new thinking" in foreign policy. But in choosing his foreign policy team, he took the most conventional of approaches -- picking experienced, loyal and generally like-minded friends and advisers whom he can count on not to get him in trouble abroad while he focuses on problems at home.
What is unsual about that experienced team of advisers is that for most of them, the last time they had their hands on foreign policy was 12 years ago, when many of them served together in the Carter Administration. 
 As a result, many have not written or spoken out publicly very much on the major new foreign-policy issues confronting the United States since the end of the cold war -- from the crisis in Bosnia to the future of relations with Japan.
Therefore it is difficult to predict exactly what sort of foreign policy they will produce with Mr. Clinton, who himself is untested in that field. A Clinton adviser said, "Fasten your seatbelts, ladies and gentlemen."
 
Cold-War-Era Labels
 Secretary-of-State-designate Warren M. Christopher; Anthony Lake, his choice as national security adviser; Samuel R. Berger, the designated deputy to Mr. Lake, and Madeleine Albright, Mr. Clinton's pick as United Nations delegate, all come out of the more liberal wing of the Carter Administration that was in opposition to hard-liners in the Democratic Party who advocated a more confrontational policy toward the Soviet Union.
Immediately after Mr. Clinton announced his choices today, conservative Democrats were complaining in private that they had been frozen out of the top jobs and that Mr. Clinton had turned to cold-war doves for post-cold-war policy.
But Mr. Clinton's circle contends that those old labels have lost their meaning.
For instance, Clinton aides said Mr. Lake, an ardent opponent of the Vietnam War, was the strongest advocate that Mr. Clinton call for the use of force, if necessary, in Bosnia.
 
Veteran Defense Experts
 In many ways Mr. Clinton seemed to choose this group less for their specific views or past ideology than for their instincts and ability to work as a team.
Mr. Clinton could have chosen the leading thinkers on the new world order within his party on Capitol Hill -- like Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, who has spent a great deal of time working on the Russian economic crisis, or Senator Sam Nunn, who has specialized in the subject of arms proliferation from the former Soviet Union.
He could have turned to Representative Stephen J. Solarz, an outspoken foreign-policy specialist, or innovative but conservative academics like Will Marshall of the Progressive Policy Institute, from which Mr. Clinton draws much of his domestic agenda, and Michael Mandelbaum of the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies.
Those Democrats have spent the last few years compiling an extensive written and spoken record on the post-cold-war world.
 
No 'Team of Retreads'
 Instead, Mr. Clinton reached back into the Carter Administration and to two veteran defense experts, Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, and R. James Woolsey Jr., to be Defense Secretary and Director of Central Intelligence , respectively.
Several factors seem to have motivated that set of choices. First, as Mr. Clinton has repeatedly stated, he wanted a team that would be as collegial as the Bush Administration's National Security team.
During the campaign Mr. Lake, Mr. Berger, Ms. Albright and Mr. Christopher worked together closely, and managed to develop a Clinton foreign policy that often seemed to have Mr. Bush on the defensive. Aides said that Mr. Clinton's view was that people who proved they could work effectively in the heat of a campaign could be trusted to do the same in government, no matter what Administration they came from.
The Carter Administration "was the only Democratic Administration we had in 25 years," Mr. Clinton said, defending his choices. It was the only place a Democrat could get hands-on experience, and therefore it was unfair to suggest he had picked "a team of retreads," he said.
 
'The Vision Thing'
 Mr. Clinton also was clearly looking for advisers of sober instincts, and proven judgment -- able to handle foreign policy for him on a day-to-day basis, without his having to worry about them pursuing their own agendas or leading him into foreign adventures. In introducing Mr. Christopher, Mr. Clinton kept emphasizing how much he prized his "judgment."
In economic policy, Mr. Clinton chose an elder Congressional statesman -- Senator Lloyd Bentsen -- as Treasury Secretary to carry out a program that Mr. Clinton has already largely designed. In defense policy, Mr. Clinton did the same, seeking out one of the top experts in military spending to reduce the Pentagon budget and reshape the armed forces.
But in foreign policy, Mr. Clinton has chosen an elder foreign affairs statesman -- Mr. Christopher -- to steer a cautious course through the foreign policy problems already facing him and carry out a foreign-policy program that Mr. Clinton knows he must design but has not yet fully thought through.
Clinton aides said the President-elect was not worried about Mr. Christopher's lacking what Mr. Bush sardonically called "the vision thing." Mr. Clinton, they said, believes he knows a lot more about foreign policy than was apparent in the campaign and that he intends to be as much of an intellectual trend-setter, and public voice, in that area as in domestic policy.He will draw on Mr. Lake and Mr. Berger to help him conceptualize his views at the White House, and will lean on Mr. Christopher for his strengths as an implementor, consensus builder, and seasoned negotiator.
 
Comfort With Position Papers
 Whether that balancing act will work is already a matter of great dispute.
"I think this is a time that does call out for some strategic vision and a President who wants to concentrate on domestic policy would do well to appoint someone strong as Secretary of State," said Peter Rodman, former counselor to the national security adviser under Mr. Bush. "Mr. Christopher has many qualities, but his skills as a strategic thinker are unproven. Rightly or wrongly, some people identify him with the least impressive aspects of the Carter Administration."
"In his favor," Mr. Rodman said, "he clearly is someone of great integrity and meticulousness, as well as accomplished negotiator. The President will not have to worry about a Secretary of State with his own agenda and ambitions, or who will distance himself from the President in difficult moments. In this, Mr. Clinton will have an advantage over his predecessor."
Finally, Mr. Clinton was quite comfortable with the foreign-policy position papers that Mr. Berger, Mr. Lake, Ms. Albright and Mr. Christopher developed for him during the campaign.
They called for a much more aggressive stand in support of Bosnia against Serbia, more aid for President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia than the Bush Administration was willing to give, the use of trade sanctions to force China to moderate its human-rights abuses, a quicker United Nations rescue mission for Somalia, a tougher bargaining position in trade negotiations with Japan, and a more sympathetic posture toward Israel than was being evinced by the Bush Administration.
But Clinton aides acknowledge that those policy positions were intended in large part to distinguish Mr. Clinton from Mr. Bush during the campaign, and no one really knows to what extent they will actually shape Mr. Clinton's foreign policy when he takes office.
For instance, since the election Mr. Clinton has noticeably softened his oratory about using trade sanctions against China, and his first statement about the Arab-Israeli conflict -- in response to the Israeli expulsion of some 415 Palestinians -- was as evenhanded as anything ever uttered by the Bush Administration.

HEADLINE: U.S. WILL RELEASE WEAPONS TO CHINA

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
The Bush Administration announced today that it would send China military equipment already paid for but put in storage for more than three years to protest against the Tiananmen Square massacre.
Richard A. Boucher, the State Department spokesman, said in a statement that the shipment would consist of four anti-submarine torpedoes, two artillery-locating radars, equipment for a munitions-production line and electronic gear to upgrade F-8 aircraft. 
 The sales "were suspended to demonstrate our deep concern about the tragic events in China," Mr. Boucher said, referring to the brutal crackdown on democracy campaigners in June 1989, which left hundreds dead.
He said no further arms sales were planned, and that the United States would not provide training, maintenance or repairs for the equipment.
Senior Administration officials have recently said China has hinted that it may stop cooperating with the United States at the United Nations in response to President Bush's decision during the campaign to sell advanced fighter jets to Taiwan.
China is one of five countries that has veto power in Security Council decisions, and its diplomats have expressed dismay at the growing tendency at the United Nations to use military-intervention powers.
Still, the Administration's decision appeared likely to renew charges in Congress that the United States is coddling an oppressive Government.
The move comes less than a month after reports that American intelligence analysts had detected the shipment of Chinese M-11 medium-range missiles to Pakistan. The shipment appeared to violate an international accord on ballistic-missile proliferation that Chinese leaders, in informal talks with Americans, said they would obey.
 
Responses From Critics
 Gary Milhollin, director of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control, a Washington research group, criticized today's step as undermining American arms-control policy. "This rewards them for proliferating missiles to Pakistan," he said, "and tells them we really don't care very much what they sell to the third world."
Michael Jendrzejczyk, Washington director of the human rights group Asia Watch, said continuing reports of rights violations in China made it wrong to ship military equipment now. "This unfortunate step would reward the Chinese for continuing repression that has in no way eased in the last three years," he said.
This month China agreed, as well, to buy more weapons from Russia. Delivering still more weapons from the United States "takes away any opportunity we might have to object to any more dangerous sales the Russians might make," Mr. Milhollin said.
Mr. Boucher said Mr. Bush would notify Congress of the arms-delivery decision, as required by law. A Senate aide predicted that many members of Congress would register objections.
The President has long been sympathetic to China and its leaders, more so than most American politicians. He has repeatedly vetoed legislation that would have downgraded China's preferred trading status with the United States unless it improved its human rights record and limited arms exports to the third world.
Mr. Bush headed the American liaison office in Beijing in the early 1970's, when relations with Washington had begun to improve under initiatives by President Richard M. Nixon.
The announcement of the weapons shipment was made as Secretary of Commerce Barbara H. Franklin flew home from a six-day visit to China and Hong Kong. The trip was intended to promote trade and to mollify Chinese officials after a visit to Taiwan last month by Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative.
Mrs. Hills's visit was the first to Taiwan by a Cabinet official since the United States recognized Beijing as the Government of China at the end of 1978. Secretary Franklin's trip was the first to Beijing by a Cabinet-level economic official since the 1989 massacre.

HEADLINE: Donors to Neediest Cases Feel Lucky

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Suzanne Crawford is a single parent raising a 5-year-old son, a self-described "Murphy Brown" mom who readily acknowledges that she would have trouble coping if she did not have a good job and supportive relatives and friends.
When she reads about other single mothers who are facing overwhelming burdens, she knows that their struggle could easily be her own. With that in mind, she sent a check for $250 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, asking that the money be used to buy food for a poor woman bringing up children on her own. 
 "I see so many single mothers out there with kids who are suffering," Miss Crawford, 44, who lives in Manhattan, said. "I feel bad for them."
Many people make contributions to the Neediest Cases because they feel fortunate. In letters to the fund, they write that they will not forget New Yorkers with little hope.
Betty Frankel of Oakdale, L.I., overcame breast cancer 16 years ago. Last year, doctors discovered that the cancer had returned and spread to her bones. After treatment, it went into remission. Although Mrs. Frankel has contributed to the fund for decades, this year she enclosed a note with her $25 check.
"I feel very grateful and very thankful," said Mrs. Frankel, 62, a home economics teacher. "And the rest of my family is in good health. I wanted to share the joy I've had in being able to live with other people."
 
Helpf for a Teen-Ager
 The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which began in 1911, assists seven charities. The New York Times pays for the expenses of the Neediest Cases campaign.
Jacquelyn van der Woude, 48, of Cornwall-on-Hudson, N.Y., wrote to the fund that she felt blessed to have two healthy children and a stable job as a legal assistant. She said she hoped her check for $100 could help a teen-ager in New York City.
"It makes you feel almost uncomfortable that you have a roof over your head and you have food and have clothes," she said.
Miss Crawford said that when her son, Timothy, sees a homeless person, she explains to him about poverty and the importance of charity.
"The best way to make him understand is to tell him that other boys and girls won't get toys around Christmas," she said. "That makes him sad and he sort of understands what it's like."

HEADLINE: Lottery Fails To Finance School Safety

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
A special anti-crime lottery that was supposed to raise $50 million to pay for new programs at New York City schools this year is selling miserably, so far raising only about a half-million dollars.
In the last six months, the city's instant lottery game, part of Mayor David N. Dinkins's ambitious program to fight crime, has sold only $2 million worth of tickets. 
 But the city has received less than $500,000 of that money, partly because of the cost of printing and administering the game and partly because the city has had to share its profits with the state, officials said. To raise $50 million, $146 million in tickets would need to be sold.
"It's falling on its face," said Philip R. Michael, the city budget director.
 
Response to String of Killings
 The lottery was part of an anti-crime program that gained steam in the wake of the so-called crime wave of the summer of 1990, when a string of children were killed by random gunfire and a tourist from Utah was slain on a subway platform. It was a single plank in the financing package for the $1.8 billion anti-crime plan proposed by the Mayor in October 1990 and passed by the Legislature in early 1991.
The plan relies on a property-tax increase, a special payroll tax and a special 25-cent surcharge on state lottery tickets to pay for the hiring of thousands of new police officers. The other parts of the financing are bringing in what was expected, Mr. Michael said.
In accounting for the lackluster showing, state lottery officials say the poor economy has hurt sales of all instant games and city dwellers have historically preferred the regular lottery. Beyond those problems, they say, the city has been unable to develop a new market for the anti-crime scratch-off game.
When it was first conceived, city and state officials thought lottery buyers would be persuaded to buy the tickets because they were for a good cause.
Mr. Michael said the city would continue to pay for the school programs that the lottery was intended to support out of general tax revenues.
 
Looking to Make It Work
 The lottery money was to have been spent on security guards, after-school programs, and programs that teach teachers and children peaceful ways to resolve disputes, among other things.
City officials say they will scrap the lottery unless they can find a way to make it work.
Mr. Dinkins had envisioned that the city lottery would bring in about $120 million annually that would pay for 18 new community schools, dropout-prevention programs, teen-age pregnancy counseling, remedial summer school and extracurricular activities like math and science clubs, among other programs.
Despite the lottery problems, the Dinkins administration has remained committed to financing the anti-crime programs, including $18 million this year for new security guards and $6 million for multicultural programs and guidance counselors.
"We have received to the penny what we were promised," said the Deputy Schools Chancellor, Stanley S. Litow.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
Excerpts From Clinton's News Conference Introducing His Latest Nominees

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President-elect Bill Clinton's news conference today in Little Rock, Ark., where he introduced his selections for several top positions. The text was provided by Reuters.
 
OPENING STATEMENTS 
 WARREN M. CHRISTOPHER (Secretary of State-designate) Today I want to thank Governor Clinton for making a dream come true. In my law school days I was inspired to public service by the examples of General George Marshall and Dean Acheson, but it was far beyond imagining that I would some day be asked to serve in the office that they held.
Marshall and Acheson were present at the creation of the cold war. Then we were being challenged by a formidable adversary and an alien ideology. America measured its success by how well it contained Soviet expansion and halted the spread of communism.
Today we face a new and vastly more complicated era. As Governor Clinton has said, we're the inheritors of a new world. That world is still a dangerous place. While the risk of nuclear threat has diminished, the new era has produced a new set of dangers -- ethnic and religious conflicts threaten to ignite widespread hostilities in Central and Eastern Europe.
Weapons of mass destruction may reach the hands of untested and unstable powers, and new threats spring from old rivalries in the Middle East, in Europe and in Asia. At the same time we face a world where borders matter less and less, a world that demands we join with other nations to face challenges that range from over-population to AIDS, to the very destruction of our planet's life support system.
In this new era, the Clinton-Gore Administration will be confronted again and again by whether and how to use U.S. power and U.S. resources. We knew that we need bold new thinking to guide us in this new era.
In contrast to the well understood goals of the cold war era, it will be difficult to measure our success as we deal with these new challenges.
No doubt the surest test will be the well-being of the American people and the unfailing concern that they have always had for others.
In confronting these new challenges, we must remain cognizant that a great power requires not only military might but a powerful economy at home, an economy prepared for global competition.
 
 
. . .
 If I may close on a personal note, I'm grateful to many, but most of all to my wife, Marie, for her willingness, one day after our 36th anniversary to leave our beloved California and join me in yet another adventure.
In 1982, or in 1981, when all 52 hostages came out of Iran alive, and reasonably well, I was so thankful that I resolved that I would not again impose by asking for divine assistance in my national endeavors.
Evidently God had other plans. So I humbly ask for the strength and vision to carry out the new task that Governor Clinton has so generously given me.
CLIFTON R. WHARTON JR. (Deputy Secretary of State-Designate) . . . I, too, would like to begin with a personal bit of reminiscence. Mr. Christopher mentioned the Marshall Plan. Some 45 years ago, when I graduated from Harvard, the commencement speaker was George Marshall, and he announced the Marshall Plan. That particular event was seminal for me because it led me not to go into the Foreign Service, like my father, who spent 40 years as a career Foreign Service officer and completed his tour as the first black career ambassador.
I decided to move into the field of technical assistance and foreign economic development, which at that time I believed would eventually become a central part of U.S. foreign policy. As the young people say, what goes around comes around. And here I am at a stage where the ability of the United States to forge a new foreign policy in a post-cold war era is going to involve a significant number of new dimensions, not the least of which are likely to be those areas in which I hope I would be able to bring some experience and expertise and competence.
 
 
. . .
 MADELEINE K. ALBRIGHT (Ambassador-designate to the United Nations) . . . It would be an honor for any American to represent the United States at the United Nations when there is a President who says he will support a policy that will make a difference.
I have to say it is a special personal honor for this American to be asked to serve. I was born in Czechoslovakia and came to this country with my mother, sister and brother in 1948 after the communist coup. My father, Joseph Korbel, a Czechoslovak diplomat, was asked to represent his country as chairman of a special United Nations commission. When he completed his work, he asked the United States Government for political asylum, and as a result of the generous spirit of the American people, our family had the privilege of growing up as free Americans.
You can therefore understand how proud I will be to sit at the United Nations behind the nameplate that says "United States of America."
 
. . .
 LES ASPIN (Defense Secretary-designate) . . . The President-elect has included two sets of big challenges with this nomination. The first set involves maintaining the superb quality of our forces and our high technology edge as we go about the inevitable downsizing of our forces. We know the men and women in uniform today comprise the finest military force in the world and we know that the American technological know-how that we saw in the Gulf war will mean fewer casualties all around if and when we must use force again.
As President-elect Clinton has repeatedly said, and he's heard him say it here this afternoon one more time, our high quality in people, high technology and technological equipment -- that force must be maintained.
The second set of challenges involves meeting the demands of the new post-cold war, post-Soviet world. In this new world the definition of national security has been changed and it has been broadened. It now includes not only the threat from regional powers but it also includes the new nuclear danger of proliferation and the possibility of the reversal of reforms in the former Soviet Union with untold consequences. It even includes economic. The President-elect has set the overall task of reviving our economic security at home. The Defense Department can contribute there, too. . . .
R. JAMES WOOLSEY JR. (C.I.A. Director-designate) . . . The problem posed by one enemy with a worldwide reach is gone with the end of the cold war but the problems posed by the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, terrorism, drugs, ethnic and national hatreds, ecological damage and tough economic competition all give American intelligence a full agenda.
 In a number of ways it is a more complex and difficult agenda even than that which existed before. We have to do some things differently. . . .
W. ANTHONY LAKE (National Security Adviser-designate) . . . Our daily headlines suggest that not since 1968 has a new administration faced more difficult foreign problems. But I am convinced that our of these nettles we can pluck progress and greater security.
I look forward to making sure as best I can that the President gets the wide array of alternatives, the concise information and the broad range of advice that he requires, and that his decisions are carried out with dispatch. And I hope to see a year from now and beyond a group of senior national security officials who are as collegial and amicable as they are today.
There's an immense amount of work to do, and I cannot wait.
SAMUEL R. BERGER (Deputy National Security Adviser-designate) Over the past year, I have had the sometimes exhausting privilege of traveling across America with Governor Clinton and Senator Gore as they campaigned for the Presidency. I have seen the faces of Americans change from cynicism to hope, from serious doubt to genuine excitement about the possibilities for the future.
That is where American foreign policy begins. With the interest, the aspirations, and the values of the American people.
 
. . .

 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS

Q. Congressman, could we get your views specifically on lifting the ban against homosexuals in the military, and from your years of dealing with the military establishment, how do you feel this could be best implemented?
MR. ASPIN All right. Let me, let me say about my views on the subject, which are essentially that it has come up when I've given talks and given speeches; it comes up in the question and answer period.
And what I have said is that I think two things. Number one, that the current policy of the U.S. military, that we have set up there, has got some serious flaws with it in terms of equity and in terms of fairness. Secondly, that I saw a correlation of forces that was going to force the U.S. government to have to deal with this and the U.S. military to deal with it.
If you see what's going on in other countries on this issue, if you see what's going on in the courts, if you see what's going on on the college campuses with problems of the R.O.T.C. program because of this, the publicity that's given to rather dramatic instances of people being forced out of the service -- I thought that this was something that would have to be dealt with by the administration that was elected in 1992.
I think that even if Bill Clinton hadn't said anything about it during the campaign, this administration would be dealing with it.
I think even if George Bush had been re-elected in 1992, he would be dealing with it.
What is different now is that we have elected a President who has talked about changing the policy, and what that will do is it will force the Pentagon and the system, meaning Congress, the Administration, all of us, to deal with the subject head on.
There'll be no chance to sort of try and patch up the old program or sideslip the issue. We'll have to deal with it head on, and that's a good thing. I think that's a, definitely a good thing.
Q. Mr. Christopher, can we ask you -- Mr. Lake has referred to all of the challenges and problems that you face, perhaps the greatest number of problems of any incoming administration since 1968. What do you see as your most immediate concern? Is it Bosnia? Is it Russia? Is it Somalia? And how would you change policy?
MR. CHRISTOPHER No, there's a long established tradition in Washington at least in the Foreign Relations Committee that one doesn't answer questions like that until after he is confirmed.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Martha, a Top Clothier, in Chapter 11

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Martha, the Park Avenue institution that put such fashion designers as Valentino, Galanos, Zandra Rhodes and Christian Francis Roth on the map, succumbed yesterday to the weak economy and filed for bankruptcy-law protection.
The company, which also operates two Martha stores in Florida and a Martha International boutique next to the flagship store in Manhattan, had been struggling to pay its bills as the recession eroded the spending power of its best customers and wrought a fundamental change in attitudes toward clothing. 
 "We've been fighting for a long time, but we just had to file because we needed time to get everything in order," said Sheldon Silverberg of Silverberg Stonehill & Goldsmith, the law firm that represents Martha Inc.
 
Unsecured Creditors
 While sales in the Florida stores have resisted the weak economy, Mr. Silverberg said, plummeting sales in the New York store dragged down overall profitability. At its zenith in the late 1980's, Martha Phillips Management Inc., the parent, had annual revenues of slightly more than $20 million.
Chanel and Galanos have the two largest unsecured claims against the company, $303,540 and $300,651 respectively. Bill Blass, Saint Laurent, Bob Mackie and The New York Times also are among the 20 largest unsecured creditors.
The stores will remain open while the company puts together a reorganization plan that will include new financing. "We've been in the business now for 58 years and plan to remain viable and a trend-setter for many more years to come," Lynn Manulis, daughter of Martha Phillips, Martha's founder, said in a statement.
 
Miss Martha and Miss Lynn
 Mrs. Phillips, known by most as Miss Martha, and Mrs. Manulis, known as Miss Lynn, reign as the doyennes of haute couture in America. They always have the best front-row seats at fashion shows.
Although Mrs. Phillips is 94 years old, she regularly checks on the business. She established an exemplary level of customer service: Mother and daughter have been known to get on their knees to pin a customer's hem.
Mrs. Phillips also has a reputation as a tough businesswoman, taking some of the world's wealthiest men to task for failing to pay their wives' bills on time.
When General Motors knocked down the building at Fifth Avenue and 58th Street that housed the original Martha to put up its skyscraper, it begged Mrs. Phillips to take a shop in the sunken plaza it created under Fifth Avenue. She responded, "Martha's customers never shop in cellars," and she moved her business to Park Avenue, where it thrived.
Martha's financial difficulties were no secret on Seventh Avenue, but designers, retailers and the financiers that back design firms expressed regret that the company filed under Chapter 11. The filing was made at Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan.
"She really built the best little specialty store in the world, and I'm very, very sad this had to happen in her lifetime," Ellin Saltzman, fashion director of Bergdorf Goodman, said of Mrs. Phillips.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lynn Manulis of Martha, a New York-based clothing chain founded by her mother, Martha Phillips. The chain is facing difficult times as the recession has forced it to file for bankruptcy protection. Standing with her is the designer Christian Francis Roth. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long Bond Continues Rally; Note Auction Is Successful

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The bond market continued its holiday rally yesterday, with the price of the 30-year bond jumping more than half a point and the yield dropping to 7.34 percent, its lowest since Oct. 5.
In the last two days, the price of the long bond has risen a point, and the yield has fallen almost a tenth of a point. The rest of the market followed, with Treasury notes up a quarter-point to a half-point. 
 At the same time, the Treasury auction of the two-year note went better than some traders had expected, also giving the market a lift.
While light trading and other technical factors contributed to the rally, some traders wonder whether a new run toward lower long-term interest rates might also be in the works.
"The fact that this is happening in the current environment is not unreasonable," said Robert D. Sbarra, a managing director at Carroll McEntee & McGinley. He was referring to the fact that inflation remains low and that the economy, while growing, is not expanding rapidly. And with each day, more investors seem to have confidence that President-elect Bill Clinton will concentrate more on reducing the deficit than on stimulating the economy.
But there are others who think that the road to lower interest rates is still bumpy.
"We'll see how long-lasting it is," said Stephen Maher, the head of fixed-income trading at Nikko Securities. "We still have a Democratic Congress, a Democratic President, a big Federal deficit, a Federal funds rate already down to 3 percent and an economy beginning to recover. It just does not spell lower interest rates to me."
Mr. Maher also has doubts about the growing confidence in Mr. Clinton's conversion to deficit reduction, hinting that some investors seem to think that the President-elect "has promised not to be a Democrat anymore."
In late trading, the 30-year bond was offered at 10314/32 , to yield 7.34 percent, compared with 7.39 percent on Monday. The yield has come down from 7.59 percent since Nov. 30.
The price of the 10-year note jumped 15/32 as the yield dropped to 6.63 percent, from 6.69 percent the day before. And in the pre-auction market for the five-year Treasury note to be auctioned today, the yield dropped sharply, falling to 5.99 percent, from 6.06 percent on Monday.
 
Successful Note Auction
 Among the factors moving the market in the afternoon was the surprising success of the Treasury's two-year note auction. The $15.25 billion of notes, with a coupon of 4.625 percent, were sold at a single yield of 4.71 percent, the highest bid at which securities were awarded. But by late afternoon, the yield had dropped to 4.62 percent, reflecting a lot of buying after the auction.
It appeared that the single-price auction the Treasury is testing in the two- and five-year note auctions was still confounding the primary dealers who do most of the bidding. Yesterday it appeared that some bidders thought there would be mild demand and that they could get all the two-year notes they needed by bidding 4.71 percent, which was the yield in the pre-auction market just before the bidding closed at 1 P.M.
But a lot of other bidders were a little more aggressive, meaning that those who bid 4.71 percent only got 27 percent of the total of the securities they bid for, apparently leaving some dealers with much fewer securities than they needed to cover sales they had already made to customers.
 
Buying by Japanese
 Another factor in the rally yesterday was foreign buying. Mr. Maher and other traders said they saw a lot of demand from the Japanese, who had shunned the American bond market for some time. "We have seen more activity from our Japanese customers than we have seen in a long time," he said. One attraction, he said, was the expectation that the dollar would rise against the yen, adding to any profits from a drop in interest rates.
Also bolstering the market in the afternoon was a report by Johnson Redbook on sales by department and chain stores. In the first three weeks of December, sales fell at a 4.3 percent rate, compared with November. Although part of the decline was attributable to the recent storm in the Northeast, traders said the decline reassured investors that economic growth was not racing ahead and posing no inflationary threat.

HEADLINE: Taking the 8:15 to the Suburbs;
Commuting Transformed by Growth Outside New York City

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
More and more people in the metropolitan region are commuting from homes in the suburbs to jobs in other suburbs, a new Federal study shows, continuing a trend that experts say has been reshaping the region's economy for 30 years.
The study of commuting patterns, released yesterday by the Census Bureau, also found that while New York City remains the region's job center, reverse commuting has risen as more businesses have moved all or part of their operations to the suburbs, where many employers have fared better in the recession than their counterparts in the city.
 
Impact on Transportation Policy
 "What this all tells us is that the region has changed permanently," said Regina Armstrong, an economist and senior fellow with the Regional Plan Association, which analyzes social and economic patterns in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. 
 She said the findings will buttress calls across the region for more public transportation between suburban job centers that are not served well by commuter trains or buses.
Economists and urban planners said the findings came as little surprise, and underscored a continuing trend, with jobs being dispersed more broadly throughout the region.
But they said changing patterns of commuting have other social and economic explanations. For example, surging home prices of the 1970's and 1980's forced many workers to move far from their suburban offices or plants.
Equally important, the experts say, has been the substantial rise in the number of women in the region's work force and the increase in two-income families over the last two decades. Because many couples have jobs in communities 50 miles apart or more, many have elected to live at mid-points that require both breadwinners to endure long commutes each working day.
 
New York Still a Jobs Center
 Among the Government's findings were that New York City, while losing some of its luster as the region's epicenter of jobs and economic activity, has nonetheless remained the place where the most people in the region work, and where the most people commute to work.
It found that 3.2 million adults in New York City had jobs in 1990, and that 92 percent of them held jobs there, while in 1980, 94 percent remained in the city for work.
The study also found that thousands more New York City residents were commuting out of the city than in 1980 and that these reverse commuters were traveling to suburbs throughout the region. It found that the number traveling to Bergen County doubled, to 31,572, the number traveling to Nassau County rose by more than 80 percent, to 78,760, and the number of city residents traveling to Westchester County rose more than 85 percent, to 51,511.
Almost all the suburbs around New York City gained jobs and added new commuters. For instance, the study found that Westchester had 282,571 residents in 1990 who were over 16 years old and working, 41,000 more than in 1980, but that they increasingly commuted to jobs scattered across the region.
Indeed, the Census Bureau said 19,000 more Westchester residents commuted into New York City in 1990 than in 1980, but that thousands of others commuted to other counties. The number of Westchester residents commuting to Nassau County doubled, to 2,150, and the number working in Bergen County nearly tripled, to 5,253.
 
Changing Role of Suburbs
 Urban planners said the growing economic vibrancy of many suburban communities has all but ended their role as strictly bedroom communities providing quiet residential retreats for workers in Manhattan.
"The growth of reverse commuting is affecting low- and high-income workers alike," said Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Center for Urban Policy Research at New York University.
"Just take a look at the George Washington Bridge in the morning," he added. "There are a stream of vans taking workers from the city to manufacturing plants in northern New Jersey."
Analysts have maintained for more than a decade that the emergence of the suburbs as robust centers of office and manufacturing jobs, while benefiting many workers, has come at a cost. Like Ms. Armstrong, Mr. Moss said that the new data underscore the need for improvements in public transportation in the suburbs.
"Living in the New York region's suburbs has increasingly meant living in your car," he said. "Their roads were just not meant to handle the massive increase in traffic they have experienced."
The Government's study provided statistical snapshots of large increases in commuting -- most of it by car -- between most suburbs.
 
Enduring Long Commutes
 In Essex County, N.J., it found that the number of working adults rose 3 percent during the 1980's, to 356,562. The number commuting from Essex to New York City rose about 50 percent, to 30,385.
But the data revealed other large increases in the number of Essex residents commuting in other directions. The Government said 23,221 Essex workers commuted to Morris County in 1990, up from 13,576 in 1980. It said 14,453 traveled from Essex to Bergen County in 1990, up from 9,997 in 1980.
Similar increases in commutation between suburbs were apparent across the region, although the Census Bureau data for 1990 on Connecticut could not be directly compared with findings for 1980 because its methods of analysis had changed.
In Suffolk County, long considered by most Manhattan workers as a lengthy commute, the study showed commutation surged in the 1980's.
Suffolk had a sharp increase in the number of its residents holding jobs during the decade, from 526,407 in 1980 to 652,989 in 1990, the Government data showed. By far the largest number of the Suffolk workers, 497,746, stayed in their own county to report to their jobs.
But there was also a sharp increase in commutation from Suffolk to jobs elsewhere in region. The Government said 78,291 Suffolk residents traveled to jobs in New York City in 1990, up from 67,559 in 1980.
Some Suffolk workers traveled even farther. The report found that 1,389 reported to work in Westchester in 1990, up from 973 in 1980, and 1,014 traveled to Bergen County, up from 522 in 1980.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Wireless Phones: Way of the Future

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
WHEN the Pacific Telesis Group, one of the largest phone companies in the world, announced earlier this month that it planned to split into a $9 billion traditional phone company and a $1 billion cellular business, the chairman voted with his feet: he's going to the smaller, but faster-growing cellular company.
That seems to say volumes about the future of telephones without wires. Analysts say that while plain old telephone service will remain the biggest revenue source for most phone companies in the near future, it will eventually be displaced. 
 If the Pacific Telesis split goes according to schedule a year from now, Sam Ginn, chairman and chief executive officer, will take over as head of the cellular business, tentatively known as Pactel Wireless. Philip Quigley, who will remain president and chief executive of Pacific Bell, will succeed Mr. Ginn. The split involves assets of $22 billion, or close to the gross domestic product of Chile.
Mr. Ginn said in a recent interview that he was simply going where the Pacific Telesis board had instructed him to go. But it presumably did not take an act of mental telepathy by directors to discern where Mr. Ginn wanted to go. In 1984, he headed and helped develop the company's wireless business.
Nonetheless, "on a personal level, I would have liked things to stay the way they were," Mr. Ginn said. "I would have opposed the breakup because I've got a large important company right now," he added. "But the issue is larger than Sam Ginn."
Pacific Telesis is tired of being thought of as another boring utility, Mr. Ginn and other Pacific Telesis executives have argued. Splitting up creates the "pure play" in cellular that investors crave and transforms a company now valued by investors at $18 billion into two companies worth, according to analysts, perhaps $21 billion.
Moreover, like other regional Bell companies, Pacific Telesis operates under the strictures of the 1984 accord that broke up the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. And, unlike other "Baby Bells," Pacific Telesis faces especially strict regulation in California. A split would lift the burden of the former and perhaps lighten the latter.
The new wireless company would be free to make equipment or, more likely, form a joint venture with an equipment maker. Earlier this year, when Pacific Telesis disclosed it had invested in Qualcomm Inc., developer of an innovative way to expand cellular capacity, Pacific Telesis was criticized for perhaps violating the A.T.& T. breakup accord.
Cellular companies, in general, are lightly regulated by states. But the California Public Utilities Commission has hinted strongly that it wants even stricter oversight, already the strictest in the nation, over Pacific Telesis. The split could lighten the regulators' thumb on the wireless unit if it were separate from traditional telephones, over which the California regulators have clear jurisdiction.
The stock market has heard all of these arguments and its reaction so far has been mildly positive. "It's a mystery to me why the market reaction hasn't been more positive," said Joel D. Gross, who follows Pacific Telesis for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and favors the split.
The deal was announced on Friday, Dec. 11. The following Monday, Pacific Telesis's stock closed at $44.876 a share, a 52-week high and up 50 cents a share on the day. Despite unusually high trading volume of 2.3 million shares that day, investors added only a paltry $202 million to the company's previous market value of $18 billion.
Since then, Pacific Telesis has settled in a mid-40's trading range on the New York Stock Exchange. Yesterday it closed at $46.75, up 12.5 cents.
Mr. Ginn, the chief executive, is not troubled by the market reaction. He said that since April, when Pacific Telesis announced it was studying a split, the stock price had soared from $37 a share. "I am elated," he said.
Moreover, analysts seem to be reaching a consensus that the company's traditional phone business will have a market value of about $14 billion and the wireless unit a market value of $6 billion to $7 billion. Current Pacific Telesis holders would get new shares representing the two companies, although the exact ratio has not been determined.
Daniel Reingold, an analyst with Morgan Stanley, estimates Pacific Telesis's post-split value at close to $50 a share, with traditional phones at $35 a share and cellular at $15 a share. Robert Morris, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company, using different criteria, values cellular at $17 a share.
Analysts say the new wireless unit will have to borrow far more than the $750 million planned initial stock offering. They say future borrowings may total in the billions to develop the wireless unit's markets, which include 656,000 actual and 34 million potential United States subscribers.
Such future borrowings will be especially needed for the wireless unit's international operations -- a 26 percent stake in Germany's digital cellular network, 20 percent interest in a mobile radio project in France, and up to 15 percent interests in digital cellular networks in Japan.
Mr. Ginn implicitly acknowledged the analysts' arguments when he said that "the first $750 million is just the beginning."

HEADLINE: Rebates Kept At Chrysler

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: HIGHLAND PARK, Mich., Dec. 22

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation, seeking to bolster its share of the United States market, extended rebates today on most of its cars and trucks for three months and doubled cash incentives on some slow-selling models.
Separately, Chrysler's chairman-elect, Robert J. Eaton, predicted that North American car and truck sales for the entire industry would reach 15 million vehicles in 1993, a 5 percent increase over the 14.3 million rate expected for 1992. 
 "You can just about take 15 million to the bank," Mr. Eaton said in a statement. "And if we're lucky, we might see enough improvement next year to approach 15.5 million units."
Mr. Eaton, who takes over from Chrysler's retiring chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, on Jan. 1, said his forecast depended on a number of factors, including economic initiatives of the Clinton Administration, consumers' response and how quickly Canada recovers from recession.
Chrysler said the incentive program, which had been set to expire Dec. 31, offers cash rebates of $500 to $2,000. The promotion runs until March 31, 1993, for most models, but rebates on some models will run through next September.
As an alternative to cash, buyers may choose financing with annual percentage rates ranging from 2.9 percent for terms of up to 24 months to 6.9 percent for 49 to 60 months. Rates on mini-vans range from 5.9 percent to 8.9 percent.

HEADLINE: Bank Rates Remain Flat This Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The average yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit for the week beginning today are little changed from the previous week, according to the latest survey by The Bank Rate Monitor.
Analysts at The Monitor see no further interest rate reductions coming from the Federal Reserve, which has cut rates two dozen times since June 1989. 
 If anything, The Monitor analysts said, the numbers are in a holiday holding pattern, with the exception of a few banks, after going through a modest run-up from mid-October.
Since then, yields on certificates of deposit have risen about 5 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, on the short end and about 22 basis points on the long end, but yields on money market accounts have fallen.
At the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills on Monday, average discount rates were down. The auction is often seen as a sign of deposit-rate changes in the weeks ahead.
The average rate at auction fell 10 basis points for a three-month bill, to 3.16 percent, while a six-month bill fell 9 basis points, to 3.32 percent .
In the New York area, the average money market account yield is the same as the previous week for the second straight week, yielding 2.74 percent. For certificates of deposit, yields are down a basis point for a three-month maturity, to 2.85 percent, and down 2 basis points for a six-month maturity, to 3 percent.
At area savings banks, which traditionally offer higher yields than commercial banks, the average yield on a three-month C.D. is down a basis point, to 2.93 percent, and unchanged on a six-month certificate at 3.10 percent.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Lumber Up by Daily Limit As Supplies Have Tightened

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Lumber-contract prices soared yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as wholesalers seeking supplies for the new year found little available from American mills.
On other commodity markets, precious metals retreated; oil futures fell, and grains and soybeans were mixed, as were livestock and meat futures. 
 Spruce 2-by-4's for January delivery shot up the permitted daily limit of $5, to $268.80 for 1,000 board feet. It was the fourth limit gain in the last six trading sessions for lumber, which has risen $23.50, or about 9.6 percent, in a month.
 
'Going Hand to Mouth'
 Signs of a strengthening economy have injected optimism into the building materials industry, and lumber wholesalers looking to restock for an expected construction boom are having to turn to the futures market to lock in supplies, analysts said.
Environmental restrictions on logging in the Northwest and soggy ground conditions in the Southeast have cut deeply into the availability of yellow pine, hemlock and Douglas fir, leading to heightened demand for Canadian spruce, the futures-traded wood.
"The mills are going hand to mouth having to find logs, if they can find them," said Bud Merrill, lumber analyst for Shearson Lehman Brothers in Eugene, Ore.
 
Profit Taking in Oil
 Curt Cunningham, president of the Pacific Futures Trading Company in Seattle, said the harvest from Federal timberlands on the West Coast was 20 percent to 25 percent below a year ago and 45 percent below two years ago, mainly as a result of logging restrictions prompted by environmental concerns.
Profit taking also lowered oil futures prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Light sweet crude oil for February delivery fell 14 cents, to $19.84 a barrel; January heating oil fell 0.28 cent, to 56.83 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline tumbled 0.79 cent, to 54.73 cents a gallon, and February natural gas rose 0.3 cent, to $1.783 forr 1,000 cubic feet.
Soybean futures prices rose in quiet trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, lifted mainly by strong demand for soybean meal. Grain futures ended narrowly mixed.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises on Prediction At Bundesbank of Rate Drop

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday against most key currencies, strengthened by a German central banker's prediction of lower interest rates in Germany.
Gold prices slipped. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery fell $1.80 to close at $332.20 a troy ounce. A late bid at the New York Republic National Bank quoted it at $332.30 an ounce, off $1.65. 
 Helmut Schlesinger, president of the Bundesbank, was quoted in a German newspaper interview yesterday as saying that long-term German interest rates could fall below 6 percent in the current trend of lower European interest rates. Such a decline would represent a one percentage point fall in the current long-term German bond rates.
 
Cut Depends on Inflation
 Mr. Schlesinger added that such a cut would depend upon the Bundesbank's ability to control inflation.
German monetary officials have incurred the wrath of their European neighbors this year by keeping German interest rates high in relation to other currencies. The wide gap between German rates and those of the country's neighbors was one reason behind Europe's currency crisis in the fall. Higher rates make the German mark more attractive to foreign investors.
Mr. Schlesinger's comment contributed to an appetite for dollars, which has been based on recent signs of strength in the United States economy, traders said.
In New York, the dollar closed at 1.5895 German marks, up sharply from 1.5690 marks late Monday. In Europe, the dollar closed at 1.5875 German marks, up from 1.5680.
The market was little influenced by the latest United States economic reports showing a gain in the gross domestic product for the third quarter and a survey predicting an increase in business investment spending. Those reports were in line with expectations.
The British pound was quoted at $1.5365 in London, down from $1.5640 late Monday. At the close in New York, the pound cost $1.5370, less expensive than $1.5580 late Monday.
 
Dollar vs. Yen
 In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 123.13 yen, down 0.02 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 123.60 yen. In New York, the dollar was quoted at 123.75 yen, up from 123.095 yen late Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.4415 Swiss francs, up from 1.4145; 5.4205 French francs, up from 5.3625; 1,422.00 Italian lire, up from 1,409.00, and 1.26195 Canadian dollars, down from 1.26725.
In Europe, dollar rates, compared with late Monday, included: 1.4350 Swiss francs, up from 1.4140; 5.4175 French francs, up from 5.3575; 1.8758 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7627; 1,421.00 Italian lire, up from 1,409.50, and 1.2605 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2674.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
3 New British Plays With Serious Messages

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
It's no secret that the outstanding British farce of the moment is being written every day by the royal family. But who is going to write the great tragedy this reeling former empire demands?
Battered by recession and terrorism, uncertain of its relationship with either the new Europe or the new Washington, Britain would seem, if little else, a fertile subject for its serious native playwrights. But the most celebrated drama in London this year has been "Angels in America," by Tony Kushner, a New Yorker, and the most acclaimed contemporary works on the fringe right now are "The Wexford Trilogy," in which the playwright Billy Roche examines small-town life in his native Ireland, and the expatriate American Timberlake Wertenbaker's satire on the art market, "Three Birds Alighting on a Field." The Wertenbaker play is in a return engagement at the Royal Court, which has already produced John Guare's "Six Degrees of Separation" this year and will soon present Anna Deavere Smith's "Fires in the Mirror" and David Mamet's "Oleanna." 
 In the West End, where revivals, long-running musicals, thrillers and sex comedies perennially hold sway, new British plays are as scarce as new American plays are on Broadway. But there is one bracing exception: "The Rise and Fall of Little Voice," an acrid comedy by Jim Cartwright that originated at the Royal National Theater before transferring to the Aldwych Theater for its commercial run. Mr. Cartwright, a young Lancashire writer whose "Road" was staged by Lincoln Center Theater in 1988, is not bashful about filling the stage with the muck of present-day England. Set in a squalid lower-middle-class home where the fuses constantly blow and even the cornflakes have turned rancidly green, "Little Voice" finds some of its funnier gags in onstage bouts of alcoholic vomiting and mechanical sexual grinding. When the house burns down in Act 2, the conflagration seems less a disaster for the frequently stupefied, at most semi-literate characters than a sort of liberating deliverance.
It is not the author's view of his society's collapse that makes "Little Voice" special, however, so much as the extraordinary title role he has written for a one-of-a-kind young actress named Jane Horrocks. Miss Horrocks, whom American audiences have seen as the alienated, bulimic daughter in Mike Leigh's film "Life Is Sweet," is a bone-thin, childlike woman with flat blond hair and a catatonic air. In Mr. Cartwright's play, she is the lonely, shy, agoraphobic daughter of a boozy, barking widow (Alison Steadman, who also played Miss Horrocks's mother in "Life Is Sweet") and is known as Little Voice because she rarely speaks.
What she can do is sing. In the upstairs bedroom where she retreats from her mother, Little Voice spends her time obsessively listening to her dead father's old records of female vocalists. When she chooses to express herself, she does so by impersonating the singers (her "tongues," she calls them), often incoherently intermingling fragments of the patter from Judy Garland's Carnegie Hall concert with snatches of Garland's version of "Chicago" or Marilyn Monroe's "Happy Birthday, Mr. President" or Edith Piaf's "Milord" or Shirley Bassey's "Goldfinger."
The spectacle of these clarion, uncannily accurate voices abruptly taking possession of Miss Horrocks's previously inert face and rag-doll frame is one of the most bizarre sights I've ever seen in the theater. And Mr. Cartwright capitalizes on its otherworldly sadness by making "Little Voice" the story of how the heroine's mother and the mother's latest lover, a grotesque small-time agent named Ray Say (Pete Postle thwaite), try to exploit that weird spectacle by selling the terrified girl as a "class act" to the tatty local club.
As a play, "Little Voice" is not without its own mimickry -- of "A Taste of Honey," "Joe Egg" and "The Glass Menagerie," among others. But Mr. Cartwright's incendiary dialogue and bleak comic vision are his own. They are powerfully augmented by Sam Mendes's wired production, only to be undercut by a fairy-tale denouement and the unintelligibility (to American ears, anyway) of too many lines in Miss Steadman's otherwise bravura portrait of the mother from hell. Yet all else pales before Miss Horrocks, whose Little Voice can be as haunting as the Little Sparrow she sometimes imitates. In one incredible scene, she responds to Ray Say's repeated slaps by skipping violently among her various voices as if a needle were leaping tracks on an LP. For a cathartic finale, she at last sings in her own completely unmusical voice, a harrowing, zombielike wail in which the lyrics of "Just in Time" are used to express the same loneliness, suffering and yearning Miss Horrocks had earlier poured into a mock-Garland "Over the Rainbow."
That finale is set on a glittery variety stage that recalls the shabby domain of Archie Rice in "The Entertainer," by John Osborne. It says much about what has happened to that revolutionary 1950's generation of British dramatists, without whom "The Rise and Fall of Little Voice" could not exist, that Mr. Osborne this month put the original handwritten manuscript of "Look Back in Anger" on the auction block. (His sequel to "Anger" had failed in the West End earlier this year.) Mr. Osborne's most influential theatrical contemporary, Harold Pinter, also remains an infrequent playwright. He is currently acting in a revival of his own "No Man's Land" before directing "Oleanna."
But two other writers of similar longevity, David Storey and Peter Shaffer, are represented on London stages by brand-new work. Both of their plays are running in the small studio spaces of the major theatrical companies, both lament the decline of culture in the 20th century, and both are inward, stock-taking dramas about artists facing the waning of their powers and the prospect of mortality.
Mr. Storey's elegiac 75-minute "Stages," at the National, is a monologue with interruptions in which a celebrated painter, paralyzed by depression, tries to untangle the strands of his art, his failed marriage and his impoverished childhood. Mr. Storey, the author of "This Sporting Life" and "Home," wrote a similar and more effective valedictory play called "Early Days" for Ralph Richardson in 1980. This time the actor is Alan Bates, who happily looks to be a long, long way from retirement and who does his best to mine the poetic riffs and turgid emotions of an almost perversely undramatic exercise. The director is Mr. Storey's career-long collaborator Lindsay Anderson, who, like the entire supporting cast and much of the audience, seems to be fighting off sleep.
"The Gift of the Gorgon," as Mr. Shaffer's new play at the Royal Shakespeare Company's Pit at the Barbican Center is titled, proves a far more ambitious effort. A young Midwestern academic (Jeremy Northam) travels to Greece to research a biography of the father he never knew, a provocative playwright (Michael Pennington) who has just died under mysterious circumstances. To get the story, the illegitimate son must win the confidence of his father's protective widow (Judi Dench).
The conflict is the same as in all Mr. Shaffer's plays, that of ecstatic creative passion vs. deadening reason. The audience learns through flashbacks that the dead playwright, a spiritual equivalent to Mozart in "Amadeus" and the horse-blinding Alan Strang in "Equus," was in favor of violent revenge in both his life and in his epic theatrical works, while his wife exerted the restraining hand of gentility and censorship.
But this time Mr. Shaffer seems more ambivalent than ever about his own position (to the point of confusion in his drama's resolution), and the result is a much more stimulating evening than either of its immediate predecessors in his canon, "Yonadab" (not produced in New York) and "Lettice and Lovage." As directed by Peter Hall and fiercely acted, "The Gift of the Gorgon" is compelling when it champions the power of epic theater against the onslaught of cineplex literalism, or when it deals with its moral themes in the domestic arena. When epic theater is actually attempted -- Greek myths acted out in a style reminiscent of Mr. Hall's Lincoln Center production of John Guare's "Four Baboons Adoring the Sun" -- ponderousness ensues.
Mr. Shaffer is a compulsive rewriter of even his most successful works, and one hopes that this intriguing but unsettled piece will be no exception. First, he must recover from the heart surgery that was performed as "The Gift of the Gorgon" opened last week, in a London that his play fittingly characterizes as all "drizzle, emotional and physical."

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
FORGET the pre-wrapped food processor. And the overpriced tie. Or the gift certificate. You can do better than that, even with only two shopping days to go. When it comes to the true last-minute Christmas gift, the cliffhanger, the desperation move, it's time to think about wine.
If you are sure of yourself -- and the recipient -- the complete recordings of Glenn Gould may be in order. Or the catalogue from the Matisse show. Or Knicks tickets. But if gift-giving confidence is not your long suit, get yourself and your credit cards to the nearest wine shop. 
 Be forewarned, though: a wine shop just before Christmas can be hazardous to your health. No bargain-basement pandemonium, of course, but tensions can run high. Vague people looking for "a nice little white wine for dinner" will get short shrift. Through Thursday, stressed-out shoppers and short-fused clerks will be the order of the day.
So try to have some idea of what you want and how much you want to pay. If your choice is out of stock, listen to the clerk. There is probably something similar, and in a good liquor store, the clerks will either know something about wine or know how to find someone who does.
If you are hopelessly lost in this world, there are plenty of packaged gift sets. For example: a wicker basket holding four Champagnes -- Moet & Chandon Brut, Mumm Cordon Rouge, Piper-Heidsieck Brut and Veuve Clicquot-Ponsardin Yellow Label Brut -- all for about $160 at Morrell & Company, 535 Madison Avenue (54th Street) in Manhattan.
Morrell has an even more impressive selection, a wicker hamper with six prestige cuvee Champagnes: Mumm Grand Cordon, Dom Perigon, Veuve Clicquot La Grande Dame and Perrier-Jouet Fleur de Champagne, all from the 1985 vintage, along with a Krug Grand Cuvee and a Laurent-Perrier Rose, both nonvintage; all for $550.
Sherry-Lehmann, at 679 Madison Avenue (61st Street), offers a variety of wicker hampers, tote-bags and baskets ranging from $8 for a wicker baguette basket that can hold one bottle to an elaborate straw picnic case for $35. The wine to put in them is extra, but three bottles of Beaujolais nouveau would be about $18.
Speaking of the nouveau, which is quite tasty this year, a case of it at less than $70 makes a particularly appropriate gift. It's as seasonal as a holly wreath and at its best right now. Duboeuf, Ropiteau, Drouhin and Mommessin are just a few of the producers. Just as an aside, my own choice would be a case of the 1991 Beaujolais Villages for about a dollar a bottle more. The '91 Beaujolais were outstanding.
Always popular at this time of year is the idea of pairing a bottle of premium Champagne, like Dom Perignon, with two champagne flutes, often in a satin-lined box. A tall, thin flute is the preferred glass for sparkling wine, but if the recipients of this sort of gift have none to begin with, it might be more sensible to give six or a dozen flutes and let them buy their own champagne. Though champagne flutes can cost as much as $150 each, very good ones can be found for around $8 apiece.
Actually, a bottle of Dom Perigon, around $80, or any other fine Champagne, needs no embellishment. Not that most Champagne fans would not be delighted to get a bottle or two of Bollinger brut, which costs considerably less, about $28.
If you are buying for someone eager to be on top of events, consider J. Schram, the new premium sparkling wine from Schramsberg Vineyards in California. For about $50, it is intended to go against the best France has to offer.
If spirits seem more in keeping with the season, there are some magnificent Cognacs and Armagnacs. Here, the price range is astonishing. Remy Martin offers its Louis XIII in a Baccarat decanter for around $850 to $900, and Olev Kelt's Les Quatre Vents -- The Four Winds -- sells for $1,500 a bottle. More down to earth is Danflou's Fine Champagne for about $42 or Hennessy's V.S.O.P. for a dollar or two more.
Two truly elegant Cognacs are the Chateau Lafite-Rothschild Reserve, about $190, and the Selection Davidoff, from the famous cigar maker, about $175.
Personally, I'd opt for Armagnac. Cognac has more finesse, is silkier and more nuanced. Armagnac tends to be a bit rougher around the edges but at its best offers extraordinary richness and depth. What's more, unlike Cognac, which is a blend of different vintages, Armagnac can be vintaged. Morrell is offering a selection of vintage Armagnacs this year, including, from Loubere, a 1956 at $99.50 and a 1935 at $185.
There is no American Armagnac yet, but there is an excellent Cognac-style brandy. It's a single-cask brandy from Germain-Robin in California, and for about $40, it rivals many better-known names from the Charente district.
Mercifully, there seem to be fewer wine gadgets around this year. Perhaps it's the economy. We are told that the wine market has improved markedly in recent months, so we can probably expect a new wave of wine kitsch by this time next year.
But a gadget that has been around for a few years deserves your consideration: the Screwpull Lever by the Hallen Company. As hand-held cork pullers go, nothing is in its class. It costs about $100 and makes an excellent gift for a wine enthusiast. Unless your friends prefer their wine from screw-top bottles.
 
 
 
TASTINGS

 
Zind-Humbrecht, 1991 Pinot Blanc, Alsace; about $13.
Robert M. Parker Jr. once referred to pinot blanc as the poor man's chardonnay. At $13, this wine probably could not qualify as a poor man's wine. But given its exceptional quality, it is very much a bargain. Like all Zind-Humbrecht wines, it has intense flavors and a beautiful bouquet, a result of very low yields from the vineyards. There is a touch of spiciness, but this is no gewurztraminer, the true spicy wine of Alsace; this is leaner and more elegant. One of pinot blanc's qualities is its freshness, which is another way of saying that it tends to be acidic. This one has plenty of acidity but is well balanced by concentrated fruit, a Zind-Humbrecht trademark. It is a wine that should be drunk within a year or two of the harvest, four at the most. It is a welcome substitute for chardonnay and, in fact, is better than many of the wines made from that overrated grape.

HEADLINE: Presidential Priorities;
Mr. Clinton's New World Symphony

 BODY:
President-elect Clinton has assembled an experienced foreign policy team wise in the ways of Washington and skilled, variously, at devising policies and effecting them. But caution and competence stir no souls. If there's to be music, all now depends on the conductor. Mr. Clinton will need to define his new direction -- like the promising pro-democracy course he began to chart during the campaign.
Warren Christopher, his choice as Secretary of State, said as much yesterday, citing the global environment and global economic competition among the challenges of this new era. The appointees who will serve closest to Mr. Clinton, Anthony Lake and Samuel Berger at the National Security Council, had a large part in drafting his new direction in the campaign. And Mr. Clinton's other senior appointees have the know-how to put it into practice. 
 But the priorities will have to come from the President-elect. With warlords rampaging where the Red Army once cast its shadow, he'll need above all to articulate the standards for engagement abroad.
Mr. Lake, Mr. Clinton's choice for national security adviser, first won note as a young Foreign Service officer who took pains to learn Vietnamese. He and his designated deputy, Mr. Berger, began to challenge cold war dogmas 15 years ago, when they ran the State Department's Policy Planning staff under Cyrus Vance.
Mr. Christopher has repeatedly demonstrated dignified managerial acumen -- during the Iran hostage crisis in 1979-80, and more recently in the Clinton transition. His qualifications are enhanced by his insight, as well, into domestic affairs, including police reform in Los Angeles.
The choice of Clifton Wharton as Mr. Christopher's deputy underscores the connection between domestic and foreign policy. Mr. Wharton built his reputation as a university administrator and pension fund manager.
Les Aspin, Mr. Clinton's choice for Secretary of Defense, has spent his political life preparing for that job, first as a whiz kid in Robert McNamara's Pentagon, later as a goad and gadfly on the House Armed Services Committee. His work this year on options for downsizing the force structure was analytically sound. But the option he favored was fatter than U.S. security requires.
James Woolsey will have a difficult job weaning the C.I.A. from its cold war mentality, cutting the intelligence budget and redirecting its resources. His well-earned reputation for tough-mindedness as an Under Secretary of the Navy and conventional arms negotiator won't hurt.
The importance of collective security in this new era is nowhere more obvious than at the United Nations. Madeleine Albright, Mr. Clinton's choice of envoy, has no experience there but did serve as a staff member on President Carter's National Security Council and as a Democratic foreign policy adviser in the last three Presidential campaigns.
Bill Clinton has assembled a band of talented instrumentalists to confront the New World Order. The score remains to be composed.

HEADLINE: Hunger, a Growth Industry

 BODY:
Despite the tepid economy, one New York enterprise continues to grow rapidly. City Harvest, the nonprofit group that collects leftovers and delivers them to the hungry, expanded by 30 percent this year. City Harvest is likely to keep growing. There's no shortfall in supply or, unfortunately, demand.
That disturbing fact poses a challenge for Democrats about to move into the White House. 
 Helen VerDuin Palit, who had run a soup kitchen in New Haven, set up City Harvest in New York 10 years ago. The idea is simple: Since many people are hungry and much food goes to waste, find a way to get the food to the people.
This year City Harvest's eight vehicles will collect and distribute about 6 million pounds of food, up from 4.6 million in 1991. Bret Suval, who took over from Ms. Palit two years ago, now keeps the trucks rolling 24 hours a day, seven days a week, to make pickups even from after-theater banquets and bakers at work in the wee hours.
Even so, he says, City Harvest doesn't come close to meeting the need. It distributes to only 130 of the 750 soup kitchens, food pantries and other distribution groups in the city. Meanwhile the supply of leftovers still seems limitless, as New Yorkers continue their dining out, their weddings, bar mitzvahs, holiday parties, corporate feasts, movie shoots and charity balls.
The idea appears to be catching on nationwide. A group called the Prepared and Perishable Food Programs Network has been meeting since 1990 and soon will turn itself into a formal organization called Food Chain. It counts some 120 programs in 38 states. There's Operation Food Search in St. Louis, Twelve Baskets in St. Paul, Food Brigade in Santa Fe.
Private donations pay for City Harvest's $2 million annual budget; most of the other groups rely on charity and volunteer labor. But why leave so demonstrably successful and necessary an enterprise to the vagaries of private funding?
A Federal grant of another $2 million, for example, might allow City Harvest to expand its fleet and get within striking distance of serving all the shelters and soup kitchens that could use leftovers. Similar grants to proven programs in other cities could also yield dramatic returns.
Chronic hunger continues to shame America; so does chronic waste. Why not maximize so obvious and cost-effective a response?

HEADLINE: Home Care Serves a Need, Provides Jobs and Is Cost-Effective

 BODY:
To the Editor:
New York State's home care program, which faces serious budget cuts by the Department of Social Services, offers true social and cost advantages (front page, Nov. 20). 
 Home care is provided to the elderly or disabled with financial need who are unable to care for themselves. For less than $10 an hour (including staff salary, benefits and the costs of administration), the program lets them stay at home, a humane alternative to much more costly nursing homes. Many of the services these patients need can be provided by people with modest education; thus the program provides work to thousands of men and women.
The program limits Medicaid expenditure by keeping down the costs of care and generates tax revenue by providing work to those who might otherwise be unemployed and receiving Government benefits.
Let's hope the home care program survives the critics who would destroy it.
 
EUGENE SKLAR
STUART MEIKLEJOHN
MAXINE ROCKOFF
New York, Dec. 3, 1992
 
The writers are, respectively, executive director, chairman and treasurer of the Union Settlement Association.
