HEADLINE: Real Estate;
New Hotel For Glutted Los Angeles

BYLINE: By Morris Newman

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
CITY officials are hailing the opening of the 439-room Inter-Continental Hotel, a $100 million project that faces a bleak occupancy situation in the lodging industry.
The hotel is in California Plaza, a $1.2 billion, 11-acre mixed-use project in Bunker Hill, a financial district in the city's downtown area, which has been under redevelopment since 1959. The 17-story hotel and a 217-unit residential tower are the two most recent additions to California Plaza, which also contains two office buildings and the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art. A third office building and a second residential tower are planned. 
 The developer is California Plaza Hotel L.P., whose general partners are the Tobishima Development Company of Japan and Metropolitan Structures, which is 50 percent owned by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. The hotel operator is the Saison Group of Japan.
Despite the poor hotel market, Michael Collins, senior vice president of the Los Angeles Convention and Tourism Bureau, said downtown Los Angeles needed 4,000 more hotel rooms for conventions that are being booked for the late 1990's. The Los Angeles Convention Center is near completion of a one-million-square-foot, $500 million extension.
But the current situation is a marked contrast to three years ago, Mr. Collins said, when 15 new hotels were proposed for downtown Los Angeles. "They all dried up or went into suspended animation when the recession hit us," he said.
Hotel occupancy in downtown Los Angeles for 1992 is projected at 51.8 percent, according to PKF Associates, a unit of Pannell Kerr Forster International. A variety of factors, including the temporary closing of the Los Angeles Convention Center, the recession and the riots in Los Angeles last spring have hurt hotel occupancy in downtown Los Angeles this year.
"It's good for downtown L.A. to have another hotel, but it's unfortunately opening at the worst possible time," said Bruce Baltin, a PKF director.
While the hotel is about a mile from the Convention Center, it is only two blocks from the Los Angeles Music Center on the north end of Bunker Hill. The hotel plans to operate vans to take people from concerts to late-night restaurants and lounges, with the intent of promoting night life in a downtown that is largely empty after 5 P.M.
The hotel is in a style described as contemporary by its architects, Flatow Moore Bryan Shaffer & McCabe of Albuquerque, N.M. According to the architects, both the design and the naturally finished sandstone are intended to complement the reddish sandstone of the nearby art museum, which was designed by Arata Isozaki of Japan and completed in 1985. The interiors, by Hugh Latta of Design Continuum Inc. of Atlanta, feature neo-classical moldings and light-colored stone.
Single rooms run from $165 to $225 daily, while doubles range from $195 to $255. The Presidential Suite goes for $1,500 nightly.
Despite an unresolved dispute with Local 11 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union over whether the hotel will be a union shop, the management is emphasizing its role as a fair employer. "We are bringing 240 new jobs to the area," Michel Tourniaire, the hotel manager, said.
Mr. Tourniaire seems philosophical about a hotel market in which half the guest rooms are empty, saying he has seen worse times as the manager of other Inter-Continental Hotels in Iran and Thailand during revolutions in those countries. Compared with those events, Mr. Tourniaire said, "a recession in L.A. isn't so bad."

SECTION: Section A; Page 19; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 768 words

HEADLINE: Babes in Computerland

BYLINE: By David Gelernter; David Gelernter, associate professor of computer science at Yale, is author of "Mirror Worlds."

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
Computers, we're being told, are the answer to America's education ills. Not long ago, I heard from a parent about aggressive computer acquisition plans at the school where my 5-year-old attends kindergarten.
The same week, I appeared on a panel with Benno Schmidt, the president and chief executive officer of Whittle Communications' schooling-for-profit Edison Project. He explained the project's vision of "radical change," with classroom computers playing a big role. As we all know by now, President-elect Clinton talks a lot about technology and about education. 
 I'm an easy mark for enthusiasts. Moreover, I've lost no opportunity to pontificate about the importance of scientific and technological literacy. But the more I learn about classroom computing, the more nervous I get.
Today, computers in the classroom are modestly useful. In the future, new computing trends combined with our laziness about education could lead to disaster.
I worry that computers will be used to undermine the teaching of basic skills. The pocket calculator syndrome is well-known: over-reliance on calculators has harmed the teaching of basic arithmetic; computers are calculators writ large. If sophisticated kids' drawing programs infiltrate the schools, will children ever again feel the need to pick up a crayon? Style-checker programs evaluate writing by applying grammatical and stylistic rules; if a program can tell students whether their writing is good or bad, will they still be motivated to develop an ear for prose?
I worry that computers will undermine children's already morbidly depressed desire to read. Multimedia and hypermedia are buzzwords in educational computing.
Multimedia beefs up those mere boring words with audio and video as you browse through a text on a computer screen. What better way to make even a well-written, profusely color-illustrated book seem dull? Multimedia promotions talk up the feeling of "psychological immersion" that their systems produce. Novels used to deliver that product. A child's imagination needs exercise to develop.
Hypermedia does away with a linear presentation of material and encourages readers to roam aimlessly through a text. When you reach the end of a paragraph you don't continue on. You hop forward, at the click of a mouse button, to whatever next topic suits you -- impulse shopping for ideas. It's fun. It's also the ultimate scholarly medium of the Sesame Street age, in which nothing ever lasts for more than three minutes. Hypermedia is no way to develop concentration or the ability to understand the unfolding of a logical argument.
I worry that these systems are promoted on the grounds that kids love them. Of course kids love them! When I was a child, nothing made me happier than seeing a movie in class instead of having to turn on my brain and pay attention to the teacher.
 Most of all, I worry that the educational establishment isn't worried. Granted, these approaches can all be valuable. But to the extent that they become the educational main act and not the sideshow they should be, they all fail in the same ominous way, by fostering glitz over substance. Do schools really need a brand-new way to promote shallowness?
The situation isn't completely bleak. The tutoring software coming into use is hardly exciting but can be helpful. More important, check out the Edison Project's brochure: "If math, physics and leadership are learned more effectively when one actually builds a bridge, then set students to building bridges."
Right. But don't stop at mere hardware bridges, have students build economies, ecosystems, Napoleonic armies -- out of software. Borrow from the military's "man-in-the-loop war-gaming" techniques to let students participate in labor negotiations or a session of Congress or a stock market crash. Software is the greatest modeling clay of all time.
Unlike the predigested, canned reality of today's popular programs, these systems are dynamic, interactive and unpredictable. They offer something new, not just glitzy versions of the same old stuff.
Still, the prognosis is grim. Americans are too easily satisfied. We ask too little of our computers (which is why most are still such a royal pain to use). Sadly, we ask too little of our schools. A study comparing American and Asian schools in the December Scientific American shows Americans excelling only at self-satisfaction. Unless we get serious about classroom computers, the machines won't be agents of revolutionary change -- they will be the low-guilt, high-tech pacifiers of a vacuous Information Age.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
CLINTON PLANNING TO NAME A WOMAN FOR JUSTICE DEPT.

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 23

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton is prepared to name Zoe Baird, senior vice president and general counsel for Aetna Life and Casualty in Hartford as Attorney General, transition officials confirmed tonight. Ms. Baird would be the first woman to hold the post.
News of Ms. Baird's nomination came barely 48 hours after she came here to be interviewed by Mr. Clinton and at the end of a day in which other candidates' names rose and fell within hours of each other. 
 Mr. Clinton is also expected to announce on Thursday that he has selected Bruce Babbitt, the former Arizona Governor, to be Secretary of the Interior, Federico F. Pena, the former Mayor of Denver, as Transportation Secretary, Representative Mike Espy of Mississippi as Secretary of Agriculture and Mickey Kantor, a Los Angeles lawyer who helped run his campaign, as United States Trade Representative, the officials said.
 
Meeting Christmas Deadline
 The flurry of appointments, first reported by the Associated Press, would allow Mr. Clinton to meet his self-imposed Christmas deadline for completing his Cabinet.
Ms. Baird, 40 , is not unfamiliar in Washington circles. She served as associate counsel to President Jimmy Carter and was once a partner in the office there of O'Melveny & Myers, the law firm based in Los Angeles in which Warren M. Christopher, Mr. Clinton's transition director, is a partner.
Ms. Baird was an informal policy adviser to Mr. Clinton in the campaign, primarily on health care issues, and attended his recent meeting on the economy. She received a law degree from the University of California at Berkeley, and before going to Aetna two years ago, she was a senior lawyer at the General Electric Company.
She is a Brooklyn native and lives in New Haven. In June, she was named by Business Week magazine as one of the 50 top women in business.
 
Ending Flurry of Speculation
 Her fortunes rose so suddenly that at least one other finalist for the job, Brooksley E. Born, a Washington lawyer, believed she had been offered the job, according to associates.
The announcement that Mr. Babbitt would take the post at the Interior Department ended a 48-hour flurry of speculation that Mr. Babbitt had been bounced from contention for the position in favor of a Hispanic candidate, Representative Bill Richardson of New Mexico.
And Mr. Espy, who has long been considered Mr. Clinton's top choice for Secretary of Agriculture, emerged as the nominee for the job even after Mr. Clinton interviewed former Gov. George Sinner of North Dakota here today.
Mr. Espy, 39, would be the first black to hold the agriculture post. He was elected to Congress in 1987 and represents a largely rural district.
Mr. Espy serves on the House Agriculture Committee and was an early supporter of Mr. Clinton. He was also one of several black politicians who defended Mr. Clinton against accusations that he was distancing himself from black voters by alienating the Rev. Jesse Jackson.
Mr. Clinton's decision to give the United States Trade Representative job to his friend Mr. Kantor would also end the ideological feud about who would fill this Cabinet post. Some people active in trade issues had debated whether the person who took the job should be in favor of open markets or restricting them in order to benefit American businesses.
Mr. Kantor, who was chairman of Mr. Clinton's campaign, is a Los Angeles lawyer with Manatt, Phelps, Phillips & Kantor. Mr. Kantor, 52, is a native of Nashville with experience in Presidential campaigns dating back to 1976 when he headed the campaign of Edmund G. Brown Jr., then Governor of California. He was also state chairman of President Carter's re-election campaign in 1980 and of Walter F. Mondale's campaign in 1984
 
A Tumultuous Week
 Mr. Pena benefited from Mr. Clinton's desire to nominate a second Hispanic member of his Cabinet. Last week he named Henry G. Cisneros, the former Mayor of San Antonio, to be Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
A two-term state legislator who defeated a 14-year incumbent to become Denver's first Hispanic mayor in 1983, Mr. Pena served in that job until 1991. In 1988 he started the drive to build the $3 billion dollar Denver International Airport, which is scheduled to be opened by next fall. Since leaving as Mayor, Mr. Pena has been operating a Denver investment and counseling firm.
Mr. Clinton has had a tumultuous week of last-minute decision making that revolved primarily around his attempt to sort through finalists in search of women and Hispanics to fill the final five cabinet jobs.
Ms. Baird's nomination in particular would end weeks of frantic searching. Mr. Clinton had decided he wanted to nominate a woman to lead the Justice Department, but had been stymied when his leading choice, Judge Patricia M. Wald of the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, decided against joining the Administration after being approached on two separate occasions.
 
Pena and Richardson
 Mr. Clinton's comment earlier this week that there was a "definite possibility" that he would appoint another Hispanic to a top post caused a flurry among supporters of Mr. Babbitt, who had been in line to head the Interior Department. He is 54 and ran for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1988. He is known for tough talk about the economy and for having a sense of humor.
Reports that Mr. Babbitt might be replaced by Mr. Richardson, who is Hispanic, caused objections from some environmental groups that supported the former Arizona Governor.
Mr. Pena's emergence apparently doomed Mr. Richardson's chances, because Mr. Clinton was able to fulfill his diversity goals without rejecting Mr. Babbitt, who is a longtime friend.
Earlier this week, he dropped Tim Wirth, a political ally who is departing as United States Senator from Colorado, from contention for Energy Secretary in favor of nominating Hazel R. O'Leary, a Minnesota power company executive who is black.
Mr. Stephanopoulos said earlier today that Mr. Clinton had not scaled down his search for the best-qualified candidates to satisfy his desire for diversity.
"This is a subjective call when you talk about best qualified," Mr. Stephanopoulos said. "He wants a diverse Cabinet, he wants a Cabinet of excellent people who are well qualified or strong administrators who have views and expertise in the subjects at hand.
"I don't know that you can come out on any measure and say this person is clearly best, this person is clearly second best," he said.
"It's more important to get the right people than to meet the right deadline," Mr. Stephanopoulos said.
All of the new appointees are Democrats, a move that apparently flies in the face of Mr. Clinton's stated intention to name Republicans to his Cabinet to assure political diversity as well as representation from different sex and racial groups.

HEADLINE: Age Bias Case Cites Brokerage in 17 Dismissals

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB

 BODY:
In what Government lawyers said was the first major age-discrimination case against a brokerage and securities firm, a Federal agency yesterday accused Kidder, Peabody of unlawfully dismissing 17 senior executives, all of whom were paid $100,000 or more a year.
The Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission asserted in a lawsuit filed in Manhattan that the executives had been dismissed since January 1990, apparently as part of a youth movement in the firm's upper echelons and to fill their jobs with lower-paid employees. The ages of the former employees, who held the titles of managing director, senior vice president and vice president, ranged from 43 to 60 at the time of their dismissals.
 
 
'Younger, Cheaper Staff'
 "There was a movement at Kidder to open up positions for younger executives," said James L. Lee, the commission's chief lawyer in the New York metropolitan area. "They apparently were trying to get a younger, cheaper staff." 
 Describing the charges as "ridiculous," a spokeswoman for Kidder, Peabody & Company, Helen B. Platt, said the company maintained strict policies against discrimination. Ms. Platt said the company would not comment on the specific individuals but she added that "typically these complaints come from people who are underperforming."
She said the company had 5,000 employees in 46 cities and eight foreign counties and that "lots of them are over the age of 40 and 50." Since January 1990, Ms. Platt said, more than 100 other "professionals" had been dismissed, laid off or resigned from jobs at levels similar to those of the 17 cited in the suit.
A lawyer for the firm, Ronald M. Green, said Kidder, Peabody was being used as a "legal guinea pig" by the commission to determine if the agency has jurisdiction to investigate disputes involving employees who are registered with the New York Stock Exchange. All of the 17, as a condition of employment, had signed agreements requiring them to submit dismissal grievances to binding arbitration, rather than through court action, he said.
The year the Kidder dismissals began, 1990, was one of the most unprofitable for Wall Street, with Kidder itself losing $50 million. Securities firms cut jobs by the thousands to stanch the losses, and many of the companies were accused in civil lawsuits of dismissing the oldest employees, and women, first.
In 1991, Kidder rode Wall Street's return to profitability. The firm earned $119 million that year. And for 1992, Kidder, a unit of the General Electric Company, has had what its executives expect to be one of the most profitable years in securities firm's history. Donald R. Livingston, the commission's general counsel, maintained that under a 1991 Supreme Court ruling, the agency had the authority to pursue age discrimination suits brought to its attention against brokerage companies.
Mr. Lee said the commission had brought age-discrimination suits concerning hundreds of complainants against individual companies but never before a multiple case against a securities firm.
In the suit filed in the United States District Court in Manhattan, the commission said that based on a two-year investigation, it found that the 17 had been discharged "because of their age," in violation of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967.
Mr. Livingston, at a news conference announcing the suit, said that the number of age-bias complaints made nationwide to the agency had increased by 25 percent since 1990, from 14,526 to 19,350 for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30. He attributed the rise mainly to the economic recession.
"When the economy gets bad, some employers believe they can achieve greater savings sometimes on the backs of older employees," he said.
The vast majority of the complaints are settled through conciliation instead of suits, Mr. Livingston noted.
Mr. Livingston said the commission's inquiry had not turned up evidence of widespread age discrimination in the securities industry. Most of the 17 named in the suit had worked at Kidder, Peabody's main office at 10 Hanover Square in the Manhattan's financial district but several were in the company's Boston branch.
Louis Graziano, the commission's trial lawyer for the case, said that several of the discharged employees, whom he declined to identify, had been asked to retire although they were in their 40's or 50's. One complainant, according to Mr. Graziano, said that before being dismissed, a high management official told him that Kidder, Peabody needed younger bankers.
"The complainant was warned that the company wanted to get rid of gray hairs and dead wood," Mr. Graziano said.
The investigation arose from a complaint by Charles D. Erickson, who was dismissed in June 1990, at the age of 50, as a managing director in the firm's investment banking division. He had been in charge of sales in the utility finance group.
Mr. Erickson, who had been with the company for 25 years, brought his complaints to the commission in November 1990.
In an interview, Mr. Erickson, who lives in Essex Fells, N.J., said he had been selected by the company as its "Man of the Year" in 1986 for the volume of business he had brought to the utility finance group.
He maintained that the four executives ousted in his division were all over the age of 40.

HEADLINE: Czechoslovak Colleges Fight the ABC's: Apathy, Bureaucracy, Communism

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE

 BODY:
In his history class at Charles University, Karel Kubis befuddles his students with questions like: Was the American Revolution a real revolution? Was the French Revolution? And was the French Revolution devalued by the terror that followed it?
Most perplexing for the students is that there are no longer right or wrong answers: Mr. Kubis wants a debate, an exercise in critical thinking, evidence that history can be analyzed from several points of view. He is pleased when, in response, the class wants to question Czechoslovakia's own "Velvet Revolution" of 1989. 
 Three years after the universities stood in the forefront of protests against the Communist Government, a transformation in learning is under way across the country and educators struggle with the challenge of teaching students how to think and function in an open, critical and competitive society.
 
The Burdens of History
 Their daunting handicap, though, is that the instructors who are supposed to be fostering the new thinking are usually themselves products of the rigid, fixed ways of the past.
Thus, though Czechoslovakia is a pace-setter for educational change in the former Communist countries, it also mirrors how far they still have to go. The reflection is one of acute shortages of libraries, classrooms, money and well-trained, motivating teachers.
After Jan. 1, when Czechoslovakia splits into two nations, the situation may worsen in Slovakia, which is poorer than the Czech Republic.
"We are sclerotic, that's the problem," said Radim Palous, a philosopher and chemist who is now rector of Charles University in Prague, one of the oldest seats of learning in Europe. He speaks of education crippled for more than half a century, beginning in 1939, when Nazi Germany first closed the university, and then in the decades that followed, when Communism cut learning off from the modern world.
"We have to adapt to new sciences, new methods," Mr. Palous said. "We are searching for new standards. But how? Where do we get new teachers?"
 
Books vs. Business Skills
 As a reminder of a proud past dating to 1348, Mr. Palous led the way into the university's medieval Great Hall. He also made a point of showing the ancient ceremonial robe and mace of his office, as though still incredulous to find himself, a philosopher and chemist, at the head of this institution after the years of arrests, of holding clandestine philosophy seminars, of working as a furnace stoker.
Specialists, including foreign economists, say the state of education is a better barometer for durable change than the capitalist arts, which are already blooming in the region.
They also see education as a truer gauge of the complexity and the time required in creating a democratic society, even in Czechoslovakia, which once had strong liberal traditions.
"Our smooth and nonviolent 'Velvet Revolution' of 1989 created the illusion that the transformation from socialism would be swift and easy," said Jiri Musil, the rector of the new Central European University. "In education, that illusion is gone. The core of the problem is that we have an unbelievable scarcity of human resources, of good teachers. And no one can solve this quickly."
Some educators here, even those grateful for the help coming from the West, say they wish the West would stop harping on the glories of business expertise. They believe this shows a misunderstanding of the long-term needs of Central and Eastern Europe.
"Our disaster lies in the way people think, in their closed and passive minds," Mr. Musil said. "It's not the absence of management skills."
 
A New University's Goals
 He says Central European University in Prague is in the forefront of change because it aims at preparing the new intellectual elite. "We want to train future academics, politicians, civil servants," he said, "in the bases of an open society, the people who will build up civil society."
This graduate school in social sciences and humanities is largely financed by the Soros Foundation in New York, which was founded by George Soros, a Hungarian-born businessman, to promote democracy in Eastern Europe. Thus it is privileged compared with local institutes, providing its 110 students with one of the nation's best libraries and an international staff.
Although foreign foundations and governments, including the United States, have sent books, equipment, teachers and money, shortages everywhere are daunting.
Most precarious is the fate of Trnava University, founded in 1635, the oldest university in Slovakia, which had its funds cut back in September. The Government has claimed insolvency, but students and teachers said in angry demonstrations that the Government wants to throttle the school because the rector and others oppose the official Slovak nationalist line.
 
Classic Books, by Xerox
 At the English department at Charles University, a photocopy machine donated by the British Council makes up for missing texts, as long as teachers pay for the paper. An instructor discussing Jane Austen has used it to copy entire novels.
"I only pick essays," an American teacher said. "My courses are determined by the length of a text. If it's more than 20 pages, it will take me too long to Xerox copies."
Yet across the country, a whirlwind of formal changes has already put a great distance between this academic year and the time, just three years ago, when Czechs and Slovaks studied scientific atheism and the legal relationships between state enterprises.
The ubiquitous institutes of Marxism-Leninism have gone, and so have the many compulsory courses spun from its doctrine. The 23 Czech and 15 Slovak institutes of higher education have all overhauled their curriculums. Some changed crucial subjects like law and history; others, particularly technical institutes, tried to end the Communist-style separation between teaching and research, which was reserved for the prestigious, but separate, science academies.
 
New Curriculums Not Enough
 In its soot-covered buildings around town, Charles University has recently revived departments like theology, political science and sociology and opened new studies in economics and computer science.
Monica Vesela, a fifth-year history student, is not impressed. She singled out Mr. Kubis, the history professor, as a man of "modern" ideas, but she said she had not seen much change.
"Seventy percent of our teachers are the same people who talk the same boring way and are just as inflexible as before," she said. Many older teachers, expelled in the past as ideologically suspect, have been reinstated.
Milos Kocman, a law student, said the old-time lecturers have learned the new laws but teach on the old principle of "just copy and learn by heart."
 
First, Purge the Communists
 Except for the former East Germany, no other former East-bloc country has staged a political purge quite like Czechoslovakia's. The reaction has been intense because Czechoslovakia's former Communist bosses gave great importance to controlling all liberal reflexes, dismissing hundreds of scholars and teachers.
In the counterpurge since 1989, hundreds of faculty and staff members have lost their jobs. Many were forced out by students who labeled them Communist Party hacks or police informers, others simply because their specialties in doctrine or central planning are obsolete. Those who remain are a mix of former Communists and their critics, though many dissidents have gone into politics.
The Education Ministry says it has no statistics on these changes, but some specialists estimate that since 1989, perhaps 3,000 people, including 10 percent of the instructors and most administrators, have lost jobs in education. Mr. Palous said Charles University alone dismissed 500 of its 3,500 teachers.
Even libraries have been weeding out their shelves. "People are so allergic, they are rooting out all Marxist material, even Western views of Marxism," said Richard Ayres, a British librarian at the Central European University, who expressed a collector's regrets. "It's disturbing. They're not locking it up but throwing it all away."
 
No Lack of Enthusiasm
 But the thirst for education is impressive. Charles University, which has 30,000 students, this year had 42,000 applicants; only 6,000 were accepted. The crush has been greatest at the law schools, where 7,000 students applied and teachers complain that the 900 admitted far exceed capacity.
Communist governments had kept enrollment low, often responding to the dictates of central planners.
But demand is now high for almost any course. The Czech Republic, which had 89,000 students enrolled in higher education in 1985, has more than 150,000 enrolled today; enrollment in Slovakia has jumped at the same rate, to 60,000.
This puts enormous demands on a Government strapped for cash. Officials say they may start charging for education, which is free, as it was under Communism. Communist spending on education, despite official propaganda, was relatively low.
In 1988, Government spending on higher education accounted for eight-tenths of 1 percent of the gross national product, compared to 1 percent in West Germany, 1.3 percent in the United States and 1.8 percent, one of the highest rates, in the Netherlands. A study of higher education in Czechoslovakia to be published shortly by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development recommends that the Government start looking for private contributions, increase the number of students per teacher and give greater autonomy to schools.
Many educators agree that the battle for education will be slow and hard to win. A glimpse of this can be seen at the Teachers' Training College in Prague. Vlastimil Parizek, a deputy director, said that among the 3,000 students, a growing number have financial problems. "One of my students works half the week in a pizza parlor on Wenceslas Square, one is a night watchman, one is a waiter," he said.
Claire Wallace, a Briton who heads the sociology department at the Central European University, said the greater challenge was to break down the conformism and apathy wrought by years in a mental straitjacket.
"The mindset here is, so Marxism was wrong," she said. "So what shall I do now, where are the new rules? Most students are not looking to think but to get the new recipe. It takes time to revive, to re-open the mind."

GRAPHIC: Photo: After being at the forefront of protests against Communism in Eastern Europe, universities find that teaching students in an open, critical society is difficult. University students, gathering in Old Town Square in Prague, are being asked to think, not choose between a right or wrong answer. (Marlise Simons/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. COURT DELAYS WELFARE CUTBACK

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23

 BODY:
A Federal judge has temporarily blocked California from paying lower welfare benefits to poor women and children who move here from other states, a policy that is a linchpin of Gov. Pete Wilson's effort to cut spiraling welfare costs and balance the budget.
Under the two-tiered benefit system, aid to newcomers would be limited for 12 months to the amounts they received in their former states. The policy was approved by the Legislature this fall and went into effect on Dec. 1, when the state received a Federal waiver. 
 But the new system was challenged this week in Federal District Court in Sacramento in a suit brought by civil rights and legal service groups. The court order to restore full benefits to the newcomers was issued on Tuesday by Judge Milton L. Schwartz and will stand at least until Jan. 7, when another Federal district judge, David F. Levi, is scheduled to begin hearing the case.
The results of the California litigation will be closely watched in statehouses around the country, where vast changes in welfare policy are being debated.
 
Some National Implications
 If the law is struck down in the nation's most populous state, whose benefits are the fourth highest in the nation, it will "give great pause to other state policy makers," said Jodie Levin-Epstein, an analyst at the Center for Law and Social Policy in Washington and an author of a recent report on state efforts to restrict Aid to Families With Dependent Children.
In the last year at least 10 other states have considered similar laws to restrict the family aid program, which is operated by the states and the Federal Government. But only in California, Wisconsin and Illinois have the anti-migration measures passed and been signed into law. Like California, Wisconsin has received the necessary Federal waiver but has yet to put its program into effect; the Illinois waiver request is still pending.
Most welfare experts see the anti-migration laws as an expression of public frustration and anger over the nation's welfare system rather than as a meaningful way to hold down costs.
"This is a highly symbolic issue," said David T. Ellwood, a professor of public policy at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government. "But it is a trivial part of the budget, really. And the troubling feature is that it creates an us-against-them mentality."
According to the California Department of Social Services, which administers welfare programs here, the two-tiered benefit system would save $10 million a year -- less than one-fifth of 1 percent -- of a total state budget of $5.6 billion for the family aid program. State officials say that there are now 14,000 women and children on the welfare rolls who have arrived in the last year, and that 2,000 out-of-state migrants are arriving every month.
 
Political Maneuvering
 California's new welfare law passed the Democratic-controlled Legislature as the Governor, a Republican, tried to win passage of a ballot measure that would have made even more far-reaching changes in the family aid program.
To blunt the appeal of the Wilson measure and in deference to rising public concern about welfare, the legislators agreed in September to cut benefits for poor women and children by 5.8 percent. Under this plan, a family of three in California now receives $624 a month rather than $663.
As part of the same bill, the legislators approved the residency provision to help discourage out-of-state welfare recipients from moving here.
Only the residency provision is now being challenged. The plaintiffs argue that it violates the equal protection clause in the Constitution. In support of their argument they cite a 1969 Supreme Court ruling, Shapiro v. Thompson, which held that states cannot deny welfare benefits to newcomers from other states.
 
Mixed Reaction to Ruling
 The decision by Judge Schwartz to grant the temporary restraining order was hailed by Mark D. Rosenbaum of the American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California. Mr. Rosenbaum, a lawyer for the poor, said the law "puts a fence around our state."
Eloise Anderson, the director of the State Department of Social Services, said most of the argument had focused on the treatment of poor people from out of state. "What about the taxpayer?" she asked. "I don't mind helping my neighbor, but what have these people contributed in this state?"
Isabel V. Sawhill, an economist at the Urban Institute in Washington, said California's problem about newcomers on welfare would best be resolved by uniform national benefits.
She said she believed the inequities of the current state-by-state benefits would be part of the discussion when the Clinton Administration tries to enact new welfare legislation.
But Ms. Sawhill predicted that there would be fierce resistance to designing a true national welfare program. "There may be too many gainers and losers, too much disruption of the existing system," she said. "It may not be politically possible."

HEADLINE: Big-Ticket Orders Drop, But Spending Increases

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
A huge drop in aircraft sales pushed durable goods orders down 1.9 percent in November, but Americans increased their spending as their incomes continued to rise, the Government reported today.
The Commerce Department said that if the volatile aircraft component was excluded, orders for durable goods -- items like trucks and transformers that are expected to last more than three years -- would have risen. 
 Orders totaled a seasonally adjusted $122.9 billion, down from a revised $125.3 billion in October, the department said. The revision meant that orders in October jumped 4.6 percent, rather than the 3.9 percent advance in the department's initial estimate.
In a second report, the department said personal incomes rose two-tenths of a percent in November, to $5.15 trillion at a seasonally adjusted annual rate from $5.14 trillion a month earlier.
But the report said the November increase was held down by a large decrease in farm subsidies and by several other special factors. Excluding the special factors, incomes rose eight-tenths of a percent, mostly because of an increase in wages and salaries.
The report also said consumer spending increased five-tenths of a percent in November, to an annual rate of $4.2 trillion, up from $4.17 trillion in October. Consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of economic activity and is the main force behind the economic recovery.
But the difference between spending and incomes meant that Americans' savings rate in November fell to 4.2 percent from 4.6 percent a month earlier. It was the lowest since the rate was 4 percent in October 1990.
In October, durable goods orders were helped by a 21.3 percent surge in transportation equipment. But in November, transportation orders tumbled 10.2 percent. The department said the drop in aircraft orders more than offset an increase in orders for motor vehicles. Excluding the transportation sector, overall orders for durable goods rose 1 percent.
Shipments of durable goods increased 1.9 percent, to a record $127.5 billion, and wiped out a decline of two-tenths of a percent a month earlier.
As a result, the backlog of unfilled orders fell 1 percent. It was the 14th decline in the backlog in 15 months and suggested that factories' work forces were having little trouble keeping up with new orders, an indication that hiring for factory jobs will not increase soon.
Excluding aircraft, orders for nonmilitary capital goods edged up three-tenths of a percent in November after declining 1.8 percent the previous month. These orders often are a gauge of manufacturing plans to expand and modernize.
Orders for industrial machinery and equipment rose 4.6 percent after a decrease of 2.7 percent in October. But electronic and other electrical equipment orders fell 3.5 percent, erasing a 2.3 percent gain in October.
Orders for military equipment dropped 6.8 percent after soaring 44.4 percent a month earlier. They had plunged 20 percent in September. Excluding military sales, orders fell 1.6 percent.
In the other report, the department revised the October income gain to 1.1 percent, from 1 percent. In November, disposable income -- income after taxes -- rose a tenth of a percent, after jumping 1.2 percent in October.

HEADLINE: Venture Capital: Looking for Stars

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
Richard Kramlich invests in fledgling companies that he says typically start out as "three guys and a dream." He is one of America's leading venture capitalists, and while the entrepreneurial dreams he backs are risky, the successful ones can be incubators of new technology and new jobs.
When Mr. Kramlich and his colleagues at New Enterprise Associates, a San Francisco-based partnership, put money in a company, it stays there for five years or more. They sit on the boards of the companies they invest in. They help with marketing plans and product designs -- they even interview job applicants. 
 "Our fate is totally tied up with these companies," Mr. Kramlich said. "We are partners with them."
 
 
Proposed Tax Breaks
 To Bill Clinton, this is capitalism working the way it is supposed to, aided by a very different breed of American financier than the Wall Street deal maker of the 80's. The President-elect is betting on people like Mr. Kramlich to help build what he calls a "21st-century economy" filled with high-tech industries and high-wage jobs -- and he is planning tax breaks to ease their way.
Mr. Clinton's proposed new enterprise tax cut would exclude from taxes half the capital gains on investments in new businesses held for more than five years. The idea is to stimulate the entrepreneurial side of the American economy by increasing the rewards for venture capitalists and individual investors in start-up companies, the "angels" Mr. Clinton has praised as "those with the patience, the courage and the determination to invest in new businesses that create new jobs."
"It could open up enormous amounts to seed capital for new businesses," William Wetzel, director of the Center for Venture Research at the University of New Hampshire, said. "And it would be the sort of patient capital that young companies need."
Skeptics question whether the new incentives alone will have the desired effect. The general health of the economy, industry trends, other taxes and regulatory costs are all considerations for prospective entrepreneurs, and could discourage them from starting up despite the tax cut, warns William Sahlman of the Harvard Business School.
 Yet the new enterprise tax cut seems likely to face little opposition. Mr. Clinton's friend, Senator Dale L. Bumpers of Arkansas, has sponsored similar legislation and it has wide support in Congress. It will no longer face a Presidential veto; President Bush favored tax breaks on all investment profits.
The Clinton tax cut, by contrast, is aimed at long-term investment in small business, which creates two- thirds of the new jobs in the American economy. And the Government revenue lost would be slight in the near term because the tax break would only apply to capital gains on investments held for five years or more.
Many economists question the wisdom of this fine-tuning of tax incentives, as did the Reagan Administration, which strove to simplify the system in the Tax Reform Act of 1986. But it has certainly won Mr. Clinton support among the groups that would most benefit -- venture capitalists and high-tech entrepreneurs. About 130 of them, including Mr. Kramlich, gathered at a fund-raising dinner in San Francisco last September that brought in $300,000 for Mr. Clinton.
Other Clinton tax proposals like increasing taxes on high-income individuals and a surtax on millionaires would hurt many of the entrepreneurs and investors. But the overall impact of the Clinton policies would be to take money out of their pockets and put it into their businesses -- a trade-off they welcome.
 
 
'On the Right Track'
 "Clinton is on the right track in putting investment incentives behind the growth sector of the economy," Mr. Kramlich said.
The venture-capital firms are the aristocrats of start-up financing, and big names in the field include Mr. Kramlich's New Enterprise Associates, Venrock Associates in New York, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers in Palo Alto, Calif., Institutional Venture Partners in Menlo Park, Calif., and Sevin Rosen Bayless in Dallas.
Half of all new companies go under within two years. But the venture funds can improve the odds by being very picky. They are searching for the next crop of rising stars of corporate America, and they have backed success stories like Intel, Apple Computer, Microsoft, Genentech and Federal Express.
Once pools of funds from wealthy individuals -- Venrock, for example, is the venture arm of the Rockefeller family -- the venture-capital industry has grown sharply over the last two decades, thanks to the arrival of institutional money like pension funds. Today, there are more than 600 venture-capital firms with $32 billion invested in thousands of companies.
 
 
'Angel' Investing
 The second tier of start-up financing comes from so-called angels, an estimated 250,000 individual investors who put their personal savings into companies. Where the big venture-capital funds have offices across the country, angel investing tends to be a local or regional affair, a successful entrepreneur taking a gamble on a neighbor's new business or a friend's recommendation. And while a typical venture-capital investment might be $2 million or more, angel stakes are far smaller, from a few thousand dollars to half a million. Yet the total volume of angel investment is estimated at five times the amount of venture-capital funds.
Many investors have a foot in both camps. In 1978, when the start-up hat was being passed among a half-dozen individual investors for a new computer company in Silicon Valley, Mr. Kramlich dipped into his own pocket and put in $22,500. The company was Apple Computer, and six years later his stake was worth $5 million.
The pace of both venture-capital and angel investment fell after the 1986 tax reform took effect, eliminating the lower tax rate on capital gains compared with ordinary income. For example, venture-capital investment fell from roughly $4 billion in 1987 to under $1.4 billion last year, according to Venture Economics, a research group. This year, with the economy improving a bit, venture investments are picking up somewhat, running at a rate of $2 billion for 1992.
Economists debate how much effect tax breaks have on start-up financing, but venture-capital veterans have no doubt that the impact is significant. "The tax code is our industrial policy," said Jon Bayless of Sevin Rosen Bayless. "And you need incentives to encourage people to take the extra risk."
 
 
Pension Funds
 And Congressional tax experts are examining how to extend the proposed tax incentive for start-up investment to tax-exempt pension funds, which supply about half of all venture capital. One proposal is to apply the tax break to pension payouts that result from venture investments held more than five years. For example, if 5 percent of a pension fund's proceeds result from start-up investments, then the retirees would not have to pay income tax on 5 percent of their pension income.
The tax incentives are intended to accelerate the renewal of the American economy, as fast-growing new companies add jobs while big companies continue to cut back. For example, a survey of 428 venture-backed companies by Venture Economics and Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, found that they created 92,500 jobs from 1985 to 1991; over the same period, the big Fortune 500 companies cut their payrolls by 2 million people. And the smaller companies' research and development spending was, proportionately, twice as much as that of the big companies.
Mr. Kramlich, who is 57, had his first brush with the entrepreneurial side of the American economy more than four decades ago, as an 11-year-old selling light bulbs from his basement in Green Bay, Wis. After he graduated from the Harvard Business School, he tried a brief stint in corporate America but he soon departed for the more exhilarating arena of start-ups.
New Enterprise Associates manages venture funds of nearly $700 million invested in 140 companies. Besides San Francisco, it has California offices in Los Angeles, Menlo Park and Palo Alto; it also has offices in Baltimore, New York, Dallas and Cleveland.
 
 
Innovative Products
 Mr. Kramlich is looking for people with innovative products in promising industries like Syed Iftikar, founder of Syquest Technology Inc. That company, based in Fremont, Calif., makes specialized computer disk drives and cartridges able to store vast amounts of data on a single three-inch disk. The Syquest products are used in fields like desktop publishing, where huge capacity is needed for storing computer-generated images. "Syquest has a unique product in a commodity field -- that's what attracted us," Mr. Kramlich said.
Founded in 1982, Syquest received $1 million the following year in venture capital from New Enterprise Associates and $3 million from other venture investors. Later, New Enterprise increased its investment to nearly $6 million.
Over the years, Mr. Iftikar said, Mr. Kramlich has done everything for Syquest from getting in touch with potential customers to interviewing prospective employees.
The attention has paid off. In the year ended Sept. 30, Syquest's profits more than doubled to $13.4 million while its sales rose 52 percent, to $175 million. Today, the company employs 1,061 people, up from 370 a year ago. Mr. Iftikar expects the work force to reach 2,000 a year from now.
 
 
Winning Investment
 New Enterprise Associates made its first investment in the Pyxis Corporation in 1988, when the start-up company's assets amounted to little more than Ron Taylor, the founder, and an assistant working out of a tiny office in San Diego. Over the next three years, New Enterprise invested a total of $2.6 million; the total investment of angel and venture funds in Pyxis is $25 million.
Pyxis -- which makes computerized machines that dispense drugs and surgical equipment for hospitals, and automates inventory management, billing and reordering -- sold its shares to the public in an initial offering earlier this year. New Enterprise's $2.6 million investment is worth about $50 million. By bringing in venture investors, Mr. Taylor, the 45-year-old founder, now owns only 5 percent of his company.
"But without them, I'd have 100 percent of nothing," he said. "My 5 percent is worth $30 million. So I'm going to complain?"

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields Are Higher for Money Market Funds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered by tax-exempt and taxable money market funds were higher in the latest week, pushed up by seasonal factors.
Analysts at IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report, which surveys fund rates, said one reason for the upward pressure on rates at this time of year is that some investors sell holdings for cash. 
 Walter S. Frank, chief economist at IBC/Donoghue's, said another factor was the drop in demand for short-term paper, which forced yields higher to attract buyers.
 In the latest reporting week, which ended on Tuesday, tax-exempt yields rose modestly while assets of tax-exempt funds fell by $743 million, to a total of $99.9 billion.
The average number of days left to maturity of securities held in tax-free-fund portfolios remained unchanged, at 61.
The average seven-day compounded yield for tax-exempt funds rose 24 basis points, to 2.36 percent, while the average seven-day simple yield rose by the same amount, to 2.33 percent. Donoghue's statisticians calculated that over a 30-day period, the compounded yield has averaged 2.20 percent and the simple yield 2.18 percent.
Not assuming state taxes, the taxable bond equivalent of the seven-day compounded yield in the week for someone in the 28 percent tax bracket is about 3.28 percent, and about 3.42 percent for those in a 31 percent bracket.
 
 
Dreyfus Fund Tops Survey
 From its survey of tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million, IBC/Donoghue's said the Dreyfus Basic Municipal Money Market fund outperformed the others, with a 3.09 percent yield.
Assets of taxable money market funds declined by $800 million in the week that ended yesterday, to a total of $477.3 billion. Assets of institutional funds were up by $1.4 billion and retail funds declined $2.2 billion.
Donoghue's analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in taxable money market portfolios remained unchanged at 59 days as portfolio managers shortened maturities to take advantage of high year-end yields.
The Olde Premium Plus Money Market Series, distributed by Olde Asset Management Inc. of Detroit was the top-yielding general-purpose fund among those with assets of more than $100 million. The fund was yielding 3.78 percent for the week.
In government-only money market funds, United Services Government Securities Savings fund, distributed by United Services of San Antonio, was the leader at 3.81 percent.
As a comparative measurement, bank money market accounts, which compete directly with funds, remained unchanged despite seasonal pressures. They are still at 2.76 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Vehicle Sales 16% Higher In Midmonth

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Sales of cars and light trucks built in North America surged by more than 16 percent for the 10 days in mid-December compared with last year's period, auto makers reported yesterday. But analysts cautioned against reading too much into the year-over-year comparison, because sales last December were so sluggish.
Nevertheless, the improvement in sales, which was much more pronounced for light trucks than for cars, continues an upward trend that began more than a year ago. 
 "Sales are in the 15th month of a moderate recovery," said Ronald A. Glantz, an automotive analyst at Dean Witter. "Since the first 10-day selling period in October 1991, sales have grown at a 17 percent compound annual rate. I'll take that."
The improving auto sales figures came on a day when the Commerce Department reported that new orders for durable goods had fallen 1.9 percent in November, mostly from a decline in aircraft sales.
 
Ford-Honda Competition Intense
 Mr. Glantz and other analysts said they expected sales to get a big boost during the last 10 days of the month, due in large part to intense competition between the Ford Motor Company and Honda Motor Company for boasting rights to the top-selling car in America.
Ford is reportedly offering discounts of as much as $2,600 on its Taurus models, which currently run a close second to Honda's Accord.
Honda has extended a promotion that allows customers to lease Accords for as little as $199 a month for five years.
Ford, which typically releases a model-by-model sales breakout every 10 days, did not do so yesterday. But its car sales were up nearly 40 percent from the comparable period last year.
Honda's domestic car sales dipped by a slight three-tenths of 1 percent.
The fight between Ford and Honda "is adding to the sales picture at the end of the year, and there certainly will be some payback in January," said Harvey Heinbach, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. "But we still think this is an improving trend."
Car sales during the period totaled 6.2 million at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, compared with 5.3 million during the period a year earlier. But the sales rate dipped a little from the 6.48 million recorded during the first 10 days of December.
Cars considered to be domestically built include those assembled in Canada and Mexico, as well as those built in North American plants by Japanese companies.
 
Sales of Light Trucks Are Strong
 Big Three manufacturers reported strong sales of light trucks during the period. During the middle 10 days of December, light trucks, which include pickups, mini-vans and sport utility vehicles, sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.3 million.
Gains were particularly robust at Chrysler, where light-truck sales increased by more than 40 percent from a year ago, according to estimates from Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry publication. General Motors and Ford both saw truck sales rise more than 16 percent.
But General Motors was less successful in selling its cars, as sales dipped 2.6 percent, to 49,222 units. Continuing a trend that began last month, during the middle 10 days of December, combined sales of Ford and Chrysler cars exceeded General Motors' total.
"General Motors is losing market share to Ford and Chrysler," Mr. Heinbach said. "That trend is apparent in the truck market as well, and we think that will continue to be the case as G.M. consolidates and concentrates on profitability."
Car sales at the Chrysler Corporation were 14,400 units, up 21.7 percent from a year ago, according to estimates by Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry publication. Chrysler does not report 10-day sales figures.
The 10-day period was mixed for for transplanted foreign auto makers.
At Toyota USA, sales of domestically built cars fell nearly 14 pecent, to 5,828 units. But sales at Nissan USA were up nearly 50 percent, and Mazda USA reported a gain of 45 percent.

HEADLINE: Donations to Neediest Cases Running Behind Last Year's

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund passed the $2 million mark yesterday, but it is still falling significantly behind last year's record campaign, which raised more than $5 million. Despite numerous donations from people like Emanuel A. Sprung of Manhattan, who sent $10 for his 47th contribution in a row, the fund has taken in about $200,000 less than it had by this date in 1991.
Arthur Gelb, president of The New York Times Company Foundation, which administers the fund, said he was hopeful that a surge of post-holiday donations would make up the shortfall before the campaign ends on Feb. 28. But officials at the seven charities assisted by the fund fear that if contributions do not pick up, they may have to curtail or even eliminate programs that are helping thousands of people who lack food, clothing, shelter and health care. 
 The officials said their own fund-raising campaigns, which they run independently of the Neediest Cases, were also facing difficulties. They added, though, that it was too early to predict how their appeals would end because the last two weeks of the year often bring a burst of donations.
One of the seven charities, the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, has received several million dollars less than last year, said Stephen Solender, its executive vice president. Mr. Solender attributed the decline to two factors: a sharp drop in donations from executives in the depressed real-estate industry and a decrease in donations from middle-class people affected by the recession.
 
'People Are More Insecure'
 "It is more difficult for the middle class to maintain their quality of life, so they are more conservative in their charitable giving," he said. "People are more insecure about the future."
Philip Coltoff, executive director of the Children's Aid Society, another Neediest Cases charity, said that many people had expected the economy to pick up this year and were discouraged when there were few signs of growth, particularly in the New York region.
"There is the sense that maybe this economy is not going to turn around," he said. "And when people read about how many layoffs I.B.M. is planning, that sends shock waves. It's very frightening and people become a little more nervous."
Donations to the Children's Aid Society's general fund are down about 6 percent, Mr. Coltoff said. The Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service took in about 20 percent less at a recent fund-raising dinner than it did last year, said Donna Santarsiero, its executive director.
"We're worried in terms of the coming months," Ms. Santarsiero said. "I think as our government revenues continue to fall behind, there is going to be a need for all social services agencies to put more and more pressure on all the existing sources of private support. We're all tapping from what is not an infinite pot of resources."
But Ms. Santarsiero she said she believed that donations would rebound. "In tough times," she said, "people feel that if they can give at all, they will."

HEADLINE: New York High Court Upholds Tax on Other States' Residents

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
New York State can continue to tax out-of-state commuters at a rate based on their total family income, rather than just on what they earn in New York, the state's highest court has ruled.
A New Jersey couple, Lawrence and Barbara Brady of Aberdeen, had filed suit, contending that it was unconsitutional for New York to tax them at a rate based on the family's joint income because Mrs. Brady works in New Jersey. 
 But in a 4-to-1 ruling written by Judge Judith S. Kaye, the Court of Appeals said: "Plaintiffs' real quarrel, in the end, is with the graduated tax. A system of progressive taxation apportions the tax burden based on ability to pay -- higher income taxpayers can pay more and are, therefore, taxed at a higher rate than lower income taxpayers. This system does not implicate the State or Federal Constitutions so long as the rates are applied, as here, in a non-discriminatory manner and only to taxable New York income."
The Bradys' lawyer, David Weinstein, said he was considering an appeal to the United States Supreme Court.
"The claim that we think the Court of Appeals did not properly address," he said, "is that New York taxes one individual's income based on a rate fixed by that person's total income and that person's spouse's income, even though New York courts have held that it's unconstitutional to compel a nonresident spouse to file a joint return." But New York's Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, James W. Wetzler, said: "In a progressive tax system, it appears fairer to us to look at the taxpayer's overall economic condition. Otherwise, a millionaire can end up being treated the same as a middle-income taxpayer."
Mr. Wetzler added that when New York adopted the system in 1987, "There were vehement objections from both New Jersey and Connecticut, threats of retaliation."
Pointing out that Connecticut included the same system when it adopted its income tax last year, and that the New Jersey Assembly passed a bill last week mandating use of the system, Commissioner Wetzler said, "I think it's ironic that vehement protest has turned to imitation."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Manages Advance, With Trading Desks Quiet

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced in a dull session yesterday, with the trading desks quiet because of Christmas holiday vacations and the financial markets closed in Japan for the Emperor's birthday.
Gold rose slightly. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery was up 70 cents an ounce to close at $332.90. At the Republic National Bank of New York, gold was quoted at $332.85, up 55 cents. 
 The latest Commerce Department reports on durable goods orders and personal income trends in November ignited little excitement on currency trading desks, said Hugh Walsh, assistant vice president at Algemene Bank Nederland in New York.
Corporate economists said the reports that durable goods orders fell 1.9 percent in November while personal incomes rose two-tenths of 1 percent were within expectations.
But the dollar was buoyed by anticipation that Germany might cut interest rates in the coming months. On Tuesday, the president of the Bundesbank said Germany's long-term bond rates could fall a full percentage point in the current environment of declining rates worldwide.
Some currency traders say a cut in German rates will only encourage further buying of the dollar, which they view favorably in light of the improving United States economy.
In Europe, the dollar closed at 1.5945 German marks, up from 1.5875 late Tuesday. Later in New York, the dollar closed at 1.5950 marks, up from 1.5895 marks late Tuesday.
Otherwise, traders described very thin dealings.
In London, the dollar was quoted at 123.85 yen, up from 123.13 at Tuesday's close in Tokyo. At the closing in New York, the dollar was quoted at 123.85 yen, up from 123.75 yen late Tuesday.
The British pound fell to $1.5260, from $1.5365 late Tuesday. In New York, the pound closed at $1.5265, less expensive than $1.5370 late Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.4440 Swiss francs, up from 1.4415; 5.4415 French francs, up from 5.4205; 1,423.00 Italian lire, up from 1,422.00, and 1.26025 Canadian dollars, down from 1.26195.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Doing Well By Doing Good

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
MESSAGE to Bill Clinton: Looking for an easy $40 billion to $50 billion a year to pay for expanded health insurance coverage, or perhaps all those ambitious plans to increase productivity? Look again at tobacco taxes.
That is what a coalition of antismoking groups led by the American Medical Association is likely to advise the President-elect when it meets next month in Washington. And while the economic case for a radical increase in tobacco levies -- say, to the Canadian level of more than $3 a pack -- is a bit problematic, the politics and, arguably, the morality are alluring. "It's a case of doing well by doing good," concludes Kenneth Warner, an economist at the University of Michigan's School of Public Health. 
 Why a monster tobacco tax? Start with the money. The Advocacy Institute, a nonprofit lobbying group in Washington, estimates that adding $2 a pack on top of the 46-cent average tax collected in 1991 would bring in $35 billion a year. And while the tobacco industry is obviously prepared to fight, the success of big tax initiatives in California and Massachusetts in recent years suggest its power is on the wane.
Then, too, there is the fact that tobacco is taxed relatively lightly. The average price at the checkout counter has tripled since 1979, topping $1.80 a pack. But Jeffrey Harris, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a practicing physician, notes that only about 25 cents of the increase went to state and Federal coffers. The rest was pocketed by manufacturers and wholesalers, as competition within the highly concentrated tobacco industry apparently failed to check a stampede for higher profits.
Were revenue the only consideration, it would be just as effective to tax bread. What makes tobacco different, of course, is that it is a health hazard. And in both the California and Massachusetts tax initiatives, much was made of the financial burden smokers place on others.
This "externalities" argument is not cut and dried. Smokers do get sicker earlier than non-smokers: Tom Hodgson, the chief economist at the National Center for Health Statistics, estimates that smoking will add $500 billion to the current generation's health insurance bill.
But smokers also die younger, and thus effectively subsidize the pensions of nonsmokers. Willard Manning, an economist at the University of Minnesota's School of Public Health, calculates that on balance smoking costs nonsmokers about 15 cents a pack -- less than the current average tax.
Mr. Warner believes the Manning estimate greatly underestimates this external cost because it uses too low a figure for death and illness caused by secondary inhalation.
In any event, many economists who follow the smoking debate think the externalities question is a diversion from the more fundamental moral issue of deterring addictive, self-destructive behavior.
Cigarette taxes are apparently a very effective way to induce people to quit smoking, or never to become addicted in the first place. In Canada, the near-tripling of prices over the last decade (to a whopping $5.75 a pack) helped to reduce the number of cigarettes smoked by about 40 percent. And the recent experience in California, which raised the tax by 25 cents in 1989, has also had an impact. Theodore Keeler, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, estimated that the resulting 23 percent price increase would ultimately reduce consumption by 10 to 12 percent.
Not surprisingly, low-income individuals in general and teen-agers in particular are most easily deterred by high prices. A variety of studies suggest that a 10 percent increase in price reduces teen-age smoking by about 10 percent.
That is good news if the objective is to prevent children from getting hooked. But the tobacco industry has made much of the inequity of further taxing relatively poor adult smokers.
The poor and near-poor do indeed spend a disproportionate share of their incomes on cigarettes. Dr. Harris does not, however, think it follows that low-income Americans would be hurt by higher taxes. If the smoking tax is regressive, he points out, the financial benefits of inducing people to quit must be progressive. And the fate spared those induced to quit is especially dire. "Being sick is bad," argues Dr. Harris; "being sick and poor is much worse."
A Federal cigarette tax increase beyond the token 4 cents a pack scheduled for next month would not be simple to push through Congress. But, then, neither would any other revenue measure. Moreover, a big cigarette levy might be made palatable by earmarking the revenue. The money might, for example, be used to subsidize health insurance for those not quite poor enough to qualify for Medicaid.
The economic link between smoking costs and health insurance may be fuzzy. But with the Treasury empty and Mr. Clinton scrambling to fill it, a little fuzz might be just what the doctor ordered.

HEADLINE: South of Marrakesh, A New/Old Casbah

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

DATELINE: TAMADOT, Morocco

 BODY:
AN invitation to Luciano Tempo's casbah is not a line out of an old grade B movie. But a visit to Kasbah Tamadot, a splendid villa in the mountains south of Marrakesh, is an opportunity to experience the richness of Moroccan style and hospitality.
Casbahs are to Morocco what castles were to medieval Europe: fortified dwellings for nobility, with high, crenelated walls, towers and interior courtyards. Ruined casbahs, some deserted and some inhabited by squatters, dot the landscape, especially here in southern Morocco. 
 But unlike medieval castles, casbahs are still being built. New ones, or clusters of casbah-like dwellings often made of adobe, the sun-dried clay suited to a hot dry climate, are constructed alongside old, crumbling ones that have not withstood time and the elements.
Mr. Tempo's casbah is an exceptional example, a highly individualistic indulgence in comfort and luxury. Every room and surface is a feast for the eyes. While the ensemble pays homage to traditional Moroccan style, the details are pure Luciano Tempo.
The tall, aristocratic-looking Mr. Tempo, 56, is a native of Venice who has been a designer and antiques dealer in Carmel, Calif., for 30 years. His personal style is restlessly eclectic, ready to juxtapose antiques and artifacts in dizzying profusion, but always with a sense of proportion rather than of mere clutter.
In his casbah, the dining-room ceiling is bordered with 17th-century Burmese prayer books. Silver Berber wedding-belt buckles adorned with the auspicious hand of Fatima are used as napkin rings. A pair of enormous bronze Thai fish stand guard at the edge of a reflecting pool in the central courtyard, a playful response to the golden carp swimming in it.
About four years ago, Mr. Tempo decided to live in Morocco, a country he had once visited briefly. "I had just lost the companion of my life," he said, "and I needed a radical change." He tried Bali but could not tolerate the tropical heat and humidity and the insects. Morocco was next on his list.
In Tamadot he has no telephone and no fax. He has a manager to run Luciano's Antiques, his business in California.
While he was in Marrakesh, he drove out to Asni, a town about an hour south, in a river valley at the edge of the high Atlas Mountains, an area popular with tourists. In Tamadot, a village nearby, a house that was beautifully set on a promontory caught his eye.
"I saw this typical flat-roofed adobe house, surrounded by olive trees and red earth, that had been built at the turn of the century and was now abandoned, in ruins," he said. "I have a deep affection for things that are crumbling. Within two hours I bought it." He said he paid considerably less than the nearly $200,000 it eventually cost him to bring in electricity and to dig three wells.
"I hired an architect from Marrakesh, who took one look and advised me to tear it down and start from scratch," Mr. Tempo said. "I paid him for the day and proceeded to do the work myself, actually designing the house as I went along."
He calls the original structure the "soul of this house," and used as much of it as possible, shoring it up with concrete pilings and solid posts two feet square. Instead of adobe, the weatherproof exterior is cement, colored the same reddish shade as adobe and carved, while still wet, with fanciful interpretations of typical geometric Berber motifs.
The multilevel house has several living rooms, a vast dining room, two kitchens, the central courtyard with the reflecting pool, another courtyard with a fountain, a tower for storage and another fitted with exercise equipment, and many terraces. The house has a number of small domes decorated with spires with metal prayer balls of the kind seen on minarets.
Mr. Tempo lives alone, but he built 12 bedrooms. "I made it this large because I have a lot of friends who can't afford to stay in fancy hotels," he said. "I bring them here, and they enrich my life."
His hospitality is thoroughly Moroccan in its lavishness. Morocco is a country where there's always enough couscous on the platter to share with unexpected guests and where the typical living room or dining room, lined with couches, can easily become impromptu guest quarters. But in Mr. Tempo's casbah, guests are likely to be served excellent ravioli mastered by his Moroccan cook and to spend the night in an exotically decorated bedroom. Dennis Hopper, the actor, was a recent guest.
One bedroom ceiling is adorned with hundreds of small round, oval and rectangular Berber metal-and-enamel boxes, the kind that are routinely sold in the souks for about $2 each to those who can bargain well. "I could not find an old painted ceiling suitable to install in this room, so I decided to use the boxes," Mr. Tempo said. "I bought 1,500 of them."
The beds are covered with quilts that Mr. Tempo had made in India from strips of discarded saris. The wall behind one bed is punctuated with richly sculptured Moorish-style niches. The niches accommodate not one but a collection of rich green jugs, some antique, some modern, from Tamgrout, in southern Morocco.
And everywhere, there are bronze wall sconces and holders for fat beeswax candles. "Even though there is electricity, at night I prefer candlelight," Mr. Tempo said. The electricity is used to operate the VCR that plays movies for entertainment and to run the pair of General Electric refrigerators in the kitchen.
The decorative bronzes are typical of the designs by Mr. Tempo that mix styles and materials. They are sold in Luciano's Antiques; in Marco Polo, an antiques shop in Marrakesh that he helped establish, and through designers. They are made for him in a foundry in Thailand.
The casbah took a mere seven months to build, an accomplishment that required 120 workers. The project included doing several rooms more than once, and redoing some decorations that did not work out as planned. "When they laid the tile around the pool, they set it in plaster, not cement, and the first time it rained the tiles came off the walls and the ceilings below collapsed," he said. "I wound up employing so many people that the economy of the little village of Tamadot boomed. In fact, there were an unprecedented number of weddings that summer because so many people had steady jobs. Now there are a lot of babies named Luciano."
To a certain extent, Mr. Tempo has adopted the village, helping to repair the school and building a house to attract a nurse to the village. "I send one of my people, and he does the job," he said. "That way, if I spend a dollar, I get a dollar's worth."
His staff of 15 runs the house and tends the gardens on his two acres of land, the maximum a foreigner is allowed to own in Morocco. But the view, from 4,500 feet, is stunning and vast, uninterrupted by window coverings. "I used mirrored glass so no one could look in," he said.
Because winter in the mountains can be harsh and summer stifling, Mr. Tempo now spends about half the year at Kasbah Tamadot, three months in the spring and three months in the fall. "I did everything I wanted in this house," he said.
