HEADLINE: Washington Awaits Era of a Hotter Date

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
DEBBIE COHEN realized on election night that young Democrats would soon flood into Washington, and it pleased her. Not only would the economy improve, she reasoned, but she might also finally get a good date.
"People my generation can relate to are coming to town," said the 24-year-old staff assistant to Senator John Glenn (D-Ohio). "I mean, these are the people who played Fleetwood Mac at their convention." 
 Democrats will now control the White House, Congress and singles bars, and even conservatives begrudgingly admit that this development may pump life into what most consider one of the toughest dating scenes in the nation.
"My dating life under Bush has been pretty lousy," said David Bohley, 24, a law fellow for the Senate Commerce Committee, over lunch in the Dirksen Senate Office Building on Capitol Hill. "I can only hope that this change will be for the better."
Sure, there will still be plenty of lawyers who talk tort over dessert. But there will also be tree huggers, idealists and perhaps a cajun cook or two. Not unlike the first day of high school, January will bring new and younger faces, and with them, phone numbers.
"It is very difficult for people to date in D.C.," said Laurie Handlers, the manager of Georgetown Connection, a dating service here. "People are very busy, and it is hard to maintain relationships. It is kind of like you're on a plane and you're trying to have a relationship, and by the time you've landed, that person is engaged to someone else."
Women have the toughest time. Their complaints about the slim pickings among Washington men are second only to everyone's laments about the dearth of good pizza.
And complain they do. About the lawyers. (A Washington joke: 1 in 20 of the residents is a lawyer. One in 5 is dating one). About the "polichat" (one part small talk, one part public-policy debate). About the stuffiness and self-importance of Washington men and the monogamous relationship many have with their careers.
This situation, of course, will not not be so easy to change as the curtains in the White House salon. It is more a question of atmosphere, many say. "Bill and Al are sexy," said Lisa DePaulo, 31, who until recently was a senior editor at Washingtonian magazine, where she monitored the dating scene. "Washington men need role models. You look at the campaign staff and you hope the whole Administration will be like that. Those sunglasses, the convertibles, the Elvis thing! How can you compare that to horseshoes and fishing?"
Ms. Handlers, the matchmaker, said that the recession put a heavy damper on dating. People are less likely to invest funds in risky dates, she said. And the tired and frustrated are likely to stay home and watch "Fried Green Tomatoes" on their VCR's, which keeps them forever out of the loop.
"There is a real seriousness here about dating, and the economy influences how much they are willing to spend," Ms. Handlers said. "Now, maybe people will be less fearful about their incomes. I have also noticed a general lightening up since the election, which may help."
Even Republicans can't argue against a fiscally sound fling. "This Administration will bring the cheap date back into fashion," said Sarah Brown, a receptionist and self-proclaimed Republican. "I think barbecue. I think Arkansas. I think of people being more laid back."
Other Republicans agree, at least on the menu change. "Things will probably be less formal now," said Rebecca Escobales, 21, a staff assistant to Representative Michael Bilirakis, Republican of Florida. "People will be doing Southern restaurants instead of, say, nouveau Italian."
Ms. Escobales, who will continue to vote to the right, said that nonetheless she found this political polarity to be "sparky."
In some ways dating may now reflect the best of the campaign's debates. "People on dates will be talking about the issues now," said Charlie Peters, editor of the Washington Monthly and a Washington resident for 31 years. "They will be talking about health-care reform, things like that. People will be looking to find intellectual common ground."
Dan (Gunga) Langley, a bartender at LuLu's, one of the most popular singles bars here, has a slightly more visceral take. "There's fresh flesh in town," he said. Mr. Langley notes that the dating scene in Washington is different from that in other towns, mostly because people tend to frequent the bars with friends of the same sex, and leave with them.
If nothing else, people may begin dressing down for cocktail hour, and there is something inherently sexy about that. "When you see Bill Clinton the morning after he wins with his jeans on, it's like the 'Big Chill,' " Ms. DePaulo said. "It changes the spirit in Washington, makes it more relaxed. Jimmy Carter was relaxed, but he was like your favorite uncle. Bill Clinton is more like your hot cousin."
Not everyone in Washington is quick to agree that Democrats make the best dates. "People have the stereotype that Republicans are stuffy and that Democrats are swinging," said John Dutton, a 26-year-old legislative aid to Representative Rod Chandler, Republican of Washington. "There may be some truth to it, but I'm not really sure."
When Mr. Dutton was told that another young Republican in town thought the era of the budget date had come again, any trepidations about liberals at the helm seemed to fade.
"Really!" he said. "What's her name?"

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Leyland Is Not Bitter Over Drain of Talent

BYLINE: By Claire Smith

 BODY:
When you get right down to it, Jim Leyland didn't really ask for a lot. All the Pittsburgh Pirates' manager really wanted for Christmas was his two front-line players.
But a wickedly competitive baseball economy left little more than lumps of coal where Barry Bonds and Doug Drabek used to be. And as everyone knows, in Pittsburgh and points east in Pennsylvania the bottom fell out of the coal and steel markets there a long time ago. 
 To Leyland's credit, though, the manager isn't sitting around moping or wishing a pox on the houses of the San Francisco Giants and the Houston Astros. Times changed, as did the financial backing of those two teams, and so Leyland watched the talent pool of the Pirates, a team that either cannot or will not spend gargantuan sums for ballplayers, be drained substantially.
"It's a touchy subject for me, but I do want to say I'm happy for the players," said Leyland from his Pittsburgh home as he wished one more bit of fortune for the likes of Bonds, who signed a $43.75 million, six-year contract with the Giants. "I wish him well. And I'm happy for the managers who get those kinds of players."
As Leyland speaks, both magnanimity and reality mix and shape the opinions of the manager left behind. High finance, baseball style, Leyland insists, is not his business. Nor is it good practice to mourn the talent lost. After all, Bonds and Drabek aren't the first players he has seen come and go in his 18-year managerial tenure at both the minor league and major league levels.
But Leyland is not going to pretend that he is all that unaffected. Three weeks after witnessing Houston sign Drabek to a $19.5 million, four-year contract and then watching Dusty Baker & Co. inherit the services of Bonds, Leyland does wonder aloud more than ever about the business of baseball.
"It's a little frustrating and I might say even more confusing," Leyland said. "That's because there's a lot of talk in baseball, but the talk and the action haven't gone hand in hand. That's what confuses me."
The talk, of course, is of pleas of poverty and impending doom. It's basic-agreement-renegotiating time for management and the players union. And it does seem that baseball officials are more than ever talking out of both sides of their mouths, spending capriciously on the one hand but talking about needing a new way of doing business with the players so that somehow, someone will save them from themselves.
As ball clubs committed to over $225 million in salaries in a three-day period during baseball's recent winter meetings, one had to wonder facetiously just which clubs are going broke, again? On the other hand, one has to recognize the downsizing and salary dumping going on in places like San Diego and Pittsburgh and Milwaukee. Free agents are being let go by those teams for financial reasons, underlining all the more the "boy who cried wolf" claim that these teams cannot compete.
The Pirates must have some ability to spend; witness the continuing presence of veteran center fielder Andy Van Slyke. But, as Leyland said, no one was surprised to see Bonds settle into the low $40 million range on his multiyear contract.
"And I knew we would not be able to do that," Leyland said. Just as they were not able to keep Bobby Bonilla last winter, nor Sid Bream the winter before. All told, Pittsburgh's major losses these last three winters -- Bonilla, Bonds, Drabek, Jose Lind, Sid Bream, John Smiley, R. J. Reynolds -- were players who carried off contracts or later signed deals worth approximately $100 million.
Even with the slow drain of veterans taking the star power out of Pittsburgh, the Pirates could proudly say they were able to more than manage. The three consecutive National League Eastern Division championships and Leyland's capturing of managing honors this season attest to the extent of the successes. The overriding question for Pittsburgh faithful, for Leyland, for the rest of the division, is whether there is one more special season of magic and enough talent to survive and surprise again?
"We're not down to the bare cupboard," Leyland said. "I'm eager for spring training because I think that we do have some outstanding young kids coming, if their play last September was any indication."
"But," Leyland added, again with admirable realism, "I don't think that anybody in their right mind would pick us to win. We're a long way from where we were last year."
So Leyland will spend the rest of the off season thinking about retooling more than he did after the losses of Smiley and Bonilla and Bream. He knows this time will be different. Leyland, as talented a manager as there is in the game, vows to cope.
"Sure, you miss the players, but you know you have to go on," said Leyland. "Besides, I know they're better off financially. They're O.K. You don't have to feel bad for them. You feel bad for the minor leaguers you have to tell that their careers are over or the major leaguers you have to release. Guys like Doug and Barry, though, they're all right. I mean, they could probably buy a hamburger or two if they had to, right?"
A string of hamburger chains, no doubt. Unfortunately for Pittsburgh, they'll just be doing the buying elsewhere.

HEADLINE: Where to Learn White House Organization

 BODY:
To the Editor:
President-elect Bill Clinton has let it be known that he intends to avoid Jimmy Carter's error of overloading the Washington policy agenda and to emulate Ronald Reagan in pressing for a few initial major accomplishments. But the early signs of how he intends to organize his associates for such purposes suggest he may be in danger of reliving the failures of previous Presidents. His offhand promise to cut the White House staff by 25 percent suggests he has given more attention to the symbolism of White House operations than to the record. 
 The modern American Presidency is profoundly affected by the personality of its incumbent. A White House organization that works for one President might not work for another. A John Kennedy or Bill Clinton would not sit still for an Eisenhower staff system. A Richard Nixon would experience meltdown in the freewheeling contexts in which a Kennedy or Clinton might thrive. Still, White House structure makes a difference.
The underappreciated Gerald R. Ford took office in a glow of approval. Jettisoning the hierarchical Nixon staff system of Watergate infamy, he looked back to Harry S. Truman and attempted to be his own chief of staff. Promptly and without adequate staffing, he pardoned his predecessor, and his support plummeted. Absorbing the lesson, he installed a chief of staff and otherwise perfected an advisory system that contributed to his near victory in the 1976 election.
Kennedy, like Bill Clinton, entered office exhilarated by electoral experience and without national executive experience. Replacing a chief executive two decades his senior, and promising change, he took it for granted that there was little to be gleaned from the governing experience of his predecessors. Before his first 100 days were over, he made a catastrophic decision, authorizing the Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba.
The Bay of Pigs fiasco, as Theodore Sorenson later recollected, left Kennedy "aghast at his own stupidity" and "angry at having been so badly advised." One of Kennedy's first postinauguration actions had been to abolish the National Security Council machinery that Dwight Eisenhower installed to assure the President of the collective wisdom of the experts in his executive agencies. By the end of Kennedy's Presidency, he and his aides had begun to create the kinds of operating procedures that might have served him well from the start.
Valuable lessons in organizing the executive office are to be found even in improbable modern presidencies.
Take Mr. Clinton's proposed Economic National Security Council. Such a body existed, and performed well, in the executive office of President Ford. The able administrator of the Ford Economic Policy Board, Roger B. Porter, is assistant to the President for economic and domestic policy in the Bush White House, where his efforts appear not to have had much effect.
President Bush's domestically passive Presidency proves it is not enough for a President to employ first-rate staff aides. Squabbles over economic policy of the sort that the Ford Economic Policy Board was designed to bring to a head so that they could be resolved in the Oval Office plagued the Bush White House and contributed to President Bush's incoherent re-election campaign.
There are no inexorable laws of White House organization, but there is a body of lore, which, if intelligently used, can help prevent Bill Clinton from making all of his mistakes right away.
 
FRED I. GREENSTEIN
Princeton, N.J., Dec. 7, 1992
 
The writer directs the Woodrow Wilson School program in leadership studies, Princeton University.

HEADLINE: Companies Reducing Benefits Promised for Their Retirees

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
At least 23 large companies have abandoned the health benefits that they were providing to thousands of retired employees. Dozens more have announced that they will not provide coverage for future retirees, and most employers who still offer the benefits are reducing their share of the costs, which have been climbing steeply.
 The companies are rushing to shrink these obligations before Jan. 1, when a new accounting rule goes into effect. The rule forces employers to subtract from their profits the future costs of providing benefits to retirees. 
In the latest such action, the Primerica Corporation, a financial services concern previously known as the American Can Company, set yesterday as the deadline for 7,800 retirees to agree either to pay the full cost of continuing coverage or go without it. The retirees learned of the deadline only three weeks earlier.

 
A Jolt to Retirees
 Groups of retirees from some of those companies, including Primerica, McDonnell Douglas, the aerospace concern, and Unisys, the computer maker, have initiated class-action lawsuits contending that the changes violate the terms of the companies' retirement agreements. A ruling in the Primerica case could come by late January.
 Some retirees were shaken by the turn of events. "They told us, 'Either you take it by Dec. 23 or you drop out and cannot be reinstated,' " said Marie Esposito, a 68-year-old retired American Can executive secretary in Brooklyn. "Was it a scare tactic? If it is, they're doing a good job on me. I'm single. I live alone. I have no one I can turn to."
 Ms. Esposito, who worked at American Can for 19 years, until her department was shut down, said medicine to treat her blood pressure and stomach ulcers costs $177.67 a month, of which she currently pays $17.77. Continuing this coverage would now cost $144 a month, swallowing most of her $240-a-month pension. "I can't swing the $144 for medical coverage, which I desperately need," Ms. Esposito said.

 
Valuing Future Health Costs
 Under the new accounting rule, Financial Accounting Standard 106, employers must put a value on future retiree health costs and combine them with current medical costs as an expense. Previously, companies were required to recognize only the cost of benefits they had actually paid.
 Although the cash expenditure does not increase, the resulting annual expense must be subtracted from income in a company's financial reports. This expense can rise sharply under the new rule, often quadrupling the reported health-care costs for industrial companies that have many older employees or whose retirees were promised generous benefits. The new rule thus has the effect of reducing a company's annual income, a figure that is closely watched by securities analysts and investors. The new accounting rule was intended to make a company's health care liabilities clear to investors. It allows companies to take a single charge against earnings before the first quarter of 1993, or to spread the charges over 20 years.
 As a result of the rule, the Ford Motor Company recently said it would take a $7.5 billion charge against its earnings this year. General Motors has estimated that it must account for $16 billion to $24 billion of benefits.

 
'The Weakest Excuse'
 Advocates for retirees have accused employers of using the new rule as an excuse to shirk their obligations. "Companies have had several years' notice that they would have to comply with the accounting rule," said Cathy Ventrell-Monsees, a workers' rights manager at the American Association of Retired Persons. "To come out in this last quarter of 1992 and say, 'We are compelled to eliminate benefits because of F.A.S. 106 accounting' is the weakest excuse for hurting people just to save money."
 Representative Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat who is a member of the House Select Committee on Aging, has asked the General Accounting Office to investigate the cancellation of retiree health benefits. "My sense is that we're going to see more and more scheming to use F.A.S. 106 and other accounting sleight of hand to dump seniors and get out from under paying health benefits."
 Alain Enthoven, a health economist and professor of management at Stanford University, said that curtailing retiree benefits was "a very unfortunate consequence of costs being out of control." The cutbacks underline the urgency of fixing the health care system, he said.
 Unisys announced in November that it would phase out contributions to the medical plans of its retirees over the next three years, and McDonnell Douglas said in October that it would pay health benefits for salaried retirees from surplus pension funds, but only for the next four years. That will cut in half the approximately $1.2 billion accounting charge that McDonnell Douglas would have had to take.
 In the Primerica case, retirees were told in October that they had to decide whether to accept any of three benefits packages the company had arranged, to take advantage of a group rate. But even under the most expensive of those plans, retirees' medical coverage will be reduced. Instead of $10,000 in free life insurance, they can buy a $2,000 life insurance policy. A Primerica spokeswoman conceded that the new policy would be "expensive."

 
Less Than Chief Was Paid
 Primerica, which is based in New York, has not said how much it would cost to continue to pay retiree benefits, but that had not been a major expense in the past. In 1991, it spent $8.7 million for medical benefits for 7,800 retirees, including the American Can group. That is less than the 1991 compensation package of Primerica's chief executive, Sanford I. Weill, which Graef S. Crystal, the compensation expert, estimates at about $10.2 million in stock options and $2.2 million in salary and bonuses. It is also less than 2 percent of Primerica's profits last year of $478 million on revenues of $6.61 billion.
 Large companies spent $2,345 for each retiree, on average, for health costs in 1991, said Patricia Wilson, a principal with A. Foster Higgins, a benefits consulting firm. That is more than double Primerica's costs, which averaged $1,115 a retiree.
 Like other companies, Primerica had previously tried to shift part of its medical costs to retirees. It began asking retirees to pay more for benefits shortly after Mr. Weill acquired the company in a 1988 merger with his Commercial Credit Group Inc.

 
Raised Monthly Premium
 Primerica raised the monthly premium paid by the American Can retirees to $50, from $5, in January 1989. Trying to block the increase, the retirees and a group of former executives, headed by William F. May, who was American Can's chairman from 1965 to 1980, filed a class-action lawsuit in Federal District Court in Newark charging that they had been assured of receiving the $5-a-month medical package until they died, when their heirs would then get $10,000 in life insurance.
 But Primerica said the terms of the agreement allowed it to change the benefits, and now to terminate them. A booklet describing the health plan said the company "expects to continue this Plan indefinitely, but necessarily reserves the right to amend, modify or discontinue the Plan in the future in conformity with applicable legislation."
 Jack McGoldrick, a retired American Can executive who helped prepare the plan descriptions, said the clause meant only that changes might be made if required by new laws. The next paragraph said that "full consideration will be given to appropriate modification" if the Federal Government changed the Medicare program.
 The company argued that the wording allowed unrestricted changes. In July 1991, Judge Alfred J. Lechner Jr. ruled in Primerica's favor in United States District Court in Newark. He dismissed the retirees' case, citing other court decisions that have invalidated retiree health benefits when an employer has clearly reserved the right to do so. But on June 25, a three-judge panel of the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia unanimously reversed the dismissal, ruling that the clause in the booklet was ambiguous. The appeals court sent the case back to Judge Lechner and told him to determine the facts "as to whether the company promised lifetime fixed-cost benefits to its retirees."
 In early December, after Primerica announced the Dec. 23 deadline for retirees to choose among the three plans to pay their own benefits, lawyers for the retirees asked Judge Lechner to act in the case.

 
Asked for More Time
 The Primerica lawyers said they needed more time to deal with the 28 affidavits submitted by the retirees' lawyers. Saying the request for a hearing on short notice was "outrageous" because of the lengthy documents and legal arguments involved, Judge Lechner scheduled the hearing for mid-January. "Perhaps Christmas Day, you want me to come in here?" he said.
 The retirees appealed to the court in Philadelphia "to order the district judge to take action or to restrain Primerica from making any changes in the plan until the district court acts," said Robert D. Towey, a lawyer with Riker Danzig Scherer Hyland & Perretti in Morristown, N.J. But the appeals court ruled against the retirees last week, leaving the scheduling of the hearing to Judge Lechner.
 Mary McDermott, a spokeswoman for Primerica, said yesterday that 55 percent of the company's retirees had responded by Monday. Primerica sent them a reminder letter this week, she said. Unless the courts rule against Primerica, those who did not respond by the deadline will lose their coverage.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 24, 1992, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Dec. 24 about employers that have been terminating health benefits for retirees misstated the number of people who would be affected at the Primerica Corporation. On Jan. 1, the company stopped contributing to health benefits for 1,600 retirees of the American Can Company, as Primerica was formerly known. A spokeswoman said the company had a total of about 7,800 pensioners, of whom only the American Can retirees were receiving company-subsidized health coverage before Jan. 1. Primerica disputed the figures in a letter dated Jan. 13; this correction was delayed for clarification of the background.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
Clinton Completes Cabinet And Points to Its Diversity: Corporate Lawyer, a Woman, Gets Justice Dept.

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 24

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton finished assembling his Cabinet today, appointing more women and blacks to his inner circle than any previous chief executive and straddling his party's ideological fault lines.
In selecting Zoe Baird, a 40-year-old Connecticut corporate lawyer, to be the the first woman to serve as Attorney General, Mr. Clinton concluded a sometimes hectic selection process in which he named four blacks, three women and two Hispanic men to Cabinet jobs. Two other women were named to positions that Mr. Clinton has pledged to elevate to Cabinet level. 
 "They come from all across America," Mr. Clinton said of his nominees. "From the state capitals and the U.S. Capitol, from the city halls and the board rooms, and the classrooms. They come from diverse backgrounds and we will all be better and stronger for that diversity. I can say with pride that I believe this Cabinet and these other appointees represent the best in America."
 
Delicate Juggling
 The delicate juggling of competing interests that characterized Mr. Clinton's selection process was evident in the group he introduced today. Representative Mike Espy of Mississippi, 39, the choice for Secretary of Agriculture, is black. Bruce Babbitt, the 54-year-old former Governor of Arizona chosen to be Secretary of Interior, was championed by environmental groups. Federico F. Pena, 45, the former Mayor of Denver who would be Secretary of Transportation, is of Mexican descent.
Mickey Kantor, 52, a Los Angeles lawyer who was his campaign chairman, was picked to become United States Trade Representative and Dr. M. Joycelyn Elders, 59, the Arkansas health director, is to become Surgeon General in June when the current Surgeon General, Antonia Novello, steps down.
And John H. Gibbons, the executive director of the Office of Technology Assessment, will be Mr. Clinton's science adviser.
Mr. Clinton's nominees rounded out a selection of advisers who generally prefer a larger role for Government than the country has seen under Republican rule, but who are also less enamored of many Federal spending programs that Democrats have favored in the past.
 
Never Handled a Criminal Case
 Ms. Baird, senior vice president and general counsel of Aetna Life and Casualty in Hartford, began her career in the Justice Department's Office of Legal Counsel in the Carter Administration. At Aetna, she supervises 120 lawyers and $90 million in legal business. She has never handled a criminal case.
"If confirmed by the Senate, I will do everything within my power to be sure that this department will be firm in its prosecution of crime, will be guided by the rule of law and will be committed to the principled and deliberate advancement of civil rights, environmental protection and economic fairness and I pledge to promote the highest standards of excellence and integrity within the department," Ms. Baird said today.
Mr. Clinton and some of his aides acknowledged that the appointment process turned into something of an ordeal as he searched for unconventional appointees who represented an array of ideological and political points of view and background.
The aides said Mr. Clinton's tendency to closely manage decisions that bear his stamp played a crucial role in what seemed a rocky course as Mr. Clinton sought to complete his Cabinet by Christmas.
"If one lesson is to be learned from this process, it's that he will be involved," said Harold Ickes, a Clinton transition aide.
Other Clinton advisers said the process seemed more helter skelter than it actually was. They contended that candidates for a variety of Administration posts misread the President-elect's signals, prematurely making it known that they expected jobs that were later given to others. Senator Tim Wirth of Colorado, for example, told friends he would be Secretary of the Energy, and Brooksley E. Born, a Washington lawyer, expected the Attorney General's post.
 
'We Worked Very Hard'
 "I don't think it's anything they hear," said one Clinton adviser. "It's what they don't hear. Sometimes it's sort of circular. They hope it, people reinforce their belief. As the process goes along, they believe it's true because they read it in the press."
Advisers maintained to the end that the only people who were actually privy to Mr. Clinton's thinking were a small circle that included his wife, Hillary; his new chief of staff, Thomas F. McLarty; his friend and adviser, Bruce Lindsey, and Vice President-elect Al Gore.
Mrs. Clinton attended today's news conference.
"We worked very hard," Mr. Clinton said. "I mean, the President is only one person. Much of this Administration's life will be lived out through the actions of the people that you see on this stage and those that have preceded them. So I thought it was worth the time."
Toward the end of the selection process, a number of organizations representing women, environmentalists and Hispanic groups lobbied Mr. Clinton to include their representatives in the Cabinet.
 
Critics Become Supporters
 "The one thing I think probably concerned him was the interest groups believing that unless they put pressure on him that he wouldn't do what he said he would do," said one adviser who was close to the decision-making process. "The testiness that people noted was a sort of frustration at the prejudgement."
Today, some of the critics became supporters. Eleanor Smeal, the president of the Fund for the Feminist Majority, who had led earlier criticism of Mr. Clinton's pace in selecting women, praised his final choices.
In a statement, Ms. Smeal said the composition of Mr. Clinton's Cabinet constitutes "a step forward for women in breaking the glass ceiling in public leadership."
Mr. Clinton also won praise from environmental groups who had campaigned for Mr. Babbitt, a lawyer who is president of the League of Conservation Voters. Fred Krupp, the executive director of the Environmental Defense Fund, called him the "ideal nominee" and the National Audubon Society called him a "champion of the environment."
 
Pushing Teamwork
 Mr. Clinton said today that the input from the special interest groups was less energetic than he expected and that he considered the last-minute lobbying no more than a request for "a hearing."
But earlier this week, he was more critical of these efforts, saying that demands that he add more women to his Cabinet came from "bean counters" who were interested in forcing him to abide by quotas.
Mr. Clinton said he expected his group to be "more teamwork-oriented" than in past Administrations.
"What I thought about all along the way is how all these people would relate to one another, not just what their individual strengths are, although they are very impressive, but whether they would be able to fit into the economic team, the domestic policy team, the foreign policy team," he said.
Such criteria torpedoed some candidates who thought they had jobs on Mr. Clinton's team. Ms. Born, the Washington lawyer who had told associates on Wednesday that she would be Mr. Clinton's Attorney General, faded as the Clinton investigators began to inquire more about Ms. Baird. One Clinton adviser said Ms. Baird "got stronger and stronger" upon close inspection while other candidates grew weaker.
"She is tough, tenacious and gifted," Mr. Clinton said of Ms. Baird today.
He added, "We concluded we really needed to try to get somebody in there who could put together a team of excellent lawyers, lift morale, solve problems and restore a sense of movement to it within the proper boundaries, and I think she'll be able to do that."
Mr. Clinton failed in one of his stated goals. He was unable to find a Republican for his Cabinet. He said today that one Republican candidate, who aides later identified as John Young, the Hewlett-Packard chairman who was asked to be Secretary of Commerce, decided against joining the Administration.
If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Clinton's Cabinet would also be made up of a number of people who started their ascents in the political and business world at relatively young ages.
Mr. Pena, who would be Transportation Secretary, was elected Mayor of Denver at age 35, after he had already served two terms in the State Legislature.
And Ms. Baird became associate general counsel to President Jimmy Carter in 1980 when she was 28. Four years later, she became a partner at the Washington office of O'Melveny & Myers, the Los Angeles-based law firm headed by Warren M. Christopher, who has been selected as Secretary of State and was Mr. Clinton's transition director.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
Carolco Pictures announced an agreement with M-G-M and Carolco's three biggest investors that would give the struggling Hollywood production company cash to pay its debts and start making movies again. [D1.] 
 Like many U.S. contractors, Boeing is rebuilding weapons instead of making more expensive new ones. The conversion of older weapons into modern versions now appears to account for more than half the military hardware manufactured in America, and the percentage keeps growing. [D1.]
 A $740 million Air Force contract for Zenith Data Systems was delayed, and possibly killed, when a Government panel upheld the latest round of protests from losing bidders. The contract, initially awarded to a Compuadd partnership in 1991, was supposed to have set an example of streamlined Federal procurement. [D1.]
Longtime Wal-Mart suppliers have supported the retailer in a loosely coordinated campaign of newspaper ads responding to an NBC News report that questioned the consistency of Wal-Mart's "Buy America" policy. [D2.]
The head of Shearson's asset-management unit resigned. Jerome Miller, a senior executive vice president, ran a $55 billion operation that includes mutual funds and trusts. [D2.]
Sam Zell is turning to Wall Street for cash to pay off debt. The Chicago real estate executive is seeking Federal approval to sell a major stake in his mobile-home parks business to the public and to issue mortgage-backed securities. [D3.]
Fisher-Price is squarely back in the toys-for-tots market, after learning painfully that there's nothing quite like a grinning telephone or a bubble-blowing sax. [D3.]
Plusher times may be in store for Dakin, a leading maker of gifts and stuffed toys. A menagerie that includes a kindly purple dinosaur is part of the company's strategy for returning to profitability. [D3.]
 
The Economy
Clinton and Congress are committed to reviving U.S. airlines, according to government and industry officials. Little Rock and Capitol Hill are studying proposals that include tax incentives, regulatory relief and global partnerships and persuading foreign governments to give greater access to American carriers. [D1.]
Fed policy makers intended to maintain low interest rates if the economy began to sputter, according to minutes of a mid-November meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee. [D2.] The number of Americans filing new claims for jobless benefits rose a surprising 12,000 in mid-December to the highest level in three weeks, the Government said. [D2.]
 
Markets
Blue-chip stocks closed higher in a pre-Christmas rally fueled by a recovery in shares of I.B.M. and new highs for A.T.& T. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 12.70 points at 3,326.24. HEADLINE: Old Weapons Are Plants' New Work

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
The steel hulls of 12 big Chinook cargo helicopters on the assembly line of the Boeing Company's helicopter factory here have been sanded and burnished so that the silvery metal looks new. But small numbers stenciled in black on the hulls tell a different story. "O22," one says, documenting that this was the 22d Chinook ever built, in 1961. None of the hulls is less than 15 years old.
Like so many military contractors, Boeing Helicopter is increasingly en gaged in the rebuilding and upgrading of old weapons instead of building more expensive new ones. The conversion of old weapons into more modern versions -- rather than simply overhauling them periodically as the Air Force does with the B-52 bomber -- now appears to account for more than half the military hardware manufactured in America, and the percentage keeps growing. 
 But as the numbers grow, so do the questions about whether the economics of such an approach make sense. With military budgets shrinking, rebuilding a Chinook so that it can carry more cargo, or an M-1 Abrams tank so that it is a more deadly weapon, is good business for weapons contractors, especially if it is a question of selling 20 improved weapons rather than only 6 new ones.
 
 
Improvements Are Costly
 The improved weapons, however, sometimes end up costing the Pentagon almost as much as a new weapons system. And while the practice saves money in the short run, weapons experts say it could bring on a crisis in a decade or so when Chinook and Abrams tank hulls -- and the hulls of many other rebuilt weapons -- are too old for yet another upgrade.
"You get in the bind where the oldest model costs so much to run and maintain that you have no money to buy a new system," said Maj. Peter Keating, an Army spokesman.
Congress would then have to choose between raising military spending to purchase new weapons or letting the weapons inventory shrink as worn-out weaponry is scrapped. Neither the Bush Administration nor President-elect Bill Clinton has addressed these issues.
"But right now, we have a lot of existing platforms with years of life in them, so we are looking for upgrades, and that trend will continue," said Robert Hall, a Defense Department spokesman.
The pressure to rebuild weapons has intensified because the cost of new weapons has kept rising. The Pentagon, in effect, covers a weapons maker's costs, negotiating ever-higher amounts to be covered, and then adds a profit on top -- as it has for more than two decades. As a result, the Pentagon has increasingly chosen to rebuild, say, 30 existing weapons rather than purchase 15 more expensive new ones.
The practice has gathered steam since 1987, when spending on weapons procurement began to shrink, after reaching a record $100 billion. Adjusted for inflation, the annual outlay today is about $80 billion.
For Boeing Helicopter, as for many other weapons makers, upgrading weapons has kept factories open. At Boeing's complex along the Delaware River, with its huge gray and blue buildings, upgrading the twin-rotor Chinooks keeps more than 4,000 workers employed. A brand new Model D comes off the assembly line only rarely, and usually for a foreign customer. Most of the four Model D's completed here each month are overhauled Chinooks, which first carried soldiers and supplies into battle in Vietnam.
Since the late 1980's, Boeing has been working on a contract that is costing the Pentagon more than $5 billion to rebuild 538 older Chinooks into the Model D. The Chinooks are flown here intact. Their rotors and engines are removed. The wiring, cockpit paneling and electronics gear are gutted. The paint is sanded off the hulls. The Model D's can carry more weight a longer distance.
 
 
Looking to Foreign Sales
 The last copter in this process is to be returned to the Army by mid-1995, and after that the hope is to sustain the production line with foreign sales. "We have people girdling the globe, trying to sell new Chinooks," said Stuart D. Dodge, director of Boeing's tandem rotor helicopter programs.
Anticipating that foreign sales will not be enough to keep the factory open, Boeing is now arguing that the Persian Gulf war demonstrated the need for another upgrade: Model D's should be rebuilt into the more powerful Model F, still in the design stage.
In a carpeted conference room at the headquarters building here -- a room with huge backlighted photo transparencies on every wall that show Boeing helicopters in action -- Mr. Dodge offers to a reporter the Model F sales pitch that he gives regularly now to people at the Pentagon and members of Congress.
The Model D, Mr. Dodge explained, was everywhere in Saudi Arabia and Iraq during the Persian Gulf crisis, carrying troops, drums of fuel, artillery and the injured. But fully loaded, the Model D's two engines and fuel capacity could travel only 100 miles without refueling -- half the range of the proposed Model F.
"On the first day of the ground fighting, that 100 miles took troops and supplies only halfway to Baghdad on the Euphrates from the Saudi border," Mr. Dodge said. "The Model F could have gone all the way to the Euphrates nonstop." And Mr. Dodge suggested that the Model F might have gotten American troops to Baghdad quickly enough to surprise Saddam Hussein and capture him.
 The Persian Gulf experience is frequently invoked to justify the expense of upgrading old weaponry in the post-cold-war period. The deployment of American troops in Somalia is the latest such experience.
But rebuilding older weapons rather than buying new ones raises issues that have not been adequately debated in Congress or by the public, according to Representative Andy Ireland of Florida, the ranking Republican on the House subcommittees for military procurement and for investigations of weapons contracts.
"If the threat is no worse than Saddam Hussein's Republican Guard, do you really need to spend so much on upgrading weaponry?" Mr. Ireland asked. "I know in my gut that upgrading weapons is a growing trend, although still not fully measured. Accountability is necessary to head off overcharging, which is just as likely with an upgrade as with a new B-1 bomber. Most important, is this an overlooked area for cutbacks in defense spending?"
One issue is whether companies like Boeing are rebuilding too much -- replacing too many parts -- and overcharging in the process. The rebuilding of Chinooks into Model D's, for instance, costs the Pentagon $11 million a copter, compared with $15 million to $17 million for a new Model D. In the early 1980's, when the Pentagon first began to convert earlier versions into the Model D, the cost per copter was $7 million.
In addition, the profit that Boeing earns from building a new Chinook or rebuilding an old one is roughly the same, says B. Dan Pinick, president of Boeing's Defense and Space Group. "The skills and capabilities that go into rebuilding a helicopter from the bare shell involve the same skills and capabilities that are necessary to build a new plane," Mr. Pinick said.
The source of much of the increase in costs since 1980 appears to be the new electronics systems and computers wired into the stripped-down Chinooks on the line here, or into the F-14 fighter planes that the Grumman Corporation is upgrading at its Calverton plant on Long Island, or into the older Abrams tanks that General Dynamics wants to rebuild at its Lima, Ohio, plant into the M1-A2 model. Among other upgrades, the M1-A2's have a new digital electronics system capable of detailed communication with other battle units.
In any modern weapon, the electronics gear is the costliest element and the source of the highest profit, said Peter Oram, president of Grumman Aircraft Systems. "You don't replace landing gears or wings or fuselage, and this air frame is maybe $500 a pound for aluminum and steel," Mr. Oram said. "But electronics go for $2,500 a pound installed, and if you are replacing 3,000 pounds of electronics, that is expensive."
The 18 stripped-down F-14's that Grumman has been upgrading at Calverton with new radar, new engines, new electronics and new missile-firing ability are costing the Pentagon $37 million a plane, compared with a $50.8 million price tag for an F-14, newly built.
"They don't have to do so much; they are making work," said Seymour Melman, a retired Columbia University engineering professor and a weapons industry expert.
 
 
Overhauls Without Upgrading
 Alternatively, these 10-year-old aircraft could remain in operation without becoming more powerful weapons, their lives extended through periodic overhauls at Air Force depots every year or two, at a cost of only $1 million to $2 million for each overhaul, Grumman officials say.
The Army faces a similar alternative for Abrams tanks. The new M1-A2 outperformed earlier models in the Persian Gulf crisis, with its more powerful cannon, its new electronics and a turret that offered the crew protection against chemical warfare. Until the Berlin wall came down in 1989, ending the rivalry with the former Soviet Union, General Dynamics had sought a contract to build 3,000 new M1-A2's.
But the company has switched strategies, bidding instead to upgrade 1,000 older tanks for $3.1 billion, compared with $4.6 million for a new M1-A2. A contract has not been signed, but the Army has endorsed the General Dynamics bid. It is seeking Defense Department approval to upgrade the first 260 tanks over the next five years, guaranteeing in the process the survival, until at least 1997, of the Lima plant, the nation's only tank assembly factory.
"You want to send soldiers into the field with the best equipment, even if it is an overmatch for the enemy," said Major Keating, the Army spokesman. "You want to have the best tanks up front."

HEADLINE: Marines Reach Bardera, But Not Famine Victims

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH

DATELINE: BARDERA, Somalia, Dec. 24

 BODY:
In the early morning, the only sound in some feeding centers here is the uninterrupted crying of children. Some just sit on the ground, covered with flies and so thin that their skin falls in wrinkles around their bones.
As meal time approaches, they are joined by hundreds of women with their children, plastic bowl or soot-blackened kettle in hand, who wait in line for their morning handout of steaming, high-protein gruel. Once served, they squat in the dirt, scooping up their gruel with their hands. 
 Six hundred American marines arrived here today, tired and caked with dust after a 12-hour ride through desert and scrub from Baidoa, 120 miles to the northeast. The marines set up roadblocks at the entrance to the town and took control of the airstrip, but on their first day here none of them saw the scenes in the refugee camps a mile out of town.
 
Marines Outside Hunger Zone
 Some of the newly arrived marines wondered whether starvation, disease and malnutrition even existed here.
"We've seen all these pictures in magazines that show the horror of Somalia," said Staff Sgt. Michael McClung, 32, of the 7th Engineers Support Battalion. "We've been to Mogadishu, Baidoa and now Bardera. People look definitely poor, but they're not lying around lethargically dying. We were wondering where these people were."
Bardera, a dirt road lined by bullet-pocked buildings and shanties of corrugated tin, is the second major famine relief center that the marines have secured. On Dec. 16 they entered Baidoa and began escorting food convoys to outlying villages.
Military officials have considered the Bardera operation much more difficult logistically. It is more isolated than Baidoa, reachable only by ramshackle roads or a dirt airstrip that becomes impassable whenever it rains. And mines are a problem in Bardera, a legacy of bitter fighting between rival Somali factions. The town has changed hands twice this year.
 
Hungry Cluster in Camps
 Bardera's fortunes have declined steeply from a decade ago, when it was at the heart of a fertile region. Today it is dusty and tattered. But the butchers in the market sell slabs of camel and beef, and merchants have cloth and firewood for sale. The only hints of famine in the town are the skeletal beggars who walk the streets and are regularly turned away from food stalls.
Images of famine take over in the refugee centers, and in the outlying villages.
"There are 186 villages we'd like to reach," said Bob Allen, who heads the Bardera operations of CARE, the American relief agency. "We'd like to see the Americans stay up to such time as the economy picks up and the harvest kicks in."
In September, war between clans emptied the countryside, and 16,000 refugees settled on the outskirts of town. Four months ago more than 300 people were dying each day, many of the weakest and most vulnerable among them. Since then the situation has improved considerably, said Katherine MacArthur, a CARE nurse in Bardera. The daily death toll is down to about 60.
But warehouses have been looted regularly and relief agencies keep only a few days' supply of food in town for fear that it will be stolen. Relief agency officials say they hope the American presence will end the threat from looters.
 
Weariness, but Little Cheer
 The tactics the Americans used for Bardera were similar to the approach they took in Baidoa and Kismayu. Leaflets announcing the marines' arrival were dropped on the town on Tuesday, and on Wednesday Robert B. Oakley, President Bush's special envoy to Somalia, visited with town elders and clan leaders.
The Bardera operation produced the first American death of the Somali operation on Wednesday when an American was killed and three others were injured when their car ran over a land mine. [The Pentagon identified the dead man as Lawrence N. Freedman, 51, of Fayetteville, N.C.]
The first American troops here were 64 marines in 12 vehicles from the First Combat Engineer Battalion, whose job was to sweep the roads between Baidoa and Bardera for mines. Trucks decorated with hand-lettered "Merry Christmas" signs pushed huge steamroller wheels and chains to detonate mines. They encountered none.
The rest of the troops arrived by 3:30 P.M., caked in dust. Many asked reporters where the starving Somalis were.
"We're not planning on going into town,' said Lieut. Col. Rod Getz of the First Battalion, 7th Marines. "We're trying first just to have a presence here, to create a good feeling."
The crowd that turned out to watch the Americans was quiet and calm, appearing awed by the heavily armed marines as they went about their chores, sweating profusely in the 100-degree heat.
Aside from the holiday signs, there were few signs of Christmas cheer among the weary marines in these depressing surroundings. They settled into digging foxholes at the airport or just collapsed onto cots.
"I'm trying not to think about Christmas," said Sgt. John Manoni, 28, of Elmwood, Ill. "I try to think of it as just another day."

HEADLINE: For Connecticut, the Stakes Are Not Just on the Tables

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Dec. 18

 BODY:
By proposing casinos for Hartford and Bridgeport, two large companies, Mirage Resorts and Harrah's Casino Hotels, are asking Connecticut to bet on legal gambling as a growth industry for the 90's.
The state's decision, in the end, is likely to come from the gut, like a poker player's when a long night comes down to a final hand. Like it or not, Connecticut already has such a large stake in legal gambling that rejecting casinos will almost certainly bring financial pain, though allowing them will not add greatly to the state's revenues. 
 In the fiscal year that ended June 30, $1 billion was wagered on state-sanctioned games: on the state lottery, in state-operated off-track betting parlors and at jai alai frontons and a dog track. Despite a conservative image conjured from equal parts Yankee industrialist, Greenwich preppie and Hartford actuary, the state ranks sixth in the nation in per-capita wagering, says Gaming and Wagering Business magazine.
One certainty is that some of that action, and some of the state's take of $250 million a year, will decline in this decade if Connecticut spurns casinos and nearby states welcome them. Another is that a Connecticut casino would cut into lottery sales and could put the frontons and dog track out of business. And while some of the opponents of casinos have raised the specter of organized crime, the debate has largely turned on economic issues.
"A lot of lawmakers seem to think they can balance their budgets with casinos, and that's a fantasy," said Eugene Christiansen, a gaming consultant whose company, Christiansen/Cummings Associates, recommended the limited licensing of casinos in Connecticut in a study for the State Division of Special Revenue.
Mirage and Harrah's are offering Connecticut a chance to get in early on their industry's expected spread across the country in the 90's as states scrape for new sources of revenue and as Indians force the issue by opening casinos on reservations, as the Mashantucket Pequots did in eastern Connecticut in February.
"By the year 2000," Mr. Christiansen said, "casinos will be as widespread as lotteries are today."
Even if Connecticut did gain revenue by licensing a casino, some people ask, what would happen when other states followed suit?
"When parimutuels started in this state, they were the only game in town, and they did exceedingly well," said Robert W. Werner, executive director of the Division of Special Revenue. "Now we're talking about how to save them. I think it's likely to see the same thing with casinos."
 
Governor Is Opposed
 In any case, slot machines are not the kind of technology that Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. wants to attract to Connecticut to preserve its manufacturing base, skilled work force and high quality of living. Last month the Governor bluntly restated his opposition to casinos.
"I don't see a state that has such a reputation for integrity of its politics and quality of its businesses mucking around in the business of gambling," he said. "You lay down with dogs, you get fleas.
"I'm going to have a terrible time getting legitimate business into the State of Connecticut if it knows that our budget is going to be based on gambling, or that they're going to be sitting physically cheek to jowl with casinos."
The strength of the sentiment for casinos will become clear in January, when a legislative task force will make its recommendation before the General Assembly convenes. The Greater Hartford Chamber of Commerce, with its own task force, will also take a position next month.
A task force for the Bridgeport Regional Business Council has already recommended that its organization endorse up to two casinos for Bridgeport, where both Mirage and Harrah's have proposed $300 million developments on the waterfront.
 
The Lure of Development
 The casinos counter Governor Weicker's objections by pointing to his administration's difficulty in stanching the state's loss of industrial jobs and by describing what they could do for its largest cities.
Mirage Resorts, for example, has proposed spending up to $350 million to build a casino, convention center, restaurants, shops and theaters in downtown Hartford, which has lost several department stores and hotels. Mirage says the complex would employ 6,000 people and pay up to $100 million a year in state and local taxes.
Mr. Christiansen's company, in an estimate based on three casinos operating in Fairfield County, projected revenues of $49 million a year for the state and $20 million a year for the localities.
Casinos would also allow Connecticut to capture some of the estimated $150 million a year its residents now spend in Atlantic City, Nevada and Caribbean casinos.
The casinos have sought to make themselves more attractive by promoting their plans as developments that include casinos but represent much more to their host cities: a convention center for Hartford, which wants but cannot afford one, or a huge family-entertainment center in Bridgeport.
Even if a casino complex were built around entertainment, critics say, unskilled jobs like maids, busboys and waiters are not what the state needs to pull itself out of recession and rebuild its manufacturing base.
"The Governor has much more ambitious employment goals for the people of this state than the kinds of jobs that are available in a casino," Mr. Weicker's spokeswoman, Avice Meehan, said.
 
Image Is Cited
 The administration and other opponents are also concerned that the insurance companies that gave Hartford its reputation as a financial center, which are undergoing great changes themselves, will not care to share a skyline with a casino.
"It will affect our reputation as a conservative business community," said the Rev. Christopher L. Rose, pastor of Grace Episcopal Church in Hartford, who has lobbied against casino legislation.
He is also distressed that some people are willing to take a chance on gambling as an economic enterprise.
"I can't believe we're still making the same mistakes, that we haven't learned the lessons of the 1980's," he said. "We fell in with Colonial Realty on all of those great real-estate deals, we had four or five skyscrapers promising to be the salvation of downtown Hartford. The reason our recession is so deep is because of all the money taken out of the economy by that speculation."
Colonial Realty, forced into bankruptcy in September 1990, had attracted as many as 6,000 people, who invested $350 million.
Still, it remains difficult to measure how the legalization of gambling affects the soul of a state. Many people look to New Jersey, where the unredeemed slums of Atlantic City stand to them as a symbol of failure.
Professor James W. Hughes of Rutgers University, the co-author with George Sternlieb of "The Atlantic City Gamble" in 1983, said the driving force behind any state's legalizing gambling is almost always "economic desperation."
New Jersey voters approved Atlantic City casinos in 1976, after a harsh recession, but its ambivalence showed in its strict regulation of the industry through the 1980's. The return of tough times is changing that. The state now allows 24-hour gaming. There is pressure to legalize sports betting.
"As the economy has weakened and the state's fiscal situation has weakened, the state has essentially become a much stronger partner," Professor Hughes said. "It now has a vested interest in the success of gambling."

HEADLINE: Mulroney Calls for Naval Blockade of Haiti

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: OTTAWA, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said an international naval blockade should be set up around Haiti to bring down the military dictatorship, according to a television interview transcript released today.
Mr. Mulroney has become increasing frustrated with a lack of effort to help restore a democratic government in Haiti, and the failure of a limited economic blockade to be effective, his spokesman said today. 
 "There should be a naval blockade, by Canada, the United States, France and Venezuela to name but four to bring that Government down," Mr. Mulroney said in the transcripts of a CTV television network interview to be broadcast on Sunday.
The democratically elected Haitian President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, was overthrown in a Sept 30, 1991 military coup.
Canada has many Haitian immigrants, particularly in Quebec, and has supported the Organization of American States blockade of Haiti.
"If you really want to shut these guys down, you have to put a stranglehood on them," said Mark Entwistle, Mr. Mulroney's spokesman.
Mr. Mulroney has continued to raise the issue with President Bush, and will try to persuade President-elect Bill Clinton to support a more effective blockade.

HEADLINE: Jamaica's Coffee Makes Japan a Jealous Lover

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MAVIS BANK, Jamaica

 BODY:
On the steep mountainsides overlooking Kingston, the afternoon air is renowned for two things: the coolness that reliably descends the slopes while the capital still swelters below, and the aroma of roasting coffee beans.
While other developing countries may rue the economic "cures" from Washington that urge them to produce ever more of their commodities, seemingly forcing prices inexorably downward, Jamaica has happily established its Blue Mountain coffee as one commodity that seems always in demand across the world. 
 Through intense attention to quality, heavy investments in marketing and considerable luck with geography, production of Blue Mountain coffee is booming. So are prices.
Able to command $7.50 a pound, 10 times the price of run-of-the-mill varieties, Jamaicans have thrown themselves with gusto into coffee cultivation in the last few years. The beans must grow at high altitudes in the Blue Mountain range near Kingston in order to be legally marketed with the prized brand name.
Growers in the range, which rises from the blue Caribbean to an apex of 7,500 feet in the space of a scant 12 miles, are hoping to quadruple their production in the next five years or so, to 16 million pounds.
Seated in his small, smartly appointed Kingston office, Mitsuo Seyama, an executive of Japan's Ueshima Coffee Company, is a major reason for Jamaica's recent success with coffee. His company is the biggest importer of Blue Mountain in Japan, which alone imports 90 percent of Jamaica's crop.
"Elsewhere we have to breed coffee to get just the right acidity and flavor balance," said Mr. Seyama. "But we consider that Blue Mountain is naturally perfect -- medium acid with just the right sweetness."
The combination of high quality and aggressive marketing by Ueshima has resulted in a willingness by Japanese consumers to pay $8 to $10 a cup in restaurants for his Jamaican brews, versus about $3 a cup for regular coffee.
After Hurricane Gilbert hit Jamaica in 1988, leaving much of the island looking like a plucked chicken, prices soared on the Japanese coffee market. In a gesture that left a lasting impression, Jamaican growers say that Japanese importers were on the telephone in the first days after the storm offering whatever help they needed in restoring their operations.
Now the Japanese have a near lock on the market, and little genuine Blue Mountain coffee reaches American consumers, although it can be found in gourmet shops selling for $20 to $40 a pound. Seeking to cash in on the cachet of Jamaica's beans, many retailers in the United States sell coffee that has little or no Jamaican content under deceptive names like Blue Mountain blend, or style.
Keble Munn, the 73-year-old managing director of the Mavis Bank Central Factory, the biggest processor of Blue Mountain coffee in Jamaica, said he would like to make more of his coffee available to the American market.
"We have Americans and Europeans who call up all the time and say, look, we'll pay you $11 a pound," Mr. Munn said. "Well that's fine for one shot, but what do you do four years hence, when the next hurricane hits? That's when you remember the Japanese, and the lesson for us has been taking care of clients like that first."

HEADLINE: Ontario's Socialists Falter After 2 Bitter Years

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
In elections a little over two years ago, the 10 million people of Ontario, Canada's richest and most populous province, voted for their first taste of democratic socialism.
Trade unions, social-action groups and other supporters on the left of the political spectrum rejoiced at the surprise victory of the New Democratic Party and proclaimed Ontario a leader in fashioning a more just society, economically and socially. 
 But the taste of power, so sweet on Sept. 6, 1990, has turned sour. Almost nothing since then has gone right for the Government and the former labor lawyer, Bob Rae, 44, who became the province's first Socialist Premier.
A recession forced him to make especially painful decisions in cutting spending, for example, on provincial schools, hospitals and municipalities. And his administration has fallen victim to a seemingly unending series of political scandals.
After a bartender said that the Minister of Tourism, Peter North, a 32-year-old father of two, had offered her a $45,000-a-year Government job during a relationship that he wanted to become sexual, Mr. North resigned.
The Premier's press adviser, John Piper, 49, a former executive with the giant public relations firm, Hill & Knowlton, quit after trying to discredit a woman who was charging sexual misconduct by a former Cabinet minister. Mr. Piper had offered to leak the woman's criminal record to a reporter from The Toronto Sun.
Carlton Masters, who heads Ontario's United States trade office, an operation employing 57 people in six cities with an annual budget of $7.5 million, resigned after being accused of sexually harassing female employees in New York and Boston.
Mr. North, Mr. Piper and Mr. Masters have declined to explain their actions and have avoided of the press.
The opposition is rejoicing as opinion surveys show the New Democratic Party's popularity plummeting. The most recent Gallup poll showed Ontario New Democrats at 22 percent, the Liberals at 46 percent and the Conservatives at 29 percent.
The Liberal Party leader in Ontario, Lyn McLeod, said Mr. Rae had a "reverse Midas touch." The Progressive Conservative leader, Michael Harris, described the Government as "just sort of wallowing in the ocean."
Adding to the Premier's discomfort are the standards he set. "We must at all times act in a manner that will not only bear the closest public scrutiny but will go further and insure public confidence and trust in the integrity of government," he said when elected.
Lawrence LeDuc, professor of Canadian politics at the University of Toronto, said, "Bob Rae set some pretty straight guidelines, and now he's stuck with them." But he also said that the Government had been hurt by the recession and the unpopularity of some of its policies.
Mr. Rae, who has not been implicated in any of the scandals, has acknowledged disappointment, but he tends to take a more philosophical view than his critics and is convinced the tide will turn. Legally, he does not have to call elections until 1995.
Although he is ideologically an adversary, some of the arguments Mr. Rae now uses echo those of the Conservative Prime Minister, Brian Mulroney, whose popularity has been skidding over an even longer period.
Both have found the Liberal Party a convenient scapegoat. Mr. Mulroney has frequently blamed spending excesses of earlier Liberal governments in Ottawa for the economic retrenchment that he has imposed nationally.
Now Mr. Rae is blaming 1985-90 spending increases by Liberals, while they were running the province, for compounding his Government's difficulties in fighting the recession.
Like Mr. Mulroney, Mr. Rae is also saying that he expects the economy to improve and that this will enhance his political fortunes.
But Professor LeDuc and other analysts note that Mr. Rae is in danger of being too closely identified with Mr. Mulroney. Many New Democratic core supporters see the Government they worked so hard to bring to power now behaving just like a Tory Government in cutting back or delaying programs for students, hospitals and women.

HEADLINE: Clinton to Focus on Helping U.S. Airlines

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Helping the nation's airline industry recover from its $8 billion tailspin since 1990 is a top priority for both President-elect Bill Clinton and the new Congress, according to Government and industry officials,
Proposals under study, they say, include tax incentives, regulatory relief, global partnerships and revisions of the bankruptcy laws to bolster the troubled industry. 
They also hope to persuade foreign governments to provide greater access to American carriers that seek to increase their lucrative international routes. That issue led to the abandonment this week of a plan by British Airways to invest $750 million for a 44 percent stake in troubled USAir, the nation's fifth-largest carrier.
The deal fell through because the United States and Britain were unable to agree on steps to open their airline industries to greater competition. Its failure was cited by some as an example of how the industry and the Federal Government should have been able to work more successfully.
"There is a sense that many of the international carriers are working in partnership with their respective governments, and that kind of partnership does not exist here in the United States, where our carriers are left to their own devices as they compete globally," said Federico Pena, who is chairman of Mr. Clinton's transition team on transportation and was nominated today to be Secretary of Transportation.
In a telephone interview before his nomination was announced, Mr. Pena predicted that under the new Administration, "There's going to be much closer attention on the part of the Federal Government to the U.S. airline industry, to assure the ultimate survival of the industry."
The industry went from a $1.7 billion profit in 1988 to a $4 billion deficit in 1990, and $2 billion deficits in 1991 and 1992, according to the Air Transport Association, which represents the major airlines.
Mr. Pena envisions more of a Government partnership with the airline industry and less of an adversarial relationship. He supports tax incentives "to allow the industry to thrive, something that foreign governments do all the time."
"We're all concerned about the thousands of people who have lost their jobs, and have to make sure that that doesn't continue to be the trend in the future," he said.
Similarly, Representative Norman Y. Mineta, the incoming chairman of the Public Works and Transportation Committee, said that the airline industry would be "a top priority" of his committee, as well as the new Congress.
The California Democrat said that he had already discussed some specific measures with Mr. Clinton, including a reduction in the $3 charge that some localities charge airline passengers. To remain competitive, airlines sometimes elect to pay the fees themselves, at a cost last year of $1.2 billion to the industry.
Patricia Goldman, USAir's senior vice president for corporate relations, cited these "passenger facility charges" as an example of "an enormous number of regulations that have significant costs attached and significantly impact our bottom line."
Most industry experts believe that the airlines have been a primary victim of the faltering economy. "We are very much slaves to the economy," said Jim Landry, president of the Air Transport Association, which represents the major airlines. "A great many of our seats are being filled at below-cost prices. If there is an economic recovery, we'll get a return to a more normal traffic demand."
Mr. Mineta's prescription follows similar lines. "First," he said, "the economy has to be turned around. Then you go to the specific problems -- too many seats chasing too few passengers."
Most experts cite overexpansion as a major cause of the airlines' woes. Last month, only 58.4 percent of airline seats on domestic routes were filled, compared with 62 percent of the seats on international routes.
"I don't know if there's anything to be done until that overexpansion has ended and the economy has recovered," said Alfred E. Kahn, who championed deregulation as chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board during the Carter Administration.
Mr. Kahn believes that international alliances could be the savior of America's airlines. "I'm terribly disappointed by the failure of the British Airways-USAir deal," Mr. Kahn said. "We don't see anything wrong with the British owning banks, insurance companies and hotels. It's good for American consumers to get that capital."
But Mr. Mineta was leery of the 44 percent stake in USAir's equity and 21 percent of the voting stock that British Airways had sought in exchange for the $750 million it had offered the ailing airlines. And Lee Howard, president of Airline Economics, an aviation consulting firm, said that "these deals ought to be structured so that control remains with the American carrier."
 
 
Tougher Bankruptcy Laws Urged
 Many industry experts urged tougher bankruptcy laws. At present, T.W.A., Continental and America West are in Chapter 11. Previously, Pan Am, Eastern and Braniff were in Chapter 11.
John V. Pincavage, a partner at the Transportation Group Ltd., a New York firm that specializes in financing airlines and airplanes, said: "We should not allow airlines to go into Chapter 11 and dissipate creditor assets while they continue to operate and not have to pay their bills. That's what has led to continued overcapacity in the industry. The day a company declares bankruptcy we should padlock the doors and put it out of business. This would help reduce excess capacity and help the remaining airlines, which would get the traffic from the bankrupt airlines."
Mr. Mineta said that under the bankruptcy law, an airline that does not have to pay its creditors sometimes becomes "the tail that wags the dog." He noted that several weeks ago, when one airline (American) announced a fare increase, another airline, in bankruptcy (Continental), decided to cut fares. "They didn't have to pay their creditors," Mr. Mineta said.
Most industry experts agree with Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, who said, "There's no quick fix; there's no unscrambling the egg." But they disagree with his diagnosis: "They screwed up their own system of deregulation." They also do not like his remedy: "Go back to the old days and make the airlines a public utility."
 
 
'Unfair Trade Practice'
 Mr. Nader supports creation of new airlines, new airport slots, the ending of abuse of computerized reservation systems and the ending of Frequent Flier programs, which he believes are "an unfair trade practice."
Mr. Howard of Airline Economics also blames the airlines for some of their woes. "The airlines should discipline themselves with regard to fares, and gear them more to stability in the future than short-term cash," he said.
Mr. Landry of the Air Transport Association offered a list of tax incentives intended to promote economic growth, including investment tax credits. He noted that the industry would replace 2,600 older aircraft by the year 2000, at a price of $130 billion. He also urged a modification of the alternative minimum tax law "which has carriers suffering operating losses borrowing money to pay taxes."
Mr. Landry was among several experts who urged overhaul and modernization of the air traffic control system.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Rise for Week

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for jobless benefits rose a surprising 12,000 in mid-December to the highest level in three weeks, the Government said today.
The Labor Department said first-time applications for unemployment insurance totaled 360,000 in the week that ended on Dec. 12, up from a revised 348,000 a week earlier. 
 It was the highest level of new claims since 362,000 were filed in the week that ended on Nov. 21. Many analysts had expected the number to fall.
Still, it was the 12th straight week that claims remained below 400,000, which many analysts consider the threshold between an improving or deteriorating job market.
The department said earlier this month that the jobless rate dipped to 7.2 percent in November from 7.4 percent a month earlier; the recent peak was 7.8 percent in June. At the same time, it said 105,000 jobs were created last month.
The four-week moving average of regular weekly claims also fell during the period that ended on Dec. 12, to 348,750 from 352,250 a week earlier. It was the lowest level since the moving average was 345,750 for the period that ended on May 26, 1990, and the 10th straight week that it remained under 400,000.
