HEADLINE: Law;
At the Bar

BYLINE: By David Margolick

 BODY:
Come what may over the last decade, Bruce and Nancy Young of Minneapolis have tithed -- that is, given 10 percent of their income to their church. They gave in the good times, when business at their electrical contracting business was brisk. And they gave in the bad times, when Mr. Young's heart attack and the recession led them into bankruptcy.
But when the Youngs mark Christmas today at the Crystal Evangelical Free Church in nearby New Hope, they may reflect on Federal judges as well as the Wise Men, statutes as well as the Star of Bethlehem. The Book of Deuteronomy has run right into the Federal Bankruptcy Code. 
 Chief Judge Robert J. Kressel of the United States Bankruptcy Court in Minneapolis recently had to decide whether the Crystal Church could keep the Youngs' money, or whether the money should go to the banks and credit card companies to whom they owed money. That required Judge Kressel, in turn, to answer a more puzzling theological question: whether Mr. and Mrs. Young got their money's worth for their contributions.
An intensely devout couple, the Youngs learned of tithing from their reading of the Bible, which first mentions the tradition in Deuteronomy 14:22. They immediately began donating to the Crystal Church 10 percent of their gross earnings, contained in 52 weekly offering envelopes. They made their donations, Mr. Young said, "come feast or famine"; in 1991 their largess amounted to $13,450 even though, as of last Jan. 14, Young Electric was officially insolvent and, as of Feb. 3, the Youngs filed for bankruptcy. All told, they were at least $150,000 in debt.
As provided for under Federal law, the court appointed a trustee to collect the couple's remaining assets and distribute them among their creditors. The trustee was Julia Christians, but she showed little reverence for the donations to the Crystal Church. Citing Section 548(a)(2) of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, she argued that the church had to disgorge the funds.
The Youngs said they were thunderstruck by her determination -- the result, they felt, of an overly zealous young lawyer out to make a name for herself. Ms. Christians said the bankruptcy code authorizes trustees to "avoid," or rescind, all donations made by an insolvent party within a year of filing for bankruptcy when the donee "received less than a reasonably equivalent value in exchange," and made no exception for churches.
What constitutes something of value? Can one put a price tag on succor? The Youngs contended that they had received considerable value for their contributions, largely in the spiritual and psychological realm.
Mrs. Young said in an affidavit that her attendance at Sunday morning services and weekly Bible study classes "was valuable because it nourished my spiritual needs." Mr. Young was a bit more explicit. "The spiritual nourishment I received from my attendance at Crystal Evangelical Free Church helped keep me stable during stressful business times," he wrote.
But Ms. Christians maintained that the bankruptcy code does not place a value on such intangible things. "Value," she argued, meant "property," and whatever else they might have received for their good deeds, the couple received no property in exchange.
Enter Judge Kressel, whose analysis of the problem was as much etymological as legal. After poring through Black's Law Dictionary and Webster's Third New International Dictionary for the definitions of "property," "thing," "ownership" and "rights," he concluded that everything the Youngs had received -- "feelings of association, comfort, affection, companionship, love" -- were "mere gratuities," without the economic value the law required.
Rejecting two other court decisions that good will and religious services constitute property, Judge Kressel ruled that the Crystal Church had to refund the money, to be picked over by various creditors. "While I am not  thrilled about making a church return contributions," he wrote, the law permitted no other result. "The voice of Congress is loud," he wrote. "Property is value, charitable contributions are not."
Judge Kressel's decision, made public on Dec. 17, constituted a rude Christmas present for Mr. and Mrs. Young, who are now back on their feet financially and continue to tithe.
It was bad news as well for William Sisterson, the pastor of the Crystal Evangelical Free Church, who said he is contemplating an appeal. He is also pondering the changing relationship between the churches and courts, one which, he said, have left churches far less sacrosanct than they were 20 years ago, when he was ordained.
"Good will toward churches has eroded, and this case is symbolic of that change," Mr. Sisterson said. "Churches are in more of a free-fire zone than they used to be, and we're just joining the club."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS: Merry Christmas to The Donald;
Here's an Investment Scrooge Would Love

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Martin Mittlemark may win the prize for the most original holiday gift idea for 1992: tax liens on property owned by Donald Trump.
Mr. Mittlemark, president of Municipal Liens Inc. of Tinton Falls, N.J., isn't joking. 
 The liens are certificates comparable to other types of securities, backed by the properties as collateral. They can pay the equivalent of double-digit interest rates, far better than Treasury bonds or bank deposits.
In Mr. Trump's case, the liens are against taxes that the flamboyant New York financier has not paid on his Atlantic City casinos. The gaming parlors have all been restructured under bankruptcy protection laws and now seem to be doing substantially better, which makes the tax liens on them worth even more.
"Each one comes with a full title search showing how Donald overextended himself and how the banks rushed in to save him, heaping one mortgage upon the next," Mr. Mittlemark writes in an industry trade journal.
The former municipal bond trader and commodities market trader is an aggressive promoter of tax liens as an alternative to stocks and bonds.
"It's really one of the safest investments around," he said. Before the property can be sold, the property owner or the mortgage lender must pay off the tax lien, and any associated penalties.
Tax liens have priority over other claims, which provides a measure of investment security typically found in government bonds, Mr. Mittlemark said.
What isn't commonly understood is that private investors can buy the tax liens from city, county or state governments. Depending on the local government rules, the liens can yield anywhere from 6 percent to 25 percent, Mr. Mittlemark said.
Investors need to carefully sort out the specific laws on tax liens, which can vary by municipality. Mr. Mittlemark's company plows through the dense tax records and advises pension funds, former bank directors and others about the best deals.
He hopes to develop a cottage industry of "tax liens of the rich and famous," but concedes only the liens on Mr. Trump's Atlantic City properties qualify for star status.

HEADLINE: Fed, in Mid-November, Favored Easing of Rates

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers decided at a mid-November meeting to maintain a policy leaning toward lower interest rates if the economy began to sputter, according to minutes released today.
Members of the Federal Open Market Committee reviewed information that "suggested that economic activity had been expanding at a moderate pace," the minutes said. At the same time, wage and price data suggested "a continuing trend toward lower inflation." 
 As a result, all but 3 of the 12 members agreed to maintain a policy that would include "some bias" toward easing interest rates, if needed. As it turned out, the Fed did not act.
 
 
Greenspan in the Majority
 In the majority were Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman; Wayne D. Angell, Edward W. Kelley Jr., Lawrence B. Lindsey, David W. Mullins Jr. and Susan M. Phillips, who are all Fed governors, and E. Gerald Corrigan, Thomas H. Hoenig and Richard F. Syron, who are regional Fed bank presidents.
One Fed governor, John P. LaWare, and a regional president, Thomas C. Melzer, disagreed. They said the bias toward lower interest rates was unnecessary because of the strengthening economy.
One regional president, Jerry L. Jordan, also dissented because of a desire for faster growth in the money supply.
The committee adopted the current policy leaning toward lower interest rates, if needed, in midsummer when the economy appeared to slump. It voted to continue that policy at meetings in August and October, although it agreed to a stronger, "marked bias" toward easing at the latter meeting.
 
 
Met Again This Week
 The committee met again this week. Its meetings are closed to the public, but minutes of the proceedings will be released in early February.
Analysts believe the committee decided against any immediate action because of signs that the economy continues to strengthen gradually. They added, however, that the Fed could push interest rates higher by mid-1993 if the economy appeared to be overheating and building inflationary pressures.
The Fed has not cut rates since Sept. 4, when it allowed the Federal funds rate to drop to 3 percent, from 3.25 percent. The funds rate is the interest banks charge each other for overnight loans. The rate has been cut 24 times over the last three years to help stimulate the economy.
The committee comprises the seven governors, including Mr. Greenspan, and the presidents of the 12 regional Federal Reserve banks. Only the governors and five of the regional presidents are voting members.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
You May Call It Art, But Some Call It Dessert

BYLINE: By Andrew H. Malcolm

DATELINE: EAST HANOVER, N.J.

 BODY:
WHEN you're trying to build something as colossal as a castle, it takes an incredible amount of drawing and planning, not to mention real inspiration. It takes careful staging of all the materials. It takes vision and an artisan's touch. And it takes an awful lot of icing. Also cookies, crackers and cardboard. And an oven preheated to 350.
"Any time you begin something of this scale," warns Walt Wanner, "you've got to be very careful and creative." You've also got to have a spouse blessed with saintly patience. 
 Mr. Wanner is one of nearly 20 artistes des nourritures whose oeuvres a manger are on display these days here at the sprawling headquarters of Nabisco Brands U.S.A. It's called edible art. There are castles and cottages and towers, even a mosque and a church. And they are open for public viewing every day from noon to 4 P.M.
So this morning as soon as you find part M for the plastic race track, and the 3/8-inch lug nut for the red wagon with the missing bolt and 16 more D batteries for the Galactica robot that ran over the cat's tail, you might want to scoot on over and catch a little sugar culture. But Please Do Not Eat the Exhibits!
This is probably the most delicious art show Nabisco has ever sponsored in the lobby of its divisional headquarters. In recent years a fair number of large corporations have moved from the city, where few people know their neighbors, to the suburbs, where few people still know their neighbors but most keep close track of them (you know, property values and all).
When Nabisco bought a bankrupt golf course here in 1976, it not only dropped a huge corporate presence into a residential neighborhood, it closed down the best sledding hill for miles around (you know, insurance liability and all).
But it also opened its doors, trying to establish a kind of good-neighbor policy for anyone who could survive the climb up the hill. Since Nabisco doesn't actually make anything here and since there really isn't that much exciting about three floors of office space, even suburban office space, Nabisco executives devoted the long lobby hallway to rotating exhibits of art that might interest their neighbors and 1,000 employees.
The exhibits, under the tasteful eye of Mary Chandor, Nabisco's art consultant, stress New Jersey artists who, like other Garden State residents, often feel themselves laboring in Manhattan's long shadow. "Good art space is hard to find in New Jersey," she explains with an accent that sounds suspiciously Canadian.
"We've exhibited -- and sold -- watercolors and rugs, photographs and oils," Ms. Chandor adds. "Last spring, when planning our Christmas exhibit, we thought, 'Why not have a little fun with this one?' "
Fun, you say? Have you ever tried to make a gingerbread turret topple-free? Have you ever tried to make a sidewalk out of Snackwell's cheese crackers and a sturdy cottage roof out of Mini-Oreos while your husband finished his Ph.D. thesis on animal behavior and your two cats eyed this special dessert you were making them on the dining room table of the usual tiny apartment in Queens? And don't forget to paint sweaters on each Teddy Graham cookie playing in the partially hydrogenated margarine snow.
See, that was the catch of this contest. Each edible art submission had to use at least five Nabisco products. Peggy Schmidt used 11 in her cottage, which consumed two 20-hour days. That apartment has smelled sweet for three weeks. But, hey, she took third place.
Mr. Wanner, a retired West Orange construction worker and veteran gingerbread-baking grandpa, won second with his castle featuring a cheddar Zing fence, Mini-Oreo path and Fruit Stripe gum bridge. (The little Christmas trees were festooned with Life Saver Holes.)
Charles Petretti of Spotswood, N.J., captured first prize with his 25-inch-tall bubble gum tower, although, truth be told, his girlfriend, Kiersten Dahlquist, unwrapped the 110 packs of Bubble Yum. That's a lot of bubble gum, even if you don't glue each piece in like a brick. (Much of the structural weight, however, is carried by beams of diet Stella D'oro breadsticks.)
"The idea just came to me," explained Mr. Petretti, a part-time liquor-store clerk and unemployed architect who hopes to use his edible art fame to acquire a job designing real buildings. "I'm psyched now!" he said.
Mr. Petretti blew his entire $500 prize on Christmas presents. Ms. Schmidt, a restaurant-arts student, will spend her $100 entering other contests. And Mr. Wanner has put his $300 toward next summer's vacation at the shore. One question remains for when the exhibit closes Jan. 11.
Since the edible art market is somewhat limited, what does one do with a well-planned but stale castle?

HEADLINE: Dow Shows A 12.70 Gain In Short Day

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks closed higher yesterday in a pre-Christmas rally fueled by a recovery in shares of I.B.M. and new highs for A.T.& T.
The Dow Jones industrial average was up 12.70 points at 3,326.24. Volume in the shortened session was only 95.2 million shares, the lightest of the year, compared with 234 million shares Wednesday. Advances led declines, 954 to 705. 
 The stock market closed two hours early, at 2 P.M., for Christmas Eve. It will be closed today for Christmas.
Analysts said the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was becoming the new blue-chip market leader, replacing the International Business Machines Corporation, which sank recently to an 11-year low. A.T.& T. jumped 1 1/2, to a record high of 52 3/4. I.B.M. also rose 1 1/2 to close at 52 3/4.
"There's a new leader here on the Street and it's called Ma Bell," said James Andrews of Janney Montgomery Scott.
"There is leadership here that's encouraging the rest of the market," a Bear, Stearns analyst, Jack Solomon, said. "The tone was set by the recovery in I.B.M. and the new highs in A.T.& T."
Bear, Stearns repeated a buy rating on A.T.& T., saying disappointment in other blue chips helped move the stock higher.
Analysts said the market largely ignored disappointing news that weekly jobless claims rose by 12,000, to 360,000, in the week ended Dec. 12. It was the second consecutive week that jobless claims rose, reversing several weeks of decline.
The latest total was above Wall Street's expectations of a decline to 342,000 claims on a seasonally adjusted basis.
"The data reinforces the point that the improvement in the labor market will be gradual," said Marilyn Schaja, economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
The market gains were expected to continue into next week, analysts said.
Yesterday's session "bodes well for the rally to extend into the new year," Patrick O'Malley, managing director at Needham & Company, said.
 
Traditional Year-End Rally
Analysts said bargain-hunting ahead of the market's traditional year-end rally also helped stocks.
"People want to jump on the bandwagon early," said Robert Walberg, an analyst at MMS International. "The market usually gets its biggest boost in the last week of December and the first week of January." Mr. Solomon at Bear, Stearns noted that the Dow index was showing a recovery, closing at its highest level since Oct. 9, when it closed at its low for the year, 3,137.
Among individual issues, shares of Bell Atlantic lost 3/4 at 53 after Josephthal, Lyon & Ross downgraded the company.
Novell topped the Nasdaq most active list, gaining 1 3/8, to 27 1/2, and rebounding from recent losses.
Ventritex surged 4 1/8, to 35 1/4, after the company said it had received an "approvable" letter from the Food and Drug Administration for its Cadence implantable defibrillator system for patients with irregular heartbeats.
Medicine Shoppe fell 1, to 25 1/2, on a downgrading by A. G. Edwards.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 0.74 point, to 439.77. The American Stock Exchange index was up 1.38 at 394.17.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index of all listed common stocks rose 0.23, to 241.23. The average share was up 4 cents. The Nasdaq index rose 2.92, to 665.88.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Are Mixed in Light Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury bonds ended mixed yesterday, with many participants already out of the market for the Christmas holiday.
Volume was light, and the market closed early at 2 P.M., Eastern time,for the holiday. 
 The price of the Treasury's closely watched 30-year bond was down 3/32 point, or 94 cents for each $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which rises when prices fall, was 7.36 percent, up from 7.35 percent late Wednesday.
 
 
3-Month Yield Unchanged
 Yields on three-month Treasury bills were unchanged at 3.22 percent, as the discount held steady at 3.16 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 3.39 percent, as the discount rose a basis point to 3.30 percent. Yields on one-year bills were unchanged at 3.59 percent, as the discount held at 3.46 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The market disregarded a Labor Department report that initial claims for unemployment insurance rose a surprising 12,000 in mid-December to the highest level in three weeks. Many analysts had expected the number to decline.
Paul Kasriel, an economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, said the jump was not large enough to persuade traders that the economy was recovering. He noted that the four-week moving average of unemployment claims, a more widely respected measure, was down.
Mr. Kasriel said investors were increasingly convinced "that the recovery is for real, that we are unlikely to lapse into another period of stagnation -- in fact, that we are more than likely to start building a stronger forward momentum in the economy."
He added, "And with that, the Federal Reserve is likely to keep policy on hold, but the odds will favor that their next move will be to push rates up." He added that a tightening of credit would probably not happen until the second quarter of next year.
 
 
Inflation May Rise
 Not only is the economy improving, Mr. Kasriel said, but the low inflation rates that the market has been enjoying are beginning to be viewed as unsustainable.
"With those two factors, interest rates would have a tendency to creep up from here," he said.
Interest rates tend to rise, and bond prices fall, if market participants anticipate that the economy will heat up enough to reignite inflation, or if they believe the Federal Reserve is likely to tighten monetary policy.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was 6 percent, unchanged from late Wednesday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 9719/32, down from 9720/32 on Wednesday. The average yield to maturity was unchanged at 6.40 percent.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Wheat Contract Prices Rise On Fears of a Crop Freeze

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Concerns that freezing temperatures would damage the developing crop lifted wheat futures prices today on the Chicago Board of Trade in light pre-holiday trading.
Although the winter wheat crops are dormant under moist soil conditions, fears of winter crop kills lingered as temperatures dipped below zero in Chicago and across the Midwest and western plains. 
 The freezing temperatures also lifted cattle and hog futures at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The cold weather could cause another setback in the rate of weight gain for livestock.
Live cattle futures for February closed up 0.125 at 76.375 cents a pound and February hogs also closed 0.125 higher at 43.675 cents.
The deferred July and September wheat contracts, in particular, were supported by the adverse weather. The spread widened between those contracts and the nearby March contract.
The March contract was also bogged down by another round of Russian defaults on American credit loans. United States banks filed 20 default notices today ahead of the extended-holiday weekend, bringing the outstanding debt to $95.7 million.
"The market right now has the understanding the Russian debt situation is more than just an economic problem," said Joe Victor, director of marketing at Allendale Inc. in Northbrook, Ill.
Wheat for March delivery closed off 1/4 cent at $3.58 1/2 a bushel, while March corn ended steady at $2.19 3/4 and soybeans closed up 1 3/4 at $5.77 1/4 a bushel.
Sugar prices ended marginally higher on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, with the March contract 0.02 cent higher at 8.21 cents.
Barrett Lewald, senior futures market analyst with Lind-Waldock in Chicago, said sugar was restrained by local trading, which dominated the market ahead of the holiday.
Copper futures also finished higher on the Commodity Exchange amid trading driven by technical factors. The March contract rose 1.25 cents, to 102.40 cents.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
A Most Extraordinary Fella

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.

 BODY:
One looks for turning points. How is it that he has come this far, this way? Maybe it was the time when Jim Abbott was 5 years old and came home from school, angry and tearful, and held up the steel hook a doctor had recommended he use for a right hand. "I don't want to wear this anymore," he told his parents.
Other children were afraid to play with him and, in the way that small children can be cruel, called him names like "Mr. Hook." Even then he struggled not to appear different. He never wore the hook again. 
 Or maybe it was the time when he saw that his parents had learned to tie a shoe with one hand so they could teach it to him. He, unlike them, was born with just one hand, his left.
Or maybe it was when his father in a park in Flint, Mich., taught him to throw a baseball and then remove the glove ever so smoothly and swiftly from his right wrist and place it on his left throwing hand in order to catch his dad's quick throw back, and then switch the glove back again in order to throw.
He developed the technique so skillfully that when he was pitching in high school, the story goes, the first nine batters on an opposing team tried to bunt for hits. He threw the runners out each time.
"That story has grown out of proportion," Abbott said. "It was only five or six batters."
 
As Normal as Any Other Kid
 Or maybe for Abbott, the 25-year-old pitcher recently obtained by the Yankees in a trade with the California Angels, there was no single turning point. Maybe it was simply the concept that his parents, Mike and Kathy Abbott, had come to live by, that Jim, except for the strange fate of having been born with one hand -- there is a stub with one small finger-like protrusion where the right hand would be -- was as normal as any other kid, and should think of himself that way.
Four years ago, Abbott became the first and only one-handed pitcher in baseball history, and one of the elite who can throw the ball at speeds of up to 94 miles an hour. Abbott also accomplished something else that, while not singular, is rare. He went from the campus of the University of Michigan to the Angels, their first-round pick in the amateur draft. He has never spent a day in the minor leagues.
Abbott's parents were married at 18 and had Jim when they were still 18. There was a time early on when they felt sorry for themselves, but they soon overcame the shock and influenced Jim not to feel sorry for himself, either.
Kathy Abbott recalled that occasionally Jim drew stares from people. "Oh, yes, because of Jim's hand," she said. "I'd forgot about it."
"I never heard Jim ask, 'Why me?' " said his father recently. "And as he grew up, I watched the way he handled himself around people. He's always had a lot of friends, always laughed. Even when some people have said insensitive or cruel things. Like a reporter asking, 'Is anyone else in your family deformed?' But Jim is always a gentleman. I don't understand how he does it. His dad is now taking lessons from him."
"My parents kept me in the mainstream; they never shielded me," Abbott said, sitting recently with his wife, Dana, on a stuffed white couch in their ground-floor apartment here. Outside, near the window, stood a palm tree. Inside, there was a small, decorated Christmas tree. Abbott said he felt blessed. "When we moved into a new neighborhood, my father said, 'Jim, go out and meet the kids. Say, I'm Jim Abbott. Ask to play in their game.' "
 
'I Look Back With Admiration'
 One can somehow still picture Abbott, now 6 feet 3 inches and 215 pounds and looking husky in a short-sleeve blue shirt, blue jeans and worn running shoes, as that blond-haired, open-faced, seeking boy. He recalled that his parents always supported him but never pushed him, that they emphasized he should do whatever came naturally, and that he could just about realize whatever dreams he had, including, eventually, pitching in the major leagues.
"I will always be thankful to my parents for how they dealt with it," he said. "They were young. They were alone. There were no support groups. Really, I look back with admiration."
Pitching for a mediocre Angels team that, as it happened, often didn't play well behind him or hit well for him, he managed to post commendable statistics. Last season, for a team that tied for fifth place in the American League West, Abbott compiled a 2.77 earned run average, fifth best in the league, although his record was 7-15. The year before, he was 18-11, with a 2.89 e.r.a. In his two previous seasons, his records were 12-12 and 10-14 (and in those 14 losses his team scored a total of 15 runs).
"He pitches his heart out every time," said Rod Carew, the Hall of Famer and the Angels' batting coach. "But he pitched with incredibly bad luck. He could win 20 games for the Yankees, easy. I'd put him in the category with Catfish Hunter and Nolan Ryan, some of the greatest pitchers I faced. And he's a terrific guy to be around. I hated to see him go."
On the bench, Angels players laughed among themselves how Abbott, with his cutting fastball and hard slider, broke five or six opponents' bats a game. And they would take pleasure in observing other players watch Abbott field a shot through the box, handling his glove so fast that it was nearly sleight-of-hand. "Did you see that!" players in the other dugout exclaimed. "Did you see that!"
Why, then, did the Angels trade Abbott? A contract dispute seems at the crux. Abbott was at the end of a one-year contract with an option. The Angels offered a four-year contract at $16 million. Abbott's agent, Scott Boras, had asked for a four-year deal for $19 million but made it clear that this was negotiable. At this point, it seems, Jackie Autry, who runs the team for her husband, the old troubadour-cowboy Gene Autry, and the general manager, Whitey Herzog, decided they would show Abbott and Boras who was boss and traded the pitcher for three Yankee minor league prospects.
"I was surprised," said Abbott. "I just thought I'd spend my whole career with the Angels. It's kind of easy to get it into your head that you're indispensable. And then suddenly I was traded and felt a real sense of rejection. And there were the concerns about coming to New York -- just a big, looming city. As great a city as it is -- and I've always loved to visit there -- I wasn't sure. You hear a lot of horror stories. And I was concerned about Dana making the transition because she was born and raised in Southern California. But she seemed excited about it."
Dana Douty lettered in basketball and earned a degree in economics from the University of California at Irvine last year, shortly before she and Abbott were married.
"Jim's such a fierce competitor that going to the Yankees will just be another challenge for him," she said. "He even hates it when I beat him in gin rummy."
"But I'm getting better," Abbott insisted.
"You are," she assured with a smile, "you are."
Despite his boyish looks, Abbott hardly seems one to be intimidated, even by New York City.
"I like the team the Yankees are putting together," he said. "I like the players they've recently picked up, like Jimmy Key and Wade Boggs and Spike Owen and Paul O'Neill, and plus, of course, it's a privilege to play with guys like Mattingly -- or should I call him Don?" He smiled. "Or Mr. Mattingly?" He was half serious.
"And I have no problem with anything I've heard about George Steinbrenner. I mean, it sounds to me like he wants to have a winner in the worst way. I love that."
Abbott spoke about a phone call from Yankees Manager Buck Showalter. "You'll like the fans," Showalter told Abbott. "They stay for the whole game and hang on every pitch, and they know baseball. They'll cheer you when you do well and boo when you don't. But there's an excitement at Yankee Stadium that's different from Anaheim."
"The call pumped me up," said Abbott. And while he didn't want to say anything bad about the Angels, a team that "gave me a chance," he was nonetheless upset when he read something an Angels executive had said: "Oh, people are unhappy to lose Abbott only because he's a one-armed pitcher."
"I have an arm," said Abbott. "I don't have a hand."
Abbott is not the only one-handed player in major league history. There was Pete Gray, the one-armed outfielder for the St. Louis Browns in 1945. "I didn't grow up wanting to be another Pete Gray," said Abbott. "I grew up wanting to be another Nolan Ryan."
From a Scholarship
To Sullivan Award
Abbott was always a good athlete, and sports has helped give him a sense of stature that he might not have had otherwise. He became a high school pitching sensation and then got a scholarship to Michigan, where he majored in communications and was so brilliant a pitcher (and a capable batter, too) that in 1987 he was named amateur baseball player of the year. In 1988, he won the Sullivan Award as the best amateur athlete in the country.
With all that, he is not pleased when, for example, people have come to him to autograph a baseball that Pete Gray had signed. While Abbott admires Gray, he doesn't want to be thought of as an oddity.
Gray, for all his remarkable achievements and ability, was still kind of a sideshow in the major leagues, a wartime player used primarily to draw crowds, a player who would be introduced last to the fans in pre-game introductions. Gray batted .218 in his one year in the big leagues. Abbott is one of the finer pitchers in baseball, and, after four seasons, an established one.
"I just don't think all of this about me playing with one hand is as big an issue as everyone wants to make it," said Abbott. "I don't try to run from the attention about it, I just accept it."
Abbott received so much mail with the Angels -- as many as 300 letters a week -- that the public relations department regularly piled it into shopping carts when he was on the road. Many of the letters were from children who were physically handicapped or disabled, or from parents of such children.
"Some of the stories are unbelievable, so tragic," said Abbott. One letter came from an 8-year-old girl who had been attacked by a mountain lion and lost an arm. Another boy had lost an arm when fireworks exploded.
"I try to write them all back. But sometimes there's really not much I can say. I don't really believe in this stuff about ballplayers as role models. But if I can be of help to anyone, if anyone can take something from the fact that I'm a baseball pitcher, then fine.
"But when I'm out on the mound pitching, I'm pitching because I love it, because I like the challenge of trying to get people out. I'm not pitching because I want to prove anything to anyone."
In every city he travels to, parents bring their children to meet him. "There was this one boy, about 7 years old, who came into the clubhouse with his parents," Abbott recalled. "He had only parts of two fingers on one hand. He asked me if kids were mean when I was growing up. He said they called him 'Crab' at camp. I said, 'Yeah, they used to say that my hand looks like a foot.' I said to him, 'Do you think that teasing is a problem?' He said, 'No.' I said, 'Is there anything you can't do?' And he said, 'No.' And I said, 'Well, I don't think so either.'
"Then I looked around the room and said to him, 'Look, I'm playing with guys like Dave Winfield and Wally Joyner and Dave Parker. I'm playing with them and I'm just like you.' I'd never said that before, that I was thrilled to be here and it didn't matter if I had two good hands. But I put myself into his shoes and remembered what I was like at his age. And I'm sure that kids need someone to relate to. But so do their parents. Most of the time I think it's my parents these people should be talking to, not me."
While there were surely grim moments in his background, much of it, he says, he has blocked out. Like, perhaps, his feelings of self-consciousness as he tried to hide the stub of his hand from view. Even now, perhaps subconsciously, his father said, he still sometimes does.
But Abbott, meanwhile, tries to look forward, not backward, which is why he has turned down numerous movie and book offers.
"I'd hate to be held to what I said or thought when I was 21 years old," he said. "But anyway, a book on me would be boring. Like, 'Oh yeah, he pitched a great game.' Or, 'When he was losing with the Angels he got booed.' Not great literature."
It was near the end of day, the sun was setting behind the palm tree and the Christmas tree, and the Abbotts rose to get in some late Christmas shopping.
They entered the apartment garage, where a set of his golf clubs in a red golf bag leaned against the wall. Abbott climbed behind the wheel of his cream-colored minivan. He was asked: Is there anything he can't do that he wished he could?
"Yes," he said, after a moment. "I'd love to play the piano."

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Bruce Weber

 BODY:

Looking for the Brass Ring
The thunderous success of "Carousel" at the National Theater in London was the catalyst of nearly all the Christmas-week buzz in the theater world. What will happen to Nicholas Hytner's production when it closes at the National's Lyttelton Theater on March 28? 
 Whether a commercial production opens first in New York City or in London seems to be a matter of when an appropriate theater will be available on Broadway. "Carousel" needs a deep stage and would best be served by a house with an intimate feel, but it's a big musical -- the cast numbers 36 -- and economics demand a lot of seats.
The same economics is what has created the Broadway logjam. Big musicals have to run and run and run to pay for themselves, and it is unlikely that "Carousel" can displace, any time soon, any of the shows now in theaters where it would fit -- "Les Miserables" at the Imperial, for example, or "Jelly's Last Jam" at the more modern Virginia. Indeed, neither the Shubert Organization nor Jujamcyn Theaters has an available venue this spring, and many people believe that the two available theaters owned by the Nederlander Organization -- the Minskoff (1,621 seats) and the Gershwin (1,933) -- are too cavernous to serve "Carousel" in a befitting manner.
"It's playing at a modern theater in London," said Ted Chapin, the executive director of the Rodgers and Hammerstein Organization, which controls the rights to the show, referring to the 890-seat Lyttelton. "But the big, modern houses on Broadway are not emotionally friendly."
It would be difficult, in any case, to move the show to Broadway before the Tony deadline (the first week in May), particularly since there will be the added complication of satisfying union requirements for a largely British cast. Mr. Chapin said the possibilities included an immediate commercial run in London (although it's far from clear where the show could be put on to advantage in the available West End houses, either) or a hiatus, with the company reconstituting itself, perhaps in the fall, when some other theaters may come available. He also said that Cameron Mackintosh had the inside track as the producer for a commercial run, but he didn't know what Mr. Mackintosh, who is spending the holidays at a phoneless retreat in Scotland, had in mind.
 
A Clash of Performing Cultures
 Part of the charm of "Orpheus in Love," the witty operatic update of the Orpheus myth running at Circle Rep through Jan. 3, is in the collision of theatrical and musical cultures, and the almost riotous discomfort it has engendered in its audiences. With its atonal score by Gerald Busby and its half-slapstick, half-literary libretto (the Orpheus character is a viola teacher at a community college) by Craig Lucas, it's an odd duck of a piece, especially at Circle Rep, where more conventional theater has long been cozily received.
"Theater people don't seem to like it, but music people do," said Bradley Garvin, the bass who sings the central role, much of it lying in bed.
"You can feel their dismay; it's palpable," Mr. Lucas said of some regular Circle Rep attendees who have arrived unprepared. "There was a clear sense of 'I didn't buy my subscription to go to an opera.' " At one intermission, Mr. Lucas said, a man stood outside the theater exhorting people to leave. "He was on the sidewalk, shouting: 'Set yourselves free. You don't have to go back in.' "
Mr. Lucas spoke with an air of humor and resignation; not everyone goes to the theater to be surprised or challenged, after all. And besides, he acknowledged, the piece, weird in its execution, was weird from its inception. It began as a collection of individual, unrelated songs that he and Mr. Busby wrote and later rewrote and knitted together into a loosely connected dream sequence, suggestive of love and loss. The Orpheus rubric was Mr. Busby's idea, and Mr. Lucas embraced it, at least in part for its symbolic value.
"You don't have to have been awake during the AIDS epidemic to find it in the opera," he said. "It is about someone who has love cruelly taken away from him."
Tanya Berezin, Circle Rep's artistic director, spent about $200,000 mounting the show, about twice what is typical, largely because of a longstanding relationship with Mr. Lucas, whose previous Circle Rep productions include "Reckless" and "Prelude to a Kiss." She admitted that the board had been "very reticent and nervous" about taking on the project, and that casting for singers who could act was particularly difficult, but said that ultimately everyone was pleased by the stretch.
For their part, the performers have also found some perplexities in crossing over from the operatic stage. "Most operatic arias are sung standing up, not lying on your back," Mr. Garvin observed.
Diane Ketchie, a soprano and a pianist, said the singers had to teach the theater people about "the concept of vocal rest. When we saw the schedule -- two Saturday shows and two Sunday shows every week -- I nearly went into cardiac arrest."
Ms. Ketchie said she has been enjoying the intimacy of the Circle Rep space, but she sympathized a bit with the audience. "I wonder, when we're singing full-throttle high notes, what kind of experience it is listening to that."
 
Tap: Past, Present, Future
 "I remember when Duke Snider retired," Gregory Hines said. "I figured, that's it for centerfield. Then along came Willie Davis."
Mr. Hines was using baseball's Dodgers to make a point about his own place in the world of tap dance, a place emphasized by "Ted Levy and Friends," the evening of tap he directed on Monday night at the New School. Featuring, among others, Jimmy Slyde, 67; Mr. Hines, 46; Mr. Levy, 32, and the prodigiously athletic 19-year-old Savion Glover, the show illustrated the art's line of descent, and its current red-hot flame. "Gregory Hines is the Pied Piper of modern tap," Mr. Levy said afterward, "but the torch is always being passed."
Mr. Levy, who said he was moved to make tap his career when he saw the movie "White Nights," which starred Mr. Hines and Mikhail Baryshnikov ("I said, this cat is dancing with a ballet dancer?"), pointed to Mr. Glover's recent television commercial for Chevrolet as a sign that tap is on the verge of going mass market.
Mr. Hines agreed it's tap's time -- and Savion Glover's time. The two of them, who share the stage in "Jelly's Last Jam," have a movie project in the works.
"When I was 14," Mr. Hines said, "I looked up to Honi Coles and Sammy Davis and Bunny Briggs. Those men were 25 or 30 years older than I was. When Savion was 14, he looked up to me. The 14-year-old dancers now look up to Savion. There's a wave going to come, with Savion in the lead."
 
 
 
FILLING ANOTHER SISTER'S SHOES
 Next Friday, Christine Estabrook will replace Frances McDormand as Pfeni, the youngest of "The Sisters Rosensweig" in Wendy Wasserstein's play at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater. Ms. Estabrook, who appeared in Ms. Wasserstein's "Heidi Chronicles," will join the rest of the original "Sisters" cast when the show moves to the Ethel Barrymore Theater on March 3.

HEADLINE: A Nostalgic Look At Fun and Games

BYLINE: By ANDREW H. MALCOLM

DATELINE: KATONAH, N.Y.

 BODY:
PARCHEESI, it can now be revealed, causes stomach flu.
I know this because in my childhood every single time I stayed home from school because I had turned green, the Parcheesi board was found next to my bed, plus crackers, warm ginger ale, at times tepid tea and sufficient Kleenex to blip the stock of the Kimberly Clark Corporation. (Never mind the battered pot always within emergency reach.) 
 To be fair, some bedside blame for my flus, measles, mumps, chicken pox and other childhood maladies should also fall on Chinese checkers, Snakes and Ladders and perhaps poker, which my father taught me when Mom was out. (When Dad was away, she tried tutoring me in bridge. But I fell asleep.)
As youngsters, we have the most wondrous way of unconsciously soaking up indelible intellectual associations. Say New Year's Eve today, and I instantly picture little-boy pajamas with the seat flap and built-in slippers, because that's what I was always wearing when roused to watch Ben Grauer watch the next year arrive in Times Square. (Why, by the way, does every new year start with those same two men climbing that light pole and removing their shirts at midnight to celebrate Dick Clark's growing one year younger?)
Likewise, the slightest scent of cigar smoke today makes me think of yesterday's baseball games, which may explain that sport's declining attendance.
So, now you say Parcheesi, and I think of retching. No offense to Milt Bradley.
That explains the absence of a closetful of battered game boxes in our house, each with the traditional one piece missing. (All right, there is a game of rabblSce, but words are my profession and a triple-word score can make an entire day.) And it explains my initial reaction to news that the Katonah Museum of Art has opened a new exhibition titled "The Board Game: America at Play 1845-1945." Even with free admission in tree-strewn Westchester County, who wants to wax nostalgic about nausea?
But Skip Hospital and Go Directly to Museum. For many, this exhibition about what I once thought were called bored games may well be more fun than the games themselves. Certainly more informative.
Of course, it's not so much the myriad games on display here through Feb. 28. (Did anybody with the slightest sign of brain activity ever really buy and then play a game called Bobby and Betty's Trip to the New York World's Fair?) What's compelling is what the games tell us about the contemporary society that produced and played them, its passions, priorities and prejudices, and how our country and its values have changed since. "Our games mirror our society," says William C. Ketchum, the show's guest curator, who also writes about folk art.
 
Reflecting Their Times
 What a mirror! Early board games were flat morality plays with players spinning a wheel (dice, you'll recall, were associated with gambling and the devil) to move through Frugality and Diligence to a pictorial Heaven bearing a remarkable resemblance to the suburbia in promotional brochures for modern housing developers.
In the faddish 1890's, when bicycling swept the land like nothing until Hula Hoops, there was the Bicycle Race: A Game for Wheelmen. In expansionist turn-of-the-century days, families could sit around with jingoistic pastimes like the Rough Riders Game and the Philippine War Game: Crushing the Rebellion in Luzon. (The ultimate goal was Manila, of course, but the landing came at a place called Subic Bay, which the United States just lost.)
By the Roaring 20's, American consumers were consumed by Keeping Up With the Joneses. (Wouldn't it be interesting someday to peruse the checkbook of the original ostentatious Joneses?) Then came Monopoly, of course, which Mr. Ketchum and his siblings played all through their father's long unemployment, and Cabby: The Game With Rules Made to Be Broken. Of course.
In 1939, before the enemy could be properly identified, there was Flying G-Men: Dynamiting the Lid Off the Foreign Spy Menace, followed in 1942 by Dave Dawson's Pacific Battle Game, then the Ration Board Game and Air Raid Warden ("Unexploded Bomb on Broadway Between Union and Main"). And just imagine the excitement of the Let's Go to College Game (1944).
 
Evolution of a Pastime
 Some form of board game existed 4,000 years ago. (That's a good question for Trivial Pursuit. Here's another: In what country was Trivial Pursuit invented?) But modern games have typically required a middle class with sufficient size, disposable income and time to play.
Not surprisingly, different cultures produce different games. Board games were popular in 17th- and 18th-century Europe. To this day Europeans like chess along with cheese, wine and car races full of finesse turns. Americans prefer Monopoly, beer, chips and the Indianapolis 500, which entails 2,000 very fast left turns. Other popular American games involve vaporizing aliens with electron guns or smashing a mallet on the heads of gophers who pop up from holes in a table. (The mallet, thank goodness, is chained to the table.)
Games -- video, athletic and board -- have become an integral part of American culture. In fact, someone could argue that thanks to opinion polls and television, modern American life is like one big board game with few players and millions of spectators. Win New Hampshire. Pass Iowa. Capture California. Enter the White House. Add some rich competitors, and you can see Barry Bonds Break the Bank, Ivan Boesky Land on Insider Trading (Go to Prison) and Donald Trump Buy the Plaza, Mortgage Boardwalk, Lose Wife, Sell Airline, Enter Bankruptcy and Refinance Casino.
Historically, the growth of American board games was greatly hindered by the enduring Puritan ethic of the Cotton Mather crowd (picture them sitting around in those immense collars saying, "Go Fish!") and the lingering belief that leisure time was a fertile field for the work of you-know-who from you-know-where. Few frontier homes had time or space for parlors or drawing rooms.
The 1840's, however, witnessed the start of drastic changes in the lives of Americans, and their games. Instead of being merely extra farmhands, society began seeing children as future adults, who required training. And how better could conscientious parents train offspring than through educational games, which reinforced and rewarded the same virtues society professed to value in real life?
 
A Certain Kind of Progress
 No accident that early game producers were book publishers and mapmakers. No accident that games' popularity grew with the advent of labor-saving machinery and socially acceptable leisure time in the post-Civil War Industrial Age. (No accident, either, that the painful Civil War -- and Vietnam too, come to think of it -- did not immediately produce games.)
However, the spread of the nation's transportation network provided game possibilities for competitors to cross the country and ostensibly learn geography en route, as did Lucky Lindy's trans-Atlantic flight and the newspaperwoman Nellie Bly's successful bid to circle the globe and beat Jules Verne's 80-day record by one week. (Ponder the commercial sophistication in that one: an 1890 board game of a newspaper's circulation stunt to beat a fictitious travel record.)
The advent of radio and the mass media in the late 1920's opened a new spectrum of commercial game possibilities, from Superman and Little Orphan Annie to games built around a dummy called Charlie McCarthy and a rodent named Mickey Mouse. As a sign of progress, millions of Americans chewing dinner each night can now yell "Jeopardy" answers at their deaf television sets.
But imagine the impact of board games on values and aspirations before the mass media, back when 8 of 10 Americans lived in the country. They might spend one hour a week in church, but many more spinning the wheel on Mansion of Happiness, the Chequered Game of Life, Shall I Marry? or Errand Boy, which turned Horatio Alger into a game.
 
Shifting Values
 In Mansion (1843), players moved through five dozen spaces from Piety and Charity (move ahead) to Audacity and Immodesty (lose one turn). The European edition showed a topless woman for Chastity, an image deemed contradictory to players in North America, where she received a robe and torch. Over the years other changes crept in: Poverty became a vice, along with Sabbath Breakers (baseball players), and Prudence (a woman sewing) became a man banking money.
In Chequered (1863), the point was to acquire the most points (5 for landing on Honesty or College, but 10 big ones for Government Contract). Fat (political) Office was a major goal.
Shall I Marry? (1890) was another in the Old Maid genre suggesting women could be fulfilled only through marriage. Interestingly, however, many other games like Nellie Bly reflected women's liberation long before even suffrage. Although American Indians were generally portrayed as wily foes, other games like Watermelon Patch (1896) played to racial stereotypes and prejudices.
With no national media, each game's box had to sell itself. This produced colorful and imaginative lithography, which still excites collectors like Mary Lou Alpert, who spent nearly two years assembling this exhibition. Many collectors have made a game out of acquiring old games at auctions for thousands of real dollars.
Congratulations! You have reached The End. The answer to that Trivial Pursuit question is: Canada.
 
WHERE ANY NUMBER CAN PLAY
 "THE BOARD GAME: AMERICA AT PLAY, 1845-1945" is on view through Feb. 28 at the Katonah Museum of Art, Route 22 at Jay Street, Katonah, N.Y. Hours: tomorrow, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sunday and Tuesday through New Year's Day, 1 to 5 P.M. After Jan. 1, the museum is open Tuesdays through Fridays and Sundays, 1 to 5 P.M.; Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Free admission.
Special events are planned at the Katonah Museum as part of the exhibition. There will be a family workshop on making one's own game on Jan. 9 at 10:30 A.M.; fee, $8 a family. There will be a workshop for children in game-making on Jan. 16 at 10:30 A.M. Information: (914) 232-9555.
On Jan. 23, from 10 A.M. to 1 P.M., there will be a free seminar called "Games in America, Then and Now," featuring a discussion with Robert Weis, a consultant on childhood play; Richard H. Berg, a game designer, and William C. Ketchum, a guest curator.
In addition, in Manhattan there is a games exhibition on view at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 76th Street. "VICTORIAN PLEASURES: 19TH-CENTURY AMERICAN BOARD AND TABLE GAMES" will be on view through Jan. 3 at the society. On permanent display, there is "A TREASURY OF TOYS," a collection of stuffed toys, doll furniture, racing cars and other items from the 19th and early 20th centuries. Hours: Sunday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Jan. 3, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. On Jan. 4, the exhibition galleries are to close for at least nine months and reopen in September pending a permanent collaboration with the New York Public Library or another cultural institution. Admission: $4.50; $3 for students and the elderly; $1 for children under 12. Information: (212) 873-3400.

HEADLINE: Sounds Around Town: On New Year's Eve

 BODY:

POP AND ROCK
 
Dr. John 
 Dr. John, Tramps, 51 West 21st Street, Chelsea, (212) 727-7788. When Dr. John comes to town, he brings with him an air of fantastic New Orleans decadence: as he sits at the piano, tossing off blues, funk and honky-tonk riffs, an exotically outfitted snake dancer enters the stage and puts his music in motion. Her pet is a long, thick, heavy reptile that she wears around her neck like a boa; she preens, dances with it and occasionally allows its tongue to graze Dr. John's ear. All the while he keeps playing, aloof and unfazed by this parlor trickery. His repertory runs from the Louisiana standard "Iko Iko" to his own hits like "Right Place, Wrong Time," and his gruff voice is as lazily entrancing as his effortless piano style. Dr. John plays one show from about 11 P.M. until 1 A.M.; the zydeco accordionist Rockin' Dopsie, who likes to dress modestly in a royal crown and robe, performs a set before and after, around 9 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. A table reservation with four-course dinner, Champagne toast and party favors costs $110 a person; general admission, which includes just Champagne toast and party favors, is $50. KAREN SCHOEMER
 
Punk Party
Lunachicks and the Vacant Lot, CBGB, 315 Bowery at Bleecker Street, East Village, (212) 982-4052. New Year's Eve at CBGB is a kind of case study in antifestivity. The celebrated punk dungeon has grimy, graffiti-encrusted walls; crowded tables that wobble but don't fall down; a string or two of colored lights (if you're lucky), and onstage at midnight, the abrasive, angst-and-estrogen-charged Lunachicks. Also on the bill is the Vacant Lot, whose three-chord guitar jive is awfully reminiscent of former CBGB kings the Ramones; the Vacant Lot's new single "Just One Night" is loaded with retro-pop positivity. Other bands include the psycho noisemakers Karen Black and heavy-metal buffoons Rawg. Show starts around 10 P.M. The $15 admission includes Champagne toast and party favors. K. S.
 
Old-Style Crooning
Howard Hewett and After Seven, Apollo Theater, 253 West 125th Street, Harlem, (212) 749-5838. A bunch of love men up there telling the audience -- mostly women -- who, what and where. Howard Hewett is an old-style crooner, and After Seven, a vocal group, is retro old-style, all slick harmonies and smooth moves. Shows are at 7 and 11 P.M. Tickets are $30 to $40 for the first show and $35 to $45 for the second, which includes a Champagne toast. PETER WATROUS
 
Brash Iconoclast
Chaka Khan, the Roxy, 515 West 18th Street, Chelsea, (212) 307-7171. Extravagance personified, Chaka Khan has been on a roll recently. She has been singing songs from her almost 25-year career, and audiences have been going wild, appropriate behavior for New Year's Eve. She has become an institution. The doors open at 10, with an appearance by Ms. Khan at 2 A.M. Tickets are $30. P. W.
 
Thoughtful Funk
Kid Creole and the Coconuts, Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (212) 353-1600. August Darnell, alias Kid Creole, leads New York City's most literary funk band, working out questions of desire, ego and cultural identity with the help of a wise and sassy chorus line, the Coconuts. The band performs at midnight. Tickets are $40 in advance or $50 at the door, including a Champagne toast and party favors, or $100 for V.I.P. tickets, including an open bar. JON PARELES
 
Cajun and More
Beausoleil, Lone Star Roadhouse, 240 West 52d Street, Manhattan (212) 245-2950. Based in Lafayette, La., Beausoleil started out as Cajun-music traditionalists, then broadened its mandate. Now, its fiddle and accordion and rhythm section look to the Caribbean and beyond for good-timey hybrids. Opening: the Pinballs, a New York Cajun band. The show starts at 9:30 P.M. Tickets are $20, $35 and $65. J. P.
 
Soukous and Soca
Diblo Dibala and Matchatcha, with Black Stalin, Harambee, 127 West 43d Street, Manhattan, (212) 819-1133. Diblo Dibala's gleaming, coiling, tickling guitar lines helped define modern soukous (a light rumba rhythm garlanded with guitars) with Kanda Bongo Man's band and with Loketo. His latest group, Matchatcha, is as buoyant as ever. Black Stalin, from Trinidad, is a soca singer who slips political comment into his double-entendres. Doors open at 8 P.M. The live show starts sometime after 11 P.M. Three disk jockeys will play dance music until 7 A.M. Admission is $70 a person or $130 a couple with dinner and a Champagne toast; $30 a person and $55 a couple with just a Champagne toast. J. P.
 
A Soulful Voice
Joan Osborne, Wetlands, 161 Hudson Avenue, at Laight Street, TriBeCa, (212) 966-4225. Like a younger Bonnie Raitt, Joan Osborne applies the lessons of blues and soul music -- directness, economy and a voice that can flirt and sob and sigh -- in songs about what she sees now, from lowlife to true love. Doors open at 9 P.M. on New Year's Eve; admission is $20. J. P.
 
Old Favorites
Elliott Sharp Trio, Nick and Eddie, 203 Spring Street, at Sullivan Street, SoHo, (212) 219-9090. Elliott Sharp on tenor saxophone and guitar, Dave Hofstra on bass and Bobby Previte on drums usually perform with downtown jazz and improvisational groups, including Carbon, the Microscopic Septet and the New York Composers Orchestra. For their annual New Year's Eve job, they relax with standards, rhythm-and-blues tunes and other non-avant-garde material. Show starts at 9:30 P.M. A four-course dinner with a Champagne toast is $75; reservations are required. At the bar, there is no cover or minimum. J. P.
 
Flo and Eddie
The Turtles, featuring Flo and Eddie, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, at Mercer Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 228-6300. Although the Turtles had pop hits like "Elenore" and "Happy Together," they never took rock too seriously, which may be why their singers, Howard Kayland and Mark Volman, nicknamed Flo and Eddie, moved on to work with Frank Zappa. They're likely to mix the oldies with jaundiced parodies of recent hits. On New Year's Eve, tickets are $25 for the 10 P.M. show, $16 for the 1 A.M. show. There are also shows on Wednesday, next Friday and Jan. 2 at 8 and 11 P.M.; tickets are $16. J. P.
 
Avant-Garde Fury
Diamanda Galas, the Village Gate, 160 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 475-5120. The Persephone of avant-garde music continues her reports from the underworld with a show that includes excerpts from her recent composition, "Judgment Day." If you thought heavy-metal singers could howl, you've never witnessed the fury of Galas. A very serious way to usher in the New Year. Show starts at 12:30 A.M. Tickets, at $30, include an open bar and buffet from 10 P.M. to 2 A.M. and are available at the box office or through Ticketmaster: (212) 307-7171. ANNE POWERS
 
Upbeat Diva
Ce Ce Peniston with Marky Mark and the Funky Bunch, the Palladium, 126 East 14th Street, East Village, (212) 473-7171. Ce Ce Peniston, a sunny-spirited diva, broke through with "Finally," a dance-floor smash that showed off her bright vocal tones against an irresistible, optimistic beat. Her show will probably be short (she's a diva, after all) but fun. As for Marky Mark, if you've walked past a billboard or bus-stop ad lately, you know what you'll get. This hip-hop pinup's music is secondary to his floor show, which isn't bad. Tickets are $40 in advance or $50 at the door and are available at the box office or through Ticketmaster: (212) 307-7171. Doors open at 9 P.M. The show starts at 12:30 A.M. A. P.
 
From the Clash
Big Audio Dynamite and Moby, Roseland, 239 West 52d Street, Manhattan, (212) 249-8870. The Clash's funkiest member, Mick Jones, grew out of punk rock into a love for British dance music, and he's making swell sounds out of what he's learned. B.A.D. II plays with techno but stays centered in sparkly guitar pop. Moby, the show's opener, is one of rave's pioneers, moving these days toward an ambient house sound that gives his creativity some breathing room. Doors open at 9, and the show starts at 10 P.M. Tickets are $35 in advance, $40 the day of the show, available through Ticketmaster: (212) 307-7171. A. P.
 
Anarchist Rock
The Mekons, Maxwell's, 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J., (201) 798-4064. A party with these British dance-hall punks and anarchist intellectuals always brings a tear to the eye and a new idea to the brain. The last few years have been hard for the Mekons, between record-company problems and personal differences among members, but the band has a new album coming out soon and, one hopes, a new lease on life. Anyway, they're always good for a drinking song. Doors open at 9:30 P.M., and the show starts at 10:30. Tickets are $30 and include a buffet and a Champagne toast; they can be purchased through Ticketron: (212) 307-7171. A. P.
 
Hard Rockabilly
Belmont Playboys, Louisiana Community Bar and Grill, 622 Broadway, at Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 460-9633. With slicked-back hair, tattoos, a bass painted with flames and an Elvisocentric attitude, the Belmont Playboys (from Belmont, N.C.) pump out high-powered rockabilly songs that never stop twanging. The show begins at midnight. A $30 dinner package includes a Champagne toast. Show tickets only, at $10, include one drink. J. P.
 
Sixties Excess
Blues Travelers/Chris Whitley, the Paramount, Seventh Avenue at 33d Street, Manhattan, (212) 465-6741. Like a bad acid flashback, Blues Traveler recreates the jejune excesses of 1960's blues-rock. While barefoot fans twirl, John Popper sings in a nasal whine, then spews hundreds of harmonica notes in endless, aimless jams. But Chris Whitley, sharing the bill, has learned the economy, pain and enigma of the blues; he sings in a hard-won voice and plays slide-guitar lines that make every note count. The Mad Hatters open at 9 P.M.; tickets are $30. J. P.

 
 
JAZZ
Acoustic Corea
Chick Corea, Hilton Ruiz and Koko Taylor, Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 475-0049. What a strange show! Chick Corea will be performing acoustically, and perhaps he'll show some of the musical ability for which he is best known. Koko Taylor is a blues shouter without a bit of subtlety, raw and overdriven, while Hilton Ruiz is a fine pianist who knows the difference between a mambo and a bossa nova, rare in jazz. The New Year's Eve shows are at 6 and 9:30 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. Tickets, including a four-course dinner, are $110 for the first show and $175 for the second; the third, which includes breakfast instead of dinner, is $90. P. W.
 
Piano Man
John Hicks, Bradley's, 70 University Place, Greenwich Village, (212) 228-6440. John Hicks, one of jazz's best pianists, will be joined by an exceptional rhythm section: Ray Drummond on bass and Idris Muhammad on drums. Expect absolutely refined, interactive music. The music starts at 9 P.M. Admission, including a five-course dinner, is $115. From 1 to 4 A.M., there is a $20 cover charge. P. W.
 
New Orleans Jazz
Dr. Michael White, Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at Perry Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 255-4037. It's hard to imagine anything more festive than Dr. Michael White's band, which specializes in the raucous sounds of New Orleans polyphony. This is where one of the sounds of joy comes from in American music, and Dr. White does it better than most. Shows are at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M., and the cover is $40, with a $20 drink minimum. Cajun snacks are provided. P. W.
 
Trumpet Trip
Nat Adderley, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 242-1785. Nat Adderley, a gifted, smooth-toned trumpeter, always leads a fine band. He'll travel between elegance and intensity, and explosions are part of the musical landscape. The show starts at 9 P.M. and includes dinner and Champagne for $99. The last show starts at 1 A.M.; there is a $20 cover charge. P. W.
 
 
 
CABARET

 
Black Tie
 The Rainbow Room and Rainbow and Stars, 30 Rockefeller Center, 65th floor, (212) 632-5000. For those who can afford it, the complex of nightclubs atop Rockefeller Center offers the kind of Manhattan glamour that recalls a dreamy Astaire-Rogers fantasy of the Emerald City. At the Rainbow Room, Tommy Tune will perform in an evening of festivities that begins at 9 P.M. and includes a seven-course dinner and dancing to the Rainbow Room Orchestra, featuring Steven Davis and Claudette Sierra. At midnight, the debonair dancing star with the eternally boyish smile will lead a parade through the entire 65th floor of the complex. The price is $375 a person, not including tax, tip or beverages, and black tie is required. Rainbow and Stars will present "Make Someone Happy! The Jule Styne Revue," an uneven cabaret show featuring Ann Hampton Callaway, Gregg Edelman, David Garrison, Kay McClelland, Jay Leonhart and William Roy. The high points are Ms. Callaway's bravura performances of two songs from "Funny Girl." The evening, which starts at 9 P.M. and includes a five-course dinner, is $300 a person, not including tax, tip or beverages; black tie is required. At the Rainbow Pavilion, the Impalas, a late-50's doo-wop group, will perform. The evening, which includes a five-course dinner and continuous dancing, starts at 9 P.M. The cost is $300 a person, not including tax, tip or beverages. Black tie is required. STEPHEN HOLDEN
 
Jelly Roll Salute
"Vernel Bagneris Presents Jelly Roll Morton: A Me-morial," Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, Manhattan, (212) 758-2272. Vernel Bagneris has created several shows saluting musicians from his native New Orleans. In the latest, he portrays the pioneering jazz pianist and composer, quoting from tapes that Morton recorded in 1938 for the Library of Congress and singing some Morton songs. The Norwegian pianist Morten Gunnar Larsen plays Morton's music beautifully. Shows are at 8:45 and 11:30 P.M. The cover charge is $25 for the early show and $35 for the late show, with a two-drink minimum at each. There is also an alternative prix fixe, dinner-and-show package at $65 for the early show and $85 for the late. S. H.
 
A Romantic
Andrea Marcovicci, the Oak Room at the Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, Manhattan, (212) 840-6800. Nobody embodies the modern woman as a romantic nostalgist -- and all the contradictions that implies -- more engagingly than Andrea Marcovicci, who is performing her special seasonal show, "Home for the Holidays," on New Year's Eve. Dinner is at 8, and the show is at 10 P.M. The price for dinner, the show and a Champagne toast is $160 a person, not including tax, tip and other beverages. S. H.
 
Torch Songs
Amanda McBroom, Russian Tea Room, 150 West 57th Street, Manhattan, (212) 265-0947. Amanda McBroom, who is still best remembered as the composer of "The Rose," may be the most talented cabaret performer based in Los Angeles. She sings her confessional torch songs in a luscious, theatrical voice that is full of heart and tinged with a hint of country. Shows on New Year's Eve are at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M. There is a $45 music charge and a $30 minimum per person. S. H.
 
Two Jazz Women
Rosa Maria and Blossom Dearie, the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, Chelsea, (212) 244-3005. The Ballroom will begin its third annual winter season of Brazilian music on New Year's Eve with the jazz and blues singer Rosa Maria. Her program will focus on the kinship between samba and reggae. If this year's show is like last year's, it will include several well-known American rock and soul songs rearranged in Latin American styles. Shows are at 10 P.M. and 1 A.M., and there is a $45 cover charge and a two-drink minimum. Earlier in the evening, at 7:30 P.M., Blossom Dearie, the jazz singer, pianist and songwriter, with a delicious wisp of a voice and an impeccable sense of swing, will perform. The show is at 7:30 P.M., and there is a $25 cover charge and a two-drink minimum. S. H.
 
 
 
COMEDY
Stand-Up Comics
Mike Sweeney and Others, Caroline's, 1626 Broadway, at 49th Street, (212) 757-4100. New York's leading comedy club is offering two separate New Year's Eve packages. The first is an 8 P.M. dinner show with Mike Sweeney as host; it will feature several top New York comics, including David Attel, Jon Stewart and the very funny, politically acute, feminist comic Brett Butler. The package, which includes a three-course dinner, is $45 a person. The "Countdown Celebration" at 10:30 P.M. includes an open bar, an antipasto platter, a Champagne toast and party favors. Mr. Sweeney will again be the host for a program that features Dave Chappel, Henriette Mantell, Warren Hutcherson and John Mullrooney. It is $125 a person and includes a dance party from 12:30 to 4:30 A.M. S. H.
 
Improv Skits
The First Amendment Comedy Troupe and Sam Greenfield, Creative Place Theater, 750 Eighth Avenue, at 47th Street, Manhattan, (212) 678-0076. The First Amendment is one of New York's longest-running improvisational companies. Although its personnel continually change, its countercultural attitudes have remained constant. Joined by Sam Greenfield as guest comedian, the troupe will look back at the year in skits inspired by audience suggestions. Expect nasty parting shots at the Bush Administration. New Year's Eve shows are at 8 and 10 P.M. Tickets are $20 for the early show and $30 for the late. There will be Champagne and a post-performance party for ticket holders to either show. S. H.
 
Up-and-Comers
Susie Essman, Walli Collins, Judy Gold and Joe Mulligan, Stand-Up NY 236 West 78th Street, Manhattan, (212) 595-0850. Al Lubel is the special guest at the 10:30 P.M. show, which is $40 a person with a $10 minimum. S. H.

A five-mile run that starts at Tavern on the Green, Central Park West and 67th Street, and continues south to the East Drive and north to 95th Street and then heads back to Tavern on the Green, where it ends. FIREWORKS IN PROSPECT PARK, Brooklyn. Midnight. Preceded by music and dancing on the Main Drive, off Flatbush Avenue, at 11 P.M.
FIREWORKS AT THE SOUTH STREET SEAPORT, lower Manhattan. A display over the East River. Midnight.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 464 words

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
Clinton's Last Selections for the Cabinet Reflect His Quest for Diversity

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

 BODY:

Bruce Babbitt
Secretary of the Interior 
 Bruce Babbitt, the man President-elect Bill Clinton has chosen to be Secretary of the Interior, inherited his interest in the outdoors.
His forebears were frontier merchants in the canyon country of northern Arizona, and he is now president of the League of Conservation Voters.
Environmental groups rejoiced today at the selection of Mr. Babbitt, saying they could think of no one better qualified to serve as custodian of the nation's natural resources.
 
'Excellent Relationship'
 In Arizona, where he was Governor from March 1978 to January 1987, business executives spoke highly of Mr. Babbitt. Wayne M. Kaplan, a spokesman for the Arizona Public Service Company, the state's largest utility, said, "We've had an excellent working relationship with him."
Mr. Babbitt, who was also considered for the job of United States Trade Representative in the Clinton Administration, is fluent in Spanish and often expresses his concern about Washington's neglect of Latin America. His wife, Hattie, serves on the board of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund. They have two sons.
Fred Krupp, executive director of the Environmental Defense Fund, said: "As Governor of Arizona, Bruce participated in a real campaign to crack down on the copper smelters. Few governors would have been so concerned about air pollution, the emerging acid rain problem, to make sure that modern technology was installed on each and every copper smelter. That removed a million tons of sulfur dioxide that would have been pouring into Western air every year."
Mr. Krupp described Mr. Babbitt as "a new-style leader who understands that economic and environmental concerns must be integrated."
 
Less Popular With Labor
 But Mr. Babbitt is less popular with organized labor, which harshly criticized his decision in 1983 to send the National Guard to a Phelps Dodge plant during a strike by the United Steelworkers union.
Mr. Babbitt, 54, graduated from the University of Notre Dame, where he studied geology, and from Harvard Law School. He sought the Democratic nomination for President in 1988 and was praised for discussing difficult issues, but his style was too thoughtful for most voters. He withdrew from the race after finishing fifth in the Iowa caucuses and sixth in the New Hampshire primary.
As a Presidential candidate, Mr. Babbitt provided a detailed accounting of his plans to reduce the Federal budget deficit. He had no use for political orthodoxy, and often stated his intention to impose a national sales tax, limit the deduction for home mortgage interest and eliminate some farm subsidies.
Mr. Babbitt is a partner at the law firm of Steptoe & Johnson, which has offices in Phoenix and Washington.

PUB-DATE: December 25, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 430 words

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
Clinton's Last Selections for the Cabinet Reflect His Quest for Diversity

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:

Mickey Kantor
Trade Representative 
 Mickey Kantor, President-elect Bill Clinton's choice to become the next United States Trade Representative, will be the latest of several people who have taken the job with very little background in trade issues.
Mr. Kantor, a longtime friend of Mr. Clinton, was the chairman of Mr. Clinton's election campaign and had been widely expected to receive a Cabinet position as a political reward.
His views on trade, if any, are a mystery to people who have worked with Mr. Kantor, and his brief speech at a news conference in Little Rock, Ark., today was devoted to thanking friends and political supporters.
Robert M. Strauss and Bill Brock, who took the job after successful tours as party chairmen, as well as Carla A. Hills, the former Secretary for Housing and Urban Development who currently holds the job, also had modest experience in trade issues when they took the office.
 
Partner in Law Firm
 Mr. Kantor, a partner at Manatt, Phelps, Phillips & Kantor in Los Angeles, heads a small group of lawyers who specialize in representing corporations before state and local regulators of air quality, transportation and other issues. George D. Kieffer, a partner at the law firm, said Mr. Kantor had done little if any work for foreign clients.
But Manatt, Phelps has registered with the Justice Department as a paid lobbyist for the NEC Corporation, based in Tokyo. NEC is one of the world's largest electronics companies.
Mr. Kieffer said he did not know of any work Mr. Kantor had done for NEC, which is a client of the firm's Washington office. Facing a comparable situation, Mrs. Hills removed herself for one year after taking office from all issues handled by her former colleagues at the law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges.
One of the first trade issues to face the Clinton Administration next year will be a review in March of whether Japan has met a target of buying 20 percent of its semiconductor chips from foreign companies. If Mr. Kantor removes himself because of NEC's position in the semiconductor industry, his deputy would have to make what is sure to be a politically sensitive decision on whether to retaliate if Japanese purchases fall short.
Mr. Kantor will enter an Administration with no shortage of trade experts. Laura D'Andrea Tyson, Mr. Clinton's choice to head the Council of Economic Advisers, and Robert B. Reich, who has been named Labor Secretary, both advocate a greater role by the Government in helping high-technology industries that face subsidized foreign competitors.
