HEADLINE: For Maloney, a New Arena, but the Same Style

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The day could not have been drearier. Gray skies. Intermittent rain. Chilly winds. Yet Carolyn B. Maloney was bouncing around like a teen-ager on spring break. "Can't you just feel your heart beating faster around here?" she said, heading toward the Rayburn office building for a quick lunch between meetings.
This was Ms. Maloney's first day in Washington after nearly a week attending seminars at Harvard for new Democrats in Congress. A member of the New York City Council for 10 years, she was the upset winner last month over Bill Green in New York's expanded Silk Stocking District to join the 103d Congress in the House of Representatives, and now the spoils of victory were all about: the majestic Capitol, the Mall, the Washington Monument and the one-bedroom apartment less than three blocks away that she rented for a song, compared with New York prices. "I can walk to work," she said. 
 But there was little time to gawk or discuss the impact of the next two years, commuting between New York City, where her husband, Clifton, and two daughters will remain, and a new life in Washington as a member of the largest Democratic freshman class in Congress in 18 years. This was a day for contacts, bridge building and learning that being effective in a House of 435 members is quite a different thing from getting notice in a City Council of 51.
 
Concentrating Energy
 In a style that became familiar in the City Council, it was accomplished at fevered pitch in a series of meetings.
At each stop, Ms. Maloney engaged her hosts in rat-a-tat-tat questioning, focused on how she could concentrate her energy on her areas of interest, as she had in the City Council, where she pushed the city to computerize its awarding of contracts and monitoring of contractors, as well as for child care, health care and women's rights.
She ran against Mr. Green, a 14-year incumbent, by running as a Clintonesque Democrat and emphasizing both her accomplishments in the City Council and Mr. Green's support of Republican positions under Presidents Reagan and Bush that she said cost New York jobs and programs. She scored a victory by 2 percentage points, barely 5,000 votes, capitalizing on margins in the new sections of the district, Greenpoint in Brooklyn and Astoria, Queens.
 
Committee Selections
 As her day of engagement unfolded, however, it became evident that not even her pugnacious New York City style would gain her all the positions she wanted. In the House, where members serve on no more than one major committee and only a few freshmen get their first choice, Ms. Maloney was appointed to Government Operations and to Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs.
She said she was reasonably satisfied, saying those assignments could produce benefits for New York City and accommodate her interests in finance and the governmental process.
In a meeting with an aide to Representative Robert T. Matsui of California, Azar Kattan, Ms. Maloney hammered away, asking questions until she finally heard something that sounded like a path to another pet issue. "Join the women's caucus," Ms. Kattan told her. "Use that as a tool, too. It's bipartisan, but it gets into the Economic Equity Act each year."
"That is great advice," said Ms. Maloney, as if it were the key to solving E=MC<2>.
Ms. Maloney, 44 years old, is a teacher by training. A 1968 graduate of Greensboro College in North Carolina, her home state, she had intended to be a lawyer and spent a year in law school at the University of North Carolina. But a summer trip to New York City changed everything.
"I went up to see a friend and never left," she said. "I just fell in love with the place. My father was furious."
She found work as a teacher in the city school system but quickly moved into administrative positions with the Board of Education. They led to jobs as an aide in the State Assembly and later, the State Senate. In 1982 she ran for the City Council for the first time and defeated the incumbent, Robert Rodriguez, by a 2-to-1 margin.
 
Vallone's View
 As a Council member, she forged an image as a legislator who appeared somewhat unfocused until she found an issue she was interested in. Several members, who asked not to be identified, described her as "a little spacey," but only until she had found an issue to champion. Then, they agreed, she became a dogged advocate. One member described her as a "pit bull."
"I would have said the same thing if I didn't get to know her," said Peter F. Vallone, the Council Speaker from Queens, who played a major role in Ms. Maloney's campaign success in Astoria. "Unless you're working on a specific committee, you might not know what's happening on other committees. I'm one of the few people who know what she did."
It was not long after her arrival in New York City that she met her husband, an investment banker, and had two daughters, Christine, now 12, and Virginia, 5.
Their lives, as much as her own, will be affected by her election to the House. She plans to spend two, maybe three nights a week in Washington when Congress is in session, leaving Mr. Maloney and the girls in New York.
"My older daughter is like a lot of 12-year-olds, very independent, with her own friends and her own agenda," Ms. Maloney said. "She understands the importance of the position, the challenge of the position, that Mother is voting on pressing problems of the country. For my younger daughter, it's very hard. When I was at Harvard, my husband told me she was kissing my picture and asking, 'When's Mommy coming home?' "
Mr. Maloney was reluctant to discuss the implications of her job on the family, or anything else, for that matter. During the Harvard seminars, he attended a lunch for spouses, where each of them received a bit of advice, in the form of a letter once written by Dennis Thatcher, the husband of the former British Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher.
"He said the No. 1 cardinal rule is never talk to the press," Mr. Maloney said in a telephone interview. "I think that's appropriate."
 
Feminist Leaders
 The final meeting of the day, with feminist leaders in Arlington, Va., was a highlight of sorts for Ms. Maloney. A strong advocate of women's issues for years, she gave her first child the middle name Paul, after Alice Paul, the suffragist who wrote the first equal-rights amendment proposal, nearly 70 years ago.
"It's funny," Ms. Maloney told the women around the table, "usually when I come to Washington, it's to march." They laughed, and recalled some of their more memorable moments pressing their issues with the Republican administrations of the last dozen years. "Now," she said, "I've got to get us some visibility."
Visibility for women's issues might not be the problem she imagines, once Congress opens. The new Congress will include a record number of women, 54, including 48 in the House. "We just have to figure out how to undo the damage of the 80's," said Eleanor Smeal, president of the Fund for the Feminist Majority, as the meeting was ending.
After a round of goodbyes, the other women left, leaving only Ms. Smeal and Ms. Maloney, who had planned to have dinner at a nearby restaurant. Old friends, they left the building as if the meeting had never adjourned. "So, Elly," Ms. Maloney said as they made their way out of the building. "How are we going to pass the E.R.A.?"

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

 FREE MARKET IN ACTION OR CRIME?
Ticket scalping has been very good to Kevin Thomas, and he makes no apologies. He sees himself as a classic American entrepreneur: a high-school dropout from the Bronx who taught himself a trade, works seven nights a week, earns $40,000 a year, and at age 26 has $75,000 in savings, all by providing a public service outside New York's theaters and sports arenas. But he has been arrested many times. But while New York and New Jersey officials are cracking down on scalpers, economists tend to see them as performing a valuable function. Page 1.
 
 NEW YORK CITY
 
 TEAMSTER HEAD SEEN AS BOUNCING BACK 
 The allegations against Barry Feinstein, one of New York City's top municipal-employees union leaders, looked overwhelming when they were made public in September. Bluntly put, he was accused in noncriminal charges of embezzling and misusing $500,000 in union funds to finance a lavish personal life style. But three months later, labor and political experts say, Mr. Feinstein has emerged relatively unscathed and remains a potent union official and political figure. Page 25.
 CONSTRUCTION UNIONS MOVE TO INTEGRATE
Construction unions in New York City that have long been criticized for excluding members of racial minority groups have agreed to recruit 25 percent of their new apprentices from the overwhelmingly black and Hispanic graduating classes of the city's vocational high schools. Page 25.
 
 A NEW, AND BUSY, LIFE IN WASHINGTON
Carolyn B. Maloney, a member of the New York City Council for 10 years and the upset winner last month over Bill Green in New York's expanded Silk Stocking District, has joined the 103d Congress in the House of Representatives. Now, the spoils of victory are hers: the majestic Capitol, the Mall, the Washington Monument and the one-bedroom apartment less than three blocks away that she rented for a song, compared with New York prices. But on her first day in Washington, there was little time to gawk. Page 25.
 
 REGION
 
 SAD TESTIMONY IN SCHOOLS TRIAL
The principal of an elementary school in Hartford's North End testified in Superior Court this week that of his 580 pupils, only 17 don't qualify for free lunches. As civil-rights lawyers complete a portrait of Hartford's public schools as institutions overwhelmed by the poverty and racial isolation of their students, such details sometimes seem to fill the courtroom with the feeling of hopelessness that teachers say suffocates their classrooms. Page 26.
 
 THE $700-MILLION-DOLLAR QUESTION
A malpractice insurance fund set up by New York State in the 80's has collected a huge pool of money. In the last six years, while more than $1 billion has been paid into the fund, less than $2 million has been paid out in awards. The unused money has already been used twice to help balance the state budget. Now, with more than $700 million in the fund and the state's ailing largest insurer, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, looking hungrily at it, the question is: why does the fund exist at all? Page 26.

HEADLINE: A Vision of Capitalism In the Ex-Soviet Bloc

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 25

 BODY:
As president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, Jacques Attali has a grand vision for financing the emergence of vibrant capitalist economies in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union, leading eventually to a vast pan-European market.
"We should be a go-between between East and West," the ebullient 49-year-old Frenchman said in an interview at the bank's headquarters here. 
 His aspirations strike some diplomats and business executives as outsized if not pretentious, given the European Bank's record so far. The institution, established 20 months ago by Western European nations and the United States to provide loans and investment funds to fledgling enterprises in the old Soviet bloc, has completed only about 50 transactions and committed $1.5 billion of capital.
 
Starting to Gain Respect
 The European Bank may never be as big or as influential as Mr. Attali envisions. But with other sources of financing in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union extremely limited, the bank is starting to gain respect from government officials and business executives for making the most of its money. Its sponsors have committed $3.75 billion of capital through 1996.
Certainly its efforts have not gone unappreciated by the companies it has financed. For instance, Konspol-BIS, a poultry-processing company in Poland, said a $16 million loan from the bank was essential to getting an additional $9 million needed to build a new plant that will create 300 jobs.
"The European Bank's involvement in the project was absolutely crucial to putting the deal together, and in that respect the bank is fulfilling the mandate given to it to promote and develop industry in Eastern Europe," said Maciej Raczkiewicz, who owns 22 percent of Konspol. "From my point of view, the European Bank is essential because at this point the private banks are still reluctant to commit themselves to Poland."
Mr. Attali, a French socialist philosopher-politician with no training as a banker, who was pushed for the job by President Francois Mitterrand of France, said he recognized the impatience felt by Eastern European nations as well as the Western governments financing the bank.
"We are still in the takeoff period at a time when people wish we were at full speed," he said.
He said the institution faced some deep-rooted biases, among them the European Community's reluctance to help build economic competitors in the East and then open up trade with them. Mr. Attali said, for example, that the Western nations should provide more financial assistance to help the East get its exporting industries up and running.
 
Several Projects Under Way
 Nonetheless, Mr. Attali said, the European Bank's accomplishments so far are not inconsiderable. It has financed a venture to provide better international telephone service in Moscow. It has backed an Italian-Polish joint venture setting up a jeans-production plant in Poland, provided capital to a Romanian bank to make loans to farmers and agriculture-related industries, and lent money to a company setting up Burger King franchises in Hungary.
It helped finance a deal under which General Motors set up a plant in Hungary. Along with Air France, it took a stake in CSA, the Czechoslovak state airline. In the last several weeks it has approved loans to a new Hungarian company to build a plant that will supply tire and rubber companies in Europe with carbon black, and to a company in Poland that makes turbo generators.
Mr. Attali himself also seems to be finding his stride. He initially alienated some members of the bank's board, who are appointed by the nations that have contributed the institution's capital and who have final say over all of the bank's transactions. They said they saw him as publicity hungry and headstrong. For example, Mr. Attali has issued news releases offering his help in resolving the war in Yugoslavia.
Mr. Attali was in most ways an unconventional choice to head an institution devoted to creating democratic capitalism in Eastern Europe. As a close adviser to President Mitterrand in the early 1980's, he helped develop a program, later reversed, of nationalizing key industries in France.
And while no one doubts that he is well read in economics -- he wrote a book several years ago on the threat of a decline in manufacturing in the United States -- his energies over the years have been diffused among a wide variety of interests and projects, ranging from writing novels to studying the changing conceptions of property rights.
Mr. Attali was firmly rebuked earlier this year by the United States Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, for pushing a plan to make cut-rate loans in support of long-term economic changes to Eastern European governments and to the states of the former Soviet Union.
The United States, the largest contributor to the European Bank's capital, with a 10 percent stake, held that such a program would have violated the bank's charter to operate by commercial bank standards and concentrate on providing help to the private sector.
"Let Mr. Attali say whatever he wants," Mr. Brady said at the bank's annual meeting in Budapest in April. "I want him to understand what we think. We've had our differences before, and I assure you we're very determined about this."
But Mr. Attali in recent months has patched up his differences with the United States and concentrated on transactions that provide financing directly to private enterprise, or that help provide the infrastructure -- the roads, the telephone systems and the like -- that are essential to the development of competitive market economies. In the process he is winning praise, even from the United States, for having instilled in the institution a sense of energy and urgency.
 
Keeping Up With Attali
 "There is an understandable push from Attali," said William Curran, the United States representative on the bank's board, "to want to use the bank as a platform for him to give his views, which are intelligent and very innovative on a variety of subjects, whether he's talking about a pan-European market from Lisbon to Vladivostok, or the problems of nuclear safety.
"I'd much rather have to steer someone as a member of a board than to push somebody, and with him you have to run to stay up."
Bank officials said their main strategy was not to try to finance deals completely on their own, since the bank's capital was so limited. Instead, they said, they try to put together financing packages that would not be possible without their help.
"We have to be very efficient in multiplying our resources," said Ron Freeman, who heads the institution's merchant banking operation. "For every penny we invest, we need to mobilize three or four pennies from other sources."
To that end, the bank looks for partners, often Western companies (more often than not from the United States), that are interested in joint ventures with Eastern European companies. In the case of Konspol-BIS, the Polish poultry-processing company, the loan from the European Bank was accompanied by an additional $9 million in equity and other financing from partners including Mr. Raczkiewicz and A. Epstein & Sons, a construction and engineering company based in Chicago.
 
Financing for G.M.
 In some cases the European Bank has invested its funds as capital in other financing organizations seeking to make loans in its territory. Last year it agreed to a deal with the NMB Postbank Group N.V. of the Netherlands under which it will provide $40 million and NMB $60 million to small and medium-sized private enterprises in Poland and other countries.
Critics of the bank have contended that the money it provides often is not needed since most Western investors already have access to sufficient financing. Some critics questioned, for example, why the bank agreed to help finance General Motors's new plant in Hungary, since G.M. has far more resources at its disposal than the bank has.
But Mr. Freeman said that the bank's participation in a deal provided other investors a sense of confidence that they would otherwise not have, a contention that G.M. and other investors agreed with. And in some cases, the bank's participation has bottom-line implications: commercial banks that lend in deals involving the European Bank share its preferred-creditor status, a legal nicety that permits them to minimize the risk provision they must normally make on loans in economically weak nations.
Most of the deals done directly with private enterprises have been in Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia, the three most economically advanced of the Central and Eastern European nations. But with the collapse of the Soviet Union, the bank has increasingly focused on ways to help the former Soviet republics, where there is still little private enterprise.
Most of the lending being done in the former Soviet Union is therefore going toward telecommunications and other infrastructure projects. But ultimately the bank would like to concentrate on the oil industry, which could provide significant foreign-exchange earnings, and help establish banks and other financial institutions within the republics to provide financing to the emerging private sector.
"If we concentrate on what we do best," Mr. Curran said, "which is to help develop a private sector, help develop a banking system and a semiprivatized energy sector, and to help create an atmosphere in which small and medium-sized businesses can develop, then we can have a big role to play in the former Soviet Union. The mistake we might make would be to wander too far into the huge black hole of infrastructure."

HEADLINE: A SHARP REBOUND IN CHRISTMAS SALES

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
It was a hair-raising holiday season for many of the nation's retailers: sales started out strong, dropped off precipitously and finally skyrocketed the last weekend before Christmas.
Most merchants say their holiday business improved this year despite the ups and downs caused by unusually nasty weather and news of more layoffs and revampings among America's blue-chip companies. 
 "People have shopped this year like there really is a Christmas," said John J. Schultz, president of the National Retail Federation.
 
Sales May Be Up 9%
 So much for the notion that Christmas was dead. While retailers will not release hard and fast numbers on how they fared during the holidays until Thursday, a few experts are even estimating that sales may be 8 or 9 percent higher than those of a year ago. Most believe sales will have risen around 5 percent.
"We couldn't ask for much better this season," said Myron E. Ullman 3d, co-chairman and chief executive of R. H. Macy & Company. Sales have exceeded expectations at stores like Bloomingdale's, Sears and Tiffany & Company, that were punished for the last three years by penurious shoppers. Macy expects sales to be 2 to 3 percent ahead for the season; although its sales were much stronger in New York City and Washington as well as Georgia and Florida, that success was tempered by weak sales in California.
Discount stores were less of a destination for shoppers this year. Kmart struggled the last few days before Christmas to meet its projections for the season, and analysts expected Target to match its sales performance last year but not exceed it. And even though Wal-Mart raised its estimates for sales growth in December by 2 percent, it still did not plan to post its usual monthly double-digit sales gain.
Strict inventory controls at several big chains virtually guaranteed a more profitable season even if sales did not notch up.
Mr. Schultz noted that the calendar this year was almost ideal for retailers. He estimated that the two more days between Thanksgiving and Christmas this year could mean as much as 4 percent more sales for some merchants.
What is more, Christmas fell on a Friday this year, which gave people today and Sunday to go back to stores to return gifts and clear out leftover merchandise.
Retailers are trying to squeeze as much out of Christmas 1992 as possible, since they do not expect the windfall to persist into the new year. Many merchants and analysts believe the first quarter of 1993 will be weak, because consumer spending has recently outpaced income growth. Credit-card companies have reported strong increases in transactions, and some shoppers may be shocked when they get their bills next month. Also, this year had a strong start, which will make it tougher to squeeze out gains in the start of 1993.
"The fear a little bit is that a lot of the energy is being sucked out of the quarter by the strength of Christmas," said Carol Sanger, a spokeswoman for Federated Department Stores, which operates Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus, Burdines and several other chains.
For the holidays, Federated's sales exceeded its cautious expectations. Analysts expect its sales in stores open at least one year, the best measure of a retailer's performance, to increase somewhere between 4 and 6 percent.
For Federated and several other chains, improvement was achieved in fits and starts as the holiday season progressed. Inclement weather kept shoppers in some regions of the country at home, and Californians, in the midst of a statewide recession, were stingy spenders. A few retailers said news of corporate layoffs at I.B.M., General Motors and other companies also might have dampened the giddiness produced by the election of Bill Clinton and speculation about the impact of his Administration.
 
Up, Down, Up Again
 The Christmas and Hanukkah selling season started with a frenzy resembling the heady holidays of the 1980's, as shoppers jammed stores in the week after Thanksgiving. Intoxicated by the excitement, some analysts and retailers rushed to revise their sales forecasts and began predicting sales that would soar 9 percent beyond those registered in the same period last year.
Then sales trailed off in the second week of the season and in some cases nearly died as vicious storms pummeled the Atlantic Coast and froze parts of the Midwest. The two extra days of selling time between Thanksgiving and Christmas also allowed shoppers to postpone spending they would have done in the third week until the fourth week, leaving retailers to gnaw their nails and hope.
Analysts returned to their original estimates of sales growth around 5 or 6 percent, a moderate improvement but sparkling when compared with last year's sales growth of less than 2 percent.
The Johnson Redbook Service, the retail industry monitor published by Lynch, Jones & Ryan, calculated that sales grew 6.9 percent in the first week, rose just 1.4 percent the second week, then picked up their pace to increase 5.9 percent in the third week, largely because of accelerated momentum last Saturday.
Hermes, the exclusive luxury goods chain that sells ties for $110, silk scarves for $225 and handbags for as much as $14,000, sold more than $500,000 worth of merchandise that Saturday in its New York store alone.
Customers lined up outside Toys "R" Us in Herald Square in Manhattan and fought for position in check-out lines at Macy's flagship store there. Cars cruised the jammed parking lots outside Wal-Mart stores across the country, searching for available space.
Retailers reported that the fast pace continued through Wednesday, though last Saturday will probably stand out as the biggest day of Christmas sales 1992. Tactical Retail Solutions Inc., a retail consulting firm in New York, estimates that merchants took in $4 billion that day, or roughly 4 percent of total estimated sales of $71 billion for the holiday season.
"Now we're hearing guesses that they'll see 25 to 50 percent increases in the fourth week," said Edward Johnson, the analyst who compiles the Johnson Redbook. Based on that, he is sticking to his estimate of 8 to 9 percent sales growth this month.
 
Last-Minute Shopping Grows
 A sales explosion in the final week -- which may not be retailing hyperbole given that sales surged 20 percent in the last week of the weak 1991 holiday season -- would support what is becoming a new tenet in the retail handbook. Consumers are last-minute shoppers, making the holiday sales season a perennial cliffhanger.
"The unfortunate part of the Christmas season is that we don't know so much about how it's going until after it's over," said Orren F. Knauer, director of investor relations for the Kmart Corporation.
"The election was over, and suddenly the media is making it out to be the best Christmas in four years," he added. "Maybe it will; maybe it won't. We just don't know until Christmas Eve."
Clark A. Johnson, chairman of Pier 1 Imports Inc., a specialty-store chain that sells home furnishings, decorations and gift items, said that for merchants this season was something like riding a roller coaster, although he expected his stores would exceed his projections of 5 to 6 percent comparable-store sales growth.
"It's been tricky," he said Wednesday. "But this last week will be the largest week of sales in the history of the company."
Retailers were also heartened by unexpectedly strong sales of big-ticket merchandise like furniture and appliances. Sears in particular benefited from its selection of home and office furniture, computers, fax machines and appliances. "What it's telling us is that customers are finally willing to make longer-term commitments," said Matthew A. Howard, senior vice president of marketing for Sears.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Bell's Future Linked to New Services

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
For New Jersey Bell, winning approval this week from state regulators to install a $1.5 billion fiber-optic network and operate with new competitive freedoms may turn out to be the easy part.
A new struggle looms larger: Can the phone company persuade New Jersey residents to sign up for a host of new services to help pay for the new network? The offerings are expected to include so-called interactive video services like educational networks that would enable people to take classes, as well as video services providing virtually instant access to a library of television programs. 
 "Clearly the marketing challenge is the bigger challenge," said Jack Grubman, an analyst at Paine Webber, who follows Bell Atlantic, New Jersey Bell's parent. "The question is: Is anyone going to buy anything?"
 
An Adventuresome Deal
 Industry analysts point to many factors they believe will ultimately reward the unusually adventuresome approach of the telephone company and its state regulators, which clears the way for New Jersey to become the first state with border-to-border fiber-optics telecommunications. "Everything is in place to make this a success," said Charles W. Schelke, an analyst at Smith Barney.
In broad terms, the arrangement with state regulators should enable the phone company to earn greater returns on services for which it faces or may face competitors. In return, New Jersey Bell has agreed to freeze rates through 1999 for the basic telephone services on which the company has a monopoly.
Investors have signaled their support of the plan, pushing up the stock of Bell Atlantic this week to levels last reached in early 1991. Although many telecommunications stocks are doing well these days, the ruling on Tuesday gave a special push to Bell Atlantic, whose shares hit their high for the year on Wednesday at $53.875 before receding slightly in lighter trading Thursday to close at $53 on the New York Stock Exchange.
The initial phase of the New Jersey fiber-optic network is to be operational by 1999, and the entire network is to be completed by 2010. Fiber-optic cable, which can transmit millions of pieces of information each second, is equally adept at carrying voice, data and video signals.
Anticipating the capabilities, New Jersey Bell forged an agreement last week with Future Vision of Doylestown, Pa., to provide cable television service to some New Jersey residents through the phone line.
With the enormous capacity of the fiber-optic network, New Jersey Bell may be able to market so-called video-on-demand, giving consumers greater choice in watching what they want at the moment they want it.
 
Selling Other Services
 More salesmanship may be required to make a success of other services, like transmitting lectures over the network into homes, or receiving some medical attention through a two-way video link, or scrolling through a video version of classified advertising.
Although the population of New Jersey is among the most affluent in the nation -- giving residents at least the financial ability to dabble in the new services -- many industry observers are skeptical about how attractive the interactive services will be to consumers and businesses.
New Jersey Bell helped set up a trial educational network using fiber optics that is operating in Bergen County. But no other examples of the technology exist because of the limited use of fiber optics in telephone networks around the country.
Under Federal law, New Jersey Bell is prohibited from originating the services, but because the company will earn money from others supplying the services, it has a stake in making them a success.
 
Added Costs Minimal

 
 To a degree, the business implications of installing the fiber-optic network mitigate the riskiness of the new service. Over a period of years, the relative cost of installing the fiber-optic cable compared with copper wire is largely the same, according to New Jersey Bell executives, because the maintenance costs of the more durable fiber-optic cable are much lower.
And once the initial phase is operational by 1999, the company plans to use revenues from new services to complete the project.
Although the company said it might raise money through the capital markets to help pay for the cable, New Jersey Bell will more likely allocate part of its yearly profits. New Jersey Bell's capital expense budget averages between $500 million and $600 million a year. This year, the company anticipates it will earn $444 million on revenues of $3.1 billion.
There are also more indirect benefits to the phone company for upgrading its network. As New Jersey shifts increasingly from a manufacturing economy to a service-based economy, a high-technology phone network will be a boon to New Jersey economic development officials.
 
Beset By New Competitors
 New Jersey Bell faces tough competition from companies like Teleport Communications Group of Staten Island, which operates fiber-optic networks in a dozen metropolitan areas, including New York City. Teleport's main business is linking corporations in downtown business districts with their long-distance carriers. But the company, which was jointly acquired earlier this year by cable giants Tele-Communications and Cox Communications, is increasingly seeking to compete head-to-head against local telephone companies on a full range of services.
In September, the Federal Communications Commission voted to encourage competition in local telephone service by permitting companies like Teleport to sharply expand their use of the networks operated by the regional Bell companies and other local phone carriers.
Also, cable television companies like Comcast of Philadelphia are aggressively trying to compete with telephone companies by investing in technology to build wireless telephone networks using their existing cable.
"New Jersey Bell is being attacked by competitive access providers that require Bell Atlantic to have the most modern infrastructure," said Berge Ayvazian, an analyst at the Yankee Group, a market research firm in Boston.

HEADLINE: Schools Can Build on Apprentice Programs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
By describing the experience of two Boston students in Project ProTech, you present a convincing case for apprentice programs in your "Finding What Works" series (front page, Nov. 26). As an educator who coordinates an apprenticeship program for high school students, I concur about the value of a supervised work experience. However, I am concerned that such an expensive program (Project ProTech costs the taxpayer $8,000 a student per year) has the limited goal of "placing people in particular jobs." I regard this approach as a missed opportunity. 
 Your article illustrates how apprentices gain motivation when they have a credible role in the workplace with a committed supervisor. At this age, students are sensitive to the need to plan for their future. From my own observation, it is apparent that they gain confidence from being treated as responsible colleagues, especially if this is new to them. They also discover the value of academic credentials. Why not build on this opportunity by providing school classes that complement, rather than compete with their work experiences?
 Two supplemental activities come to mind. The first is more instruction in a relevant academic subject, such as biology or chemistry for apprentices in medical labs. Why are the students uninterested in physics, as you are at pains to emphasize?
The second activity is workshops to develop communication skills and cognitive strategies. In such workshops, apprentices would spend a few hours each week in discussion with peers, in writing about their experiences at work and devising new ways of learning on the job. If the apprentices make oral presentations about their progress, they will gain insight about the demands of the workplace and their own ability to succeed.
Why do the Project ProTech designers fail to recognize the potential for apprentices to gain such marketable career skills, as well as competence in a specific job?
Would industry be prepared to sponsor programs with this wider focus? To suggest that industry is interested merely in recruiting employees underestimates the goals of participating employers and supervisors.
In practical terms, it is difficult to predict where students will look for work, and those who acquire transferable skills will contribute more both to their apprenticeship and the economy.
 
FIONA M. GOODCHILD
Santa Barbara, Calif., Dec. 10, 1992
 
The writer is educational coordinator, Center for Quantized Electronic Structures, University of California.

HEADLINE: Schools Can Build on Apprentice Programs;
A New York Project

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Apprenticeship programs for high school students are more than "a tonic for the nation's ailing economy" (front page, Nov. 26). They are a tonic for the country's ailing schools. The comment you quote by the mother of one student tells it all: "I'm shocked. This is the first time I've ever seen a school program work." 
 The Boston school system's Project ProTech is only one of several similar programs in the country. In Arkansas, Oregon and Maine, pilot programs are under way to provide occupational training for high school students. In Philadelphia and Chicago, partnerships between employers and schools are preparing students for the world of work.
 In the fall of 1991, Cornell University sponsored a youth apprenticeship demonstration project for 25 high school juniors in Broome County, New York. And next February, a pilot apprenticeship program called Project GROW (Getting Real Opportunities for Work) will be initiated involving seniors from Norman Thomas High School in Manhattan.
This project is the brainchild of a volunteer group of former executives from business and education, the Business and School Collaborative. They have devised a plan for high schools seniors to hold full-time jobs while earning school credit.
"The concept is simple," the group's prospectus states. "The best place to train students for work is at the work site. The best trainers are working people. The problem is to provide this training at the workplace and still insure that the student completes his or her education."
With the cooperation of the New York State Department of Labor and the New York City Job and Career Center, students in this project will be given pre-employment training in social skills and attitudes valued by business people. They will then be offered a selection of jobs where they will be trained by mentors for six months. School guidance personnel will monitor student progress. After six months, students will be tested and, if successful, will receive a certificate of completion. They can then choose continued employment or enrollment in college.
Unlike Project ProTech in Boston, Project GROW has operated without public financing and practically without cost. Incidental expenses have been covered by a small contribution from a local corporation. The volunteers in the Business and School Collaborative are donating their time and expertise in the hope that this project can be expanded and become the prototype of a successful apprenticeship program for the students of New York City high schools.
Then, perhaps, we shall see an end to the drift and aimlessness, the bouncing around from job to dead-end job, that characterizes so many of our high school graduates. Then, perhaps, students will find new meaning and value in their schooling, which for too many has seemed to be marking time with no goal in sight.
 
JACK M. POLLOCK, ISAIAH ROBINSON
New York, Dec. 4, 1992
 
The writers were, respectively, principal of Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn and president, New York City Board of Education.

HEADLINE: Ex-Rep. Richard Ichord, 66, Dies; Led Un-American Activities Panel

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Former Representative Richard H. Ichord, a fervent anti-Communist who crusaded against the peace movement during the Vietnam War and served as the last chairman of the House Un-American Activities Committee, died yesterday at a hospital in Nevada, Mo. He was 66.
He died of complications from a heart attack on Dec. 18, said his daughter, Pam Ichord Ehlers. He had divided his time in recent years between Washington and a cattle ranch in Waynesville, Mo., she said. 
 A conservative Democrat who represented a district in central and southern Missouri, Mr. Ichord (pronounced EYE-cord) spent 10 terms in the House of Representatives before retiring in 1981. He earned a reputation as a man preoccupied by the spread of Communism abroad and at home, where he feared radicals were trying to undermine the Federal Government.
His critics accused him of engaging in smears and witch hunts similar to the activities of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, in the 1950's.
"The kooks of the right and the left say that nobody in Congress should be dealing with such problems, but I think they're wrong," Mr. Ichord said in 1974 when asked about the Un-American Activities Committee. The Communist Party in the United States, he added, "could be a real threat if the country has an economic depression of the 1930's type."
The Un-American Activities Committee earned notoriety in the 1940's and 1950's, when it investigated Alger Hiss and others accused of being Communists. Richard M. Nixon, a little-known Representative from California in that time, gained national attention from the committee's hearings.
After Mr. Ichord was named chairman of the committee in 1969, he used his position to campaign against antiwar protesters. He published a list of "radical orators" at colleges around the country, including Muhammad Ali, Angela Davis, Abbie Hoffman and Dr. Benjamin Spock. Other lawmakers said it represented an effort to stifle dissent.
Mr. Ichord also introduced a bill banning travel to countries with which the United States was at war. The bill was prompted, he said at the time, by Jane Fonda's trip to North Vietnam at the height of the war in Southeast Asia.
The committee was disbanded in 1975, a few years after it had changed its name to the House Internal Security Committee. Mr. Ichord fought to save it, maintaining that it was needed to fight terrorism, crime and other activities.
Mr. Ichord was born on June 27, 1926, in Licking, Mo. He enlisted in the Navy Air Corps in World War II and later earned his undergraduate and law degrees from the University of Missouri.
When he was 32, he became the youngest speaker in the history of the Missouri House of Representatives. In 1960 he was elected to Congress, where he was known for his folksy wit. He also served as a member of the Armed Services Committee.
After he retired, he worked as a lawyer and lobbyist in Washington and served on several corporate boards. The Pentagon awarded him the Distinguished Civilian Service Award, the Army's highest honor for civilians.
Besides his daughter, he is survived by his wife, Millicent, his son Richard and three grandchildren.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 28, 1992, Monday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about former Representative Richard H. Ichord misidentified his hometown in some copies. He lived in both Waynesville, Mo., and Washington, not in Nevada, Mo.

HEADLINE: Jobs Without Hope -- A special report;
Solid Jobs Seem to Vanish Despite Signs of Recovery

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEMPHIS

 BODY:
The nation's economy is staggering out of the recession, say most of the gauges that measure it, but people who are getting jobs again tell a sobering story.
 Many good factory jobs and white-collar office jobs with good wages and benefits are giving way to unstable and mediocre jobs. That makes this recovery different from any other. 
Trends that started in the 1980's have produced a new look to working in America. Part-time jobs, temporary jobs, jobs paying no more than the Federal minimum wage of $4.25 an hour, jobs with no more benefits than a few vacation days are displacing permanent regular jobs that people would lose in layoffs in past recessions and reclaim when business picked up.
 
An Empty Promise
 Now, with corporate giants like General Motors and I.B.M. announcing plans to shed tens of thousands of workers next year, the resilience of the recovery is in some doubt. Retraining for better jobs is proving an empty promise for many workers because the better jobs are not there.
 The problems posed by this kind of feeble recovery can be seen in three very different communities: Brockton, Mass., an old industrial town that was all but flattened by the recession; Wichita, Kan., whose bad luck may be starting only now, and Memphis, which, like most of the South, has suffered in recent years but with a little less unemployment than the national average.
 "What is the definition of a job?" asked Mayor Winthrop H. Farwell Jr. of Brockton, whose worries are shared by officials and residents in all three cities. "Is it to meet expenses and nothing else? That's not good for our long-term interests. The definition of a job is having expendable income to travel, put an extension on the house, make a big purchase."
 With workers in Brockton earning too little to pay for such things, Mr. Farwell sees little hope for the merchants that sell to them and thus for the local economy. "President-elect Clinton has a challenge to meet here," said the Mayor, who, like Mr. Clinton, is a Democrat. "And he won't meet it in four years unless he has some extraordinary powers and a magic wand."
 Some people expect more of Mr. Clinton. Robert Earl Evans, a 35-year-old construction worker here, said he could buy half as much this year -- with his pay of $7.50 an hour until he was laid off a few days ago -- as he could a decade ago. "I made good money until Reagan and Bush got in," he said. "Clinton might sweeten the deal by putting jobs out in the streets for people. Things can't get no more worse."
 In these cities, the disappearance of factory jobs poses sociological questions. "That's the way semiskilled workers move into the middle class and minorities get high wages," said John Gnuschke, head of the Bureau of Business and Economic Research at Memphis State University. "Now there's no real hope of acquiring a single job that will allow them to move up."
 No one can know how strong these trends are. Typically, as businesses come back from a recession, they push employees to work overtime before they commit to more hiring. And in this recovery, they may be using part-time and temporary workers to see how well each fits in. Those who do can be offered full-time jobs as business picks up.
 Employment in factories could recover, too, with more and more American businesses trying to regain a competitive edge over foreign industry.
But one trend that seems to be taking root is a proliferation of jobs in which the old commitments of both sides, worker and employer, are fading. "American employers fill in the first paragraphs of their annual reports with statements like, 'Our employees are our most valuable assets,' " said Tony Redwood, director of the Institute for Public Policy and Business Research at the University of Kansas. "But it's a big lie.
 "They don't treat them as assets. They treat them as an expense."
 And they do so at their peril, Mr. Redwood said, because "to have a quality work force, to compete with Japan and Germany, they'll have to treat them as assets."
 
Brockton
There Is Nowhere To Go but Up
 In Brockton, once the shoe-making capital of America, downtown looks as wasted as any in Appalachia. Most big stores are long gone, leaving Main Street strewn with their carcasses. The working people of this worn and brutal city of 93,000 describe how a responsive economy in the 70's and 80's that had the strength to lift them from their reversals has become a mean economy that drives them to ruin.
 For a while in the 80's, Richard Wolfe, 49, and his wife, Mary-Ann, 54, had two cars and earned about $35,000 a year, sufficient to rear their six children. For 20 years, Mr. Wolfe worked in a warehouse at the General Dynamics shipyard in Quincy; he lost the job in 1985, while the yard was closing down.
 The Brockton Water Department picked him up as a laborer and paid him the same $11 an hour he earned before. A year ago he lost that job in a city budget cut.
 Mrs. Wolfe worked at a sandpaper factory in the early 80's but lost the job when the company left town. She became a data-entry clerk for a shoe wholesaler, earning $6.50 an hour. She was laid off from that job three years ago.
 She took nine months' training in office work -- word processing, filing, typing. Still, neither has had a single offer.
 A big problem is transportation. The Wolfes' last car broke down two years ago. "It cost too much to fix," Mrs. Wolfe said. "My husband sold it for junk. He got $30."
 
Benefits Running Out
 The family lives on Mr. Wolfe's unemployment benefits checks of $502 every two weeks. They expect them to expire in January. Mrs. Wolfe lost her benefits two years ago. Losing the benefits means that the Wolfes will have to turn to the unemployed worker's last resort, the welfare system.
 Some things hint that Brockton's economy is beginning to thaw. In October, unemployment slipped to 9.1 percent after nearly two years above 10 percent. Joseph Notini, Brockton area director for the Massachusetts Department of Employment and Training, said stores added more Christmas workers this year than last. He said he was called out to counsel workers at failing and fleeing businesses once a week now, compared with as often as four times a week last year.
Yet for people who are finding work, these few signs of recovery say little about the pay, benefits and job security. For the first time in Brockton, employment officials there say, most new jobs are temporary or part time, with wages of $5 to $8 an hour.
 For nearly five years, David French, 49, was a machinist-mold maker, earning $10 an hour. He lost the job in June 1991, when the company closed its machine shop. He has found two temporary machine shop jobs, one for 43 days, one for two weeks, and the last ended six months ago. "Every job that's permanent -- there's 10 or 12 people applying," he said.
 
Restaurants Closing Up
 George Bouchard, 34, went to the University of Montana, where he learned hotel and restaurant management. He ran a restaurant in Brockton for seven years, until it closed a year ago. "I was making 40 grand a year," he said. Mr. Bouchard says that he stays in Brockton to be near both his girlfriend, who works in a convenience store, and his father, who is terminally ill in Rhode Island.
 "Here in Brockton alone," he said, "two restaurants have closed in three weeks and a third is up for sale." So Mr. Bouchard has been taking temporary jobs at little more than the minimum wage tending bar and cooking in a fast-food restaurant.
 The one big merchant still downtown, Alexander Rysman, owner of Romm's Jewelers, says his sales, like the nation's economy, have perked up. But he doubts that the trend shows that people are working and earning more. "People buy on the basis of their feelings of hope," said Mr. Rysman, who has a doctorate in sociology from New York University.
 Mayor Farwell said, "If the economy is recovering, I haven't seen it yet."
 
Wichita

 No Longer Recession Proof
 This city never saw the recession. Anyone who really wanted a job had one. Boeing, Beech Aircraft, Cessna, Learjet, the aircraft companies that power the economy here the way steel once drove Pittsburgh, had enough advance orders to go on working as the nation's economy sank. About 25 percent of the jobs here are in manufacturing, in the aircraft plants and the hundreds of job shops that service them. That is well above the national rate of 17 percent.
 But aircraft customers far beyond Wichita that were hit by the recession -- the airlines and corporations that buy executive jets -- have slowed or canceled orders for two years. Military contracts, a smaller part of Wichita's business, slowed, too. Four thousand well-paid aircraft workers of the city's nearly 64,000 in 1990 have lost jobs. With companies like Boeing's biggest customer, United Airlines, mired in losses and talking of canceling orders, more will be laid off in 1993.
 Sylvia Williams had one of the good jobs. She was a member of Wichita's blue-collar aristocracy, an aircraft factory worker. She worked at Boeing. Her father works at Cessna. Her mother, now supervisor of the electrocardiogram department at St. Francis Hospital here, once worked at Beech. Ms. Williams is 26 and has two years of college.
 "I started out there five years ago at $5.60," Ms. Williams said. "I was a mail clerk. I was salaried. They have that line at Boeing. Your're salary or you're hourly. Salary didn't have the union. They kept voting it down. Hourly has the union. Entry level for hourly was $9.60."
 So she decided to quit the mailroom and apply for the higher paying factory job. "I went for the money," she said.
 Eventually Ms. Williams was earning $13 an hour. That meant $26,000 a year, $3,000 more than average for workers in Wichita. Her fiance earns $29,000, so they expected to begin their marriage already rooted in the middle class.
 Then on June 2, Ms. Williams was laid off, one of 2,000 workers Boeing let go in Wichita this year. She collects $231 a week in unemployment benefits, less than half her former pay.
 With the job losses in aircraft, Wichita's unemployment rate has been creeping up to 4.5 percent this fall, from 4 percent a year ago, while the nation's rate has been falling, to 7.2 percent in October, from a peak of 7.8 percent in June. The state's economic forecasters see Wichita's jobless rate rising a little more next year.
 At those levels, Brockton would be a boom town. But the economists say the low unemployment in Wichita masks a troubling trend. The city, with 300,000 people, is becoming a center of low-wage retail and service businesses that depress the standard of living. The biggest new employers are telemarketers, among them reservation clerks for Best Western hotels and order takers for Sears catalogue customers.
 At Boeing, the average factory wage is $17.84 an hour, or $35,700 a year. The state employment service here lists offers of $4.25 to $4.50 an hour for telemarketers, stock clerks, cashiers, fast food workers and an auto mechanic with four years' experience. And many of the jobs are temporary or part time.
 "We're replacing good manufacturing jobs with part-time service jobs that don't provide any benefits," said Pat Lehman, an officer here of the machinists union. "So people still qualify for food stamps."
 She asks Wichita's civic boosters, "Explain to me how that's a boon for the economy?"
 Boeing, the city's biggest employer, provides uncommonly rich benefits for workers. "They have the best you could ever get," Ms. Williams said. Under its contract with the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, Boeing helps people who were laid off and is paying for Ms. Williams to go to Wichita State University for three years. By studying through her summers, she plans to get a master's degree in social work.
 But few of Wichita's service, temporary and part-time workers have patrons like Boeing and the union. Tony Frazier, 35, was laid off from his job as a cook at one of Wichita's better restaurants where he was paid $7 an hour. After that he could only find jobs in fast food outlets, which paid even less.
 "So what I decided to do was get some retraining to learn meat cutting," he said. The father or two children, 3 and 9, and the husband of a part time nurse's aide, Mr. Frazier spent $2,000 to go to butchers school for four months. He wanted a job in a meat packing plant for $10 an hour. Then he found that plants nearby were hiring immigrants from Mexico. "They're willing to take $6 or $7 an hour," he said.
 For many the heaviest burden is health care. Daryl Donaldson, 23, works for a temporary employment service. It assigned him to a company where for $5 an hour, 50 hours a week, he built cold storage equipment. He lost the job when he caught pneumonia.
 "I had it in the Army," he said. "It was just the same." But without health insurance, he said seeing a doctor was out of the question. For four days he stayed in bed at home, a trailer he shares with his father.
 Jon Weaver, owner of Bud's Mower and Saw near Wichita in Hayesville, says he worries about the moral dilemma that the cost of health care poses for his business and his workers. His own monthly insurance premium has risen from $155 to $300 in four years. Providing similar insurance for his one full-time, $5-per-hour employee would force him to raise the prices of his mowers, which he said would scare customers away.
 
Memphis
Low Paying Jobs In the Services
 David Smith, 47, stops by the Ablest temporary help agency to inquire about his paycheck. In his crisp, navy blue windbreaker, button-down plaid shirt and steel-rim glasses, in the confidence of his handshake and the assertiveness of his speech, Mr. Smith could readily pass for a big-time lawyer.
 "I was a land man for oil and gas companies for 10 years," he said. When a company smelled oil on someone's land, Mr. Smith found the owner and acquired exploration and drilling rights. He earned $50,000 to $75,000 a year. Then the industry collapsed. His last day as a land man was June 19, 1990. The Denver office of the oil company he worked for shut down then, putting him and 500 people on the street.
 Mr. Smith went to Louisiana and became a reporter for a small newspaper for $500 a month. This fall, for a little more money, he became an adjuster there for an insurance company helping homeowners file claims after Hurricane Andrew. That work dried up, so he moved to Memphis, where he heard there was work. Ablest found him some in a printing shop on the night shift.
 
Older Men Losing Jobs
 "These are the men we're hearing about through downsizing," said the manager of the Ablest office, Malinda Dawson. "I have seen more older gentlemen, 40 to 60, than I have ever seen before. We've always had older ladies but not that age group of men. They're accountants and vice presidents for finance."
 Like Atlanta, Raleigh, Charleston, Birmingham and Little Rock, Memphis is a hub of the new South that attracts job losers from other regions. In terms of unemployment, Tennessee and the eight states that touch it suffered far less from the recession than the big population centers of the Northeast and California. Their unemployment rate was a little above 6 percent when the nation's was hovering close to 8.
 Memphis, with a population of 600,000, flourished in the 1980's as a city built on services. It is a huge distribution and transportation center, with a port on the Mississippi River, scores of truck lines and the nation's busiest airport at night because of all its freight traffic then.
 Federal Express, a giant of the services industry, sets the wage standard here. Steve Priddy, vice president for personnel administration, says the starting wage for a package handler is $7.51 an hour. In major urban centers, he said full-time couriers earn an average of $15.
 Other services pay less. "In Memphis you can get itty-bitty jobs," said James Savage, 26, who has been laid off from his $4.55-an-hour job as a cook at a company that makes potato chips. He lives with a woman who earns $6.25 as a cook at the Peabody Hotel. "She has a daughter," he said. "The daughter has a baby."
 According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the average annual pay in Memphis last year was $23,042, about $2,500 below the national average, $3,600 below Atlanta's average and $12,000 below New York City's. Living is cheaper here, too, but one reason for the lower wages is that Memphis has already landed where Wichita could be heading.
 Big manufacturers -- International Harvester, Ford, RCA, Firestone -- have left town in recent years, and no big newcomers have replaced them. Manufacturing represents only 12 percent of Memphis area jobs now, down from 18 percent before the exodus. As such a small part of the economy, factories do not have to scramble for skilled workers and bid up their wages. So many factory workers earn little more than service workers.
 
Problems of the Urban Poor
 The recovering economy also illuminates the difficulties that the nation's millions of urban poor, in Memphis primarily black, face in finding and keeping jobs.
 Tennessee does little to help prepare people for jobs. The state spends less on education per capita than nearly any other state, it has one of the nation's lowest high school graduation rates, and it has one of the highest poverty rates. Some job seekers visiting a state's employment service offices seem to have learned little of what the employers requires, like getting to work on time. But employers can also treat them severely.
 Ronald Wooden, 30, stopped school in the seventh grade. He said he was dismissed from one job and then another, both paying the minimum wage. "They said I was being late," he said. "It was usually my fault, but when I got there I would work."
 He said he will keep trying. "A man's got to work and make his own wage," he said. "I don't want to sit back and wait on them food stamps."
 David Smith, has at least escaped those problems. The printing company he works for makes display signs that stores use to call attention to things on their shelves. "I help the pressmen operate the printing press," he said. Business is brisk this holiday season, so he is working 12 hours a day, starting at 7:30 P.M., and eight hours on Saturdays.
 His pay? "Five dollars an hour," he said. "I don't like admitting it. It's pitiful. But I'll do anything. I'll dig ditches."
 Without an Ablest to take him on and steer him into a job, he might have no work at all.
 "The thing that is really shocking," he said, "is when a guy like me walks into a McDonald's or a Wal-Mart looking for a job. They look at you like you're crazy."

HEADLINE: A World From Scratch

BYLINE: By G. John Ikenberry; G. John Ikenberry, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, is author of the forthcoming book, "Moments of Creation: The Rebuilding of International Order, 1815, 1919, 1945 and 1990."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Will the new era be dominated by regional alliances and economic pacts or by a renewal of global and multilateral institutions? The 1990's are shaping up as a struggle between these rival international orders. So far, regional relationships -- in Europe, North America and elsewhere -- have the upper hand. The emerging world order looks like an old house: new rooms, windows and doors have been added, but the foundation, plumbing and wiring remain in dangerous disrepair.
There is a need to make regional economic experiments complement, not compete, with multilateralism. This requires agreement among the major nations about a blueprint of a new world order. 
 Most creative foreign policy in recent years has been directed at regional economic integration, particularly in Europe, North America and Asia. These efforts need not compete with the larger global order. Most studies of European and North American integration conclude that it will create more trade than it diverts. Nor are regional agreements necessarily incompatible with the global regime of GATT: Pulling down internal walls without raising external ones is good for the world economy.
The real danger of regionalism lies elsewhere. Regionalism is difficult to shield from domestic and trans-national political pressures and disputes. The European Community's hard line against Japanese imports suggests how regionalism deepens fault lines. European and North American regionalism also diverts attention from GATT and other multilateral institutions. The "promise" of European unity and the North American free-trade agreement has reduced the political costs should the current round of multilateral trade negotiations fail. In this real sense, regional and global institutions compete.
The task is to fold regional experiments into global institutional reform. Key will be the relationship among the industrial democracies -- the Group of Seven. Some suggest a Group of Seven declaration on the limits and responsibilities of "good regionalism." This would ease fears in Asia and elsewhere about the ultimate aims of recent regional agreements. It would also push the Group of Seven countries to use their next summit to discuss the basic structure of world order. Helmut Kohl and John Major are not Bismarck and Palmerston, and President-elect Bill Clinton certainly has none of the pretensions of Woodrow Wilson, but these leaders must be strongly encouraged to be global architects.
The Group of Seven should also focus on its own inadequate process. The annual summit meetings of heads of state are overly formal, scripted events that produce little more than bland official communiques. Experts -- nicknamed "sherpas" -- do the real work in the months leading up to the meetings. Coordination must be strengthened by turning the summits into informal discussions, while formalizing meetings of ministers and experts.
Global institutional reform must also extend to traditional multilateral organizations -- the United Nations, International Monetary Fund and World Bank. Without a new mission, they look increasingly like relics. Security Council seats for Japan and Germany are inevitable. Negotiations over this issue should be broadened into an effort to make the U.N. more relevant in international disputes. The 50th anniversary of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank in 1994 and of the U.N. in 1995 will be moments of symbolic opportunity. American officials need to articulate a vision of how these global institutions serve our interests and strategy for shaping the emerging order.
Recession and election-year politics have inevitably obscured the big issues of foreign policy. After World War II, Americans were more worried about the economy than in building a new international order. Stalin provided the jolt to the West for united action. Today there is no such stimulus. Leadership and vision will have to make the difference if we are to put our global house in order.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN THE ARTS: ARCHITECTURE/1992;
Barcelona Up, Louis Kahn Down, Philip Johnson Redux

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp

 BODY:

All This and Gaudi, Too -- Barcelona played host to the Olympics and captured the gold in architecture with dozens of new parks, squares and streetscapes that expand the possibilities of public space.
 
Department of Landmarks Preservation -- Philip Johnson, 87, parted company with his longtime associate John Burgee and launched a new solo career with projects in Texas, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Germany. 

 Book of the Year -- In "The See-Through Years," Joel Warren Barna offered architecture's answer to "Den of Thieves" -- a sober, morning-after look at Texas architecture in the 1980's.
 
Goodbye, Blue Collar; Hello, Green Necklace -- The New York City Planning Commission's Comprehensive Waterfront Plan, which outlines development along the 578-mile shoreline, highlighted the city's continuing transformation into a post-industrial metropolis.
 
Last Boat for Post-Modernism -- Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown, the architects whose ideas launched the now-capsized post-modern movement, won a competition to design the Manhattan Terminal of the Staten Island Ferry, their first New York building.
 
Kahn Watch '92 -- The Salk Institute for Biological Studies in La Jolla, Calif., moved closer to disaster with its proposal for an addition that would compromise the integrity of Louis Kahn's masterpiece, though after a ground-breaking ceremony the institute announced it would restudy the plan.
 
Club Gug -- With projects for new museums in Salzburg, Austria; Venice, and Bilbao, Spain, the Guggenheim Museum seems determined to become the Club Med of the art world, though unless the museums' architects are willing to accept pop-it beads in payment it remains uncertain whether these artistic resorts will fly.
 
Wake-Up Call -- With the force of a sociological earthquake, the riots in South-Central Los Angeles provoked a long-overdue recognition that privatization, laissez-faire and social Darwinism do not an urban policy make.
 
Street Smarts -- Bill Clinton's symbolic walk down an inner city street on his first visit to Washington as President-elect sent a signal that the new Administration will not regard cities as alien territory.

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN THE ARTS: DANCE/1992;
Russian Flair, Danish Dazzle, Domestic Diamonds

BYLINE: By Jack Anderson

 BODY:

Big Bold Revival -- The Kirov Ballet presentation of Leonid Lavrovsky's "Romeo and Juliet" confirmed that this version from 1940 -- the first Russian staging of the Prokofiev ballet -- remains unsurpassed for dramatic pace and musical sensitivity.
 
Tiny but Terrific -- When it was restaged this fall, "Epic," Paul Taylor's 1957 solo made up of ordinary gestures to recorded time signals, proved an unnerving study in quiet desperation. 

 Transatlantic Fireworks -- The Royal Danish Ballet's spring Bournonville Festival in Copenhagen dazzled the eye with August Bournonville's buoyant 19th-century choreography and prompted scholarly discussions about preservation and revivals.
 
Talking Points -- Despite some unevenness, the New York City Ballet's Diamond Project brought together several stimulating new works in various idioms of the balletic language.
 
Curiosity Arousers -- Dances -- serious and comic, crisp and quirky -- presented on New York stages by such choreographers as David Allen, Nils Christe, Sean Curran, Alonzo King, Tim Martin, Meg Wolfe and Ed Wubbe made one long to see more of their output.
 
Curiosity Quencher -- With its dull choreography and pallid dancers, the Florence Dance Theater of Italy made a decidedly premature New York debut.
 
Awesome Eloquence -- Carmen de Lavallade revealed her remarkable artistic range when she performed Geoffrey Holder's uplifting "Creation" with the Trisler Danscompany and John Butler's harsh "Portrait of Billie" at Jacob's Pillow.
 
Reason for Worry -- Churning out dance after dance, as he did this year, Mark Morris too often confused glibness with inventiveness.
 
Reason to Rejoice -- Although many companies are burdened with debts, managerial flair has enabled Tulsa Ballet Theater in Oklahoma to remodel a former elementary school into an impressive new headquarters and to cross the threshold with the premises paid for.
 
A New Year's Wish -- That all troupes everywhere will solve their economic problems and go on to new artistic achievements.

HEADLINE: FERRY TERMINAL;
A Timely Civic Symbol

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In his essay "For Staten Island, a Ferry Terminal Rooted in the Past" [Nov. 22], Herbert Muschamp expresses a limited view of what he thinks a modern ferry terminal should be and goes on to shortchange the design, by Venturi, Scott Brown & Associates in conjunction with Anderson/Schwartz. 
 In writing "the designs of the six finalists ran heavily toward nostalgia" and that the jurors were left to decide only "which nostalgia would be best," he failed to note that during deliberations, the jury's discussion roamed freely over a wide range of functional, technical, social and esthetic issues. The selection of a winning scheme was based on a consideration of all these factors.
Lost in the controversy over the now-famous clock is the fact that the selected scheme features a spectacular waiting room that will rival the great space of Grand Central Station and a plaza that is certain to become one of lower Manhattan's finest public open spaces. Most important, in its operational characteristics, this design addressed the functional aspects of the terminal better than the other proposals.
We also find disturbing Mr. Muschamp's statement that "the whole building has lost track of the time" -- a cute reference to the clock. His superficial view of the building and his mistaken perception of a "nostalgia bias" in the competition program is unfair to the architects as well as the competition sponsors, the New York City Economic Development Corporation and the Department of Transportation.
Throughout the competition, our goal was to develop a ferry terminal that would serve the people of New York for generations to come. From the city's substantial reinvestment in this terminal as the anchor of a revitalized lower Manhattan business district to the technical requirements for energy conservation, the project looks to the future in every way.
Workers and tourists of the next century will be well served by a terminal that accommodates new ferries and provides better passenger movement, more commodious waiting areas and easier connections.
Finally, we are puzzled by the statement that "in calling for architects to create a civic symbol, the program sets forth a notion of civic identity rooted in the past." Civic symbols, like much else, evolve with culture and time. In this competition, New York expected -- and got -- a scheme for the new terminal that will meet the needs of commuters and tourists and bring life and civic symbolism to the Manhattan waterfront well into the next century.
 
CARL WEISBROD, LUCIUS RICCIO
New York
 
The writers are, respectively, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation and commissioner of the New York City Department of Transportation.
 
 Mr. Muschamp replies: The Whitehall Ferry Terminal competition program did indeed include many good features, and so does the winning design. That is why my review of the project was generally favorable. Mr. Weisbrod and Commissioner Riccio, however, have chosen to ignore both my praise of the design and the substance of my criticism, which focused on what I termed the program's "re tro slant."
In a city of magnificent public works, conceived and built in a vigorously progressive spirit, I find it disheartening that the sponsors of this program do not recognize the difference between forward and reverse. Evidently, they believe that mere mention of the magic words "Grand Central Station" should stun us all into grateful silence.
 They also appear to believe that the competition process insures immunity from criticism. On the contrary, competitions and criticism share the common goal of exposing important public projects to wider public debate.

HEADLINE: IN SHORT: NONFICTION

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:

MOSCOW MEETS MADISON AVENUE
The Adventures of the First American Adman in the U.S.S.R.
By Gary Burandt with Nancy Giges.
Harper Business, $22.50. 
 The idea of a Madison Avenue advertising executive opening a giant agency's first office in what was the epicenter of Communism is one of those fish-out-of-water tales that Hollywood delights in calling "high concept." Even if "Moscow Meets Madison Avenue" never becomes a film or even a television sitcom, Gary Burandt's experiences should gain a wider audience through this wry, frank memoir. Mr. Burandt, an executive at Young & Rubicam, which handles clients like Colgate-Palmolive, Johnson & Johnson and Xerox, had the dubious honor of spending a year and a half, beginning in the fall of 1988, to found Young & Rubicam/Sovero, pioneering principles so alien to their new home that the Soviet Encyclopedia once defined advertising as "swindling." Yet despite difficulties in introducing the concept of choice into a society where scarcity reigns, Mr. Burandt found some foundations on which to establish the precepts of consumerism: Moscow is, after all, "a city where people will stand in line 45 minutes for a handout of a tiny free sample tube of toothpaste because usually they stand in line for hours just for the privilege of buying toothpaste." While the book's detailed recountings of the tribulations of acquiring office furnishings in the former Soviet Union are likely to be of limited interest, its broader insights into economics, geopolitics and human behavior, absorbingly described by Mr. Burandt, now the chief executive officer of Dentsu, Young & Rubicam Partnerships, and his co-author, Nancy Giges, the international editor of Advertising Age, should interest even those whose closest brush with advertising comes when they watch a commercial.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Long Search for a Site;
An L.I. Olympus Headquarters

 BODY:
For more than two and a half years the Olympus Corporation, the United States arm of Tokyo's Olympus Optical Company Ltd., tried to find a Long Island site for its headquarters. One after the other, seemingly viable sites fell through because of problems with local zoning boards.
Then the New York State Urban Development Corporation, eager to keep jobs on Long Island, came calling. It offered Olympus a lease on 10 percent of a 540-acre site that once housed mentally impaired people in Melville. 
 The price -- $7.2 million up front, applicable to purchase in 10 years -- was certainly right, as were the $40 million in Industrial Development Agency bonds that Suffolk County floated to help the developer, Parr Development, with its financing for the $49 million project.
In June 1994 some 510 Olympus employees, currently scattered throughout Long Island, will move into a new three-story, 250,000-square-foot building designed by the Spector Group, North Hills architects. A state task force is studying what to do with the rest of the land.
The building's actual footprint will only be about two and a half acres, leaving space for parking and landscaping.
"It was a long, exhaustive, frustrating search, so it was terrific to have this land finally come to us," said Patricia Whitlock, Olympus's vice president of corporate resources.
