HEADLINE: Housing List In New York Hits Record

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
The number of people waiting for New York Housing Authority apartments has risen to 240,000 families, the highest level ever and nearly equal to the total number of units in all of the city's public housing projects and subsidized apartments.
Based on the current vacancy rate of about 4.5 percent a year in Housing Authority apartments, those applying for housing today without priority consideration could face a 20-year wait for one of the estimated 8,000 units that become available annually. 
 Currently the Housing Authority manages nearly 180,000 units in its own buildings as well as about 61,000 privately owned apartments through a rent voucher program. There are 324 projects and about 600,000 tenants.
Housing officials say the dramatic growth in families seeking public housing in recent years, up from about 180,000 names in 1990, reflects the accumulated impact of 12 years of neglect of housing at the Federal level, the city's burgeoning homeless population, the economic downturn and the impact of the crack and AIDS epidemics on families.
 
600 Applications a Day
 "The need for housing has not been addressed on the Federal front," said Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, chairwoman of the city's Housing Authority. "We have suffered not just because of a lack of money, but because of a lack of a housing policy. There has been no meaningful construction of new apartments and the city does not have the means to construct housing in a major way."
Despite the scarcity of available units, applicants continue to pour into Housing Authority offices at a rate of about 600 a day. They come, housing officials say, desperate to get out of city shelters, or dilapidated privately owned apartments or the cramped homes of friends and families.
Some are like Nadja Moore, 19, mother of a 5-month-old son. Living, for the time being, with in-laws who she said were eager for her to find her own apartment, she traveled recently from Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, to the Housing Authority's application center in Manhattan to look into taking a vacant apartment she knows about in the Rutland Towers complex in Flatbush, Brooklyn.
"I am already on the list," said Ms. Moore, who is not currently working. "I filled out the application for the first time about a year ago." She said that in a previous interview, "I was told I was priority because I was pregnant, but that it would take at least six months for us to get an apartment."
She described the place where she was living as a dump with rats and broken windows.
"We have to get out of there," she said. "I know people who live in Rutland, and they have better apartments than the place I live now."
Not far from Ms. Moore, Awilda Cordera, 31, worked on an application for herself and her two children. She said that she had heard that housing was nearly impossible to get but that she needed to try.
"We are now in a studio apartment in Manhattan," she said. "It is not enough room for three of us."
 
Little Incentive to Move
 Housing Authority statistics show that, on the average, a family stays in public housing for 15.8 years. That length of time reflects their lack of alternatives, said Albert A. Walsh, a lawyer and board member of Citizens Housing and Planning Council, a national advocacy organization based in New York.
"What is unique to New York is that the spread in rent paid in public housing and what it costs to live in decent neighborhoods is so large that moving out is an insurmountable barrier to many," said Mr. Walsh, who was chairman of the city's Housing Authority during the John V. Lindsay administration in the late 1960's and early 70's.
This does not mean that public housing tenants have solved all of their shelter problems, as the Dec. 17 slaying of a popular school principal in a Housing Authority complex in Red Hook, Brooklyn, illustrated. Concerns about security, the poor condition of buildings and the disruptive presence of drugs are ever-present in some complexes.
Still, Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said, "Despite our problems, and we do have them, people still want to live in Housing Authority buildings. We have almost no vacancy rate while in many other cities the public housing has double-digit vacancy rates."
 
List Called False Hope
 Ruth Mathis, a working mother with three sons, has lived for 12 years in the Louis Armstrong Houses in Bedford-Stuyvesant. She says she has stayed in public housing because it gives her a decent, inexpensive place to live.
"I love my apartment, and most of the people here are very good," said Ms. Mathis, who works for the New York City Police Department. "The only thing I don't like are the few undesirables who live in the complex, who can make life difficult for the rest of us," referring to disruptive residents.
Some housing officials have expressed concern that maintaining an open waiting list perpetuates a hope that realistically does not exist for most applicants until well after the turn of the century. Moreover, the intake operation costs about $6 million in an annual budget of $1.5 billion for the Housing Authority.
When asked whether closing the list was a possibility, Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said that because her priorities were improving security and expanding a drug elimination program, she did not feel she could address the issue now.
Jeanne Nathan, a spokeswoman for the Housing Authority, says that when people are interviewed for housing, they are told of the extreme shortage of units. But they are not given an estimate on the time it will take for them to be placed. "There is no accurate way of saying how long the wait will be," she said. "So much depends on factors like the size of the apartment required and where the applicant wants to live."
 
Homeless Get Priority
 An applicant's rank on the list can be affected by a change in personal situations, such as the addition of another member to the household, she said.
Every three years, she said, the list is purged of applicants who no longer need or want public housing.
"It is a long shot for most applicants," she said. "So few apartments become available each year. But like Lotto, you have to be in to win it."
The New York City Housing Authority was created nearly 60 years ago under the administration of Fiorello H. La Guardia to provide a safe, clean environment for the working poor. A state-chartered, public agency, the Housing Authority gets about 80 percent of financing from the Federal Government and the rest from the city and state.
Traditionally, the tenant mix in Housing Authority complexes held at about one third working poor, one third elderly and one third people on public assistance. But the percentage of families on welfare has jumped from about 35 percent to nearly 50 percent of the mix in recent years.
In the last four years, public housing has also been used by the city to alleviate the homeless problem. In 1988 the Housing Authority began giving priority to 2,000 homeless families a year as a way for the city to meet a Federal deadline of removing homeless families from welfare hotels.
Last August Ms. Hernandez-Pinero negotiated a cut in the Housing Authority's obligation from 2,000 to 1,420 of homeless families each year.
 
Federal Aid Cut
 And the Authority's priority placements are not limited to the homeless. It is often called upon to find shelter for others with special needs, like victims of domestic violence.
The line for public housing has continued to grow despite the addition of 48,000 units of housing created at a furious pace, by the city, since 1987. The vast majority of what has been created in city-owned vacant buildings by the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development.
Federal aid for public housing, however, has been cut sharply. The Housing Authority's statistics show that Federal financing for new public housing units in the city fell from just over 20,820 in 1977 to zero in 1982 and 1983.
There was a minor restoration of funding for new units during the remaining years of the 1980's.
In 1990 New York received nothing from Washington for additional housing but the last two years have seen partial restoration of new construction financing. Currently the Housing Authority has plans for 2,500 new units.
The Housing Authority's waiting list is far from the only symbol of New York's severe housing shortage. For example, the wait for units in subsidized, Mitchell-Lama housing complexes, housing built with public subsidies for moderate-income families, can be as long as 12 years.
Ms. Hernandez-Pinero, like other housing officials and advocates, is hopeful that the change in administrations in Washington bodes well for the effort to improve housing opportunities.
"But even if the new administration makes housing an early priority," she said, "any significant impact is years away, because housing was literally abandoned for so long."

HEADLINE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;
Mashburn Goes Searching for Himself

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LEXINGTON, Ky.

 BODY:
Jamal Mashburn leaned back on the trainer's table recently, and reflected on his career as a University of Kentucky basketball player and his life as a student. In the last three years, the two have become separate entities.
In terms of his career, life has been extraordinary. 
 Mashburn, who played high school basketball for Cardinal Hayes in the Bronx, is firmly established as one of the nation's elite players. The 6-foot-8-inch, 240-pound player has achieved the perfect balance between the pivot, where he dominates with a strong, versatile inside game, and the perimeter, where he is a lethal 3-point shooter.
His scoring average has increased from 12.9 points a game as a freshman, to 21.3 last season, to 25.3 this season.
 
The Monster Mash
 When Kentucky faces Rutgers at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, all eyes will be on the man Kentuckians have nicknamed the Monster Mash. Mashburn, born in New York City and raised in the Rangel Homes on 155th Street, has never played at the Garden.
"It'll be exciting, mainly because my mother has never seen me play college ball in New York," he said.
When Mashburn gauges the distance he has traveled since leaving New York, he measures his progress by what has taken place outside the arena. His world has now expanded to a point where proficiency in basketball isn't enough.
"Sometimes I feel that playing basketball is the only gift I have, really," he said. "I wish I could write music or play music. Basketball is not a real big thing. Something besides sports, I think, is a real talent, a gift God gave you. In sport, you can work on it and become good with hard work and talent."
Indeed, those who know Mashburn talk about how hard he has worked to change from being a pudgy playground hopeful to becoming one of the nation's leading players.
 
'People Are Jealous'
 "A lot of times people are jealous, but everybody's so proud of Jamal, first of all because they know what he had to do to get this far," said Russell Glover, Mashburn's cousin and one of his closest friends. "When he was younger, Jamal had a hard time even getting chosen for a team when they played in back of the building. They called him a big baby, said he would never make it.
"The other reason people are happy for Jamal is because of the kind of person he is," Glover added. "He's quiet, doesn't bother anybody. People want to talk with him or touch him. I remember once a couple of people, I guess they were crackheads, came up to him and wanted his autograph and wished him good luck. They said they followed his career and were happy he'd made it. That meant a lot to Jamal. He sees himself as part of the community."
Indeed, aside from becoming a pro-caliber basketball player, Mashburn's must consistent quest, as he negotiates fame, is a longing to fit in. In Lexington he is the Monster Mash, No. 24 or an all-America basketball player. He is featured on posters showing him crushing a basketball.
 
Search for Reality
 Trips back to New York tend to ground him in reality, help him maintain a fix on what is real and what is not.
"I know that's all part of the hype, but that's not who I am," Mashburn said. "Sometimes in Lexington, there's so much hype around basketball, you're treated in a way than can make you lose sight of reality. Back home, around my friends I'm just Jamal. They ask me about my experiences. They want to know what it's like playing against the Dream Team or playing at Kentucky. But it's not like I'm this big star. I'm just a friend who's had some different experiences."
After playing on a select team of college all-stars who scrimmaged against the United States Olympic squad, Mashburn spent most of last summer in New York. He proudly recalls how he spent a good deal of time in recording studios with Glover, an aspiring musician-writer who plays keyboards and hopes to produce rap, rhythm and blues and gospel groups.
"He's a person I really admire," Mashburn said. "Sometimes I envy him because he's so creative, he taught himself to play. He can write and mix. That's the thing, there's so much music where I grew up. People just don't have the resources to get it out."
Perhaps a little more then he would like, trips to Harlem also help remind Mashburn that, for all the hype of his all-America career at Kentucky, in some eyes, in some environments, he is merely a potential criminal in a perpetual game of cops and robbers.
According to his family, Mashburn was stopped by the police in Harlem twice last summer -- both in cases of "mistaken identity." The first time Mashburn and two friends had just picked up Glover from his job at a bank on 145th Street. They were four young black men riding in a car with Kentucky license plates.
Glover said the police stopped the car, and with guns drawn told everyone to get out. Only when Mashburn announced that his father was a police officer was the situation diffused.
His father, Robert Mashburn, recalled the other incident when his son was stopped outside of the Rangel Homes. "Same thing: out-of-town license, black male wearing a certain type of shirt," Robert Mashburn said. "They thought he was selling drugs."
Both of Mashburn's parents agree that since their son has been in Kentucky, they have slept easier.
 
Centerpiece of Rebuilding
 When he committed himself to the Wildcats three seasons ago, Mashburn became the centerpiece of Kentucky's rebuilding process, with Coach Rick Pitino at the helm. Mashburn was a freshman when the Wildcats completed the final season of a two-year probation. Last season, he helped pull Kentucky within an overtime victory of reaching the Final Four.
This season may be Mashburn's final one at Kentucky. He is projected as a National Basketball Association lottery pick should he choose to leave school after this season.
Mashburn says whether he leaves this season or next, in many positive ways he will not be the same person coming out of Kentucky that he was going in.
"I've matured a lot," he said. "I appreciate education. Before, I just wanted to come in, play ball and go to the pros. Now I understand the value of an education, particularly for an African-American male. Even if you don't finish in four years, you absorb information. It changed the way I approach some things."
His mother would like for Mashburn, a communications major, to earn his degree. The reality of economics, however, may dictate a different course of action.
 
Wants to Help
 He would like to move his family out of New York City, he would like to give his cousin's production company a boost.
"There's more than just me to think about," Mashburn said, referring to his decision whether to leave school or stay.
Of course, the first order of business for Mashburn is to have a dominating year. After deferring to upperclassmen his first two seasons, Mashburn, with prodding from Pitino, has taken over. But he has not taken over in a frenzied, egocentric manner. He might take the open shot when he would have passed off, or now he might demand the ball in clutch situations.
"Basically, Jamal is unselfish," his father said. "He's a team player, but it goes past basketball. He was taught to respect all people, to respect his elders. He knows how to wait his turn."
"The way I approach the game, and people, is to respect all and fear none," Mashburn said. "So far, that's what's worked for me."

SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 15; Column 4; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 825 words

HEADLINE: No Surprise the Public Is Out of the Loop

 BODY:
Mrs. Gualtieri of the Suffolk Community Alliance shouldn't be surprised that "the democratic process was circumvented" by the State Power Authority at Holtsville ["State Presses Plan to Build Power Plant, Dec. 6]. The public has no control over energy decisions, and she might have added where are the citizens on Judge Weinstein's citizen advisory panel? Where are the elections for the directors of the L.I. Power Authority, and where is the public in the Public Service Commission?
The State P.S.C. is about 90 years old, and governors of that time, including Franklin D. Roosevelt, thought that the public was too stupid to set electric rates. So politicians would appoint commissioners, instead of having them stand for election, sort of like our present Governor's thinking that the public was stupid in turning down the last bond issue for this debt-ridden state. 
 The results were predictable, with Shoreham's being perhaps the worst example. Not only do we have a situation that costs the Island more than the greatest financial scandal in United States history, the savings and loan swindle, but during the Lilco trial some of the P.S.C. commissioners actually testified that they would have approved rate increases even if they knew that Lilco was lying.
The situation becomes even more onerous when one of the politicians selecting P.S.C. commissioners owns a law firm representing Lilco and when commissioners who vote for increases leave to become high-priced "utility experts" and lobbyists. Then there is the violation of the intent of The Sherman Antitrust Act that allows Lilco to control two energy monopolies, gas and electric, that should compete with each other.
The public knows best. Our Founding Fathers, especially Thomas Jefferson, knew that only the citizens should control the public purse. And in a survey that was as close to a referendum as we will have on Shoreham, the citizens rightfully rejected it in spite of years of propaganda from Lilco. Then there is the verdict from another group of citizens in the jury that found Lilco guilty of fraud and perjury.
The statement that "after years of asserting that the 800-megawatt Shoreham plant was essential to meeting electric demand, Lilco now projects that even without Holtsville, supplies will be adequate in the year 2000" is amazing. There are the same people who wanted two more reactors at Shoreham plus four more at Jamesport and threatened "a massive power crisis," offshore oil wells, "one or more coal plants," etc. No wonder the jury found them guilty.
We, the Long Island citizens, are being robbed blind by Lilco's nuclear dream, and the chief executive office of Grumman was right about the cost of Shoreham bankrupting us. I wonder if Judge Weinstein, who threw out the jury's decision and predicted that the people would rue the day Shoreham closed, is now aware of the real truth. We have the highest rates in the nation, and while the average United States electric rate actually shows a slight decrease by the year 2000, ours will increase again by 60 to 100 percent under the Governor's "wonderful deal!"
His Honor also seemed impressed by "this nuclear plant in all its technical glory!" But if he read accounts in the technical press, he might have come to the conclusion that only Rube Goldberg would have been impressed. We are the laughingstock of the technical world for ever letting Lilco pull off this incredible heist, and the details of Shoreham's bungled construction read like a comedy, unless you are one of the innocent victims who have to pay for the mess.
Mr. Koppelman is right about conservation's reducing the need for future plants, and that option is surprisingly good, both for the Island and the nation. Someone in the electrical engineering society, the I.E.E.E., estimated that it takes 50 medium-size plants just to power America's refrigerators and that the fridge design is old and terribly inefficient. How about a redesign of that and many of our other appliances? Bet it would cost a fraction of the Holtsville price, with longer-lasting benefits.
The price for Holtsville seems low -- hopefully not 20 times below the actual price like Shoreham. But if you accept it and even ignore the economy of scale, we could have a half-dozen Shoreham-size gas-fired plants for the amount of money wasted on Shoreham. However, in spite of all the reasons for stopping Holtsville, and Shoreham, there is another that is more important. We live in the largest hydro region in North America, some of which we paid for and some of which was built by an Islander, Robert Moses. Hydropower, where available, is the optimal source of electricity. And the New York Power Authority would be doing the Island a service by stopping Holtsville and increasing our connections to this power. No matter what Lilco now says, hydro should be the major ingredient in our power mix.
 
JOHN HURLEY
Remsenburg

HEADLINE: U.D.C. Doesn't Have Plan for 500 State Acres

 BODY:
"State Bypasses Town in Zoning Approval" [Dec. 6] about Huntington had better be a warning to Long Islanders that their vision of humane living and sustainable economic growth is the least concern of our Governor. The mutilation of this 500 acres of residentially zoned state land may well set the pattern for the next phase of wildcat industrial development on Long Island, this time right on top of a sole-source water-aquifer recharge area.
As homeowners we are outraged by Governor Cuomo's use of state authority, i.e., the Urban Development Corporation, to open the door for a hodgepodge of industrial-commercial businesses polluting our drinking water and congesting the two-lane residential roads around this land. The Northern State Parkway, which borders one side of the site, provides no access road and, anyway, does not permit the inevitable trucks, unless that restriction is dropped, giving us another Long Island Expressway for all New Yorkers to enjoy! 
 The chopping up of this land could certainly happen, because the state itself still has no use plan for the 500 acres, even after seven years of frustrating efforts by our Town of Huntington and local residents to work with the state to get one. Furthermore, this is not an urban area, and the U.D.C. was established to focus its projects on distressed areas, not to use our taxes to finance the multimillion-dollar Olympus Corporation to relocate from Nassau to Suffolk.
If this U.D.C. outrage is implemented, it will repeat once again exactly how commercial development should not happen on Long Island. The state says it no longer needs the land. So, instead of turning it over to the Town of Huntington, it will keep it and lease it piecemeal to a series of developers who understandably want to be free of our town's zoning regulations.
Instead of allowing the town to control the property and work with local businesses to intelligently develop a low-density use plan, our Governor is setting up a giveaway scheme that will benefit a few while thumbing his nose at the rest of us. Adding insult to injury, we all will be expected to pay taxes to pay off the flow of bond issuances, which the U.D.C. will continue to use to finance these projects.
The majority of Long Islanders do not want to join in the massive development of the Boston-to-Washington corridor. For sustainable growth we do not need a Calverton jetport. We do not need more shopping malls than we can use. Not in my backyard is not the issue. Instead, the issue is not in anyone's backyard.
 
GERALD S. and ELFRIEDE CRADDOCK
Dix Hills

HEADLINE: The Winners and (Many) Losers of '92

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
A year ago, the seers thought 1992 would be a year in which unity would prevail in Europe and George Bush in the American elections. Neither bet, it turned out, proved a winner. But there were winners -- and a lot of losers, too -- justifying the following awards. There will, unfortunately, be no awards ceremony.

Teflon Award 
 To Ernst & Young, whose predecessor firm came to dominate a large part of the savings and loan auditing business in the 1980's with a reputation for being, well, not hostile to aggressive accounting techniques. This year Ernst agreed to pay $400 million to Federal regulators and $63 million to investors who had bought junk bonds issued by the parent of Charles Keating's Lincoln Savings. Ernst's competitors got no fees but are being forced to pay for the transgressions through sharply higher insurance premiums. And Ernst's insurers, not the partners who allowed the bad accounting to go on, paid most of the firm's penalties.

"Did I Say That?" Award
 To John Frazee Jr., chairman of the Centel Corporation, who talked of values above $60 per share if Centel was sold, then agreed to a merger in which Centel shares were exchanged for Sprint stock worth about $33.50, $9 below Centel's market value at the time. Mr. Frazee did not offer refunds to shareholders who, having listened to him, paid premium prices for Centel stock.

Profiles in Courage Award
To Gary L. Roubos, chief executive of the Dover Corporation, for being the only member of the Business Roundtable, big business's lobbying arm, to accept that stock options for executives are worth something. That may have helped persuade the S.E.C. to require that shareholders be told the value of the options so eagerly sought by many of the same executives who claim they are worthless.

Charity for the Greedy Award
To Western Europe's Finance Ministers, who maintained the European exchange rate mechanism just long enough to allow speculators from around the world to get positioned for its inevitable breakdown. Central banks lost billions even as their governments were crying poor.

Pinocchio Award
To Norman Lamont, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, who vowed to take "whatever measures are necessary" to avoid devaluation of the pound, then, within hours, devalued it. To the surprise of many, Mr. Lamont has kept his job.

Boy Who Cried Wolf Award
To George Bush, who had seen so many signs of economic growth since the recession began in 1990 that he was ignored when he talked of recovery -- correctly, it turned out -- in mid-1992.

J.F.K. Missile Gap Award
To Bill Clinton, who ran on the theory that the recession was still on, and discovered almost as soon as the votes were counted that it had vanished.

Worst Inside Trade
To Richard Knight of Chambers Development. As chief financial officer, Mr. Knight was one of the few who knew that Chambers was using dubious bookkeeping techniques that inflated reported profits. When that fact came out, Chambers stock plunged to below $5 a share. Mr. Knight, who has lost his job, had purchased 2,000 shares -- at $26.625 each.

What a Way to Go Award
To Stephen Chao, president of Fox Television Stations, ousted by Rupert Murdoch after arranging for a male stripper to appear at an anti-censorship speech before a group including Mr. Murdoch and the head of the National Endowment for the Humanities.

Nothing Personal Award
To Robert C. Stempel, ousted by the General Motors board as chief executive, then promptly rehired as a consultant.
Runner-up: James Robinson 3d, chairman of American Express, forced to lead a board committee to choose his successor so he could take early retirement.

Best Unpopular I.P.O.
To the Equitable Companies and its chairman, Richard Jenrette, for a public offering that drew Wall Street hisses at $9 per share, then rose above $14 this month.

Worst I.P.O. (Completed)
To Computervision, formerly Prime Computer, which, after cutting its price and reducing the number of shares offered, finally got to market at $12 a share in August. Most of the proceeds went to the underwriter, Shearson Lehman, which just happened to be the firm that had made the mistake of financing Prime's leveraged buyout in 1989. Computervision is trading around $5.

Mr. Magoo Award for Auditing
To KPMG Peat Marwick, which did not notice that checks issued by the Comptronix Corporation to pay for equipment were being deposited into Comptronix's own bank accounts as payment for products it had supposedly sold. In fact, none of the transactions were real, and KPMG certified fictional profits for three years.

Flip of the Year
To Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, which bought American Re, the reinsurance firm, from Aetna in September, and proposes to sell part of it to the public, at triple the price, early next year. Why the increase in value? Hurricanes caused big losses for insurers. Wall Street, in its infinite wisdom, figured this made insurance stocks more valuable, because the companies would be sure to raise premiums.

Best Industry Remaking
To Ed Artzt, chairman of Procter & Gamble, for changing the way consumer goods are sold. Rather than charge high prices to retailers and then offer them lots of money for promotion, the company simply cut prices and promotional money. That raised profits and, to the surprise of cynics, apparently changed the way the industry operates.

Worst Industry Remaking
To Robert Crandall, chairman of AMR, American Airlines' corporate parent, for unsuccessfully trying to rationalize industry pricing. His attempts failed in part because he could not resist punishing competitors that offered discounts -- by discounting even more. As the red ink mounted, AMR began to fire executives to save money. Mr. Crandall was not among those receiving pink slips.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 3, 1993, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about the winners and losers of 1992 misstated the role of Gary L. Roubos, chief executive of the Dover Corporation, in arguing that stock options for executives have value. Mr. Roubos took that position in a letter to the Business Roundtable.

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
New Accord in Hartford And Other Bright Spots

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHERMAN

 BODY:
A YEAR ago, the musical review of 1991 contained the doleful tidings that the Hartford Symphony strike, which had already forced the cancellation of three sets of subscription concerts, was not yet resolved. Even the most pessimistic could hardly have guessed that the impasse would continue for the rest of the season and into the fall.
Happily, a three-year agreement has been reached between the musicians' union and the Symphony, and the sounds of orchestra are again being heard in Hartford. The winter-spring schedule lists five pairs of monthly concerts at the Bushnell, along with three sets of Pops programs and another trilogy in the family series. For a brochure or reservations, call the Symphony office at 244-2999. 
 There were other bright spots on the 1992 Connecticut horizon, of course, including a number of organizational births, debuts and other blessed musical events.
Though it did not seem like the most propitious time to start a new opera company, given the perilous economic state of the arts, Connecticut Concert Opera did precisely that last January, introducing a four-event premiere season at the Centennial Theater in Simsbury. "People came streaming out into the lobby absolutely beaming," recalled the president of the opera, John Wadhams, who looks forward to giving listeners many future opportunities to hear "some of the best singing in Connecticut."
Harvard and Yale may be rivals on the football field, but for the first time in their histories, the chapel choirs of each university joined together in a February program at Woolsey Hall. They will try it again next year in Cambridge.
Also in February, Erick Friedman was joined by several of his Yale faculty colleagues at Sprague Hall, the joyful occasion marking the great violinist's first full recital since a car accident five years earlier.
A beautiful new theater opened in March at Norwalk Community College, with opera and jazz concerts ushering in what has grown into a diverse and exceptionally worthy performing arts series.
A May concert in Westport celebrated the merger of Friends of Music, founded in 1956, and the Burndy Library Adventures in Music, which started nine years later. Then in November, Rossini's Cinderella story, "La Cenerentola," was chosen to celebrate the new alliance of Connecticut Grand Opera (which itself had amalgamated with Stamford State Opera several years back) and the Stamford Chamber Orchestra.
At the American Symphony Orchestra League's national conference in June, the Norwalk Symphony and its music director, Jesse Levine, were given an ASCAP citation for "Adventuresome Programming of Contemporary Music."
On Aug. 1, Princeton University published an article by a Connecticut College professor, Timothy Jackson, asserting that the "Four Last Songs" of Richard Strauss are actually Five Last Songs. Not one to waste time, the artistic director of the Summer Music Festival in Waterford, Peter Sacco, conducted what are now titled "Last Orchestral Songs" that same evening at the festival in Waterford, with the soprano Dinah Bryant as soloist.
It took two "extravaganza gala benefits" for the Stamford Center to dedicate the new Rich Forum in September, introducing the communications complex and its several new performing spaces. Having overseen the creation of the forum from its earliest planning stages, the center's executive director, Randall Brion, resigned to pursue new challenges, the board expressing its deepest gratitude to Mr. Brion for his "leadership, artistic vision and deep sense of commitment to excellence."
Connecticut became home to a new folk cafe earlier this month, when the Starry Night Coffeehouse opened for business in Bridgewater. The artists and their songs, said its director, Mitchell Katz, "are sure to capture your attention and captivate your heart."
Finally, congratulations to some of the organizations and artists with round-number anniversaries in 1992.
5: The Shubert Opera and Westfair Chamber Singers have performed for five years now, and Michael Palmer celebrated his fifth season at the helm of the New Haven Symphony by signing a three-year contract.
10: The Connecticut Early Music Festival, Chamber Music at St. John's and the Camerata Ensemble each marked a decade of music making.
15: Newtown Friends of Music has offered recitals for a decade and a half.
20: A January gala celebrated Gustav Meier's 20th year as music director of the Greater Bridgeport Symphony.
25: Three Connecticut conductors marked silver anniversaries last spring: James Humphreville was honored at a benefit for his service to the Danbury Music Center, Richard Vogt led a "Joyful Noise" concert at First Congregational Church of Old Greenwich, and Richard Einsel marked the occasion with a performance of "The Eighth Day," a work commissioned in his honor from Toby Hall and Nancy Evans Bush. And two weekends ago Mr. Humphreville conducted the Danbury Music Center's 25th annual performance of Tchaikovsky's "Nutcracker."
30: The Fairfield County Choral opened its 30th anniversary season only last month, so the party continues into the spring.
35: A similar milestone with five years added, prevails for the Greenwich Symphony.
45: Add yet another decade to catch up with the Candlelight Concert Series in Wilton.
50: The anniversary is golden for Fairfield University, the festivities thus far including the premieres of two commissioned scores, David Leisner's work "Ad Majorem Dei Gloriam" and "Dream Quest" by the Bridgeport composer Peter DeMarco.
500: Orchestra New England gave Concert No. 500, with its founding director, James Sinclair, conducting another world premiere, a horn concerto by Nicholas Skedgell of Hamden.

HEADLINE: Clinton Turning to New Yorkers

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

 BODY:
Just a few months ago, the Vice President of the United States came to New York, not to praise, but to berate and in fact to ridicule the place where Democrats would nominate their Presidential candidate.
"In so many ways," Dan Quayle said last June, "the liberal Democrats chose the perfect site for their convention, almost as if they feel a strange compulsion to return to the scene of the crime." 
 But now, the Democrats are returning to the White House. And after 12 years of Republican rule, President-elect Bill Clinton is looking to the state for something other than jokes: for people to serve in his Administration.
At least five people who are either from New York or who have spent much of their professional lives in the state, among them Roger C. Altman and Robert E. Rubin, Wall Street bankers, are among the three dozen major appointments announced by Mr. Clinton so far.
It may now take months to fill hundreds of mid- and lower-level posts. But several transition officials said that when the appointments are completed there will almost certainly be more New Yorkers wandering in and out of the Oval Office than at any time since the Johnson Administration.
 
Angling for President's Ear
 Even as many from New York, including those appointed, exult in this sign of renewed eminence, nobody agrees on exactly what it all means. However powerful, these power brokers will only be angling for the President's ear.
Still, there are those like Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat, who say that more New Yorkers in the White House can only mean wonderful things for the state.
"Of course it does," said Mr. Moynihan, himself now in line to assume the powerful post of chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. "It means that they'll know what you're talking about. I mean, if I was sitting there in Treasury and a Senator from Wyoming called me, with the best will in the world I wouldn't really know what he was talking about."
But then there are those like New York's other Senator, Alfonse M. D'Amato, a Republican, who take a less rosy view. Mr. D'Amato agreed that it was certainly interesting that so many New Yorkers were coming to Washington, then politely suggested that this fact and $1.25 could get someone a ride on the New York City subway.
 
'They Won't Have the Money'
 "So there are going to be some sympathetic ears," said Mr. D'Amato. "But let's face it. People in Washington are not going to be able to meet the demands which will be made upon the Federal Government, by New York or by anybody else. There's no way. They're just not going to be able to do it. They won't have the money. They don't have the money."
It would of course be nice to come up with a specific dollar estimate of what a Clinton Administration will mean for New York: an official projection, say, that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo can now count on $827,336,428.53 more for his beleaguered budget this year than he would have gotten from a re-elected President Bush.
But as Mr. D'Amato indicates, that would be wrong. Nobody in New York seems to be counting on any immediate fiscal windfall, although Mayor David N. Dinkins did helpfully send a 24-page letter to Mr. Clinton the day after the election. He urged the President-elect to spend billions more on urban problems like health care, education, housing, roads, bridges, drug treatment, job training and police officers.
Still, even if there are no immediate, tangible benefits at hand, some people here are latching onto the notion that New York, particularly New York City, stands to be helped in some more amorphous but nonetheless important way.
 
Cities High on the Agenda
 "You're going to have people who you know, who we can reach out to directly to make our case," said Anthony E. Shorris, the First Deputy Executive Director at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and an adviser to the Clinton transition team on transportation appointments. "This is an Administration that right from the get-go says the problems of the cities are high on our agenda."
For the moment, anyway, the auguries are much less clear for New York's neighboring states. It is true that Connecticut might now claim the allegiances of the woman who was nominated by Mr. Clinton to be Attorney General, Zoe Baird, a lawyer for a Connecticut insurance company; but then again, by that logic the state is losing Mr. Bush, who grew up there.
Among the big New York names in Washington these days are Mr. Altman and Mr. Rubin, who are on Mr. Clinton's economic A-team; Donna E. Shalala, a former president of Hunter College, who is his choice for Secretary of Health and Human Services; and Clifton R. Wharton Jr., the chancellor of the State University of New York from 1978 to 1987, who was tapped for Deputy Secretary of State.
 
Studied Law Under Cuomo
 Another New Yorker named to the Cabinet is Ronald H. Brown, who was raised in Harlem, studied under Mr. Cuomo at St. John's Law School, and cut his political teeth as a Democratic district leader in Mount Vernon. He is set to head the Commerce Department.
And plenty of others who now live elsewhere can certainly claim the title of honorary New Yorker. For instance, Samuel R. Berger, the new deputy national security adviser, was a special assistant to New York City Mayor John V. Lindsay and a legislative assistant to New York Representative Joseph Resnick.
Vincent Tese, New York State's Director of Economic Development, said it is significant that both Mr. Rubin and Mr. Altman are from New York City, and he noted that both had served as economic advisers to Governor Cuomo.
 
Knowing Urban Problems
 "Roger Altman and Bob Rubin are people who have lived in the city of New York," said Mr. Tese, "who know the problems associated with urban centers and have a keen appreciation that unless cities are doing well, the country won't do well." He was noticeably more disparaging about some of Mr. Bush's top officials, remarking, for instance, that Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady was from "the horse country of New Jersey."
Still, top officials on the Clinton transition team, including those from New York, categorically reject the notion that any particular region of the country will or should benefit from the Clinton Presidency.
"I find it inconceivable that anybody is going to be designing policies to help New York just because they're from New York," said Harold M. Ickes, the special assistant to the transition director, Warren M. Christopher, in a telephone interview from Little Rock. Mr. Ickes, himself a New York City resident, is expected to be given an important position in the new Administration.
There are, arguably, a lot more reasons for states in the South to get excited about the changing of the guard in the White House. Not only is Mr. Clinton a Southerner, so is his Vice President, Al Gore of Tennessee.
And Mr. Clinton was once quoted as sounding a mite wary of New York: several months before the convention he told a reporter that it was "a risk" to hold the Democratic convention in New York, that it could make the Democrats appear to be supporting "status-quo programs and interests that don't work." Mr. Clinton later said his remarks were misconstrued.
But never mind. With a Democrat in the White House, Democrats from New York see a glass that is more than half full.
"We've just had two Republican Administrations that had an antipathy to New York, that held New York up as an example of failure," said New York's Lieutenant Governor, Stan Lundine. "But now it's all going to change. It's not only a matter of the residence of the top officials in the new Administration. It's a matter of perspective."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "THE CLINTON APPOINTEES -- New Yorkers in Washington"
 
THE CLINTON APPOINTEES
 
New Yorkers in Washington
 
Roger C. Altman
 Nominated to be Deputy Treasury Secretary. Served as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for domestic finance in the Carter Administration and played a role int he rescues of the Chrysler Corporation and New York City. He is among those who say that any financial stimulus to the sluggish economy must be applied with caution so as not to aggravate the Federal budget deficit or disturb the financial markets. 46 years old.

Robert E. Rubin
 Nominated to be Senior Economic Adviser. He is co-chairman and 26-year veteran of the investment banking firm of Goldman, Sachs & Company. He has a reputation as a good manager who absorbs diverse opinions and then focuses on building consensus. Although not a particular ideologue, many believe he would bring a willingness to balance concern about the financial markets with concern about economic and political needs. A longtime Democratic fund-raiser who helped raise millions of dollars to finance the Democratic National Convention in July. 54 years old.

Clifton R. Wharton Jr.
 Nominated to be Deputy Secretary of State. Former President of Michigan State University, where he was the first black president of a major college that was predominantly white. He is the first black to serve as chancellor of the State University of New York, from 1978-1987. He is chairman and chief exectuive of Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association and College Retirement Equities Fund, one of the country's largest private pension systems. He is the son of Clifton R. Wharton Sr., the first black American career diplomat to attain the ranks of Minister and Ambassador in the Foreign Service. 66 years old.

Donna E. Shalala
 Nominated to be Secretary of Health and Human Services. Served as President of Hunter College in New York City from 1980 to 1988, also became famous as the first woman to serve on the Municipal Assitance Corporation, created in the mid-1970s to rescue New York City from fiscal crisis. Was an assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, currently Chancellor of the University of Wisconsin at Madison. 51 years old.

Ronald H. Brown
 Nominated to be Secretary of Commerce. Raised in Harlem, graduated from St. John's University Law School, admitted to New York Bar, was a Democratic Party district leader in Mount Vernon, N.Y., from 1971 to 1973. Serves as chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

HEADLINE: What We Pay For

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Dec. 2 and 3 editorials on "managed competition" state that patients "give little attention to doctor's fees or employer-paid insurance premiums because they pay only a small part of these bills." We disagree. Patients have a growing sensitivity to their bills, deductibles, co-payments and premiums as the cost of medical care grows at a rate four times faster than the national economy and patients are forced to pick up a bigger share of the burden. 
 What many people don't realize is that fees for physician services represent only 19 cents of each health care dollar nationally, compared with 23 cents for drugs and supplies and 38 cents for hospitals.
Yes, creating an integrated network of providers can achieve some cost savings, but real savings will come only when the emphasis is on keeping people well through preventive care and a continuing relationship with a physician. Clearly, the cost of staying well at home is a lot less than the cost of getting better in a hospital.
 
MORTON KURTZ, M.D.
President, Medical Society
of the State of New York
Lake Success, L.I., Dec. 4, 1992

HEADLINE: Hawaii's Gentle Throwback

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD; ROBERT REINHOLD is chief of the Los Angeles bureau
of The Times.

 BODY:
SIXTEEN years ago, in one of those boondoggles for which Hawaii is infamous, then Gov. John Burns had an international airport built in Hilo. The idea was to attract jumbo jets full of mainland and Japanese tourists direct to this lush historic city that hugs a crescent-shaped bay at the foot of two mammoth volcanoes on the Big Island of Hawaii. But the airport's long corridors and runways are mostly quiet now. The expected armies of tourists never came, bypassing Hilo for the sunny dry Kona coast of the Big Island, with its glittery new condominiums, hotel developments, golf courses and high prices.
 The problem with Hilo is rain, roughly 130 inches, 280 days or so a year. One no more leaves home in Hilo without an umbrella than without shoes. Visitors and residents stroll through the quaint downtown of old wooden clapboard and stucco buildings under corrugated tin overhangs that cover the sidewalks. The warm tropical rains come and go during the day, on and off, then are heavy and steady during the night, the year round. The patter of drops outside becomes as familiar as chirping birds, something local people screen out as New Yorkers do honking taxicabs. "What Rain?" asks a button distributed by the Hawaii Island Chamber of Commerce. 
But this is a good rain. It makes Hilo a land of orchids, anthurium and plumeria, of magnificent gardens and parks. Moreover the rains have preserved Hilo from the tourism excesses and pretentious accommodations that repel many long-time visitors who long for Hawaii's simpler, quieter days. One can still park in downtown Hilo, the state's second largest city after Honolulu, for 5 cents an hour and get a haircut for $5 ($6 for "style"), and "talk story," or gossip, with the barber.
 Hilo seems stuck in time, a throwback to Hawaii's plantation days, when the islands were merely a quiet remote territory of the United States and when the economy was based more on growing sugar cane and pineapple than on catering to Japanese tourists in search of such typical Hawaiian handicrafts as Gucci luggage and Rolex watches. They were the days when Hilo served, as it still does to a large extent, as the port and commercial center for the island's agricultural industries.
 It is a place where Hawaii's diverse cultures, more Asian than European, all merge into one appealing mix. The influences are astonishingly diverse: Japanese, Polynesian, Filipino, Chinese, Puerto Rican, Portuguese, even Russian.
 Just walking through downtown Hilo brings this into sharp relief. The sounds of drums draw the visitor up a rickety set of outdoor stairs to a hula dance studio, where young people are practicing the art of hula. Nearby, the eerily beautiful sounds of a Tongan church service waft out into the street; inside Tongan men in colorful skirts worship. This may be America, but the names of the shops suggest there is something very different about Hilo: Hale Nani Beauty Salon, Koji's Bento, Shibata's, Sakaki Barber Shop.
 Hilo is the county seat of the Big Island, the largest and youngest of the Hawaiian islands, which at 4,034 square miles is about half the size of New Jersey and more than twice the combined area of the other islands. The city's population has grown to about 45,000, swelled somewhat in recent years by an influx of unreconstructed hippies, retirees and refugees from the rat race on the mainland for whom the subtle mix of soggy weather, lush growth, slow pace and comparatively low prices has a certain appeal.
 For the visitor, it offers not only ready contact with the real Hawaii but also a good jumping-off point for touring the Big Island's natural wonders, especially Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, where the powerful forces of an active volcano can be glimpsed close-up on foot, , by car or from a helicopter, and the rarefied upper reaches of the snow-capped 13,796-foot peak of Mauna Kea, where a half dozen countries maintain astronomical observatories.
 Nature has both blessed and cursed Hilo. The Big Island is home for the Hawaiian goddess of fire, Pele, who in the harmonious spiritual cosmology of Hawaiians is the source of both destruction and creativity, destroying what lies in the wake of her lava eruptions, but creating new land and energy at the same time. In 1990, new lava vents from the 4,077-foot Kilauea crater slowly incinerated the entire town of Kalapana, 30 miles south of Hilo. And the still-active 13,680-foot Mauna Loa, which sent a fiery tongue of lava right into Hilo in 1881, remains an uncertain threat. Hilo is also vulnerable to tsunamis, ocean waves generated by distant earthquakes; one such tsunami swamped and wrecked much of downtown in 1960. But science now provides timely warnings of such hazards, and the visitor faces no particular danger..
 Hilo is most famous for the Merrie Monarch Festival, an annual celebration of Hawaii's most notable native cultural asset, hula, which combines dance, music, wisdom and religion. Every April, hula teachers and their disciples from all over the Hawaiian islands converge on Hilo for a week of hula competitions, dancing, eating and partying. It is an immensely colorful event, the dancers in elaborate feathered costumes competing with each other in dazzling performances. There are arts and crafts exhibits, elaborate floral displays and a final parade -- all in honor of the "merrie monarch," David Kalakaua, the last King of Hawaii (1836-1891), who was a great promoter of the art of hula and all the partying the accompanies it.
 But Hilo is worth a visit even without the hula. Any visit should start with a walking tour of the historic downtown, whose center is the serene Kalakaua Park, a grassy square with a huge old banyan tree, statue of the king and a reflecting pool. On one side is the 1919 Federal building, a graceful open-air affair of loggias and porticoes that combines Neo-Classical and Spanish mission characteristics.
 Opposite is the old police station, now converted into the East Hawaii Cultural Center, which has constantly changing art exhibits and performances by local artists.
 An excellent self-guided walking tour of old Hilo has been prepared by the Hilo branch of the American Association of University Women. The two-mile tour takes you to such landmarks as the Haili Church, built in 1857 by New England missionaries, and the 1913 Taishoji Soto Mission, a Zen Buddhist temple. The tour is available at local shops and bookstores for $1.
 Just up the street from the Haili Church is the Lyman Mission House and adjoining museum, one of the best small-town museums to be found anywhere. The New England style house was the original home of the first Christian missionary to go to Hilo, the Rev. David Belden Lyman. It has been restored to its 1854 style, with antique china and handcrafted furniture and flooring of Hawaiian koa wood. The museum offers fascinating exhibits on the various ethnic groups who settled Hilo, as well as displays on vulcanology, minerals, plants and animals native to the island.
 If you are in Hilo on Wednesday or Saturday, don't miss the colorful farmer's market, a friendly affair where local farmers come out with an inviting variety of local produce, including papayas, macadamia nuts, arugula, bamboo shoots, ginger root, shitake mushrooms, fresh goat milk cheese, as well as flowers and snacks. The market, protected under awnings from the inevitable rains, fills two empty lots on either side of Mamo Street at Kamehameha Avenue.
 Not far away, on Hilo Bay, there is a seafood version of the farmer's market, the historic Suisan Fish Auction. The auction has taken place every day except Sunday since 1907.
 EACH morning the boats dock with their catch of yellowfin tuna, marlin, squid and other delicacies, which are lined up on pallets on the floor and weighed in a big open-air green shed under a huge monkeypod tree at the foot of Lihiwai Street. The auctioneer's bell rings at about 8 A.M. and the buyers for restaurants, sushi bars and wholesale canners make their bids to the auctioneer's guttural bark.
 In one of the cultural dissonances that is so typical of modern Hawaii, the auctioneer keeps accounts on an abacus while the buyers communicate with their offices by cellular phone.
 After the auction, visitors should stroll through the nearby Liliuokalani Park, a serene Japanese style garden named for Hawaii's last monarch, Queen Liliuokalani, who was illegally deposed 100 years ago this January by United States Marines. With its footbridges, Japanese stone lanterns and spreading banyan trees, the gardens are among Hilo's finest assets. Just across a footbridge from the garden is a little island, now known as Coconut Island, that is a kind of sacred ground, a place where early Hawaiians built a refuge, a heiau, a temple or place of worship.
If the rains bring anything good to Hilo, it is the gardens. There are two private gardens worth visiting for a fee.
 The Nani Mau Gardens just south of town has 20 acres of almost formal plantings of almost every conceivable native and imported tropical plant, including giant honeysuckle, wiliwili trees, scented star jasmines. One can spend hours walking through its meandering paths; umbrellas available for free. JUST north of Hilo on the Four Mile Scenic Route is the more rugged Hawaii Tropical Botanical Garden, a 17-acre rain forest that doubles as a nature preserve on Onomea Bay. Visitors can explore winding nature trails, lush with rare exotics, gingers, heliconia, bromeliads, more than 1,800 species of plants, not to mention the dazzling parrots and other tropical birds and koi fish.
 No visit to Hilo is complete without a close-up look at volcanic activity, the powerful force that created the Hawaiian islands and continues daily to enlarge the Big Island. About 35 miles south of Hilo on Highway 11 is the 377-square-mile Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, which offers a fascinating education in vulcanology and drives around the steaming Kilauea crater and through forests scarred and burned by years of lava flows. A few years ago, before the town of Kalapana was destroyed by the lava, it was possible for visitors to view the fiery flows up close as they poured into the sea and turned the ocean into steam.
 But the lava has cut the roads now and those areas are inaccessible.
 The only way to see them is from the air, which costs about $135 a person by helicopter or $65 in fixed-wing planes. (Several companies operate out of Hilo airport.) These flights of 45 minutes or an hour usually take the visitor over the famed Rainbow Falls on the Wailuku River just above Hilo, over great stands of eucalyptus and ohia trees, sugar cane fields and macadamia nut farms before the land turns black and treeless with fresh lava.
 Soon there are large billows of smoke, and a dry heat fills the helicopter. The pilot steers over a large hole, about the size of small house, through which a river of red molten rock can be seen flowing under the surface at 10 miles an hour, 2,000 degrees.
 It is truly a window into hell, and one can imagine the spiritual impact the fire goddess Pele had on the Polynesians who first discovered this island 1,500 years ago.
LODGING, DINING AND VISITING Hotels
 The best hotels in Hilo are strung along Banyan Drive on Hilo Bay about a mile from downtown, and they are bargains by Hawaiian standards. Top-drawer are two recently renovated Japanese-owned properties, the Hawaii Naniloa and the Hilo Hawaiian. At both many of the rooms overlook the bay.
 Rates at the 325-room Naniloa start at $96 for a standard double. 93 Banyan Drive, Hilo, Hawaii 96720; (808) 969-3333 and (800) 367-5360 from the mainland, or (800) 442-5845 in Hawaii. The Hilo Hawaiian, 285 rooms, is comparable, starting at $99 for a double. 71 Banyan Drive; (808) 935-9361 and (800) 367-5004 from the mainland and Canada, or (800) 272-5275 within Hawaii.
 In between is an old standby, the Hilo Bay Hotel, rather musty and tacky now but cheaper at about $65. 87 Banyan Drive; (808) 935-0861, or (800) 367-5102. from mainland.
 Hilo also has many good bed and breakfast inns. One of the best is the Hale Kai, on a bluff facing the ocean about two miles from downtown, with just five rooms. Rates are from $75 to $98 a night per room, including full breakfast; three-day minimum, no credit cards. 111 Honolii Pali, Hilo, Hawaii 96720; (808) 935-6330). Other inns run from $45 a night or so. For a list, write the Hawaii Island Bed and Breakfast Association, Post Office Box 726, Volcano, Hawaii 96785.
Restaurants
 Hilo offers no haute cuisine but a wide array of restaurants that reflect the polyglot culture of the island, at very reasonable prices. One old local favorite is the Fuji Restaurant, serving Japanese cuisine, in the Hilo Hotel. Good fish dishesinclude ahi misohaki teishoku, a filet of tuna dipped in a miso sauce and broiled in foil, at $12.60, or a bento box lunch at $10.75.
 For something more lively, Lehua's Bay City Bar and Grill at the corner of Kamehameha and Waianuenue avenues, has a piano bar and serves a charbroiled chicken at $9.95; (808) 935-8055. A popular newcomer to the food scene is Cafe Pesto, nearby on Kamehameha Avenue near Mamo Street, serving a California-style menu of wood-fired pizzas with such toppings as wild mushrooms and artichokes at $9.95; (808) 969-6640).
 Visitors should not leave Hilo without trying some local favorites, like loco moco, a concoction of rice with a hamburger patty and brown gravy topped by an egg. For that, go to Don's Grill, which serves loco moco for $2.50, as well as the house specialty, roast chicken at $5.50. 485 Hinano Street; (808) 935-9099).
 For authentic Hawaiian food there is Kimo's Ono Hawaiian Food, a tiny take-out place at 806 Kilauea Avenue; (808) 935-3111. The lau lau plate, which consists of pork, lomi salmon, poi (taro root) and haupia, or coconut pudding, costs $5.75.
Attractions
 East Hawaii Cultural Center, in Kalakaua Park, is open 9 A.M.to 4 P.M. Monday through Saturday; admission free. (808) 961-5711 for current events.
 Lyman Mission House and adjoining museum, open 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Monday through Saturday; admission is $3.50, $2.50 for children aged 13 to 18, and $1.50 for 6 to 12, and includes a guided tour of the Lyman House. 271 Haili Street; (808) 935-5021. The museum offers a sampan bus tour of historic Hilo for $6.50; $3.50 for children.
 The Nani Mau Gardens are just south of town, 421 Makalika Street, just off Volcano Highway; (808) 959-3541. Admission is $5; a tram ride is available for $3 extra when not raining. Open daily 8 A.M. to 5 P.M.
 For the Hawaii Tropical Botanical Garden, travel seven miles north from Hilo on Highway 19, turn right on the scenic route and park at the Old Yellow Church, which is the garden office, (808) 964-5233. Admission is $12, including umbrellas; children under 16 free. Open 8:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. daily.
 A good source for books and maps of Hilo is Basically Books at 46 Waianuenue Avenue; (808) 961-0144.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 27, 1992, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Dec. 27 about the Big Island of Hawaii included conflicting information about the opportunity to see lava flows from the Kilauea crater in Hawaii Volcanoes National Park. As the initial reference said, visitors may approach and see the flows on foot as well as observe them from aircraft. Access by foot has been possible since October.

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: Hometown Boy Takes Over Ft. Monmouth as Cutbacks Loom

BYLINE: By ARTHUR Z. KAMIN

DATELINE: FORT MONMOUTH

 BODY:
"YOU'RE talking about a one-in-a-million chance," Otto J. Guenther said. The slim, straight-as-a-ramrod 51-year-old was talking about the odds against an officer's being chosen to command his hometown Army base.
But Major General Guenther, born in Long Branch and raised in Red Bank, beat the odds when he was named commander of Fort Monmouth five months ago. And he has spent the time since then coping with threatened cutbacks in the size and scope of the fort's operations. 
 General Guenther presides over a sprawling 1,500-acre complex that is a city unto itself, complete with post exchange, bank, theater, bowling alley, gymnasium, library, day care center, newspapers, social service agencies, even a Burger King. It is the headquarters of the worldwide Communications and Electronics Command plus such institutions as the Army Chaplain Center and School, the United States Military Academy Preparatory School and Patterson Army Community Hospital.
The fort is occupied by 7,800 civilian workers, 2,300 military personnel and 3,800 Army family members, and it provides services for 35,000 military retirees in the region. The yearly payroll: $312 million for civilian employees, $51 million for the military.
A visitor senses considerable tension among the military and civilian workers these days, caused by the Government's decision to reduce the size of the nation's military establishment.
Just before Thanksgiving, General Guenther announced that the Communications and Electronics Command could lose 1,000 civilian jobs worldwide by next summer. Army officials say voluntary early retirement, normal attrition and a hiring freeze could cut that number to 650 -- with the direct impact on Fort Monmouth still unclear.
Then, three weeks ago, the Army reported that the 513th Military Intelligence Brigade, also based at the fort, might be moved to Fort Gordon in Georgia. That could mean a transfer of 558 military and 31 civilian employees by Sept. 30 of next year. A final decision is expected next month.
There have long been rumors that Fort Monmouth may be entirely shut down. But when General Guenther is asked about them, his face tightens and he enunciates his words with crystal-clear clarity. "They didn't bring me here for that," he said.
On the other hand, he said, "there is no question we are going to downsize." He added: "The Department of Defense will draw down approximately 25 percent in both military and civilian strength over the next five years. And Fort Monmouth will take its share of the personnel cuts."
If the base is to remain viable, he said, it will have to pass muster when it undergoes the base-closing review process required by Federal law every other year. "There is no such thing as a free lunch, no guarantees," he said, "but that's the way it is today."
Both of the area's United States Representatives, Frank Pallone Jr., a Democrat, and Richard A. Zimmer, a Republican, have declared their opposition to staff reductions at the fort. And in 1990 there was a revival of the Save the Fort Committee, which was organized in 1977 by Representative James J. Howard, a Democrat, when the future of the base was similarly in jeopardy.
Of General Guenther, Representative Pallone said: "We are fortunate to have him here at this critical time. He knows the area and the people."
General Guenther is also keeping a close watch on the Somalia situation. Three logistics people from the Communications and Electronics Command are there, and several others have been alerted. An emergency operations center at the fort is in contact with troops in Somalia on a 24-hour basis. The 513th Military Intelligence Brigade has sent 11 of its linguists there who are trained in the language of that country. Other brigade elements are on alert.
 
Boyhood in Red Bank
 The general grew up in a two-family house on Washington Street in Red Bank, and he says he drives by every so often to recall his early years there. He remembers helping his father make pickups and deliveries for the Little Falls Laundry and playing his saxophone in the Red Bank High School band.
Recently General Guenther spoke at a Student Council induction ceremony at what is now Red Bank Regional High School. "It meant a great deal to everyone," said Dr. Robert Nogueira, the principal. "The general hasn't forgotten his old high school and the positive impact it had on him."
Nor has he forgotten the stately United Methodist Church on tree-lined Broad Street that his family attended. Chester Apy of Little Silver, a Red Bank lawyer and a former State Assemblyman, recalled that, after young Otto Guenther's graduation from high school, the family did not have enough money to send him to college, and the church fathers eventually encouraged an anonymous member of the parish to set up a scholarship assistance committee to help him out.
The committee has become a fixture at the church and has provided about $300,000 in scholarship aid to needy students over the years.
General Guenther is now the president of the church's board of trustees. "He's very low-key," Mr. Apy said, "and passes the collection plate when asked, and takes on a variety of other church duties."
At Western Maryland College, where he majored in economics, he enrolled in the Reserve Officers Training Corps and entered the Army after his graduation in 1963. It wasn't long before he decided to make the military his career because, he said, he liked the responsibility and the opportunity to motivate and work "with people in all walks of life."
 
A Host of Assignments
 Over the next decades, he had a host of assignments -- most of them in administration and in the communications field, some of them overseas, including Vietnam. He attended some of the Army's most prestigious professional and command schools and received a Master of Science degree in procurement and contract management from the Florida Institute of Technology.
He was a colonel when he was assigned to Fort Monmouth in 1987 but became a brigadier general after serving as the program executive officer for communications systems, a position in which he supervised dozens of projects in such areas as satellite communications and airborne radar systems. He was little known outside the military, he said, until his promotion to commanding general of the fort and of the Communications and Electronics Command.
"That's when everybody started to make a fuss," he said.
The communications command is charged with anticipating the military communications needs of the future and developing equipment that will do the job, from the original concept to the finished product to the eventual distribution of that equipment in the field.
General Guenther describes the command's research mission in these terms: "We will continue to provide battlefield superiority to our soldiers, and that means giving them the technological tools to own the night, own the spectrum, apply software as a force multiplier and know the enemy."
 
Proceeding With Construction
 Despite the proposed downsizing of the military in general, and Fort Monmouth in particular, General Guenther is proceeding with a major construction program. "We are known as an 'Army Community of Excellence,' " General Guenther said, a reference to awards the base has won for its community services. "I want to do everything possible to continue that."
The construction plan calls for extensive renovation of housing, a new youth center and expanded day care services.
General Guenther and his wife, Jan, have two college-age daughters, and the general has a younger sister, Barbara, who lives in Red Bank and is a history teacher at Middletown North High School. It was Barbara Guenther who first introduced her sorority sister at Trenton State, Jan Peterson of Caldwell, to Otto Guenther.
One of his classmates at Red Bank High was John D'Amico Jr., the son of a beautician, who went on to graduate from Harvard College and the Harvard Law School and become a State Senator and, now, a Superior Court judge.
"I remember him well," said Judge D'Amico, a resident of Oceanport. "He was not only a nice guy, but we all knew he would be a high achiever."
What stands out in Judge D'Amico's mind, he said, is how he and General Guenther could move ahead so rapidly in a single generation. "But that's America, that's Red Bank and that's Red Bank High School," he said. "The melting pot at work."

HEADLINE: Will Darkened Theaters Imperil a State Tradition?

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
IT is a well-known theater story. After a performance of "Green Grow the Lilacs," by Lynn Riggs at the Westport Country Playhouse one summer night in 1939, Theresa Helburn, the producer, had a brainstorm: make it into a musical. Four years later, the musical retitled "Away We Go!" had its world premiere at the Shubert in New Haven where Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, in their first collaboration, had the title changed yet again, this time to "Oklahoma!"
Then there's the one about Moss Hart when he was a director suffering Broadway opening-night jitters. "It's just a New Haven hit. That's all. Just a New Haven hit," Mr. Hart said, panicking. The show was "My Fair Lady" and the year was 1956. 
 The tales are legendary, their numbers are legion and they all involve Connecticut as a center for the birth of musicals. Not just at the Shubert, though that theater holds the state's most dazzling archive of historic pre-Broadway tryouts, including "Brigadoon," "Carousel" and "Fiorello." Add the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam where "Annie," "Man of La Mancha" and "Shenandoah" had their beginnings. And "Ballroom," Michael Bennett's musical after "A Chorus Line," tried out at the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford.
Even though the number of new American musicals being produced in Connecticut has dwindled drastically, the state's theaters have consistently offered professional musical productions. Adjusting to the times, the state's reputation as a showcase, and still to some extent a birthplace, for musicals has been maintained. Now, for example, the Shubert books an occasional national touring company of an established musical like the current "Guys and Dolls." So does the Bushnell in Hartford.
But the closing or dormancy of several theaters devoted to musicals appears to signify the eroding state of musical theater in Connecticut. Whether new or existing theaters can can take up the slack is uncertain.
Consider the abrupt shutting down last fall of Connecticut's Broadway Theater, formerly the Darien Dinner Theater. Consider also the precarious circumstance -- perhaps homeless, perhaps not -- of Candlewood Playhouse in New Fairfield, a continuing void in place of an operating theater in Stratford, the "for sale" sign on Sharon Playhouse (dark for four years), this season's "for rent" status of Stage II at Long Wharf Theater in New Haven (now available for private ceremonies and receptions). And a dispute with Actors Equity made the Coachlight Dinner Theater in East Windsor a non-union theater in 1989.
 
A Musical Identity
 Wholly or in part, all these theaters had a musical identity. Even in a curtailed summer season the Stratford theater, where touring productions of "Li'l Abner" and "A Chorus Line" once passed through, presented the American Conservatory Theater of San Francisco's production of "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum" in 1989. Renamed the American Festival Theater 10 years ago, after bankruptcy was declared, the theater has since been owned by the state. According to a spokeswoman for the state's Department of Economic Development, proposals for a new life for the Stratford theater -- three proposals have been rejected so far this year -- will be sought in February. First-rate professional stagings of "A Chorus Line" and "One Mo' Time" were seen in Sharon in the mid-1980's. And "I'll Be Seeing You," a review of songs by Sammy Fain, was moved onto the Main Stage at Long Wharf last summer when Stage II's theater activity was curtailed for economic reasons.
 
Abrupt Halt in Darien
 Professional musical theater in Darien was halted abruptly on the morning of Nov. 1 before a matinee performance of "42d Street" -- and a month before the scheduled opening of "Camelot," which was in rehearsal. The theater's producing director, Jane Bergere, cited a list of reasons for the 16-year-old theater's financial straits, including a lack of support by the audience and the landlords (a mortgage interest payment on the building was overdue) and said: "It's of great concern that a theater devoted to a form indigenous to our heritage should disintegrate and disappear. Musicals need to be perpetuated. Maybe the town wasn't welcoming enough. Maybe some people don't know or care what makes a production professional. We employed 110 to 150 people per show, including children who were learning discipline, concentration and an alternative to Nintendo and television."
The 27-year-old Candlewood Playhouse in New Fairfield, with a history of financial and administrative problems, closed on Oct. 30 because of health code violations. Four performances of "Ain't Broadway Grand," a new musical in a pre-Broadway tryout, remained to be seen. "We're closed but not out of business," said Candlewood's executive producer, Rick Belzer, who has run the theater for nine years. A 1993 season, to consist of seven musicals, has been announced to begin in April.
 
Where to Do Big Musicals
 Howard Marron, the composer of "Fauntleroy," a new musical that had a tryout run at Candlewood in September, said, "There are so few places one can do a big new musical. Goodspeed is one; Candlewood could be another if it got itself together." Most regional theaters can only do small shows.
Burry Fredrik -- the artistic director of the Fairfield County Stage Company at the Westport Country Playhouse (which produced last season's revival of "Flora, the Red Menace," and the recently closed "No Frills Revue") and who was in charge of the Candlewood Playhouse in the late 1970's -- said: "We wanted the playhouse ultimately to be a complete home for musicals, re-creations and tryouts, which Candlewood became under Rick Belzer. You have to venerate the American musical which the most enormous contribution we've made to live theater.
"We're all in the same boat from an economic point of view, but I don't know whether that's the reason. We're just barely holding our heads up -- and whether we do musicals next year will depend on whether we're alive."
 
'Walking Across Your Grave'
 Added Susan Hallinan, the director of press relations for Downtown Cabaret Theater in Bridgeport (where a production of "Sophisticated Ladies" is now playing), "You just feel someone's walking across your grave."
What then enables Goodspeed to maintain a secure niche on the musical theater map? The theater, which is to begin its 30th year and an extended season with a new production of "On the Town" in April, while the adjunct house, Norma Terris-Goodspeed at Chester, where musicals in progress are produced, will start its eighth. "I don't know," said Goodspeed's producing director, Michael Price. "But our audiences are comfortable with Goodspeed. They keep coming and Chester's audiences are younger and more risk taking. The outlook is good."
Other promising signs of the perpetuation of musical theater in Connecticut are the upcoming engagement of a touring edition of "Falsettos," which is still running on Broadway. It is to open next month at the Truglia Theater of the new Rich Forum in Stamford where it will be the only musical in a season of four shows. "Forbidden Broadway," in a 1993 updating, is now having an open-ended run in the Leonhardt Studio of the Rich Forum. And the Hartford Stage Company, where "Falsettos" was first seen last year, on Saturday will offer the world premiere of "Martin Guerre," a dramatic musical.
Will such a smattering of musical theater replace its imperiled consistency? Ms. Bergere isn't sure. "All these years, I've been urging people to see musicals in their own back yard. 'Come to Darien, that's where theater is,' I'd say."
"Now what do I say?" she asked.
